text: A. EINSTEIN
author: Einstein, Albert

text: PART I
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE SPECIAL THEORY OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: PHYSICAL MEANING OF GEOMETRICAL PROPOSITIONS
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In your schooldays most of you who read this book made acquaintance
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with the noble building of Euclid's geometry, and you remember --
author: Einstein, Albert

text: perhaps with more respect than love -- the magnificent structure, on
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the lofty staircase of which you were chased about for uncounted hours
author: Einstein, Albert

text: by conscientious teachers. By reason of our past experience, you would
author: Einstein, Albert

text: certainly regard everyone with disdain who should pronounce even the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: most out-of-the-way proposition of this science to be untrue. But
author: Einstein, Albert

text: perhaps this feeling of proud certainty would leave you immediately if
author: Einstein, Albert

text: some one were to ask you: "What, then, do you mean by the assertion
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that these propositions are true?" Let us proceed to give this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: question a little consideration.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Geometry sets out form certain conceptions such as "plane," "point,"
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and "straight line," with which we are able to associate more or less
author: Einstein, Albert

text: definite ideas, and from certain simple propositions (axioms) which,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in virtue of these ideas, we are inclined to accept as "true." Then,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: on the basis of a logical process, the justification of which we feel
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ourselves compelled to admit, all remaining propositions are shown to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: follow from those axioms, i.e. they are proven. A proposition is then
author: Einstein, Albert

text: correct ("true") when it has been derived in the recognised manner
author: Einstein, Albert

text: from the axioms. The question of "truth" of the individual geometrical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: propositions is thus reduced to one of the "truth" of the axioms. Now
author: Einstein, Albert

text: it has long been known that the last question is not only unanswerable
author: Einstein, Albert

text: by the methods of geometry, but that it is in itself entirely without
author: Einstein, Albert

text: meaning. We cannot ask whether it is true that only one straight line
author: Einstein, Albert

text: goes through two points. We can only say that Euclidean geometry deals
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with things called "straight lines," to each of which is ascribed the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: property of being uniquely determined by two points situated on it.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The concept "true" does not tally with the assertions of pure
author: Einstein, Albert

text: geometry, because by the word "true" we are eventually in the habit of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: designating always the correspondence with a "real" object; geometry,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: however, is not concerned with the relation of the ideas involved in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: it to objects of experience, but only with the logical connection of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: these ideas among themselves.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: It is not difficult to understand why, in spite of this, we feel
author: Einstein, Albert

text: constrained to call the propositions of geometry "true." Geometrical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ideas correspond to more or less exact objects in nature, and these
author: Einstein, Albert

text: last are undoubtedly the exclusive cause of the genesis of those
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ideas. Geometry ought to refrain from such a course, in order to give
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to its structure the largest possible logical unity. The practice, for
author: Einstein, Albert

text: example, of seeing in a "distance" two marked positions on a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: practically rigid body is something which is lodged deeply in our
author: Einstein, Albert

text: habit of thought. We are accustomed further to regard three points as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: being situated on a straight line, if their apparent positions can be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: made to coincide for observation with one eye, under suitable choice
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of our place of observation.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: If, in pursuance of our habit of thought, we now supplement the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: propositions of Euclidean geometry by the single proposition that two
author: Einstein, Albert

text: points on a practically rigid body always correspond to the same
author: Einstein, Albert

text: distance (line-interval), independently of any changes in position to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which we may subject the body, the propositions of Euclidean geometry
author: Einstein, Albert

text: then resolve themselves into propositions on the possible relative
author: Einstein, Albert

text: position of practically rigid bodies.* Geometry which has been
author: Einstein, Albert

text: supplemented in this way is then to be treated as a branch of physics.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We can now legitimately ask as to the "truth" of geometrical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: propositions interpreted in this way, since we are justified in asking
author: Einstein, Albert

text: whether these propositions are satisfied for those real things we have
author: Einstein, Albert

text: associated with the geometrical ideas. In less exact terms we can
author: Einstein, Albert

text: express this by saying that by the "truth" of a geometrical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: proposition in this sense we understand its validity for a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: construction with rule and compasses.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Of course the conviction of the "truth" of geometrical propositions in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this sense is founded exclusively on rather incomplete experience. For
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the present we shall assume the "truth" of the geometrical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: propositions, then at a later stage (in the general theory of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity) we shall see that this "truth" is limited, and we shall
author: Einstein, Albert

text: consider the extent of its limitation.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Notes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: *) It follows that a natural object is associated also with a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: straight line. Three points A, B and C on a rigid body thus lie in a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: straight line when the points A and C being given, B is chosen such
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that the sum of the distances AB and BC is as short as possible. This
author: Einstein, Albert

text: incomplete suggestion will suffice for the present purpose.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE SYSTEM OF CO-ORDINATES
author: Einstein, Albert

text: On the basis of the physical interpretation of distance which has been
author: Einstein, Albert

text: indicated, we are also in a position to establish the distance between
author: Einstein, Albert

text: two points on a rigid body by means of measurements. For this purpose
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we require a " distance " (rod S) which is to be used once and for
author: Einstein, Albert

text: all, and which we employ as a standard measure. If, now, A and B are
author: Einstein, Albert

text: two points on a rigid body, we can construct the line joining them
author: Einstein, Albert

text: according to the rules of geometry ; then, starting from A, we can
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mark off the distance S time after time until we reach B. The number
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of these operations required is the numerical measure of the distance
author: Einstein, Albert

text: AB. This is the basis of all measurement of length. *
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Every description of the scene of an event or of the position of an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: object in space is based on the specification of the point on a rigid
author: Einstein, Albert

text: body (body of reference) with which that event or object coincides.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This applies not only to scientific description, but also to everyday
author: Einstein, Albert

text: life. If I analyse the place specification " Times Square, New York,"
author: Einstein, Albert

text: **A I arrive at the following result. The earth is the rigid body
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to which the specification of place refers; " Times Square, New York,"
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is a well-defined point, to which a name has been assigned, and with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which the event coincides in space.**B
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This primitive method of place specification deals only with places on
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the surface of rigid bodies, and is dependent on the existence of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: points on this surface which are distinguishable from each other. But
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we can free ourselves from both of these limitations without altering
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the nature of our specification of position. If, for instance, a cloud
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is hovering over Times Square, then we can determine its position
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relative to the surface of the earth by erecting a pole
author: Einstein, Albert

text: perpendicularly on the Square, so that it reaches the cloud. The
author: Einstein, Albert

text: length of the pole measured with the standard measuring-rod, combined
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with the specification of the position of the foot of the pole,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: supplies us with a complete place specification. On the basis of this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: illustration, we are able to see the manner in which a refinement of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the conception of position has been developed.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (a) We imagine the rigid body, to which the place specification is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: referred, supplemented in such a manner that the object whose position
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we require is reached by. the completed rigid body.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (b) In locating the position of the object, we make use of a number
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (here the length of the pole measured with the measuring-rod) instead
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of designated points of reference.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (c) We speak of the height of the cloud even when the pole which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reaches the cloud has not been erected. By means of optical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: observations of the cloud from different positions on the ground, and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: taking into account the properties of the propagation of light, we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: determine the length of the pole we should have required in order to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reach the cloud.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: From this consideration we see that it will be advantageous if, in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: description of position, it should be possible by means of numerical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: measures to make ourselves independent of the existence of marked
author: Einstein, Albert

text: positions (possessing names) on the rigid body of reference. In the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: physics of measurement this is attained by the application of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Cartesian system of co-ordinates.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This consists of three plane surfaces perpendicular to each other and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rigidly attached to a rigid body. Referred to a system of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinates, the scene of any event will be determined (for the main
author: Einstein, Albert

text: part) by the specification of the lengths of the three perpendiculars
author: Einstein, Albert

text: or co-ordinates (x, y, z) which can be dropped from the scene of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: event to those three plane surfaces. The lengths of these three
author: Einstein, Albert

text: perpendiculars can be determined by a series of manipulations with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rigid measuring-rods performed according to the rules and methods laid
author: Einstein, Albert

text: down by Euclidean geometry.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In practice, the rigid surfaces which constitute the system of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinates are generally not available ; furthermore, the magnitudes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the co-ordinates are not actually determined by constructions with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rigid rods, but by indirect means. If the results of physics and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: astronomy are to maintain their clearness, the physical meaning of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: specifications of position must always be sought in accordance with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the above considerations. ***
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We thus obtain the following result: Every description of events in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: space involves the use of a rigid body to which such events have to be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: referred. The resulting relationship takes for granted that the laws
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of Euclidean geometry hold for "distances;" the "distance" being
author: Einstein, Albert

text: represented physically by means of the convention of two marks on a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rigid body.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Notes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: * Here we have assumed that there is nothing left over i.e. that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the measurement gives a whole number. This difficulty is got over by
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the use of divided measuring-rods, the introduction of which does not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: demand any fundamentally new method.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: **A Einstein used "Potsdamer Platz, Berlin" in the original text.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In the authorised translation this was supplemented with "Tranfalgar
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Square, London". We have changed this to "Times Square, New York", as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this is the most well known/identifiable location to English speakers
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in the present day. [Note by the janitor.]
author: Einstein, Albert

text: **B It is not necessary here to investigate further the significance
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the expression "coincidence in space." This conception is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: sufficiently obvious to ensure that differences of opinion are
author: Einstein, Albert

text: scarcely likely to arise as to its applicability in practice.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: *** A refinement and modification of these views does not become
author: Einstein, Albert

text: necessary until we come to deal with the general theory of relativity,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: treated in the second part of this book.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: SPACE AND TIME IN CLASSICAL MECHANICS
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The purpose of mechanics is to describe how bodies change their
author: Einstein, Albert

text: position in space with "time." I should load my conscience with grave
author: Einstein, Albert

text: sins against the sacred spirit of lucidity were I to formulate the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: aims of mechanics in this way, without serious reflection and detailed
author: Einstein, Albert

text: explanations. Let us proceed to disclose these sins.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: It is not clear what is to be understood here by "position" and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: "space." I stand at the window of a railway carriage which is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: travelling uniformly, and drop a stone on the embankment, without
author: Einstein, Albert

text: throwing it. Then, disregarding the influence of the air resistance, I
author: Einstein, Albert

text: see the stone descend in a straight line. A pedestrian who observes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the misdeed from the footpath notices that the stone falls to earth in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a parabolic curve. I now ask: Do the "positions" traversed by the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: stone lie "in reality" on a straight line or on a parabola? Moreover,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: what is meant here by motion "in space" ? From the considerations of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the previous section the answer is self-evident. In the first place we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: entirely shun the vague word "space," of which, we must honestly
author: Einstein, Albert

text: acknowledge, we cannot form the slightest conception, and we replace
author: Einstein, Albert

text: it by "motion relative to a practically rigid body of reference." The
author: Einstein, Albert

text: positions relative to the body of reference (railway carriage or
author: Einstein, Albert

text: embankment) have already been defined in detail in the preceding
author: Einstein, Albert

text: section. If instead of " body of reference " we insert " system of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinates," which is a useful idea for mathematical description, we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: are in a position to say : The stone traverses a straight line
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relative to a system of co-ordinates rigidly attached to the carriage,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: but relative to a system of co-ordinates rigidly attached to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ground (embankment) it describes a parabola. With the aid of this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: example it is clearly seen that there is no such thing as an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: independently existing trajectory (lit. "path-curve"*), but only
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a trajectory relative to a particular body of reference.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In order to have a complete description of the motion, we must specify
author: Einstein, Albert

text: how the body alters its position with time ; i.e. for every point on
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the trajectory it must be stated at what time the body is situated
author: Einstein, Albert

text: there. These data must be supplemented by such a definition of time
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that, in virtue of this definition, these time-values can be regarded
author: Einstein, Albert

text: essentially as magnitudes (results of measurements) capable of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: observation. If we take our stand on the ground of classical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mechanics, we can satisfy this requirement for our illustration in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: following manner. We imagine two clocks of identical construction ;
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the man at the railway-carriage window is holding one of them, and the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: man on the footpath the other. Each of the observers determines the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: position on his own reference-body occupied by the stone at each tick
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the clock he is holding in his hand. In this connection we have not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: taken account of the inaccuracy involved by the finiteness of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: velocity of propagation of light. With this and with a second
author: Einstein, Albert

text: difficulty prevailing here we shall have to deal in detail later.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Notes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: *) That is, a curve along which the body moves.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE GALILEIAN SYSTEM OF CO-ORDINATES
author: Einstein, Albert

text: As is well known, the fundamental law of the mechanics of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Galilei-Newton, which is known as the law of inertia, can be stated
author: Einstein, Albert

text: thus: A body removed sufficiently far from other bodies continues in a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: state of rest or of uniform motion in a straight line. This law not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: only says something about the motion of the bodies, but it also
author: Einstein, Albert

text: indicates the reference-bodies or systems of coordinates, permissible
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in mechanics, which can be used in mechanical description. The visible
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fixed stars are bodies for which the law of inertia certainly holds to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a high degree of approximation. Now if we use a system of co-ordinates
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which is rigidly attached to the earth, then, relative to this system,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: every fixed star describes a circle of immense radius in the course of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: an astronomical day, a result which is opposed to the statement of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: law of inertia. So that if we adhere to this law we must refer these
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motions only to systems of coordinates relative to which the fixed
author: Einstein, Albert

text: stars do not move in a circle. A system of co-ordinates of which the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: state of motion is such that the law of inertia holds relative to it
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is called a " Galileian system of co-ordinates." The laws of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mechanics of Galflei-Newton can be regarded as valid only for a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Galileian system of co-ordinates.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE PRINCIPLE OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (IN THE RESTRICTED SENSE)
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In order to attain the greatest possible clearness, let us return to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: our example of the railway carriage supposed to be travelling
author: Einstein, Albert

text: uniformly. We call its motion a uniform translation ("uniform" because
author: Einstein, Albert

text: it is of constant velocity and direction, " translation " because
author: Einstein, Albert

text: although the carriage changes its position relative to the embankment
author: Einstein, Albert

text: yet it does not rotate in so doing). Let us imagine a raven flying
author: Einstein, Albert

text: through the air in such a manner that its motion, as observed from the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: embankment, is uniform and in a straight line. If we were to observe
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the flying raven from the moving railway carriage. we should find that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the motion of the raven would be one of different velocity and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: direction, but that it would still be uniform and in a straight line.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Expressed in an abstract manner we may say : If a mass m is moving
author: Einstein, Albert

text: uniformly in a straight line with respect to a co-ordinate system K,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: then it will also be moving uniformly and in a straight line relative
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to a second co-ordinate system K1 provided that the latter is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: executing a uniform translatory motion with respect to K. In
author: Einstein, Albert

text: accordance with the discussion contained in the preceding section, it
author: Einstein, Albert

text: follows that:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: If K is a Galileian co-ordinate system. then every other co-ordinate
author: Einstein, Albert

text: system K' is a Galileian one, when, in relation to K, it is in a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: condition of uniform motion of translation. Relative to K1 the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mechanical laws of Galilei-Newton hold good exactly as they do with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: respect to K.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We advance a step farther in our generalisation when we express the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: tenet thus: If, relative to K, K1 is a uniformly moving co-ordinate
author: Einstein, Albert

text: system devoid of rotation, then natural phenomena run their course
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with respect to K1 according to exactly the same general laws as with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: respect to K. This statement is called the principle of relativity (in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the restricted sense).
author: Einstein, Albert

text: As long as one was convinced that all natural phenomena were capable
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of representation with the help of classical mechanics, there was no
author: Einstein, Albert

text: need to doubt the validity of this principle of relativity. But in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: view of the more recent development of electrodynamics and optics it
author: Einstein, Albert

text: became more and more evident that classical mechanics affords an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: insufficient foundation for the physical description of all natural
author: Einstein, Albert

text: phenomena. At this juncture the question of the validity of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: principle of relativity became ripe for discussion, and it did not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: appear impossible that the answer to this question might be in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: negative.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Nevertheless, there are two general facts which at the outset speak
author: Einstein, Albert

text: very much in favour of the validity of the principle of relativity.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Even though classical mechanics does not supply us with a sufficiently
author: Einstein, Albert

text: broad basis for the theoretical presentation of all physical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: phenomena, still we must grant it a considerable measure of " truth,"
author: Einstein, Albert

text: since it supplies us with the actual motions of the heavenly bodies
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with a delicacy of detail little short of wonderful. The principle of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity must therefore apply with great accuracy in the domain of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mechanics. But that a principle of such broad generality should hold
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with such exactness in one domain of phenomena, and yet should be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: invalid for another, is a priori not very probable.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We now proceed to the second argument, to which, moreover, we shall
author: Einstein, Albert

text: return later. If the principle of relativity (in the restricted sense)
author: Einstein, Albert

text: does not hold, then the Galileian co-ordinate systems K, K1, K2, etc.,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which are moving uniformly relative to each other, will not be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equivalent for the description of natural phenomena. In this case we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: should be constrained to believe that natural laws are capable of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: being formulated in a particularly simple manner, and of course only
author: Einstein, Albert

text: on condition that, from amongst all possible Galileian co-ordinate
author: Einstein, Albert

text: systems, we should have chosen one (K[0]) of a particular state of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion as our body of reference. We should then be justified (because
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of its merits for the description of natural phenomena) in calling
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this system " absolutely at rest," and all other Galileian systems K "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in motion." If, for instance, our embankment were the system K[0] then
author: Einstein, Albert

text: our railway carriage would be a system K, relative to which less
author: Einstein, Albert

text: simple laws would hold than with respect to K[0]. This diminished
author: Einstein, Albert

text: simplicity would be due to the fact that the carriage K would be in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion (i.e."really")with respect to K[0]. In the general laws of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: nature which have been formulated with reference to K, the magnitude
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and direction of the velocity of the carriage would necessarily play a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: part. We should expect, for instance, that the note emitted by an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: organpipe placed with its axis parallel to the direction of travel
author: Einstein, Albert

text: would be different from that emitted if the axis of the pipe were
author: Einstein, Albert

text: placed perpendicular to this direction.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Now in virtue of its motion in an orbit round the sun, our earth is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: comparable with a railway carriage travelling with a velocity of about
author: Einstein, Albert

text: 30 kilometres per second. If the principle of relativity were not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: valid we should therefore expect that the direction of motion of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: earth at any moment would enter into the laws of nature, and also that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: physical systems in their behaviour would be dependent on the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: orientation in space with respect to the earth. For owing to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: alteration in direction of the velocity of revolution of the earth in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the course of a year, the earth cannot be at rest relative to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: hypothetical system K[0] throughout the whole year. However, the most
author: Einstein, Albert

text: careful observations have never revealed such anisotropic properties
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in terrestrial physical space, i.e. a physical non-equivalence of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: different directions. This is very powerful argument in favour of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: principle of relativity.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE THEOREM OF THE
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ADDITION OF VELOCITIES
author: Einstein, Albert

text: EMPLOYED IN CLASSICAL MECHANICS
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Let us suppose our old friend the railway carriage to be travelling
author: Einstein, Albert

text: along the rails with a constant velocity v, and that a man traverses
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the length of the carriage in the direction of travel with a velocity
author: Einstein, Albert

text: w. How quickly or, in other words, with what velocity W does the man
author: Einstein, Albert

text: advance relative to the embankment during the process ? The only
author: Einstein, Albert

text: possible answer seems to result from the following consideration: If
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the man were to stand still for a second, he would advance relative to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the embankment through a distance v equal numerically to the velocity
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the carriage. As a consequence of his walking, however, he
author: Einstein, Albert

text: traverses an additional distance w relative to the carriage, and hence
author: Einstein, Albert

text: also relative to the embankment, in this second, the distance w being
author: Einstein, Albert

text: numerically equal to the velocity with which he is walking. Thus in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: total be covers the distance W=v+w relative to the embankment in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: second considered. We shall see later that this result, which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: expresses the theorem of the addition of velocities employed in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: classical mechanics, cannot be maintained ; in other words, the law
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that we have just written down does not hold in reality. For the time
author: Einstein, Albert

text: being, however, we shall assume its correctness.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE APPARENT INCOMPATIBILITY OF THE
author: Einstein, Albert

text: LAW OF PROPAGATION OF LIGHT WITH THE
author: Einstein, Albert

text: PRINCIPLE OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: There is hardly a simpler law in physics than that according to which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: light is propagated in empty space. Every child at school knows, or
author: Einstein, Albert

text: believes he knows, that this propagation takes place in straight lines
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with a velocity c= 300,000 km./sec. At all events we know with great
author: Einstein, Albert

text: exactness that this velocity is the same for all colours, because if
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this were not the case, the minimum of emission would not be observed
author: Einstein, Albert

text: simultaneously for different colours during the eclipse of a fixed
author: Einstein, Albert

text: star by its dark neighbour. By means of similar considerations based
author: Einstein, Albert

text: on observa- tions of double stars, the Dutch astronomer De Sitter was
author: Einstein, Albert

text: also able to show that the velocity of propagation of light cannot
author: Einstein, Albert

text: depend on the velocity of motion of the body emitting the light. The
author: Einstein, Albert

text: assumption that this velocity of propagation is dependent on the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: direction "in space" is in itself improbable.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In short, let us assume that the simple law of the constancy of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: velocity of light c (in vacuum) is justifiably believed by the child
author: Einstein, Albert

text: at school. Who would imagine that this simple law has plunged the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: conscientiously thoughtful physicist into the greatest intellectual
author: Einstein, Albert

text: difficulties? Let us consider how these difficulties arise.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Of course we must refer the process of the propagation of light (and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: indeed every other process) to a rigid reference-body (co-ordinate
author: Einstein, Albert

text: system). As such a system let us again choose our embankment. We shall
author: Einstein, Albert

text: imagine the air above it to have been removed. If a ray of light be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: sent along the embankment, we see from the above that the tip of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ray will be transmitted with the velocity c relative to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: embankment. Now let us suppose that our railway carriage is again
author: Einstein, Albert

text: travelling along the railway lines with the velocity v, and that its
author: Einstein, Albert

text: direction is the same as that of the ray of light, but its velocity of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: course much less. Let us inquire about the velocity of propagation of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the ray of light relative to the carriage. It is obvious that we can
author: Einstein, Albert

text: here apply the consideration of the previous section, since the ray of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: light plays the part of the man walking along relatively to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: carriage. The velocity w of the man relative to the embankment is here
author: Einstein, Albert

text: replaced by the velocity of light relative to the embankment. w is the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: required velocity of light with respect to the carriage, and we have
author: Einstein, Albert

text: w = c-v.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The velocity of propagation ot a ray of light relative to the carriage
author: Einstein, Albert

text: thus comes cut smaller than c.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: But this result comes into conflict with the principle of relativity
author: Einstein, Albert

text: set forth in Section V. For, like every other general law of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: nature, the law of the transmission of light in vacuo [in vacuum]
author: Einstein, Albert

text: must, according to the principle of relativity, be the same for the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: railway carriage as reference-body as when the rails are the body of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference. But, from our above consideration, this would appear to be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: impossible. If every ray of light is propagated relative to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: embankment with the velocity c, then for this reason it would appear
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that another law of propagation of light must necessarily hold with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: respect to the carriage -- a result contradictory to the principle of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In view of this dilemma there appears to be nothing else for it than
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to abandon either the principle of relativity or the simple law of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: propagation of light in vacuo. Those of you who have carefully
author: Einstein, Albert

text: followed the preceding discussion are almost sure to expect that we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: should retain the principle of relativity, which appeals so
author: Einstein, Albert

text: convincingly to the intellect because it is so natural and simple. The
author: Einstein, Albert

text: law of the propagation of light in vacuo would then have to be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: replaced by a more complicated law conformable to the principle of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity. The development of theoretical physics shows, however,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that we cannot pursue this course. The epoch-making theoretical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: investigations of H. A. Lorentz on the electrodynamical and optical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: phenomena connected with moving bodies show that experience in this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: domain leads conclusively to a theory of electromagnetic phenomena, of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which the law of the constancy of the velocity of light in vacuo is a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: necessary consequence. Prominent theoretical physicists were theref
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ore more inclined to reject the principle of relativity, in spite of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the fact that no empirical data had been found which were
author: Einstein, Albert

text: contradictory to this principle.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: At this juncture the theory of relativity entered the arena. As a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: result of an analysis of the physical conceptions of time and space,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: it became evident that in realily there is not the least
author: Einstein, Albert

text: incompatibilitiy between the principle of relativity and the law of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: propagation of light, and that by systematically holding fast to both
author: Einstein, Albert

text: these laws a logically rigid theory could be arrived at. This theory
author: Einstein, Albert

text: has been called the special theory of relativity to distinguish it
author: Einstein, Albert

text: from the extended theory, with which we shall deal later. In the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: following pages we shall present the fundamental ideas of the special
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory of relativity.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ON THE IDEA OF TIME IN PHYSICS
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Lightning has struck the rails on our railway embankment at two places
author: Einstein, Albert

text: A and B far distant from each other. I make the additional assertion
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that these two lightning flashes occurred simultaneously. If I ask you
author: Einstein, Albert

text: whether there is sense in this statement, you will answer my question
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with a decided "Yes." But if I now approach you with the request to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: explain to me the sense of the statement more precisely, you find
author: Einstein, Albert

text: after some consideration that the answer to this question is not so
author: Einstein, Albert

text: easy as it appears at first sight.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: After some time perhaps the following answer would occur to you: "The
author: Einstein, Albert

text: significance of the statement is clear in itself and needs no further
author: Einstein, Albert

text: explanation; of course it would require some consideration if I were
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to be commissioned to determine by observations whether in the actual
author: Einstein, Albert

text: case the two events took place simultaneously or not." I cannot be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: satisfied with this answer for the following reason. Supposing that as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a result of ingenious considerations an able meteorologist were to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: discover that the lightning must always strike the places A and B
author: Einstein, Albert

text: simultaneously, then we should be faced with the task of testing
author: Einstein, Albert

text: whether or not this theoretical result is in accordance with the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reality. We encounter the same difficulty with all physical statements
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in which the conception " simultaneous " plays a part. The concept
author: Einstein, Albert

text: does not exist for the physicist until he has the possibility of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: discovering whether or not it is fulfilled in an actual case. We thus
author: Einstein, Albert

text: require a definition of simultaneity such that this definition
author: Einstein, Albert

text: supplies us with the method by means of which, in the present case, he
author: Einstein, Albert

text: can decide by experiment whether or not both the lightning strokes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: occurred simultaneously. As long as this requirement is not satisfied,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: I allow myself to be deceived as a physicist (and of course the same
author: Einstein, Albert

text: applies if I am not a physicist), when I imagine that I am able to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: attach a meaning to the statement of simultaneity. (I would ask the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reader not to proceed farther until he is fully convinced on this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: point.)
author: Einstein, Albert

text: After thinking the matter over for some time you then offer the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: following suggestion with which to test simultaneity. By measuring
author: Einstein, Albert

text: along the rails, the connecting line AB should be measured up and an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: observer placed at the mid-point M of the distance AB. This observer
author: Einstein, Albert

text: should be supplied with an arrangement (e.g. two mirrors inclined at
author: Einstein, Albert

text: 90^0) which allows him visually to observe both places A and B at the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: same time. If the observer perceives the two flashes of lightning at
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the same time, then they are simultaneous.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: I am very pleased with this suggestion, but for all that I cannot
author: Einstein, Albert

text: regard the matter as quite settled, because I feel constrained to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: raise the following objection:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: "Your definition would certainly be right, if only I knew that the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: light by means of which the observer at M perceives the lightning
author: Einstein, Albert

text: flashes travels along the length A arrow M with the same velocity as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: along the length B arrow M. But an examination of this supposition
author: Einstein, Albert

text: would only be possible if we already had at our disposal the means of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: measuring time. It would thus appear as though we were moving here in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a logical circle."
author: Einstein, Albert

text: After further consideration you cast a somewhat disdainful glance at
author: Einstein, Albert

text: me -- and rightly so -- and you declare:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: "I maintain my previous definition nevertheless, because in reality it
author: Einstein, Albert

text: assumes absolutely nothing about light. There is only one demand to be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: made of the definition of simultaneity, namely, that in every real
author: Einstein, Albert

text: case it must supply us with an empirical decision as to whether or not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the conception that has to be defined is fulfilled. That my definition
author: Einstein, Albert

text: satisfies this demand is indisputable. That light requires the same
author: Einstein, Albert

text: time to traverse the path A arrow M as for the path B arrow M is in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reality neither a supposition nor a hypothesis about the physical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: nature of light, but a stipulation which I can make of my own freewill
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in order to arrive at a definition of simultaneity."
author: Einstein, Albert

text: It is clear that this definition can be used to give an exact meaning
author: Einstein, Albert

text: not only to two events, but to as many events as we care to choose,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and independently of the positions of the scenes of the events with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: respect to the body of reference * (here the railway embankment).
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We are thus led also to a definition of " time " in physics. For this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: purpose we suppose that clocks of identical construction are placed at
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the points A, B and C of the railway line (co-ordinate system) and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that they are set in such a manner that the positions of their
author: Einstein, Albert

text: pointers are simultaneously (in the above sense) the same. Under these
author: Einstein, Albert

text: conditions we understand by the " time " of an event the reading
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (position of the hands) of that one of these clocks which is in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: immediate vicinity (in space) of the event. In this manner a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: time-value is associated with every event which is essentially capable
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of observation.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This stipulation contains a further physical hypothesis, the validity
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of which will hardly be doubted without empirical evidence to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: contrary. It has been assumed that all these clocks go at the same
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rate if they are of identical construction. Stated more exactly: When
author: Einstein, Albert

text: two clocks arranged at rest in different places of a reference-body
author: Einstein, Albert

text: are set in such a manner that a particular position of the pointers of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the one clock is simultaneous (in the above sense) with the same
author: Einstein, Albert

text: position, of the pointers of the other clock, then identical "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: settings " are always simultaneous (in the sense of the above
author: Einstein, Albert

text: definition).
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Notes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: *) We suppose further, that, when three events A, B and C occur in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: different places in such a manner that A is simultaneous with B and B
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is simultaneous with C (simultaneous in the sense of the above
author: Einstein, Albert

text: definition), then the criterion for the simultaneity of the pair of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: events A, C is also satisfied. This assumption is a physical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: hypothesis about the the of propagation of light: it must certainly be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fulfilled if we are to maintain the law of the constancy of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: velocity of light in vacuo.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE RELATIVITY OF SIMULATNEITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Up to now our considerations have been referred to a particular body
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of reference, which we have styled a " railway embankment." We suppose
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a very long train travelling along the rails with the constant
author: Einstein, Albert

text: velocity v and in the direction indicated in Fig 1. People travelling
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in this train will with a vantage view the train as a rigid
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-body (co-ordinate system); they regard all events in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Fig. 01: file fig01.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference to the train. Then every event which takes place along the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: line also takes place at a particular point of the train. Also the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: definition of simultaneity can be given relative to the train in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: exactly the same way as with respect to the embankment. As a natural
author: Einstein, Albert

text: consequence, however, the following question arises :
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Are two events (e.g. the two strokes of lightning A and B) which are
author: Einstein, Albert

text: simultaneous with reference to the railway embankment also
author: Einstein, Albert

text: simultaneous relatively to the train? We shall show directly that the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: answer must be in the negative.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: When we say that the lightning strokes A and B are simultaneous with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: respect to be embankment, we mean: the rays of light emitted at the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: places A and B, where the lightning occurs, meet each other at the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mid-point M of the length A arrow B of the embankment. But the events
author: Einstein, Albert

text: A and B also correspond to positions A and B on the train. Let M1 be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the mid-point of the distance A arrow B on the travelling train. Just
author: Einstein, Albert

text: when the flashes (as judged from the embankment) of lightning occur,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this point M1 naturally coincides with the point M but it moves
author: Einstein, Albert

text: towards the right in the diagram with the velocity v of the train. If
author: Einstein, Albert

text: an observer sitting in the position M1 in the train did not possess
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this velocity, then he would remain permanently at M, and the light
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rays emitted by the flashes of lightning A and B would reach him
author: Einstein, Albert

text: simultaneously, i.e. they would meet just where he is situated. Now in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reality (considered with reference to the railway embankment) he is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: hastening towards the beam of light coming from B, whilst he is riding
author: Einstein, Albert

text: on ahead of the beam of light coming from A. Hence the observer will
author: Einstein, Albert

text: see the beam of light emitted from B earlier than he will see that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: emitted from A. Observers who take the railway train as their
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-body must therefore come to the conclusion that the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: lightning flash B took place earlier than the lightning flash A. We
author: Einstein, Albert

text: thus arrive at the important result:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Events which are simultaneous with reference to the embankment are not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: simultaneous with respect to the train, and vice versa (relativity of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: simultaneity). Every reference-body (co-ordinate system) has its own
author: Einstein, Albert

text: particular time ; unless we are told the reference-body to which the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: statement of time refers, there is no meaning in a statement of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: time of an event.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Now before the advent of the theory of relativity it had always
author: Einstein, Albert

text: tacitly been assumed in physics that the statement of time had an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: absolute significance, i.e. that it is independent of the state of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion of the body of reference. But we have just seen that this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: assumption is incompatible with the most natural definition of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: simultaneity; if we discard this assumption, then the conflict between
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the law of the propagation of light in vacuo and the principle of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity (developed in Section 7) disappears.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We were led to that conflict by the considerations of Section 6,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which are now no longer tenable. In that section we concluded that the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: man in the carriage, who traverses the distance w per second relative
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to the carriage, traverses the same distance also with respect to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: embankment in each second of time. But, according to the foregoing
author: Einstein, Albert

text: considerations, the time required by a particular occurrence with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: respect to the carriage must not be considered equal to the duration
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the same occurrence as judged from the embankment (as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-body). Hence it cannot be contended that the man in walking
author: Einstein, Albert

text: travels the distance w relative to the railway line in a time which is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equal to one second as judged from the embankment.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Moreover, the considerations of Section 6 are based on yet a second
author: Einstein, Albert

text: assumption, which, in the light of a strict consideration, appears to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: be arbitrary, although it was always tacitly made even before the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: introduction of the theory of relativity.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ON THE RELATIVITY OF THE CONCEPTION OF DISTANCE
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Let us consider two particular points on the train * travelling
author: Einstein, Albert

text: along the embankment with the velocity v, and inquire as to their
author: Einstein, Albert

text: distance apart. We already know that it is necessary to have a body of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference for the measurement of a distance, with respect to which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: body the distance can be measured up. It is the simplest plan to use
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the train itself as reference-body (co-ordinate system). An observer
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in the train measures the interval by marking off his measuring-rod in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a straight line (e.g. along the floor of the carriage) as many times
author: Einstein, Albert

text: as is necessary to take him from the one marked point to the other.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Then the number which tells us how often the rod has to be laid down
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is the required distance.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: It is a different matter when the distance has to be judged from the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: railway line. Here the following method suggests itself. If we call
author: Einstein, Albert

text: A^1 and B^1 the two points on the train whose distance apart is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: required, then both of these points are moving with the velocity v
author: Einstein, Albert

text: along the embankment. In the first place we require to determine the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: points A and B of the embankment which are just being passed by the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: two points A^1 and B^1 at a particular time t -- judged from the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: embankment. These points A and B of the embankment can be determined
author: Einstein, Albert

text: by applying the definition of time given in Section 8. The distance
author: Einstein, Albert

text: between these points A and B is then measured by repeated application
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of thee measuring-rod along the embankment.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: A priori it is by no means certain that this last measurement will
author: Einstein, Albert

text: supply us with the same result as the first. Thus the length of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: train as measured from the embankment may be different from that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: obtained by measuring in the train itself. This circumstance leads us
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to a second objection which must be raised against the apparently
author: Einstein, Albert

text: obvious consideration of Section 6. Namely, if the man in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: carriage covers the distance w in a unit of time -- measured from the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: train, -- then this distance -- as measured from the embankment -- is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: not necessarily also equal to w.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Notes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: *) e.g. the middle of the first and of the hundredth carriage.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE LORENTZ TRANSFORMATION
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The results of the last three sections show that the apparent
author: Einstein, Albert

text: incompatibility of the law of propagation of light with the principle
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of relativity (Section 7) has been derived by means of a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: consideration which borrowed two unjustifiable hypotheses from
author: Einstein, Albert

text: classical mechanics; these are as follows:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (1) The time-interval (time) between two events is independent of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: condition of motion of the body of reference.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (2) The space-interval (distance) between two points of a rigid body
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is independent of the condition of motion of the body of reference.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: If we drop these hypotheses, then the dilemma of Section 7
author: Einstein, Albert

text: disappears, because the theorem of the addition of velocities derived
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in Section 6 becomes invalid. The possibility presents itself that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the law of the propagation of light in vacuo may be compatible with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the principle of relativity, and the question arises: How have we to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: modify the considerations of Section 6 in order to remove the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: apparent disagreement between these two fundamental results of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experience? This question leads to a general one. In the discussion of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Section 6 we have to do with places and times relative both to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: train and to the embankment. How are we to find the place and time of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: an event in relation to the train, when we know the place and time of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the event with respect to the railway embankment ? Is there a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: thinkable answer to this question of such a nature that the law of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transmission of light in vacuo does not contradict the principle of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity ? In other words : Can we conceive of a relation between
author: Einstein, Albert

text: place and time of the individual events relative to both
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-bodies, such that every ray of light possesses the velocity
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of transmission c relative to the embankment and relative to the train
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ? This question leads to a quite definite positive answer, and to a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: perfectly definite transformation law for the space-time magnitudes of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: an event when changing over from one body of reference to another.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Before we deal with this, we shall introduce the following incidental
author: Einstein, Albert

text: consideration. Up to the present we have only considered events taking
author: Einstein, Albert

text: place along the embankment, which had mathematically to assume the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: function of a straight line. In the manner indicated in Section 2
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we can imagine this reference-body supplemented laterally and in a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: vertical direction by means of a framework of rods, so that an event
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which takes place anywhere can be localised with reference to this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: framework. Fig. 2 Similarly, we can imagine the train travelling with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the velocity v to be continued across the whole of space, so that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: every event, no matter how far off it may be, could also be localised
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with respect to the second framework. Without committing any
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fundamental error, we can disregard the fact that in reality these
author: Einstein, Albert

text: frameworks would continually interfere with each other, owing to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: impenetrability of solid bodies. In every such framework we imagine
author: Einstein, Albert

text: three surfaces perpendicular to each other marked out, and designated
author: Einstein, Albert

text: as " co-ordinate planes " (" co-ordinate system "). A co-ordinate
author: Einstein, Albert

text: system K then corresponds to the embankment, and a co-ordinate system
author: Einstein, Albert

text: K' to the train. An event, wherever it may have taken place, would be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fixed in space with respect to K by the three perpendiculars x, y, z
author: Einstein, Albert

text: on the co-ordinate planes, and with regard to time by a time value t.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Relative to K1, the same event would be fixed in respect of space and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: time by corresponding values x1, y1, z1, t1, which of course are not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: identical with x, y, z, t. It has already been set forth in detail how
author: Einstein, Albert

text: these magnitudes are to be regarded as results of physical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: measurements.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Obviously our problem can be exactly formulated in the following
author: Einstein, Albert

text: manner. What are the values x1, y1, z1, t1, of an event with respect
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to K1, when the magnitudes x, y, z, t, of the same event with respect
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to K are given ? The relations must be so chosen that the law of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transmission of light in vacuo is satisfied for one and the same ray
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of light (and of course for every ray) with respect to K and K1. For
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the relative orientation in space of the co-ordinate systems indicated
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in the diagram ([7]Fig. 2), this problem is solved by means of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equations :
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 1: file eq01.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: y1 = y
author: Einstein, Albert

text: z1 = z
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 2: file eq02.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This system of equations is known as the " Lorentz transformation." *
author: Einstein, Albert

text: If in place of the law of transmission of light we had taken as our
author: Einstein, Albert

text: basis the tacit assumptions of the older mechanics as to the absolute
author: Einstein, Albert

text: character of times and lengths, then instead of the above we should
author: Einstein, Albert

text: have obtained the following equations:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: x1 = x - vt
author: Einstein, Albert

text: y1 = y
author: Einstein, Albert

text: z1 = z
author: Einstein, Albert

text: t1 = t
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This system of equations is often termed the " Galilei
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transformation." The Galilei transformation can be obtained from the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Lorentz transformation by substituting an infinitely large value for
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the velocity of light c in the latter transformation.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Aided by the following illustration, we can readily see that, in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: accordance with the Lorentz transformation, the law of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transmission of light in vacuo is satisfied both for the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-body K and for the reference-body K1. A light-signal is sent
author: Einstein, Albert

text: along the positive x-axis, and this light-stimulus advances in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: accordance with the equation
author: Einstein, Albert

text: x = ct,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: i.e. with the velocity c. According to the equations of the Lorentz
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transformation, this simple relation between x and t involves a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relation between x1 and t1. In point of fact, if we substitute for x
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the value ct in the first and fourth equations of the Lorentz
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transformation, we obtain:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 3: file eq03.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 4: file eq04.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: from which, by division, the expression
author: Einstein, Albert

text: x1 = ct1
author: Einstein, Albert

text: immediately follows. If referred to the system K1, the propagation of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: light takes place according to this equation. We thus see that the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: velocity of transmission relative to the reference-body K1 is also
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equal to c. The same result is obtained for rays of light advancing in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: any other direction whatsoever. Of cause this is not surprising, since
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the equations of the Lorentz transformation were derived conformably
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to this point of view.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Notes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: *) A simple derivation of the Lorentz transformation is given in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Appendix I.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE BEHAVIOUR OF MEASURING-RODS AND CLOCKS IN MOTION
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Place a metre-rod in the x1-axis of K1 in such a manner that one end
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (the beginning) coincides with the point x1=0 whilst the other end
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (the end of the rod) coincides with the point x1=I. What is the length
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the metre-rod relatively to the system K? In order to learn this,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we need only ask where the beginning of the rod and the end of the rod
author: Einstein, Albert

text: lie with respect to K at a particular time t of the system K. By means
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the first equation of the Lorentz transformation the values of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: these two points at the time t = 0 can be shown to be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 05a: file eq05a.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 05b: file eq05b.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the distance between the points being eq. 06 .
author: Einstein, Albert

text: But the metre-rod is moving with the velocity v relative to K. It
author: Einstein, Albert

text: therefore follows that the length of a rigid metre-rod moving in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: direction of its length with a velocity v is eq. 06 of a metre.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The rigid rod is thus shorter when in motion than when at rest, and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the more quickly it is moving, the shorter is the rod. For the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: velocity v=c we should have eq. 06a ,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and for stiII greater velocities the square-root becomes imaginary.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: From this we conclude that in the theory of relativity the velocity c
author: Einstein, Albert

text: plays the part of a limiting velocity, which can neither be reached
author: Einstein, Albert

text: nor exceeded by any real body.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Of course this feature of the velocity c as a limiting velocity also
author: Einstein, Albert

text: clearly follows from the equations of the Lorentz transformation, for
author: Einstein, Albert

text: these became meaningless if we choose values of v greater than c.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: If, on the contrary, we had considered a metre-rod at rest in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: x-axis with respect to K, then we should have found that the length of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the rod as judged from K1 would have been eq. 06 ;
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this is quite in accordance with the principle of relativity which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: forms the basis of our considerations.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: A Priori it is quite clear that we must be able to learn something
author: Einstein, Albert

text: about the physical behaviour of measuring-rods and clocks from the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equations of transformation, for the magnitudes z, y, x, t, are
author: Einstein, Albert

text: nothing more nor less than the results of measurements obtainable by
author: Einstein, Albert

text: means of measuring-rods and clocks. If we had based our considerations
author: Einstein, Albert

text: on the Galileian transformation we should not have obtained a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: contraction of the rod as a consequence of its motion.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Let us now consider a seconds-clock which is permanently situated at
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the origin (x1=0) of K1. t1=0 and t1=I are two successive ticks of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this clock. The first and fourth equations of the Lorentz
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transformation give for these two ticks :
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 07: file eq07.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: As judged from K, the clock is moving with the velocity v; as judged
author: Einstein, Albert

text: from this reference-body, the time which elapses between two strokes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the clock is not one second, but
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 08: file eq08.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: seconds, i.e. a somewhat larger time. As a consequence of its motion
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the clock goes more slowly than when at rest. Here also the velocity c
author: Einstein, Albert

text: plays the part of an unattainable limiting velocity.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THEOREM OF THE ADDITION OF VELOCITIES.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE EXPERIMENT OF FIZEAU
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Now in practice we can move clocks and measuring-rods only with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: velocities that are small compared with the velocity of light; hence
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we shall hardly be able to compare the results of the previous section
author: Einstein, Albert

text: directly with the reality. But, on the other hand, these results must
author: Einstein, Albert

text: strike you as being very singular, and for that reason I shall now
author: Einstein, Albert

text: draw another conclusion from the theory, one which can easily be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: derived from the foregoing considerations, and which has been most
author: Einstein, Albert

text: elegantly confirmed by experiment.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In Section 6 we derived the theorem of the addition of velocities
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in one direction in the form which also results from the hypotheses of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: classical mechanics- This theorem can also be deduced readily horn the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Galilei transformation (Section 11). In place of the man walking
author: Einstein, Albert

text: inside the carriage, we introduce a point moving relatively to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinate system K1 in accordance with the equation
author: Einstein, Albert

text: x1 = wt1
author: Einstein, Albert

text: By means of the first and fourth equations of the Galilei
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transformation we can express x1 and t1 in terms of x and t, and we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: then obtain
author: Einstein, Albert

text: x = (v + w)t
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This equation expresses nothing else than the law of motion of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: point with reference to the system K (of the man with reference to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: embankment). We denote this velocity by the symbol W, and we then
author: Einstein, Albert

text: obtain, as in Section 6,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: W=v+w         A)
author: Einstein, Albert

text: But we can carry out this consideration just as well on the basis of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the theory of relativity. In the equation
author: Einstein, Albert

text: x1 = wt1         B)
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we must then express x1and t1 in terms of x and t, making use of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: first and fourth equations of the Lorentz transformation. Instead of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the equation (A) we then obtain the equation
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 09: file eq09.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which corresponds to the theorem of addition for velocities in one
author: Einstein, Albert

text: direction according to the theory of relativity. The question now
author: Einstein, Albert

text: arises as to which of these two theorems is the better in accord with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experience. On this point we axe enlightened by a most important
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experiment which the brilliant physicist Fizeau performed more than
author: Einstein, Albert

text: half a century ago, and which has been repeated since then by some of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the best experimental physicists, so that there can be no doubt about
author: Einstein, Albert

text: its result. The experiment is concerned with the following question.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Light travels in a motionless liquid with a particular velocity w. How
author: Einstein, Albert

text: quickly does it travel in the direction of the arrow in the tube T
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (see the accompanying diagram, Fig. 3) when the liquid above
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mentioned is flowing through the tube with a velocity v ?
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In accordance with the principle of relativity we shall certainly have
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to take for granted that the propagation of light always takes place
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with the same velocity w with respect to the liquid, whether the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: latter is in motion with reference to other bodies or not. The
author: Einstein, Albert

text: velocity of light relative to the liquid and the velocity of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: latter relative to the tube are thus known, and we require the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: velocity of light relative to the tube.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: It is clear that we have the problem of Section 6 again before us. The
author: Einstein, Albert

text: tube plays the part of the railway embankment or of the co-ordinate
author: Einstein, Albert

text: system K, the liquid plays the part of the carriage or of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinate system K1, and finally, the light plays the part of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Figure 03: file fig03.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: man walking along the carriage, or of the moving point in the present
author: Einstein, Albert

text: section. If we denote the velocity of the light relative to the tube
author: Einstein, Albert

text: by W, then this is given by the equation (A) or (B), according as the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Galilei transformation or the Lorentz transformation corresponds to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the facts. Experiment * decides in favour of equation (B) derived
author: Einstein, Albert

text: from the theory of relativity, and the agreement is, indeed, very
author: Einstein, Albert

text: exact. According to recent and most excellent measurements by Zeeman,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the influence of the velocity of flow v on the propagation of light is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: represented by formula (B) to within one per cent.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Nevertheless we must now draw attention to the fact that a theory of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this phenomenon was given by H. A. Lorentz long before the statement
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the theory of relativity. This theory was of a purely
author: Einstein, Albert

text: electrodynamical nature, and was obtained by the use of particular
author: Einstein, Albert

text: hypotheses as to the electromagnetic structure of matter. This
author: Einstein, Albert

text: circumstance, however, does not in the least diminish the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: conclusiveness of the experiment as a crucial test in favour of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory of relativity, for the electrodynamics of Maxwell-Lorentz, on
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which the original theory was based, in no way opposes the theory of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity. Rather has the latter been developed trom electrodynamics
author: Einstein, Albert

text: as an astoundingly simple combination and generalisation of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: hypotheses, formerly independent of each other, on which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: electrodynamics was built.
author: Einstein, Albert
