author: Einstein, Albert

text: *) Fizeau found eq. 10 , where eq. 11
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is the index of refraction of the liquid. On the other hand, owing to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the smallness of eq. 12 as compared with I,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we can replace (B) in the first place by eq. 13 , or to the same order
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of approximation by
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 14 , which agrees with Fizeau's result.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE HEURISTIC VALUE OF THE THEORY OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Our train of thought in the foregoing pages can be epitomised in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: following manner. Experience has led to the conviction that, on the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: one hand, the principle of relativity holds true and that on the other
author: Einstein, Albert

text: hand the velocity of transmission of light in vacuo has to be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: considered equal to a constant c. By uniting these two postulates we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: obtained the law of transformation for the rectangular co-ordinates x,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: y, z and the time t of the events which constitute the processes of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: nature. In this connection we did not obtain the Galilei
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transformation, but, differing from classical mechanics, the Lorentz
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transformation.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The law of transmission of light, the acceptance of which is justified
author: Einstein, Albert

text: by our actual knowledge, played an important part in this process of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: thought. Once in possession of the Lorentz transformation, however, we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: can combine this with the principle of relativity, and sum up the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory thus:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Every general law of nature must be so constituted that it is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transformed into a law of exactly the same form when, instead of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: space-time variables x, y, z, t of the original coordinate system K,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we introduce new space-time variables x1, y1, z1, t1 of a co-ordinate
author: Einstein, Albert

text: system K1. In this connection the relation between the ordinary and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the accented magnitudes is given by the Lorentz transformation. Or in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: brief : General laws of nature are co-variant with respect to Lorentz
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transformations.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This is a definite mathematical condition that the theory of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity demands of a natural law, and in virtue of this, the theory
author: Einstein, Albert

text: becomes a valuable heuristic aid in the search for general laws of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: nature. If a general law of nature were to be found which did not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: satisfy this condition, then at least one of the two fundamental
author: Einstein, Albert

text: assumptions of the theory would have been disproved. Let us now
author: Einstein, Albert

text: examine what general results the latter theory has hitherto evinced.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: GENERAL RESULTS OF THE THEORY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: It is clear from our previous considerations that the (special) theory
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of relativity has grown out of electrodynamics and optics. In these
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fields it has not appreciably altered the predictions of theory, but
author: Einstein, Albert

text: it has considerably simplified the theoretical structure, i.e. the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: derivation of laws, and -- what is incomparably more important -- it
author: Einstein, Albert

text: has considerably reduced the number of independent hypothese forming
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the basis of theory. The special theory of relativity has rendered the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Maxwell-Lorentz theory so plausible, that the latter would have been
author: Einstein, Albert

text: generally accepted by physicists even if experiment had decided less
author: Einstein, Albert

text: unequivocally in its favour.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Classical mechanics required to be modified before it could come into
author: Einstein, Albert

text: line with the demands of the special theory of relativity. For the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: main part, however, this modification affects only the laws for rapid
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motions, in which the velocities of matter v are not very small as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: compared with the velocity of light. We have experience of such rapid
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motions only in the case of electrons and ions; for other motions the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: variations from the laws of classical mechanics are too small to make
author: Einstein, Albert

text: themselves evident in practice. We shall not consider the motion of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: stars until we come to speak of the general theory of relativity. In
author: Einstein, Albert

text: accordance with the theory of relativity the kinetic energy of a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: material point of mass m is no longer given by the well-known
author: Einstein, Albert

text: expression
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 15: file eq15.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: but by the expression
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 16: file eq16.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This expression approaches infinity as the velocity v approaches the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: velocity of light c. The velocity must therefore always remain less
author: Einstein, Albert

text: than c, however great may be the energies used to produce the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: acceleration. If we develop the expression for the kinetic energy in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the form of a series, we obtain
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 17: file eq17.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: When eq. 18 is small compared with unity, the third of these terms is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: always small in comparison with the second,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which last is alone considered in classical mechanics. The first term
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mc^2 does not contain the velocity, and requires no consideration if
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we are only dealing with the question as to how the energy of a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: point-mass; depends on the velocity. We shall speak of its essential
author: Einstein, Albert

text: significance later.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The most important result of a general character to which the special
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory of relativity has led is concerned with the conception of mass.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Before the advent of relativity, physics recognised two conservation
author: Einstein, Albert

text: laws of fundamental importance, namely, the law of the canservation of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: energy and the law of the conservation of mass these two fundamental
author: Einstein, Albert

text: laws appeared to be quite independent of each other. By means of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory of relativity they have been united into one law. We shall now
author: Einstein, Albert

text: briefly consider how this unification came about, and what meaning is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to be attached to it.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The principle of relativity requires that the law of the concervation
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of energy should hold not only with reference to a co-ordinate system

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

text: EXPERIENCE AND THE SPECIAL THEORY OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: To what extent is the special theory of relativity supported by
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experience?  This question is not easily answered for the reason
author: Einstein, Albert

text: already mentioned in connection with the fundamental experiment of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Fizeau. The special theory of relativity has crystallised out from the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Maxwell-Lorentz theory of electromagnetic phenomena. Thus all facts of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experience which support the electromagnetic theory also support the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory of relativity. As being of particular importance, I mention
author: Einstein, Albert

text: here the fact that the theory of relativity enables us to predict the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: effects produced on the light reaching us from the fixed stars. These
author: Einstein, Albert

text: results are obtained in an exceedingly simple manner, and the effects
author: Einstein, Albert

text: indicated, which are due to the relative motion of the earth with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference to those fixed stars are found to be in accord with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experience. We refer to the yearly movement of the apparent position
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the fixed stars resulting from the motion of the earth round the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: sun (aberration), and to the influence of the radial components of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relative motions of the fixed stars with respect to the earth on the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: colour of the light reaching us from them. The latter effect manifests
author: Einstein, Albert

text: itself in a slight displacement of the spectral lines of the light
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transmitted to us from a fixed star, as compared with the position of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the same spectral lines when they are produced by a terrestrial source
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of light (Doppler principle). The experimental arguments in favour of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the Maxwell-Lorentz theory, which are at the same time arguments in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: favour of the theory of relativity, are too numerous to be set forth
author: Einstein, Albert

text: here. In reality they limit the theoretical possibilities to such an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: extent, that no other theory than that of Maxwell and Lorentz has been
author: Einstein, Albert

text: able to hold its own when tested by experience.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: But there are two classes of experimental facts hitherto obtained
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which can be represented in the Maxwell-Lorentz theory only by the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: introduction of an auxiliary hypothesis, which in itself -- i.e.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: without making use of the theory of relativity -- appears extraneous.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: It is known that cathode rays and the so-called b-rays emitted by
author: Einstein, Albert

text: radioactive substances consist of negatively electrified particles
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (electrons) of very small inertia and large velocity. By examining the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: deflection of these rays under the influence of electric and magnetic
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fields, we can study the law of motion of these particles very
author: Einstein, Albert

text: exactly.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In the theoretical treatment of these electrons, we are faced with the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: difficulty that electrodynamic theory of itself is unable to give an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: account of their nature. For since electrical masses of one sign repel
author: Einstein, Albert

text: each other, the negative electrical masses constituting the electron
author: Einstein, Albert

text: would necessarily be scattered under the influence of their mutual
author: Einstein, Albert

text: repulsions, unless there are forces of another kind operating between
author: Einstein, Albert

text: them, the nature of which has hitherto remained obscure to us.*   If
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we now assume that the relative distances between the electrical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: masses constituting the electron remain unchanged during the motion of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the electron (rigid connection in the sense of classical mechanics),
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we arrive at a law of motion of the electron which does not agree with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experience. Guided by purely formal points of view, H. A. Lorentz was
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the first to introduce the hypothesis that the form of the electron
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experiences a contraction in the direction of motion in consequence of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that motion. the contracted length being proportional to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: expression
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 05: file eq05.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This, hypothesis, which is not justifiable by any electrodynamical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: facts, supplies us then with that particular law of motion which has
author: Einstein, Albert

text: been confirmed with great precision in recent years.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The theory of relativity leads to the same law of motion, without
author: Einstein, Albert

text: requiring any special hypothesis whatsoever as to the structure and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the behaviour of the electron. We arrived at a similar conclusion in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Section 13 in connection with the experiment of Fizeau, the result
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of which is foretold by the theory of relativity without the necessity
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of drawing on hypotheses as to the physical nature of the liquid.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The second class of facts to which we have alluded has reference to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the question whether or not the motion of the earth in space can be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: made perceptible in terrestrial experiments. We have already remarked
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in Section 5 that all attempts of this nature led to a negative
author: Einstein, Albert

text: result. Before the theory of relativity was put forward, it was
author: Einstein, Albert

text: difficult to become reconciled to this negative result, for reasons
author: Einstein, Albert

text: now to be discussed. The inherited prejudices about time and space did
author: Einstein, Albert

text: not allow any doubt to arise as to the prime importance of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Galileian transformation for changing over from one body of reference
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to another. Now assuming that the Maxwell-Lorentz equations hold for a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-body K, we then find that they do not hold for a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-body K1 moving uniformly with respect to K, if we assume
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that the relations of the Galileian transformstion exist between the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinates of K and K1. It thus appears that, of all Galileian
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinate systems, one (K) corresponding to a particular state of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion is physically unique. This result was interpreted physically by
author: Einstein, Albert

text: regarding K as at rest with respect to a hypothetical ther of space.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: On the other hand, all coordinate systems K1 moving relatively to K
author: Einstein, Albert

text: were to be regarded as in motion with respect to the ther. To this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion of K1 against the ther ("ther-drift " relative to K1) were
author: Einstein, Albert

text: attributed the more complicated laws which were supposed to hold
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relative to K1. Strictly speaking, such an ther-drift ought also to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: be assumed relative to the earth, and for a long time the efforts of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: physicists were devoted to attempts to detect the existence of an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ther-drift at the earth's surface.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In one of the most notable of these attempts Michelson devised a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: method which appears as though it must be decisive. Imagine two
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mirrors so arranged on a rigid body that the reflecting surfaces face
author: Einstein, Albert

text: each other. A ray of light requires a perfectly definite time T to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: pass from one mirror to the other and back again, if the whole system
author: Einstein, Albert

text: be at rest with respect to the ther. It is found by calculation,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: however, that a slightly different time T1 is required for this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: process, if the body, together with the mirrors, be moving relatively
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to the ther. And yet another point: it is shown by calculation that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: for a given velocity v with reference to the ther, this time T1 is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: different when the body is moving perpendicularly to the planes of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mirrors from that resulting when the motion is parallel to these
author: Einstein, Albert

text: planes. Although the estimated difference between these two times is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: exceedingly small, Michelson and Morley performed an experiment
author: Einstein, Albert

text: involving interference in which this difference should have been
author: Einstein, Albert

text: clearly detectable. But the experiment gave a negative result -- a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fact very perplexing to physicists. Lorentz and FitzGerald rescued the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory from this difficulty by assuming that the motion of the body
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relative to the ther produces a contraction of the body in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: direction of motion, the amount of contraction being just sufficient
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to compensate for the differeace in time mentioned above. Comparison
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with the discussion in Section 11 shows that also from the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: standpoint of the theory of relativity this solution of the difficulty
author: Einstein, Albert

text: was the right one. But on the basis of the theory of relativity the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: method of interpretation is incomparably more satisfactory. According
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to this theory there is no such thing as a " specially favoured "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (unique) co-ordinate system to occasion the introduction of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ther-idea, and hence there can be no ther-drift, nor any experiment
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with which to demonstrate it. Here the contraction of moving bodies
author: Einstein, Albert

text: follows from the two fundamental principles of the theory, without the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: introduction of particular hypotheses ; and as the prime factor
author: Einstein, Albert

text: involved in this contraction we find, not the motion in itself, to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which we cannot attach any meaning, but the motion with respect to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: body of reference chosen in the particular case in point. Thus for a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinate system moving with the earth the mirror system of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Michelson and Morley is not shortened, but it is shortened for a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinate system which is at rest relatively to the sun.
author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

text: electrical masses of an electron are held together by gravitational
author: Einstein, Albert

text: forces.

text: MINKOWSKI'S FOUR-DIMENSIONAL SPACE
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The non-mathematician is seized by a mysterious shuddering when he
author: Einstein, Albert

text: hears of "four-dimensional" things, by a feeling not unlike that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: awakened by thoughts of the occult. And yet there is no more
author: Einstein, Albert

text: common-place statement than that the world in which we live is a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: four-dimensional space-time continuum.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Space is a three-dimensional continuum. By this we mean that it is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: possible to describe the position of a point (at rest) by means of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: three numbers (co-ordinales) x, y, z, and that there is an indefinite
author: Einstein, Albert

text: number of points in the neighbourhood of this one, the position of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which can be described by co-ordinates such as x[1], y[1], z[1], which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: may be as near as we choose to the respective values of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinates x, y, z, of the first point. In virtue of the latter
author: Einstein, Albert

text: property we speak of a " continuum," and owing to the fact that there
author: Einstein, Albert

text: are three co-ordinates we speak of it as being " three-dimensional."
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Similarly, the world of physical phenomena which was briefly called "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: world " by Minkowski is naturally four dimensional in the space-time
author: Einstein, Albert

text: sense. For it is composed of individual events, each of which is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: described by four numbers, namely, three space co-ordinates x, y, z,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and a time co-ordinate, the time value t. The" world" is in this sense
author: Einstein, Albert

text: also a continuum; for to every event there are as many "neighbouring"
author: Einstein, Albert

text: events (realised or at least thinkable) as we care to choose, the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinates x[1], y[1], z[1], t[1] of which differ by an indefinitely
author: Einstein, Albert

text: small amount from those of the event x, y, z, t originally considered.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: That we have not been accustomed to regard the world in this sense as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a four-dimensional continuum is due to the fact that in physics,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: before the advent of the theory of relativity, time played a different
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and more independent role, as compared with the space coordinates. It
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is for this reason that we have been in the habit of treating time as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: an independent continuum. As a matter of fact, according to classical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mechanics, time is absolute, i.e. it is independent of the position
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and the condition of motion of the system of co-ordinates. We see this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: expressed in the last equation of the Galileian transformation (t1 =
author: Einstein, Albert

text: t)
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The four-dimensional mode of consideration of the "world" is natural
author: Einstein, Albert

text: on the theory of relativity, since according to this theory time is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: robbed of its independence. This is shown by the fourth equation of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the Lorentz transformation:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 24: file eq24.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Moreover, according to this equation the time difference Dt1 of two
author: Einstein, Albert

text: events with respect to K1 does not in general vanish, even when the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: time difference Dt1 of the same events with reference to K vanishes.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Pure " space-distance " of two events with respect to K results in "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: time-distance " of the same events with respect to K. But the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: discovery of Minkowski, which was of importance for the formal
author: Einstein, Albert

text: development of the theory of relativity, does not lie here. It is to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: be found rather in the fact of his recognition that the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: four-dimensional space-time continuum of the theory of relativity, in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: its most essential formal properties, shows a pronounced relationship
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to the three-dimensional continuum of Euclidean geometrical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: space.*  In order to give due prominence to this relationship,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: however, we must replace the usual time co-ordinate t by an imaginary
author: Einstein, Albert

text: magnitude eq. 25 proportional to it. Under these conditions, the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: natural laws satisfying the demands of the (special) theory of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity assume mathematical forms, in which the time co-ordinate
author: Einstein, Albert

text: plays exactly the same role as the three space co-ordinates. Formally,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: these four co-ordinates correspond exactly to the three space
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinates in Euclidean geometry. It must be clear even to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: non-mathematician that, as a consequence of this purely formal
author: Einstein, Albert

text: addition to our knowledge, the theory perforce gained clearness in no
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mean measure.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: These inadequate remarks can give the reader only a vague notion of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the important idea contributed by Minkowski. Without it the general
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory of relativity, of which the fundamental ideas are developed in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the following pages, would perhaps have got no farther than its long
author: Einstein, Albert

text: clothes. Minkowski's work is doubtless difficult of access to anyone
author: Einstein, Albert

text: inexperienced in mathematics, but since it is not necessary to have a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: very exact grasp of this work in order to understand the fundamental
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ideas of either the special or the general theory of relativity, I
author: Einstein, Albert

text: shall leave it here at present, and revert to it only towards the end
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of Part 2.

text: PART II
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE GENERAL THEORY OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: SPECIAL AND GENERAL PRINCIPLE OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The basal principle, which was the pivot of all our previous
author: Einstein, Albert

text: considerations, was the special principle of relativity, i.e. the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: principle of the physical relativity of all uniform motion. Let as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: once more analyse its meaning carefully.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: It was at all times clear that, from the point of view of the idea it
author: Einstein, Albert

text: conveys to us, every motion must be considered only as a relative
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion. Returning to the illustration we have frequently used of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: embankment and the railway carriage, we can express the fact of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion here taking place in the following two forms, both of which are
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equally justifiable :
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (a) The carriage is in motion relative to the embankment,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (b) The embankment is in motion relative to the carriage.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In (a) the embankment, in (b) the carriage, serves as the body of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference in our statement of the motion taking place. If it is simply
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a question of detecting or of describing the motion involved, it is in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: principle immaterial to what reference-body we refer the motion. As
author: Einstein, Albert

text: already mentioned, this is self-evident, but it must not be confused
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with the much more comprehensive statement called "the principle of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity," which we have taken as the basis of our investigations.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The principle we have made use of not only maintains that we may
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equally well choose the carriage or the embankment as our
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-body for the description of any event (for this, too, is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: self-evident). Our principle rather asserts what follows : If we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: formulate the general laws of nature as they are obtained from
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experience, by making use of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (a) the embankment as reference-body,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (b) the railway carriage as reference-body,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: then these general laws of nature (e.g. the laws of mechanics or the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: law of the propagation of light in vacuo) have exactly the same form
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in both cases. This can also be expressed as follows : For the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: physical description of natural processes, neither of the reference
author: Einstein, Albert

text: bodies K, K1 is unique (lit. " specially marked out ") as compared
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with the other. Unlike the first, this latter statement need not of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: necessity hold a priori; it is not contained in the conceptions of "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion" and " reference-body " and derivable from them; only
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experience can decide as to its correctness or incorrectness.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Up to the present, however, we have by no means maintained the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equivalence of all bodies of reference K in connection with the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: formulation of natural laws. Our course was more on the following
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Iines. In the first place, we started out from the assumption that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: there exists a reference-body K, whose condition of motion is such
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that the Galileian law holds with respect to it : A particle left to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: itself and sufficiently far removed from all other particles moves
author: Einstein, Albert

text: uniformly in a straight line. With reference to K (Galileian
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-body) the laws of nature were to be as simple as possible.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: But in addition to K, all bodies of reference K1 should be given
author: Einstein, Albert

text: preference in this sense, and they should be exactly equivalent to K
author: Einstein, Albert

text: for the formulation of natural laws, provided that they are in a state
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of uniform rectilinear and non-rotary motion with respect to K ; all
author: Einstein, Albert

text: these bodies of reference are to be regarded as Galileian
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-bodies. The validity of the principle of relativity was
author: Einstein, Albert

text: assumed only for these reference-bodies, but not for others (e.g.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: those possessing motion of a different kind). In this sense we speak
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the special principle of relativity, or special theory of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In contrast to this we wish to understand by the "general principle of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity" the following statement : All bodies of reference K, K1,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: etc., are equivalent for the description of natural phenomena
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (formulation of the general laws of nature), whatever may be their
author: Einstein, Albert

text: state of motion. But before proceeding farther, it ought to be pointed
author: Einstein, Albert

text: out that this formulation must be replaced later by a more abstract
author: Einstein, Albert

text: one, for reasons which will become evident at a later stage.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Since the introduction of the special principle of relativity has been
author: Einstein, Albert

text: justified, every intellect which strives after generalisation must
author: Einstein, Albert

text: feel the temptation to venture the step towards the general principle
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of relativity. But a simple and apparently quite reliable
author: Einstein, Albert

text: consideration seems to suggest that, for the present at any rate,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: there is little hope of success in such an attempt; Let us imagine
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ourselves transferred to our old friend the railway carriage, which is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: travelling at a uniform rate. As long as it is moving unifromly, the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: occupant of the carriage is not sensible of its motion, and it is for
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this reason that he can without reluctance interpret the facts of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: case as indicating that the carriage is at rest, but the embankment in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion. Moreover, according to the special principle of relativity,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this interpretation is quite justified also from a physical point of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: view.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: If the motion of the carriage is now changed into a non-uniform
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion, as for instance by a powerful application of the brakes, then
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the occupant of the carriage experiences a correspondingly powerful
author: Einstein, Albert

text: jerk forwards. The retarded motion is manifested in the mechanical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: behaviour of bodies relative to the person in the railway carriage.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The mechanical behaviour is different from that of the case previously
author: Einstein, Albert

text: considered, and for this reason it would appear to be impossible that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the same mechanical laws hold relatively to the non-uniformly moving
author: Einstein, Albert

text: carriage, as hold with reference to the carriage when at rest or in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: uniform motion. At all events it is clear that the Galileian law does
author: Einstein, Albert

text: not hold with respect to the non-uniformly moving carriage. Because of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this, we feel compelled at the present juncture to grant a kind of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: absolute physical reality to non-uniform motion, in opposition to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: general principle of relatvity. But in what follows we shall soon see
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that this conclusion cannot be maintained.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE GRAVITATIONAL FIELD
author: Einstein, Albert

text: "If we pick up a stone and then let it go, why does it fall to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ground ?" The usual answer to this question is: "Because it is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: attracted by the earth." Modern physics formulates the answer rather
author: Einstein, Albert

text: differently for the following reason. As a result of the more careful
author: Einstein, Albert

text: study of electromagnetic phenomena, we have come to regard action at a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: distance as a process impossible without the intervention of some
author: Einstein, Albert

text: intermediary medium. If, for instance, a magnet attracts a piece of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: iron, we cannot be content to regard this as meaning that the magnet
author: Einstein, Albert

text: acts directly on the iron through the intermediate empty space, but we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: are constrained to imagine -- after the manner of Faraday -- that the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: magnet always calls into being something physically real in the space
author: Einstein, Albert

text: around it, that something being what we call a "magnetic field." In
author: Einstein, Albert

text: its turn this magnetic field operates on the piece of iron, so that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the latter strives to move towards the magnet. We shall not discuss
author: Einstein, Albert

text: here the justification for this incidental conception, which is indeed
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a somewhat arbitrary one. We shall only mention that with its aid
author: Einstein, Albert

text: electromagnetic phenomena can be theoretically represented much more
author: Einstein, Albert

text: satisfactorily than without it, and this applies particularly to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transmission of electromagnetic waves. The effects of gravitation also
author: Einstein, Albert

text: are regarded in an analogous manner.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The action of the earth on the stone takes place indirectly. The earth
author: Einstein, Albert

text: produces in its surrounding a gravitational field, which acts on the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: stone and produces its motion of fall. As we know from experience, the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: intensity of the action on a body dimishes according to a quite
author: Einstein, Albert

text: definite law, as we proceed farther and farther away from the earth.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: From our point of view this means : The law governing the properties
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the gravitational field in space must be a perfectly definite one,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in order correctly to represent the diminution of gravitational action
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with the distance from operative bodies. It is something like this:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The body (e.g. the earth) produces a field in its immediate
author: Einstein, Albert

text: neighbourhood directly; the intensity and direction of the field at
author: Einstein, Albert

text: points farther removed from the body are thence determined by the law
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which governs the properties in space of the gravitational fields
author: Einstein, Albert

text: themselves.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In contrast to electric and magnetic fields, the gravitational field
author: Einstein, Albert

text: exhibits a most remarkable property, which is of fundamental
author: Einstein, Albert

text: importance for what follows. Bodies which are moving under the sole
author: Einstein, Albert

text: influence of a gravitational field receive an acceleration, which does
author: Einstein, Albert

text: not in the least depend either on the material or on the physical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: state of the body. For instance, a piece of lead and a piece of wood
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fall in exactly the same manner in a gravitational field (in vacuo),
author: Einstein, Albert

text: when they start off from rest or with the same initial velocity. This
author: Einstein, Albert

text: law, which holds most accurately, can be expressed in a different form
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in the light of the following consideration.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: According to Newton's law of motion, we have
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (Force) = (inertial mass) x (acceleration),
author: Einstein, Albert

text: where the "inertial mass" is a characteristic constant of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: accelerated body. If now gravitation is the cause of the acceleration,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we then have
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (Force) = (gravitational mass) x (intensity of the gravitational
author: Einstein, Albert

text: field),
author: Einstein, Albert

text: where the "gravitational mass" is likewise a characteristic constant
author: Einstein, Albert

text: for the body. From these two relations follows:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 26: file eq26.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: If now, as we find from experience, the acceleration is to be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: independent of the nature and the condition of the body and always the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: same for a given gravitational field, then the ratio of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational to the inertial mass must likewise be the same for all
author: Einstein, Albert

text: bodies. By a suitable choice of units we can thus make this ratio
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equal to unity. We then have the following law: The gravitational mass
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of a body is equal to its inertial law.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: It is true that this important law had hitherto been recorded in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mechanics, but it had not been interpreted. A satisfactory
author: Einstein, Albert

text: interpretation can be obtained only if we recognise the following fact
author: Einstein, Albert

text: : The same quality of a body manifests itself according to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: circumstances as " inertia " or as " weight " (lit. " heaviness '). In
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the following section we shall show to what extent this is actually
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the case, and how this question is connected with the general
author: Einstein, Albert

text: postulate of relativity.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE EQUALITY OF INERTIAL AND GRAVITATIONAL MASS
author: Einstein, Albert

text: AS AN ARGUMENT FOR THE GENERAL POSTULE OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We imagine a large portion of empty space, so far removed from stars
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and other appreciable masses, that we have before us approximately the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: conditions required by the fundamental law of Galilei. It is then
author: Einstein, Albert

text: possible to choose a Galileian reference-body for this part of space
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (world), relative to which points at rest remain at rest and points in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion continue permanently in uniform rectilinear motion. As
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-body let us imagine a spacious chest resembling a room with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: an observer inside who is equipped with apparatus. Gravitation
author: Einstein, Albert

text: naturally does not exist for this observer. He must fasten himself
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with strings to the floor, otherwise the slightest impact against the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: floor will cause him to rise slowly towards the ceiling of the room.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: To the middle of the lid of the chest is fixed externally a hook with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rope attached, and now a " being " (what kind of a being is immaterial
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to us) begins pulling at this with a constant force. The chest
author: Einstein, Albert

text: together with the observer then begin to move "upwards" with a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: uniformly accelerated motion. In course of time their velocity will
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reach unheard-of values -- provided that we are viewing all this from
author: Einstein, Albert

text: another reference-body which is not being pulled with a rope.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: But how does the man in the chest regard the Process ? The
author: Einstein, Albert

text: acceleration of the chest will be transmitted to him by the reaction
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the floor of the chest. He must therefore take up this pressure by
author: Einstein, Albert

text: means of his legs if he does not wish to be laid out full length on
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the floor. He is then standing in the chest in exactly the same way as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: anyone stands in a room of a home on our earth. If he releases a body
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which he previously had in his land, the accelertion of the chest will
author: Einstein, Albert

text: no longer be transmitted to this body, and for this reason the body
author: Einstein, Albert

text: will approach the floor of the chest with an accelerated relative
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion. The observer will further convince himself that the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: acceleration of the body towards the floor of the chest is always of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the same magnitude, whatever kind of body he may happen to use for the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experiment.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Relying on his knowledge of the gravitational field (as it was
author: Einstein, Albert

text: discussed in the preceding section), the man in the chest will thus
author: Einstein, Albert

text: come to the conclusion that he and the chest are in a gravitational
author: Einstein, Albert

text: field which is constant with regard to time. Of course he will be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: puzzled for a moment as to why the chest does not fall in this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational field. just then, however, he discovers the hook in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: middle of the lid of the chest and the rope which is attached to it,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and he consequently comes to the conclusion that the chest is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: suspended at rest in the gravitational field.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Ought we to smile at the man and say that he errs in his conclusion ?
author: Einstein, Albert

text: I do not believe we ought to if we wish to remain consistent ; we must
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rather admit that his mode of grasping the situation violates neither
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reason nor known mechanical laws. Even though it is being accelerated
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with respect to the "Galileian space" first considered, we can
author: Einstein, Albert

text: nevertheless regard the chest as being at rest. We have thus good
author: Einstein, Albert

text: grounds for extending the principle of relativity to include bodies of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference which are accelerated with respect to each other, and as a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: result we have gained a powerful argument for a generalised postulate
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of relativity.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We must note carefully that the possibility of this mode of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: interpretation rests on the fundamental property of the gravitational
author: Einstein, Albert

text: field of giving all bodies the same acceleration, or, what comes to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the same thing, on the law of the equality of inertial and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational mass. If this natural law did not exist, the man in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: accelerated chest would not be able to interpret the behaviour of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: bodies around him on the supposition of a gravitational field, and he
author: Einstein, Albert

text: would not be justified on the grounds of experience in supposing his
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-body to be " at rest."
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Suppose that the man in the chest fixes a rope to the inner side of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the lid, and that he attaches a body to the free end of the rope. The
author: Einstein, Albert

text: result of this will be to strech the rope so that it will hang "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: vertically " downwards. If we ask for an opinion of the cause of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: tension in the rope, the man in the chest will say: "The suspended
author: Einstein, Albert

text: body experiences a downward force in the gravitational field, and this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is neutralised by the tension of the rope ; what determines the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: magnitude of the tension of the rope is the gravitational mass of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: suspended body." On the other hand, an observer who is poised freely
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in space will interpret the condition of things thus : " The rope must
author: Einstein, Albert

text: perforce take part in the accelerated motion of the chest, and it
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transmits this motion to the body attached to it. The tension of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rope is just large enough to effect the acceleration of the body. That
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which determines the magnitude of the tension of the rope is the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: inertial mass of the body." Guided by this example, we see that our
author: Einstein, Albert

text: extension of the principle of relativity implies the necessity of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: law of the equality of inertial and gravitational mass. Thus we have
author: Einstein, Albert

text: obtained a physical interpretation of this law.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: From our consideration of the accelerated chest we see that a general
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory of relativity must yield important results on the laws of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitation. In point of fact, the systematic pursuit of the general
author: Einstein, Albert

text: idea of relativity has supplied the laws satisfied by the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational field. Before proceeding farther, however, I must warn
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the reader against a misconception suggested by these considerations.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: A gravitational field exists for the man in the chest, despite the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fact that there was no such field for the co-ordinate system first
author: Einstein, Albert

text: chosen. Now we might easily suppose that the existence of a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational field is always only an apparent one. We might also
author: Einstein, Albert

text: think that, regardless of the kind of gravitational field which may be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: present, we could always choose another reference-body such that no
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational field exists with reference to it. This is by no means
author: Einstein, Albert

text: true for all gravitational fields, but only for those of quite special
author: Einstein, Albert

text: form. It is, for instance, impossible to choose a body of reference
author: Einstein, Albert

text: such that, as judged from it, the gravitational field of the earth (in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: its entirety) vanishes.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We can now appreciate why that argument is not convincing, which we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: brought forward against the general principle of relativity at theend
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of Section 18. It is certainly true that the observer in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: railway carriage experiences a jerk forwards as a result of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: application of the brake, and that he recognises, in this the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: non-uniformity of motion (retardation) of the carriage. But he is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: compelled by nobody to refer this jerk to a " real " acceleration
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (retardation) of the carriage. He might also interpret his experience
author: Einstein, Albert

text: thus: " My body of reference (the carriage) remains permanently at
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rest. With reference to it, however, there exists (during the period
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of application of the brakes) a gravitational field which is directed
author: Einstein, Albert

text: forwards and which is variable with respect to time. Under the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: influence of this field, the embankment together with the earth moves
author: Einstein, Albert

text: non-uniformly in such a manner that their original velocity in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: backwards direction is continuously reduced."
author: Einstein, Albert

text: IN WHAT RESPECTS ARE THE FOUNDATIONS OF CLASSICAL MECHANICS AND OF THE
author: Einstein, Albert

text: SPECIAL THEORY OF RELATIVITY UNSATISFACTORY?
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We have already stated several times that classical mechanics starts
author: Einstein, Albert

text: out from the following law: Material particles sufficiently far
author: Einstein, Albert

text: removed from other material particles continue to move uniformly in a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: straight line or continue in a state of rest. We have also repeatedly
author: Einstein, Albert

text: emphasised that this fundamental law can only be valid for bodies of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference K which possess certain unique states of motion, and which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: are in uniform translational motion relative to each other. Relative
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to other reference-bodies K the law is not valid. Both in classical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mechanics and in the special theory of relativity we therefore
author: Einstein, Albert

text: differentiate between reference-bodies K relative to which the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: recognised " laws of nature " can be said to hold, and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-bodies K relative to which these laws do not hold.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: But no person whose mode of thought is logical can rest satisfied with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this condition of things. He asks : " How does it come that certain
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-bodies (or their states of motion) are given priority over
author: Einstein, Albert

text: other reference-bodies (or their states of motion) ? What is the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reason for this Preference? In order to show clearly what I mean by
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this question, I shall make use of a comparison.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: I am standing in front of a gas range. Standing alongside of each
author: Einstein, Albert

text: other on the range are two pans so much alike that one may be mistaken
author: Einstein, Albert

text: for the other. Both are half full of water. I notice that steam is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: being emitted continuously from the one pan, but not from the other. I
author: Einstein, Albert

text: am surprised at this, even if I have never seen either a gas range or
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a pan before. But if I now notice a luminous something of bluish
author: Einstein, Albert

text: colour under the first pan but not under the other, I cease to be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: astonished, even if I have never before seen a gas flame. For I can
author: Einstein, Albert

text: only say that this bluish something will cause the emission of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: steam, or at least possibly it may do so. If, however, I notice the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: bluish something in neither case, and if I observe that the one
author: Einstein, Albert

text: continuously emits steam whilst the other does not, then I shall
author: Einstein, Albert

text: remain astonished and dissatisfied until I have discovered some
author: Einstein, Albert

text: circumstance to which I can attribute the different behaviour of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: two pans.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Analogously, I seek in vain for a real something in classical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mechanics (or in the special theory of relativity) to which I can
author: Einstein, Albert

text: attribute the different behaviour of bodies considered with respect to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the reference systems K and K1.*  Newton saw this objection and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: attempted to invalidate it, but without success. But E. Mach recognsed
author: Einstein, Albert

text: it most clearly of all, and because of this objection he claimed that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mechanics must be placed on a new basis. It can only be got rid of by
author: Einstein, Albert

text: means of a physics which is conformable to the general principle of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity, since the equations of such a theory hold for every body
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of reference, whatever may be its state of motion.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Notes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: *) The objection is of importance more especially when the state of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion of the reference-body is of such a nature that it does not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: require any external agency for its maintenance, e.g. in the case when
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the reference-body is rotating uniformly.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: A FEW INFERENCES FROM THE GENERAL PRINCIPLE OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The considerations of Section 20 show that the general principle of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity puts us in a position to derive properties of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational field in a purely theoretical manner. Let us suppose,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: for instance, that we know the space-time " course " for any natural
author: Einstein, Albert

text: process whatsoever, as regards the manner in which it takes place in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the Galileian domain relative to a Galileian body of reference K. By
author: Einstein, Albert

text: means of purely theoretical operations (i.e. simply by calculation) we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: are then able to find how this known natural process appears, as seen
author: Einstein, Albert

text: from a reference-body K1 which is accelerated relatively to K. But
author: Einstein, Albert

text: since a gravitational field exists with respect to this new body of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference K1, our consideration also teaches us how the gravitational
author: Einstein, Albert

text: field influences the process studied.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: For example, we learn that a body which is in a state of uniform
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rectilinear motion with respect to K (in accordance with the law of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Galilei) is executing an accelerated and in general curvilinear motion
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with respect to the accelerated reference-body K1 (chest). This
author: Einstein, Albert

text: acceleration or curvature corresponds to the influence on the moving
author: Einstein, Albert

text: body of the gravitational field prevailing relatively to K. It is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: known that a gravitational field influences the movement of bodies in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this way, so that our consideration supplies us with nothing
author: Einstein, Albert

text: essentially new.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: However, we obtain a new result of fundamental importance when we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: carry out the analogous consideration for a ray of light. With respect
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to the Galileian reference-body K, such a ray of light is transmitted
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rectilinearly with the velocity c. It can easily be shown that the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: path of the same ray of light is no longer a straight line when we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: consider it with reference to the accelerated chest (reference-body
author: Einstein, Albert

text: K1). From this we conclude, that, in general, rays of light are
author: Einstein, Albert

text: propagated curvilinearly in gravitational fields. In two respects this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: result is of great importance.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In the first place, it can be compared with the reality. Although a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: detailed examination of the question shows that the curvature of light
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rays required by the general theory of relativity is only exceedingly
author: Einstein, Albert

text: small for the gravitational fields at our disposal in practice, its
author: Einstein, Albert

text: estimated magnitude for light rays passing the sun at grazing
author: Einstein, Albert

text: incidence is nevertheless 1.7 seconds of arc. This ought to manifest
author: Einstein, Albert

text: itself in the following way. As seen from the earth, certain fixed
author: Einstein, Albert

text: stars appear to be in the neighbourhood of the sun, and are thus
author: Einstein, Albert

text: capable of observation during a total eclipse of the sun. At such
author: Einstein, Albert

text: times, these stars ought to appear to be displaced outwards from the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: sun by an amount indicated above, as compared with their apparent
author: Einstein, Albert

text: position in the sky when the sun is situated at another part of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: heavens. The examination of the correctness or otherwise of this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: deduction is a problem of the greatest importance, the early solution
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of which is to be expected of astronomers.[2]*
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In the second place our result shows that, according to the general
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory of relativity, the law of the constancy of the velocity of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: light in vacuo, which constitutes one of the two fundamental
author: Einstein, Albert

text: assumptions in the special theory of relativity and to which we have
author: Einstein, Albert

text: already frequently referred, cannot claim any unlimited validity. A
author: Einstein, Albert

text: curvature of rays of light can only take place when the velocity of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: propagation of light varies with position. Now we might think that as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a consequence of this, the special theory of relativity and with it
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the whole theory of relativity would be laid in the dust. But in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reality this is not the case. We can only conclude that the special
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory of relativity cannot claim an unlinlited domain of validity ;
author: Einstein, Albert

text: its results hold only so long as we are able to disregard the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: influences of gravitational fields on the phenomena (e.g. of light).
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Since it has often been contended by opponents of the theory of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity that the special theory of relativity is overthrown by the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: general theory of relativity, it is perhaps advisable to make the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: facts of the case clearer by means of an appropriate comparison.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Before the development of electrodynamics the laws of electrostatics
author: Einstein, Albert

text: were looked upon as the laws of electricity. At the present time we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: know that electric fields can be derived correctly from electrostatic
author: Einstein, Albert

text: considerations only for the case, which is never strictly realised, in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which the electrical masses are quite at rest relatively to each
author: Einstein, Albert

text: other, and to the co-ordinate system. Should we be justified in saying
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that for this reason electrostatics is overthrown by the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: field-equations of Maxwell in electrodynamics ? Not in the least.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Electrostatics is contained in electrodynamics as a limiting case ;
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the laws of the latter lead directly to those of the former for the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: case in which the fields are invariable with regard to time. No fairer
author: Einstein, Albert

text: destiny could be allotted to any physical theory, than that it should
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of itself point out the way to the introduction of a more
author: Einstein, Albert

text: comprehensive theory, in which it lives on as a limiting case.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In the example of the transmission of light just dealt with, we have
author: Einstein, Albert

text: seen that the general theory of relativity enables us to derive
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theoretically the influence of a gravitational field on the course of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: natural processes, the Iaws of which are already known when a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational field is absent. But the most attractive problem, to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: solution of which the general theory of relativity supplies the key,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: concerns the investigation of the laws satisfied by the gravitational
author: Einstein, Albert

text: field itself. Let us consider this for a moment.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We are acquainted with space-time domains which behave (approximately)
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in a " Galileian " fashion under suitable choice of reference-body,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: i.e. domains in which gravitational fields are absent. If we now refer
author: Einstein, Albert

text: such a domain to a reference-body K1 possessing any kind of motion,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: then relative to K1 there exists a gravitational field which is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: variable with respect to space and time.[3]**  The character of this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: field will of course depend on the motion chosen for K1. According to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the general theory of relativity, the general law of the gravitational
author: Einstein, Albert

text: field must be satisfied for all gravitational fields obtainable in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this way. Even though by no means all gravitationial fields can be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: produced in this way, yet we may entertain the hope that the general
author: Einstein, Albert

text: law of gravitation will be derivable from such gravitational fields of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a special kind. This hope has been realised in the most beautiful
author: Einstein, Albert

text: manner. But between the clear vision of this goal and its actual
author: Einstein, Albert

text: realisation it was necessary to surmount a serious difficulty, and as
author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

text: reader. We require to extend our ideas of the space-time continuum
author: Einstein, Albert
