text: BEHAVIOUR OF CLOCKS AND MEASURING-RODS ON A ROTATING BODY OF REFERENCE
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Hitherto I have purposely refrained from speaking about the physical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: interpretation of space- and time-data in the case of the general
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory of relativity. As a consequence, I am guilty of a certain
author: Einstein, Albert

text: slovenliness of treatment, which, as we know from the special theory
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of relativity, is far from being unimportant and pardonable. It is now
author: Einstein, Albert

text: high time that we remedy this defect; but I would mention at the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: outset, that this matter lays no small claims on the patience and on
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the power of abstraction of the reader.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We start off again from quite special cases, which we have frequently
author: Einstein, Albert

text: used before. Let us consider a space time domain in which no
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational field exists relative to a reference-body K whose state
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of motion has been suitably chosen. K is then a Galileian
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-body as regards the domain considered, and the results of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the special theory of relativity hold relative to K. Let us supposse
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the same domain referred to a second body of reference K1, which is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rotating uniformly with respect to K. In order to fix our ideas, we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: shall imagine K1 to be in the form of a plane circular disc, which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rotates uniformly in its own plane about its centre. An observer who
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is sitting eccentrically on the disc K1 is sensible of a force which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: acts outwards in a radial direction, and which would be interpreted as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: an effect of inertia (centrifugal force) by an observer who was at
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rest with respect to the original reference-body K. But the observer
author: Einstein, Albert

text: on the disc may regard his disc as a reference-body which is " at rest
author: Einstein, Albert

text: " ; on the basis of the general principle of relativity he is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: justified in doing this. The force acting on himself, and in fact on
author: Einstein, Albert

text: all other bodies which are at rest relative to the disc, he regards as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the effect of a gravitational field. Nevertheless, the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: space-distribution of this gravitational field is of a kind that would
author: Einstein, Albert

text: not be possible on Newton's theory of gravitation.* But since the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: observer believes in the general theory of relativity, this does not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: disturb him; he is quite in the right when he believes that a general
author: Einstein, Albert

text: law of gravitation can be formulated- a law which not only explains
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the motion of the stars correctly, but also the field of force
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experienced by himself.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The observer performs experiments on his circular disc with clocks and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: measuring-rods. In doing so, it is his intention to arrive at exact
author: Einstein, Albert

text: definitions for the signification of time- and space-data with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference to the circular disc K1, these definitions being based on
author: Einstein, Albert

text: his observations. What will be his experience in this enterprise ?
author: Einstein, Albert

text: To start with, he places one of two identically constructed clocks at
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the centre of the circular disc, and the other on the edge of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: disc, so that they are at rest relative to it. We now ask ourselves
author: Einstein, Albert

text: whether both clocks go at the same rate from the standpoint of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: non-rotating Galileian reference-body K. As judged from this body, the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: clock at the centre of the disc has no velocity, whereas the clock at
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the edge of the disc is in motion relative to K in consequence of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rotation. According to a result obtained in Section 12, it follows
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that the latter clock goes at a rate permanently slower than that of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the clock at the centre of the circular disc, i.e. as observed from K.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: It is obvious that the same effect would be noted by an observer whom
author: Einstein, Albert

text: we will imagine sitting alongside his clock at the centre of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: circular disc. Thus on our circular disc, or, to make the case more
author: Einstein, Albert

text: general, in every gravitational field, a clock will go more quickly or
author: Einstein, Albert

text: less quickly, according to the position in which the clock is situated
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (at rest). For this reason it is not possible to obtain a reasonable
author: Einstein, Albert

text: definition of time with the aid of clocks which are arranged at rest
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with respect to the body of reference. A similar difficulty presents
author: Einstein, Albert

text: itself when we attempt to apply our earlier definition of simultaneity
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in such a case, but I do not wish to go any farther into this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: question.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Moreover, at this stage the definition of the space co-ordinates also
author: Einstein, Albert

text: presents insurmountable difficulties. If the observer applies his
author: Einstein, Albert

text: standard measuring-rod (a rod which is short as compared with the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: radius of the disc) tangentially to the edge of the disc, then, as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: judged from the Galileian system, the length of this rod will be less
author: Einstein, Albert

text: than I, since, according to Section 12, moving bodies suffer a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: shortening in the direction of the motion. On the other hand, the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: measaring-rod will not experience a shortening in length, as judged
author: Einstein, Albert

text: from K, if it is applied to the disc in the direction of the radius.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: If, then, the observer first measures the circumference of the disc
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with his measuring-rod and then the diameter of the disc, on dividing
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the one by the other, he will not obtain as quotient the familiar
author: Einstein, Albert

text: number p = 3.14 . . ., but a larger number,[4]** whereas of course,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: for a disc which is at rest with respect to K, this operation would
author: Einstein, Albert

text: yield p exactly. This proves that the propositions of Euclidean
author: Einstein, Albert

text: geometry cannot hold exactly on the rotating disc, nor in general in a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational field, at least if we attribute the length I to the rod
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in all positions and in every orientation. Hence the idea of a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: straight line also loses its meaning. We are therefore not in a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: position to define exactly the co-ordinates x, y, z relative to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: disc by means of the method used in discussing the special theory, and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: as long as the co- ordinates and times of events have not been
author: Einstein, Albert

text: defined, we cannot assign an exact meaning to the natural laws in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which these occur.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Thus all our previous conclusions based on general relativity would
author: Einstein, Albert

text: appear to be called in question. In reality we must make a subtle
author: Einstein, Albert

text: detour in order to be able to apply the postulate of general
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity exactly. I shall prepare the reader for this in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: following paragraphs.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Notes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: *) The field disappears at the centre of the disc and increases
author: Einstein, Albert

text: proportionally to the distance from the centre as we proceed outwards.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: **) Throughout this consideration we have to use the Galileian
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (non-rotating) system K as reference-body, since we may only assume
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the validity of the results of the special theory of relativity
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relative to K (relative to K1 a gravitational field prevails).
author: Einstein, Albert

text: EUCLIDEAN AND NON-EUCLIDEAN CONTINUUM
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The surface of a marble table is spread out in front of me. I can get
author: Einstein, Albert

text: from any one point on this table to any other point by passing
author: Einstein, Albert

text: continuously from one point to a " neighbouring " one, and repeating
author: Einstein, Albert

text: this process a (large) number of times, or, in other words, by going
author: Einstein, Albert

text: from point to point without executing "jumps." I am sure the reader
author: Einstein, Albert

text: will appreciate with sufficient clearness what I mean here by "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: neighbouring " and by " jumps " (if he is not too pedantic). We
author: Einstein, Albert

text: express this property of the surface by describing the latter as a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: continuum.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Let us now imagine that a large number of little rods of equal length
author: Einstein, Albert

text: have been made, their lengths being small compared with the dimensions
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the marble slab. When I say they are of equal length, I mean that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: one can be laid on any other without the ends overlapping. We next lay
author: Einstein, Albert

text: four of these little rods on the marble slab so that they constitute a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: quadrilateral figure (a square), the diagonals of which are equally
author: Einstein, Albert

text: long. To ensure the equality of the diagonals, we make use of a little
author: Einstein, Albert

text: testing-rod. To this square we add similar ones, each of which has one
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rod in common with the first. We proceed in like manner with each of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: these squares until finally the whole marble slab is laid out with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: squares. The arrangement is such, that each side of a square belongs
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to two squares and each corner to four squares.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: It is a veritable wonder that we can carry out this business without
author: Einstein, Albert

text: getting into the greatest difficulties. We only need to think of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: following. If at any moment three squares meet at a corner, then two
author: Einstein, Albert

text: sides of the fourth square are already laid, and, as a consequence,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the arrangement of the remaining two sides of the square is already
author: Einstein, Albert

text: completely determined. But I am now no longer able to adjust the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: quadrilateral so that its diagonals may be equal. If they are equal of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: their own accord, then this is an especial favour of the marble slab
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and of the little rods, about which I can only be thankfully
author: Einstein, Albert

text: surprised. We must experience many such surprises if the construction
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is to be successful.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: If everything has really gone smoothly, then I say that the points of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the marble slab constitute a Euclidean continuum with respect to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: little rod, which has been used as a " distance " (line-interval). By
author: Einstein, Albert

text: choosing one corner of a square as " origin" I can characterise every
author: Einstein, Albert

text: other corner of a square with reference to this origin by means of two
author: Einstein, Albert

text: numbers. I only need state how many rods I must pass over when,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: starting from the origin, I proceed towards the " right " and then "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: upwards," in order to arrive at the corner of the square under
author: Einstein, Albert

text: consideration. These two numbers are then the " Cartesian co-ordinates
author: Einstein, Albert

text: " of this corner with reference to the " Cartesian co-ordinate system"
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which is determined by the arrangement of little rods.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: By making use of the following modification of this abstract
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experiment, we recognise that there must also be cases in which the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: experiment would be unsuccessful. We shall suppose that the rods "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: expand " by in amount proportional to the increase of temperature. We
author: Einstein, Albert

text: heat the central part of the marble slab, but not the periphery, in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which case two of our little rods can still be brought into
author: Einstein, Albert

text: coincidence at every position on the table. But our construction of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: squares must necessarily come into disorder during the heating,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: because the little rods on the central region of the table expand,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: whereas those on the outer part do not.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: With reference to our little rods -- defined as unit lengths -- the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: marble slab is no longer a Euclidean continuum, and we are also no
author: Einstein, Albert

text: longer in the position of defining Cartesian co-ordinates directly
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with their aid, since the above construction can no longer be carried
author: Einstein, Albert

text: out. But since there are other things which are not influenced in a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: similar manner to the little rods (or perhaps not at all) by the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: temperature of the table, it is possible quite naturally to maintain
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the point of view that the marble slab is a " Euclidean continuum."
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This can be done in a satisfactory manner by making a more subtle
author: Einstein, Albert

text: stipulation about the measurement or the comparison of lengths.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: But if rods of every kind (i.e. of every material) were to behave in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the same way as regards the influence of temperature when they are on
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the variably heated marble slab, and if we had no other means of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: detecting the effect of temperature than the geometrical behaviour of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: our rods in experiments analogous to the one described above, then our
author: Einstein, Albert

text: best plan would be to assign the distance one to two points on the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: slab, provided that the ends of one of our rods could be made to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: coincide with these two points ; for how else should we define the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: distance without our proceeding being in the highest measure grossly
author: Einstein, Albert

text: arbitrary ? The method of Cartesian coordinates must then be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: discarded, and replaced by another which does not assume the validity
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of Euclidean geometry for rigid bodies.*  The reader will notice
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that the situation depicted here corresponds to the one brought about
author: Einstein, Albert

text: by the general postitlate of relativity (Section 23).
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Notes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: *) Mathematicians have been confronted with our problem in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: following form. If we are given a surface (e.g. an ellipsoid) in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Euclidean three-dimensional space, then there exists for this surface
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a two-dimensional geometry, just as much as for a plane surface. Gauss
author: Einstein, Albert

text: undertook the task of treating this two-dimensional geometry from
author: Einstein, Albert

text: first principles, without making use of the fact that the surface
author: Einstein, Albert

text: belongs to a Euclidean continuum of three dimensions. If we imagine
author: Einstein, Albert

text: constructions to be made with rigid rods in the surface (similar to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that above with the marble slab), we should find that different laws
author: Einstein, Albert

text: hold for these from those resulting on the basis of Euclidean plane
author: Einstein, Albert

text: geometry. The surface is not a Euclidean continuum with respect to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rods, and we cannot define Cartesian co-ordinates in the surface.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Gauss indicated the principles according to which we can treat the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: geometrical relationships in the surface, and thus pointed out the way
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to the method of Riemman of treating multi-dimensional, non-Euclidean
author: Einstein, Albert

text: continuum. Thus it is that mathematicians long ago solved the formal
author: Einstein, Albert

text: problems to which we are led by the general postulate of relativity.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: GAUSSIAN CO-ORDINATES
author: Einstein, Albert

text: According to Gauss, this combined analytical and geometrical mode of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: handling the problem can be arrived at in the following way. We
author: Einstein, Albert

text: imagine a system of arbitrary curves (see Fig. 4) drawn on the surface
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the table. These we designate as u-curves, and we indicate each of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: them by means of a number. The Curves u= 1, u= 2 and u= 3 are drawn in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the diagram. Between the curves u= 1 and u= 2 we must imagine an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: infinitely large number to be drawn, all of which correspond to real
author: Einstein, Albert

text: numbers lying between 1 and 2. fig. 04 We have then a system of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: u-curves, and this "infinitely dense" system covers the whole surface
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the table. These u-curves must not intersect each other, and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: through each point of the surface one and only one curve must pass.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Thus a perfectly definite value of u belongs to every point on the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: surface of the marble slab. In like manner we imagine a system of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: v-curves drawn on the surface. These satisfy the same conditions as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the u-curves, they are provided with numbers in a corresponding
author: Einstein, Albert

text: manner, and they may likewise be of arbitrary shape. It follows that a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: value of u and a value of v belong to every point on the surface of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the table. We call these two numbers the co-ordinates of the surface
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the table (Gaussian co-ordinates). For example, the point P in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: diagram has the Gaussian co-ordinates u= 3, v= 1. Two neighbouring
author: Einstein, Albert

text: points P and P1 on the surface then correspond to the co-ordinates
author: Einstein, Albert

text: P:       u,v
author: Einstein, Albert

text: P1:     u + du, v + dv,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: where du and dv signify very small numbers. In a similar manner we may
author: Einstein, Albert

text: indicate the distance (line-interval) between P and P1, as measured
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with a little rod, by means of the very small number ds. Then
author: Einstein, Albert

text: according to Gauss we have
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ds2 = g[11]du2 + 2g[12]dudv = g[22]dv2
author: Einstein, Albert

text: where g[11], g[12], g[22], are magnitudes which depend in a perfectly
author: Einstein, Albert

text: definite way on u and v. The magnitudes g[11], g[12] and g[22],
author: Einstein, Albert

text: determine the behaviour of the rods relative to the u-curves and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: v-curves, and thus also relative to the surface of the table. For the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: case in which the points of the surface considered form a Euclidean
author: Einstein, Albert

text: continuum with reference to the measuring-rods, but only in this case,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: it is possible to draw the u-curves and v-curves and to attach numbers
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to them, in such a manner, that we simply have :
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ds2 = du2 + dv2
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Under these conditions, the u-curves and v-curves are straight lines
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in the sense of Euclidean geometry, and they are perpendicular to each
author: Einstein, Albert

text: other. Here the Gaussian coordinates are samply Cartesian ones. It is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: clear that Gauss co-ordinates are nothing more than an association of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: two sets of numbers with the points of the surface considered, of such
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a nature that numerical values differing very slightly from each other
author: Einstein, Albert

text: are associated with neighbouring points " in space."
author: Einstein, Albert

text: So far, these considerations hold for a continuum of two dimensions.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: But the Gaussian method can be applied also to a continuum of three,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: four or more dimensions. If, for instance, a continuum of four
author: Einstein, Albert

text: dimensions be supposed available, we may represent it in the following
author: Einstein, Albert

text: way. With every point of the continuum, we associate arbitrarily four
author: Einstein, Albert

text: numbers, x[1], x[2], x[3], x[4], which are known as " co-ordinates."
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Adjacent points correspond to adjacent values of the coordinates. If a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: distance ds is associated with the adjacent points P and P1, this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: distance being measurable and well defined from a physical point of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: view, then the following formula holds:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: where the magnitudes g[11], etc., have values which vary with the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: position in the continuum. Only when the continuum is a Euclidean one
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is it possible to associate the co-ordinates x[1] . . x[4]. with the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: points of the continuum so that we have simply
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In this case relations hold in the four-dimensional continuum which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: are analogous to those holding in our three-dimensional measurements.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: However, the Gauss treatment for ds2 which we have given above is not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: always possible. It is only possible when sufficiently small regions
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the continuum under consideration may be regarded as Euclidean
author: Einstein, Albert

text: continua. For example, this obviously holds in the case of the marble
author: Einstein, Albert

text: slab of the table and local variation of temperature. The temperature
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is practically constant for a small part of the slab, and thus the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: geometrical behaviour of the rods is almost as it ought to be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: according to the rules of Euclidean geometry. Hence the imperfections
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the construction of squares in the previous section do not show
author: Einstein, Albert

text: themselves clearly until this construction is extended over a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: considerable portion of the surface of the table.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We can sum this up as follows: Gauss invented a method for the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mathematical treatment of continua in general, in which "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: size-relations " (" distances " between neighbouring points) are
author: Einstein, Albert

text: defined. To every point of a continuum are assigned as many numbers
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (Gaussian coordinates) as the continuum has dimensions. This is done
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in such a way, that only one meaning can be attached to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: assignment, and that numbers (Gaussian coordinates) which differ by an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: indefinitely small amount are assigned to adjacent points. The
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Gaussian coordinate system is a logical generalisation of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Cartesian co-ordinate system. It is also applicable to non-Euclidean
author: Einstein, Albert

text: continua, but only when, with respect to the defined "size" or
author: Einstein, Albert

text: "distance," small parts of the continuum under consideration behave
author: Einstein, Albert

text: more nearly like a Euclidean system, the smaller the part of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: continuum under our notice.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: EUCLIDEAN CONTINUUM
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We are now in a position to formulate more exactly the idea of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Minkowski, which was only vaguely indicated in Section 17. In
author: Einstein, Albert

text: accordance with the special theory of relativity, certain co-ordinate
author: Einstein, Albert

text: systems are given preference for the description of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: four-dimensional, space-time continuum. We called these " Galileian
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinate systems." For these systems, the four co-ordinates x, y,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: z, t, which determine an event or -- in other words, a point of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: four-dimensional continuum -- are defined physically in a simple
author: Einstein, Albert

text: manner, as set forth in detail in the first part of this book. For the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transition from one Galileian system to another, which is moving
author: Einstein, Albert

text: uniformly with reference to the first, the equations of the Lorentz
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transformation are valid. These last form the basis for the derivation
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of deductions from the special theory of relativity, and in themselves
author: Einstein, Albert

text: they are nothing more than the expression of the universal validity of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the law of transmission of light for all Galileian systems of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Minkowski found that the Lorentz transformations satisfy the following
author: Einstein, Albert

text: simple conditions. Let us consider two neighbouring events, the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relative position of which in the four-dimensional continuum is given
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with respect to a Galileian reference-body K by the space co-ordinate
author: Einstein, Albert

text: differences dx, dy, dz and the time-difference dt. With reference to a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: second Galileian system we shall suppose that the corresponding
author: Einstein, Albert

text: differences for these two events are dx1, dy1, dz1, dt1. Then these
author: Einstein, Albert

text: magnitudes always fulfil the condition*
author: Einstein, Albert

text: dx2 + dy2 + dz2 - c^2dt2 = dx1 2 + dy1 2 + dz1 2 - c^2dt1 2.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The validity of the Lorentz transformation follows from this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: condition. We can express this as follows: The magnitude
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ds2 = dx2 + dy2 + dz2 - c^2dt2,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which belongs to two adjacent points of the four-dimensional
author: Einstein, Albert

text: space-time continuum, has the same value for all selected (Galileian)
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-bodies. If we replace x, y, z, sq. rt. -I . ct , by x[1],
author: Einstein, Albert

text: x[2], x[3], x[4], we also obtaill the result that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is independent of the choice of the body of reference. We call the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: magnitude ds the " distance " apart of the two events or
author: Einstein, Albert

text: four-dimensional points.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Thus, if we choose as time-variable the imaginary variable sq. rt. -I
author: Einstein, Albert

text: . ct instead of the real quantity t, we can regard the space-time
author: Einstein, Albert

text: contintium -- accordance with the special theory of relativity -- as a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ", Euclidean " four-dimensional continuum, a result which follows from
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the considerations of the preceding section.

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

text: measuring-rods and clocks, arranged rigidly with respect to one
author: Einstein, Albert

text: another, shaIll indicate position and time directly. Such was the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: essence of the difficulty with which we were confronted in Section
author: Einstein, Albert

text: But the considerations of Sections 25 and 26 show us the way to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: surmount this difficulty. We refer the fourdimensional space-time
author: Einstein, Albert

text: continuum in an arbitrary manner to Gauss co-ordinates. We assign to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: every point of the continuum (event) four numbers, x[1], x[2], x[3],
author: Einstein, Albert

text: x[4] (co-ordinates), which have not the least direct physical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: significance, but only serve the purpose of numbering the points of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the continuum in a definite but arbitrary manner. This arrangement
author: Einstein, Albert

text: does not even need to be of such a kind that we must regard x[1],
author: Einstein, Albert

text: x[2], x[3], as "space" co-ordinates and x[4], as a " time "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinate.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The reader may think that such a description of the world would be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: quite inadequate. What does it mean to assign to an event the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: particular co-ordinates x[1], x[2], x[3], x[4], if in themselves these
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinates have no significance ? More careful consideration shows,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: however, that this anxiety is unfounded. Let us consider, for
author: Einstein, Albert

text: instance, a material point with any kind of motion. If this point had
author: Einstein, Albert

text: only a momentary existence without duration, then it would to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: described in space-time by a single system of values x[1], x[2], x[3],
author: Einstein, Albert

text: x[4]. Thus its permanent existence must be characterised by an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: infinitely large number of such systems of values, the co-ordinate
author: Einstein, Albert

text: values of which are so close together as to give continuity;
author: Einstein, Albert

text: corresponding to the material point, we thus have a (uni-dimensional)
author: Einstein, Albert

text: line in the four-dimensional continuum. In the same way, any such
author: Einstein, Albert

text: lines in our continuum correspond to many points in motion. The only
author: Einstein, Albert

text: statements having regard to these points which can claim a physical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: existence are in reality the statements about their encounters. In our
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mathematical treatment, such an encounter is expressed in the fact
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that the two lines which represent the motions of the points in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: question have a particular system of co-ordinate values, x[1], x[2],
author: Einstein, Albert

text: x[3], x[4], in common. After mature consideration the reader will
author: Einstein, Albert

text: doubtless admit that in reality such encounters constitute the only
author: Einstein, Albert

text: actual evidence of a time-space nature with which we meet in physical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: statements.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: When we were describing the motion of a material point relative to a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: body of reference, we stated nothing more than the encounters of this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: point with particular points of the reference-body. We can also
author: Einstein, Albert

text: determine the corresponding values of the time by the observation of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: encounters of the body with clocks, in conjunction with the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: observation of the encounter of the hands of clocks with particular
author: Einstein, Albert

text: points on the dials. It is just the same in the case of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: space-measurements by means of measuring-rods, as a litttle
author: Einstein, Albert

text: consideration will show.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The following statements hold generally : Every physical description
author: Einstein, Albert

text: resolves itself into a number of statements, each of which refers to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the space-time coincidence of two events A and B. In terms of Gaussian
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinates, every such statement is expressed by the agreement of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: their four co-ordinates x[1], x[2], x[3], x[4]. Thus in reality, the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: description of the time-space continuum by means of Gauss co-ordinates
author: Einstein, Albert

text: completely replaces the description with the aid of a body of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference, without suffering from the defects of the latter mode of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: description; it is not tied down to the Euclidean character of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: continuum which has to be represented.

text: EXACT FORMULATION OF THE GENERAL PRINCIPLE OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We are now in a position to replace the pro. visional formulation of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the general principle of relativity given in Section 18 by an exact
author: Einstein, Albert

text: formulation. The form there used, "All bodies of reference K, K1,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: etc., are equivalent for the description of natural phenomena
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (formulation of the general laws of nature), whatever may be their
author: Einstein, Albert

text: state of motion," cannot be maintained, because the use of rigid
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-bodies, in the sense of the method followed in the special
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory of relativity, is in general not possible in space-time
author: Einstein, Albert

text: description. The Gauss co-ordinate system has to take the place of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: body of reference. The following statement corresponds to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fundamental idea of the general principle of relativity: "All Gaussian
author: Einstein, Albert

text: co-ordinate systems are essentially equivalent for the formulation of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the general laws of nature."
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We can state this general principle of relativity in still another
author: Einstein, Albert

text: form, which renders it yet more clearly intelligible than it is when
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in the form of the natural extension of the special principle of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity. According to the special theory of relativity, the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equations which express the general laws of nature pass over into
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equations of the same form when, by making use of the Lorentz
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transformation, we replace the space-time variables x, y, z, t, of a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (Galileian) reference-body K by the space-time variables x1, y1, z1,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: t1, of a new reference-body K1. According to the general theory of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: relativity, on the other hand, by application of arbitrary
author: Einstein, Albert

text: substitutions of the Gauss variables x[1], x[2], x[3], x[4], the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equations must pass over into equations of the same form; for every
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transformation (not only the Lorentz transformation) corresponds to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the transition of one Gauss co-ordinate system into another.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: If we desire to adhere to our "old-time" three-dimensional view of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: things, then we can characterise the development which is being
author: Einstein, Albert

text: undergone by the fundamental idea of the general theory of relativity
author: Einstein, Albert

text: as follows : The special theory of relativity has reference to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Galileian domains, i.e. to those in which no gravitational field
author: Einstein, Albert

text: exists. In this connection a Galileian reference-body serves as body
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of reference, i.e. a rigid body the state of motion of which is so
author: Einstein, Albert

text: chosen that the Galileian law of the uniform rectilinear motion of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: "isolated" material points holds relatively to it.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Certain considerations suggest that we should refer the same Galileian
author: Einstein, Albert

text: domains to non-Galileian reference-bodies also. A gravitational field
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of a special kind is then present with respect to these bodies (cf.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Sections 20 and 23).
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In gravitational fields there are no such things as rigid bodies with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Euclidean properties; thus the fictitious rigid body of reference is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of no avail in the general theory of relativity. The motion of clocks
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is also influenced by gravitational fields, and in such a way that a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: physical definition of time which is made directly with the aid of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: clocks has by no means the same degree of plausibility as in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: special theory of relativity.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: For this reason non-rigid reference-bodies are used, which are as a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: whole not only moving in any way whatsoever, but which also suffer
author: Einstein, Albert

text: alterations in form ad lib. during their motion. Clocks, for which the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: law of motion is of any kind, however irregular, serve for the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: definition of time. We have to imagine each of these clocks fixed at a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: point on the non-rigid reference-body. These clocks satisfy only the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: one condition, that the "readings" which are observed simultaneously
author: Einstein, Albert

text: on adjacent clocks (in space) differ from each other by an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: indefinitely small amount. This non-rigid reference-body, which might
author: Einstein, Albert

text: appropriately be termed a "reference-mollusc", is in the main
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equivalent to a Gaussian four-dimensional co-ordinate system chosen
author: Einstein, Albert

text: arbitrarily. That which gives the "mollusc" a certain
author: Einstein, Albert

text: comprehensibility as compared with the Gauss co-ordinate system is the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (really unjustified) formal retention of the separate existence of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: space co-ordinates as opposed to the time co-ordinate. Every point on
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the mollusc is treated as a space-point, and every material point
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which is at rest relatively to it as at rest, so long as the mollusc
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is considered as reference-body. The general principle of relativity
author: Einstein, Albert

text: requires that all these molluscs can be used as reference-bodies with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equal right and equal success in the formulation of the general laws
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of nature; the laws themselves must be quite independent of the choice
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of mollusc.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The great power possessed by the general principle of relativity lies
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in the comprehensive limitation which is imposed on the laws of nature
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in consequence of what we have seen above.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE SOLUTION OF THE PROBLEM OF GRAVITATION ON THE BASIS OF THE GENERAL
author: Einstein, Albert

text: PRINCIPLE OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: If the reader has followed all our previous considerations, he will
author: Einstein, Albert

text: have no further difficulty in understanding the methods leading to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: solution of the problem of gravitation.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We start off on a consideration of a Galileian domain, i.e. a domain
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in which there is no gravitational field relative to the Galileian
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-body K. The behaviour of measuring-rods and clocks with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference to K is known from the special theory of relativity,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: likewise the behaviour of "isolated" material points; the latter move
author: Einstein, Albert

text: uniformly and in straight lines.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Now let us refer this domain to a random Gauss coordinate system or to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a "mollusc" as reference-body K1. Then with respect to K1 there is a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational field G (of a particular kind). We learn the behaviour
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of measuring-rods and clocks and also of freely-moving material points
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with reference to K1 simply by mathematical transformation. We
author: Einstein, Albert

text: interpret this behaviour as the behaviour of measuring-rods, docks and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: material points tinder the influence of the gravitational field G.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Hereupon we introduce a hypothesis: that the influence of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational field on measuringrods, clocks and freely-moving
author: Einstein, Albert

text: material points continues to take place according to the same laws,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: even in the case where the prevailing gravitational field is not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: derivable from the Galfleian special care, simply by means of a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: transformation of co-ordinates.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The next step is to investigate the space-time behaviour of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational field G, which was derived from the Galileian special
author: Einstein, Albert

text: case simply by transformation of the coordinates. This behaviour is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: formulated in a law, which is always valid, no matter how the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reference-body (mollusc) used in the description may be chosen.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This law is not yet the general law of the gravitational field, since
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the gravitational field under consideration is of a special kind. In
author: Einstein, Albert

text: order to find out the general law-of-field of gravitation we still
author: Einstein, Albert

text: require to obtain a generalisation of the law as found above. This can
author: Einstein, Albert

text: be obtained without caprice, however, by taking into consideration the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: following demands:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (a) The required generalisation must likewise satisfy the general
author: Einstein, Albert

text: postulate of relativity.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (b) If there is any matter in the domain under consideration, only its
author: Einstein, Albert

text: inertial mass, and thus according to Section 15 only its energy is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of importance for its etfect in exciting a field.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (c) Gravitational field and matter together must satisfy the law of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the conservation of energy (and of impulse).
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Finally, the general principle of relativity permits us to determine
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the influence of the gravitational field on the course of all those
author: Einstein, Albert

text: processes which take place according to known laws when a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational field is absent i.e. which have already been fitted into
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the frame of the special theory of relativity. In this connection we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: proceed in principle according to the method which has already been
author: Einstein, Albert

text: explained for measuring-rods, clocks and freely moving material
author: Einstein, Albert

text: points.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: The theory of gravitation derived in this way from the general
author: Einstein, Albert

text: postulate of relativity excels not only in its beauty ; nor in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: removing the defect attaching to classical mechanics which was brought
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to light in Section 21; nor in interpreting the empirical law of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the equality of inertial and gravitational mass ; but it has also
author: Einstein, Albert

text: already explained a result of observation in astronomy, against which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: classical mechanics is powerless.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: If we confine the application of the theory to the case where the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravitational fields can be regarded as being weak, and in which all
author: Einstein, Albert

text: masses move with respect to the coordinate system with velocities
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which are small compared with the velocity of light, we then obtain as
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a first approximation the Newtonian theory. Thus the latter theory is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: obtained here without any particular assumption, whereas Newton had to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: introduce the hypothesis that the force of attraction between mutually
author: Einstein, Albert

text: attracting material points is inversely proportional to the square of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the distance between them. If we increase the accuracy of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: calculation, deviations from the theory of Newton make their
author: Einstein, Albert

text: appearance, practically all of which must nevertheless escape the test
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of observation owing to their smallness.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We must draw attention here to one of these deviations. According to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Newton's theory, a planet moves round the sun in an ellipse, which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: would permanently maintain its position with respect to the fixed
author: Einstein, Albert

text: stars, if we could disregard the motion of the fixed stars themselves
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and the action of the other planets under consideration. Thus, if we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: correct the observed motion of the planets for these two influences,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and if Newton's theory be strictly correct, we ought to obtain for the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: orbit of the planet an ellipse, which is fixed with reference to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fixed stars. This deduction, which can be tested with great accuracy,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: has been confirmed for all the planets save one, with the precision
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that is capable of being obtained by the delicacy of observation
author: Einstein, Albert

text: attainable at the present time. The sole exception is Mercury, the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: planet which lies nearest the sun. Since the time of Leverrier, it has
author: Einstein, Albert

text: been known that the ellipse corresponding to the orbit of Mercury,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: after it has been corrected for the influences mentioned above, is not
author: Einstein, Albert

text: stationary with respect to the fixed stars, but that it rotates
author: Einstein, Albert

text: exceedingly slowly in the plane of the orbit and in the sense of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: orbital motion. The value obtained for this rotary movement of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: orbital ellipse was 43 seconds of arc per century, an amount ensured
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to be correct to within a few seconds of arc. This effect can be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: explained by means of classical mechanics only on the assumption of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: hypotheses which have little probability, and which were devised
author: Einstein, Albert

text: solely for this purponse.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: On the basis of the general theory of relativity, it is found that the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ellipse of every planet round the sun must necessarily rotate in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: manner indicated above ; that for all the planets, with the exception
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of Mercury, this rotation is too small to be detected with the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: delicacy of observation possible at the present time ; but that in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: case of Mercury it must amount to 43 seconds of arc per century, a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: result which is strictly in agreement with observation.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Apart from this one, it has hitherto been possible to make only two
author: Einstein, Albert

text: deductions from the theory which admit of being tested by observation,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to wit, the curvature of light rays by the gravitational field of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: sun,*x and a displacement of the spectral lines of light reaching
author: Einstein, Albert

text: us from large stars, as compared with the corresponding lines for
author: Einstein, Albert

text: light produced in an analogous manner terrestrially (i.e. by the same
author: Einstein, Albert

text: kind of atom).**  These two deductions from the theory have both
author: Einstein, Albert

text: been confirmed.

author: Einstein, Albert

text: CONSIDERATIONS ON THE UNIVERSE AS A WHOLE
author: Einstein, Albert

text: COSMOLOGICAL DIFFICULTIES OF NEWTON'S THEORY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Part from the difficulty discussed in Section 21, there is a second
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fundamental difficulty attending classical celestial mechanics, which,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to the best of my knowledge, was first discussed in detail by the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: astronomer Seeliger. If we ponder over the question as to how the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: universe, considered as a whole, is to be regarded, the first answer
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that suggests itself to us is surely this: As regards space (and time)
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the universe is infinite. There are stars everywhere, so that the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: density of matter, although very variable in detail, is nevertheless
author: Einstein, Albert

text: on the average everywhere the same. In other words: However far we
author: Einstein, Albert

text: might travel through space, we should find everywhere an attenuated
author: Einstein, Albert

text: swarm of fixed stars of approrimately the same kind and density.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This view is not in harmony with the theory of Newton. The latter
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory rather requires that the universe should have a kind of centre
author: Einstein, Albert

text: in which the density of the stars is a maximum, and that as we proceed
author: Einstein, Albert

text: outwards from this centre the group-density of the stars should
author: Einstein, Albert

text: diminish, until finally, at great distances, it is succeeded by an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: infinite region of emptiness. The stellar universe ought to be a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: finite island in the infinite ocean of space.*
author: Einstein, Albert

text: This conception is in itself not very satisfactory. It is still less
author: Einstein, Albert

text: satisfactory because it leads to the result that the light emitted by
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the stars and also individual stars of the stellar system are
author: Einstein, Albert

text: perpetually passing out into infinite space, never to return, and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: without ever again coming into interaction with other objects of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: nature. Such a finite material universe would be destined to become
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gradually but systematically impoverished.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In order to escape this dilemma, Seeliger suggested a modification of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Newton's law, in which he assumes that for great distances the force
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of attraction between two masses diminishes more rapidly than would
author: Einstein, Albert

text: result from the inverse square law. In this way it is possible for the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mean density of matter to be constant everywhere, even to infinity,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: without infinitely large gravitational fields being produced. We thus
author: Einstein, Albert

text: free ourselves from the distasteful conception that the material
author: Einstein, Albert

text: universe ought to possess something of the nature of a centre. Of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: course we purchase our emancipation from the fundamental difficulties
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mentioned, at the cost of a modification and complication of Newton's
author: Einstein, Albert

text: law which has neither empirical nor theoretical foundation. We can
author: Einstein, Albert

text: imagine innumerable laws which would serve the same purpose, without
author: Einstein, Albert

text: our being able to state a reason why one of them is to be preferred to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the others ; for any one of these laws would be founded just as little
author: Einstein, Albert

text: on more general theoretical principles as is the law of Newton.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE POSSIBILITY OF A "FINITE" AND YET "UNBOUNDED" UNIVERSE
author: Einstein, Albert

text: But speculations on the structure of the universe also move in quite
author: Einstein, Albert

text: another direction. The development of non-Euclidean geometry led to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the recognition of the fact, that we can cast doubt on the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: infiniteness of our space without coming into conflict with the laws
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of thought or with experience (Riemann, Helmholtz). These questions
author: Einstein, Albert

text: have already been treated in detail and with unsurpassable lucidity by
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Helmholtz and Poincar, whereas I can only touch on them briefly here.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In the first place, we imagine an existence in two dimensional space.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Flat beings with flat implements, and in particular flat rigid
author: Einstein, Albert

text: measuring-rods, are free to move in a plane. For them nothing exists
author: Einstein, Albert

text: outside of this plane: that which they observe to happen to themselves
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and to their flat " things " is the all-inclusive reality of their
author: Einstein, Albert

text: plane. In particular, the constructions of plane Euclidean geometry
author: Einstein, Albert

text: can be carried out by means of the rods e.g. the lattice construction,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: considered in Section 24. In contrast to ours, the universe of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: these beings is two-dimensional; but, like ours, it extends to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: infinity. In their universe there is room for an infinite number of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: identical squares made up of rods, i.e. its volume (surface) is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: infinite. If these beings say their universe is " plane," there is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: sense in the statement, because they mean that they can perform the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: constructions of plane Euclidean geometry with their rods. In this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: connection the individual rods always represent the same distance,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: independently of their position.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Let us consider now a second two-dimensional existence, but this time
author: Einstein, Albert

text: on a spherical surface instead of on a plane. The flat beings with
author: Einstein, Albert

text: their measuring-rods and other objects fit exactly on this surface and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: they are unable to leave it. Their whole universe of observation
author: Einstein, Albert

text: extends exclusively over the surface of the sphere. Are these beings
author: Einstein, Albert

text: able to regard the geometry of their universe as being plane geometry
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and their rods withal as the realisation of " distance " ? They cannot
author: Einstein, Albert

text: do this. For if they attempt to realise a straight line, they will
author: Einstein, Albert

text: obtain a curve, which we " three-dimensional beings " designate as a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: great circle, i.e. a self-contained line of definite finite length,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which can be measured up by means of a measuring-rod. Similarly, this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: universe has a finite area that can be compared with the area, of a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: square constructed with rods. The great charm resulting from this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: consideration lies in the recognition of the fact that the universe of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: these beings is finite and yet has no limits.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: But the spherical-surface beings do not need to go on a world-tour in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: order to perceive that they are not living in a Euclidean universe.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: They can convince themselves of this on every part of their " world,"
author: Einstein, Albert

text: provided they do not use too small a piece of it. Starting from a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: point, they draw " straight lines " (arcs of circles as judged in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: three dimensional space) of equal length in all directions. They will
author: Einstein, Albert

text: call the line joining the free ends of these lines a " circle." For a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: plane surface, the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its
author: Einstein, Albert

text: diameter, both lengths being measured with the same rod, is, according
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to Euclidean geometry of the plane, equal to a constant value p, which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is independent of the diameter of the circle. On their spherical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: surface our flat beings would find for this ratio the value
author: Einstein, Albert

text: eq. 27: file eq27.gif
author: Einstein, Albert

text: i.e. a smaller value than p, the difference being the more
author: Einstein, Albert

text: considerable, the greater is the radius of the circle in comparison
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with the radius R of the " world-sphere." By means of this relation
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the spherical beings can determine the radius of their universe ("
author: Einstein, Albert

text: world "), even when only a relatively small part of their worldsphere
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is available for their measurements. But if this part is very small
author: Einstein, Albert

text: indeed, they will no longer be able to demonstrate that they are on a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: spherical " world " and not on a Euclidean plane, for a small part of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a spherical surface differs only slightly from a piece of a plane of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the same size.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Thus if the spherical surface beings are living on a planet of which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the solar system occupies only a negligibly small part of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: spherical universe, they have no means of determining whether they are
author: Einstein, Albert

text: living in a finite or in an infinite universe, because the " piece of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: universe " to which they have access is in both cases practically
author: Einstein, Albert

text: plane, or Euclidean. It follows directly from this discussion, that
author: Einstein, Albert

text: for our sphere-beings the circumference of a circle first increases
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with the radius until the " circumference of the universe " is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reached, and that it thenceforward gradually decreases to zero for
author: Einstein, Albert

text: still further increasing values of the radius. During this process the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: area of the circle continues to increase more and more, until finally
author: Einstein, Albert

text: it becomes equal to the total area of the whole " world-sphere."
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Perhaps the reader will wonder why we have placed our " beings " on a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: sphere rather than on another closed surface. But this choice has its
author: Einstein, Albert

text: justification in the fact that, of all closed surfaces, the sphere is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: unique in possessing the property that all points on it are
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equivalent. I admit that the ratio of the circumference c of a circle
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to its radius r depends on r, but for a given value of r it is the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: same for all points of the " worldsphere "; in other words, the "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: world-sphere " is a " surface of constant curvature."
author: Einstein, Albert

text: To this two-dimensional sphere-universe there is a three-dimensional
author: Einstein, Albert

text: analogy, namely, the three-dimensional spherical space which was
author: Einstein, Albert

text: discovered by Riemann. its points are likewise all equivalent. It
author: Einstein, Albert

text: possesses a finite volume, which is determined by its "radius"
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (2p2R3). Is it possible to imagine a spherical space? To imagine a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: space means nothing else than that we imagine an epitome of our "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: space " experience, i.e. of experience that we can have in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: movement of " rigid " bodies. In this sense we can imagine a spherical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: space.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Suppose we draw lines or stretch strings in all directions from a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: point, and mark off from each of these the distance r with a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: measuring-rod. All the free end-points of these lengths lie on a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: spherical surface. We can specially measure up the area (F) of this
author: Einstein, Albert

text: surface by means of a square made up of measuring-rods. If the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: universe is Euclidean, then F = 4pR2 ; if it is spherical, then F is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: always less than 4pR2. With increasing values of r, F increases from
author: Einstein, Albert

text: zero up to a maximum value which is determined by the " world-radius,"
author: Einstein, Albert

text: but for still further increasing values of r, the area gradually
author: Einstein, Albert

text: diminishes to zero. At first, the straight lines which radiate from
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the starting point diverge farther and farther from one another, but
author: Einstein, Albert

text: later they approach each other, and finally they run together again at
author: Einstein, Albert

text: a "counter-point" to the starting point. Under such conditions they
author: Einstein, Albert

text: have traversed the whole spherical space. It is easily seen that the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: three-dimensional spherical space is quite analogous to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: two-dimensional spherical surface. It is finite (i.e. of finite
author: Einstein, Albert

text: volume), and has no bounds.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: It may be mentioned that there is yet another kind of curved space: "
author: Einstein, Albert

text: elliptical space." It can be regarded as a curved space in which the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: two " counter-points " are identical (indistinguishable from each
author: Einstein, Albert

text: other). An elliptical universe can thus be considered to some extent
author: Einstein, Albert

text: as a curved universe possessing central symmetry.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: It follows from what has been said, that closed spaces without limits
author: Einstein, Albert

text: are conceivable. From amongst these, the spherical space (and the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: elliptical) excels in its simplicity, since all points on it are
author: Einstein, Albert

text: equivalent. As a result of this discussion, a most interesting
author: Einstein, Albert

text: question arises for astronomers and physicists, and that is whether
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the universe in which we live is infinite, or whether it is finite in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the manner of the spherical universe. Our experience is far from being
author: Einstein, Albert

text: sufficient to enable us to answer this question. But the general
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory of relativity permits of our answering it with a moduate degree
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of certainty, and in this connection the difficulty mentioned in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Section 30 finds its solution.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE STRUCTURE OF SPACE ACCORDING TO THE GENERAL THEORY OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: According to the general theory of relativity, the geometrical
author: Einstein, Albert

text: properties of space are not independent, but they are determined by
author: Einstein, Albert

text: matter. Thus we can draw conclusions about the geometrical structure
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the universe only if we base our considerations on the state of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: matter as being something that is known. We know from experience that,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: for a suitably chosen co-ordinate system, the velocities of the stars
author: Einstein, Albert

text: are small as compared with the velocity of transmission of light. We
author: Einstein, Albert

text: can thus as a rough approximation arrive at a conclusion as to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: nature of the universe as a whole, if we treat the matter as being at
author: Einstein, Albert

text: rest.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We already know from our previous discussion that the behaviour of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: measuring-rods and clocks is influenced by gravitational fields, i.e.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: by the distribution of matter. This in itself is sufficient to exclude
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the possibility of the exact validity of Euclidean geometry in our
author: Einstein, Albert

text: universe. But it is conceivable that our universe differs only
author: Einstein, Albert

text: slightly from a Euclidean one, and this notion seems all the more
author: Einstein, Albert

text: probable, since calculations show that the metrics of surrounding
author: Einstein, Albert

text: space is influenced only to an exceedingly small extent by masses even
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the magnitude of our sun. We might imagine that, as regards
author: Einstein, Albert

text: geometry, our universe behaves analogously to a surface which is
author: Einstein, Albert

text: irregularly curved in its individual parts, but which nowhere departs
author: Einstein, Albert

text: appreciably from a plane: something like the rippled surface of a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: lake. Such a universe might fittingly be called a quasi-Euclidean
author: Einstein, Albert

text: universe. As regards its space it would be infinite. But calculation
author: Einstein, Albert

text: shows that in a quasi-Euclidean universe the average density of matter
author: Einstein, Albert

text: would necessarily be nil. Thus such a universe could not be inhabited
author: Einstein, Albert

text: by matter everywhere ; it would present to us that unsatisfactory
author: Einstein, Albert

text: picture which we portrayed in Section 30.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: If we are to have in the universe an average density of matter which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: differs from zero, however small may be that difference, then the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: universe cannot be quasi-Euclidean. On the contrary, the results of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: calculation indicate that if matter be distributed uniformly, the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: universe would necessarily be spherical (or elliptical). Since in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: reality the detailed distribution of matter is not uniform, the real
author: Einstein, Albert

text: universe will deviate in individual parts from the spherical, i.e. the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: universe will be quasi-spherical. But it will be necessarily finite.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: In fact, the theory supplies us with a simple connection *  between
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the space-expanse of the universe and the average density of matter in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: it.

text: APPENDIX III
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE EXPERIMENTAL CONFIRMATION OF THE GENERAL THEORY OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: From a systematic theoretical point of view, we may imagine the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: process of evolution of an empirical science to be a continuous
author: Einstein, Albert

text: process of induction. Theories are evolved and are expressed in short
author: Einstein, Albert

text: compass as statements of a large number of individual observations in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the form of empirical laws, from which the general laws can be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ascertained by comparison. Regarded in this way, the development of a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: science bears some resemblance to the compilation of a classified
author: Einstein, Albert

text: catalogue. It is, as it were, a purely empirical enterprise.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: But this point of view by no means embraces the whole of the actual
author: Einstein, Albert

text: process ; for it slurs over the important part played by intuition and
author: Einstein, Albert

text: deductive thought in the development of an exact science. As soon as a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: science has emerged from its initial stages, theoretical advances are
author: Einstein, Albert

text: no longer achieved merely by a process of arrangement. Guided by
author: Einstein, Albert

text: empirical data, the investigator rather develops a system of thought
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which, in general, is built up logically from a small number of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fundamental assumptions, the so-called axioms. We call such a system
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of thought a theory. The theory finds the justification for its
author: Einstein, Albert

text: existence in the fact that it correlates a large number of single
author: Einstein, Albert

text: observations, and it is just here that the " truth " of the theory
author: Einstein, Albert

text: lies.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Corresponding to the same complex of empirical data, there may be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: several theories, which differ from one another to a considerable
author: Einstein, Albert

text: extent. But as regards the deductions from the theories which are
author: Einstein, Albert

text: capable of being tested, the agreement between the theories may be so
author: Einstein, Albert

text: complete that it becomes difficult to find any deductions in which the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: two theories differ from each other. As an example, a case of general
author: Einstein, Albert

text: interest is available in the province of biology, in the Darwinian
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory of the development of species by selection in the struggle for
author: Einstein, Albert

text: existence, and in the theory of development which is based on the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: hypothesis of the hereditary transmission of acquired characters.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: We have another instance of far-reaching agreement between the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: deductions from two theories in Newtonian mechanics on the one hand,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: and the general theory of relativity on the other. This agreement goes
author: Einstein, Albert

text: so far, that up to the preseat we have been able to find only a few
author: Einstein, Albert

text: deductions from the general theory of relativity which are capable of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: investigation, and to which the physics of pre-relativity days does
author: Einstein, Albert

text: not also lead, and this despite the profound difference in the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: fundamental assumptions of the two theories. In what follows, we shall
author: Einstein, Albert

text: again consider these important deductions, and we shall also discuss
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the empirical evidence appertaining to them which has hitherto been
author: Einstein, Albert

text: obtained.

text: (a) Motion of the Perihelion of Mercury
author: Einstein, Albert

text: According to Newtonian mechanics and Newton's law of gravitation, a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: planet which is revolving round the sun would describe an ellipse
author: Einstein, Albert

text: round the latter, or, more correctly, round the common centre of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: gravity of the sun and the planet. In such a system, the sun, or the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: common centre of gravity, lies in one of the foci of the orbital
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ellipse in such a manner that, in the course of a planet-year, the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: distance sun-planet grows from a minimum to a maximum, and then
author: Einstein, Albert

text: decreases again to a minimum. If instead of Newton's law we insert a
author: Einstein, Albert

text: somewhat different law of attraction into the calculation, we find
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that, according to this new law, the motion would still take place in
author: Einstein, Albert

text: such a manner that the distance sun-planet exhibits periodic
author: Einstein, Albert

text: variations; but in this case the angle described by the line joining
author: Einstein, Albert

text: sun and planet during such a period (from perihelion--closest
author: Einstein, Albert

text: proximity to the sun--to perihelion) would differ from 360^0. The line
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the orbit would not then be a closed one but in the course of time
author: Einstein, Albert

text: it would fill up an annular part of the orbital plane, viz. between
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the circle of least and the circle of greatest distance of the planet
author: Einstein, Albert

text: from the sun.
author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert

author: Einstein, Albert
