text: APPENDIX IV
author: Einstein, Albert

text: THE STRUCTURE OF SPACE ACCORDING TO THE GENERAL THEORY OF RELATIVITY
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (SUPPLEMENTARY TO SECTION 32)
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Since the publication of the first edition of this little book, our
author: Einstein, Albert

text: knowledge about the structure of space in the large (" cosmological
author: Einstein, Albert

text: problem ") has had an important development, which ought to be
author: Einstein, Albert

text: mentioned even in a popular presentation of the subject.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: My original considerations on the subject were based on two
author: Einstein, Albert

text: hypotheses:
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (1) There exists an average density of matter in the whole of space
author: Einstein, Albert

text: which is everywhere the same and different from zero.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (2) The magnitude (" radius ") of space is independent of time.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Both these hypotheses proved to be consistent, according to the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: general theory of relativity, but only after a hypothetical term was
author: Einstein, Albert

text: added to the field equations, a term which was not required by the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory as such nor did it seem natural from a theoretical point of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: view (" cosmological term of the field equations ").
author: Einstein, Albert

text: Hypothesis (2) appeared unavoidable to me at the time, since I thought
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that one would get into bottomless speculations if one departed from
author: Einstein, Albert

text: it.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: However, already in the 'twenties, the Russian mathematician Friedman
author: Einstein, Albert

text: showed that a different hypothesis was natural from a purely
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theoretical point of view. He realized that it was possible to
author: Einstein, Albert

text: preserve hypothesis (1) without introducing the less natural
author: Einstein, Albert

text: cosmological term into the field equations of gravitation, if one was
author: Einstein, Albert

text: ready to drop hypothesis (2). Namely, the original field equations
author: Einstein, Albert

text: admit a solution in which the " world radius " depends on time
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (expanding space). In that sense one can say, according to Friedman,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: that the theory demands an expansion of space.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: A few years later Hubble showed, by a special investigation of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: extra-galactic nebulae (" milky ways "), that the spectral lines
author: Einstein, Albert

text: emitted showed a red shift which increased regularly with the distance
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of the nebulae. This can be interpreted in regard to our present
author: Einstein, Albert

text: knowledge only in the sense of Doppler's principle, as an expansive
author: Einstein, Albert

text: motion of the system of stars in the large -- as required, according
author: Einstein, Albert

text: to Friedman, by the field equations of gravitation. Hubble's discovery
author: Einstein, Albert

text: can, therefore, be considered to some extent as a confirmation of the
author: Einstein, Albert

text: theory.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: There does arise, however, a strange difficulty. The interpretation of
author: Einstein, Albert

text: the galactic line-shift discovered by Hubble as an expansion (which
author: Einstein, Albert

text: can hardly be doubted from a theoretical point of view), leads to an
author: Einstein, Albert

text: origin of this expansion which lies " only " about 10^9 years ago,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: while physical astronomy makes it appear likely that the development
author: Einstein, Albert

text: of individual stars and systems of stars takes considerably longer. It
author: Einstein, Albert

text: is in no way known how this incongruity is to be overcome.
author: Einstein, Albert

text: I further want to rernark that the theory of expanding space, together
author: Einstein, Albert

text: with the empirical data of astronomy, permit no decision to be reached
author: Einstein, Albert

text: about the finite or infinite character of (three-dimensional) space,
author: Einstein, Albert

text: while the original " static " hypothesis of space yielded the closure
author: Einstein, Albert

text: (finiteness) of space.

text: Biographical Sketch of Nikola Tesla.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: While a large portion of the European family has been surging westward
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: during the last three or four hundred years, settling the vast
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: continents of America, another, but smaller, portion has been doing
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frontier work in the Old World, protecting the rear by beating back
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the "unspeakable Turk" and reclaiming gradually the fair lands that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: endure the curse of Mohammedan rule. For a long time the Slav
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: people--who, after the battle of Kosovopjolje, in which the Turks
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: defeated the Servians, retired to the confines of the present
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Montenegro, Dalmatia, Herzegovina and Bosnia, and "Borderland" of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Austria--knew what it was to deal, as our Western pioneers did, with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: foes ceaselessly fretting against their frontier; and the races of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: these countries, through their strenuous struggle against the armies
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the Crescent, have developed notable qualities of bravery and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sagacity, while maintaining a patriotism and independence unsurpassed
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in any other nation.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It was in this interesting border region, and from among these valiant
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Eastern folk, that Nikola Tesla was born in the year 1857, and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fact that he, to-day, finds himself in America and one of our foremost
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electricians, is striking evidence of the extraordinary attractiveness
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alike of electrical pursuits and of the country where electricity
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: enjoys its widest application. Mr. Tesla's native place was Smiljan,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Lika, where his father was an eloquent clergyman of the Greek Church,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in which, by the way, his family is still prominently represented. His
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mother enjoyed great fame throughout the countryside for her skill and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: originality in needlework, and doubtless transmitted her ingenuity to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Nikola; though it naturally took another and more masculine direction.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The boy was early put to his books, and upon his father's removal to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Gospic he spent four years in the public school, and later, three
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: years in the Real School, as it is called. His escapades were such as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: most quick witted boys go through, although he varied the programme on
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: one occasion by getting imprisoned in a remote mountain chapel rarely
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: visited for service; and on another occasion by falling headlong into
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a huge kettle of boiling milk, just drawn from the paternal herds. A
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: third curious episode was that connected with his efforts to fly when,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: attempting to navigate the air with the aid of an old umbrella, he
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: had, as might be expected, a very bad fall, and was laid up for six
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: weeks.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: About this period he began to take delight in arithmetic and physics.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: One queer notion he had was to work out everything by three or the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: power of three. He was now sent to an aunt at Cartstatt, Croatia, to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: finish his studies in what is known as the Higher Real School. It was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: there that, coming from the rural fastnesses, he saw a steam engine
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: for the first time with a pleasure that he remembers to this day. At
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Cartstatt he was so diligent as to compress the four years' course
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: into three, and graduated in 1873. Returning home during an epidemic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of cholera, he was stricken down by the disease and suffered so
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: seriously from the consequences that his studies were interrupted for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fully two years. But the time was not wasted, for he had become
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: passionately fond of experimenting, and as much as his means and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: leisure permitted devoted his energies to electrical study and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: investigation. Up to this period it had been his father's intention to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: make a priest of him, and the idea hung over the young physicist like
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a very sword of Damocles. Finally he prevailed upon his worthy but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reluctant sire to send him to Gratz in Austria to finish his studies
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: at the Polytechnic School, and to prepare for work as professor of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mathematics and physics. At Gratz he saw and operated a Gramme machine
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: for the first time, and was so struck with the objections to the use
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of commutators and brushes that he made up his mind there and then to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: remedy that defect in dynamo-electric machines. In the second year of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: his course he abandoned the intention of becoming a teacher and took
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: up the engineering curriculum. After three years of absence he
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: returned home, sadly, to see his father die; but, having resolved to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: settle down in Austria, and recognizing the value of linguistic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: acquirements, he went to Prague and then to Buda-Pesth with the view
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of mastering the languages he deemed necessary. Up to this time he had
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: never realized the enormous sacrifices that his parents had made in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: promoting his education, but he now began to feel the pinch and to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: grow unfamiliar with the image of Francis Joseph I. There was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: considerable lag between his dispatches and the corresponding
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: remittance from home; and when the mathematical expression for the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: value of the lag assumed the shape of an eight laid flat on its back,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Mr. Tesla became a very fair example of high thinking and plain
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: living, but he made up his mind to the struggle and determined to go
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: through depending solely on his own resources. Not desiring the fame
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of a faster, he cast about for a livelihood, and through the help of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: friends he secured a berth as assistant in the engineering department
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the government telegraphs. The salary was five dollars a week. This
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: brought him into direct contact with practical electrical work and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ideas, but it is needless to say that his means did not admit of much
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experimenting. By the time he had extracted several hundred thousand
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: square and cube roots for the public benefit, the limitations,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: financial and otherwise, of the position had become painfully
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: apparent, and he concluded that the best thing to do was to make a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: valuable invention. He proceeded at once to make inventions, but their
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: value was visible only to the eye of faith, and they brought no grist
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to the mill. Just at this time the telephone made its appearance in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Hungary, and the success of that great invention determined his
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: career, hopeless as the profession had thus far seemed to him. He
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: associated himself at once with telephonic work, and made various
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: telephonic inventions, including an operative repeater; but it did not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: take him long to discover that, being so remote from the scenes of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrical activity, he was apt to spend time on aims and results
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: already reached by others, and to lose touch. Longing for new
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: opportunities and anxious for the development of which he felt himself
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: possible, if once he could place himself within the genial and direct
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: influences of the gulf streams of electrical thought, he broke away
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: from the ties and traditions of the past, and in 1881 made his way to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Paris. Arriving in that city, the ardent young Likan obtained
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: employment as an electrical engineer with one of the largest electric
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: lighting companies. The next year he went to Strasburg to install a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: plant, and on returning to Paris sought to carry out a number of ideas
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that had now ripened into inventions. About this time, however, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: remarkable progress of America in electrical industry attracted his
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: attention, and once again staking everything on a single throw, he
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: crossed the Atlantic.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Mr. Tesla buckled down to work as soon as he landed on these shores,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: put his best thought and skill into it, and soon saw openings for his
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: talent. In a short while a proposition was made to him to start his
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: own company, and, accepting the terms, he at once worked up a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: practical system of arc lighting, as well as a potential method of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: dynamo regulation, which in one form is now known as the "third brush
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: regulation." He also devised a thermo-magnetic motor and other kindred
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: devices, about which little was published, owing to legal
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: complications. Early in 1887 the Tesla Electric Company of New York
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: was formed, and not long after that Mr. Tesla produced his admirable
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and epoch-marking motors for multiphase alternating currents, in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which, going back to his ideas of long ago, he evolved machines having
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: neither commutator nor brushes. It will be remembered that about the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: time that Mr. Tesla brought out his motors, and read his thoughtful
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: paper before the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, Professor
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Ferraris, in Europe, published his discovery of principles analogous
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to those enunciated by Mr. Tesla. There is no doubt, however, that Mr.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Tesla was an independent inventor of this rotary field motor, for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: although anticipated in dates by Ferraris, he could not have known
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: about Ferraris' work as it had not been published. Professor Ferraris
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: stated himself, with becoming modesty, that he did not think Tesla
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: could have known of his (Ferraris') experiments at that time, and adds
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that he thinks Tesla was an independent and original inventor of this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: principle. With such an acknowledgment from Ferraris there can be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: little doubt about Tesla's originality in this matter.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Mr. Tesla's work in this field was wonderfully timely, and its worth
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: was promptly appreciated in various quarters. The Tesla patents were
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: acquired by the Westinghouse Electric Company, who undertook to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: develop his motor and to apply it to work of different kinds. Its use
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in mining, and its employment in printing, ventilation, etc., was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: described and illustrated in _The Electrical World_ some years ago.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The immense stimulus that the announcement of Mr. Tesla's work gave to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the study of alternating current motors would, in itself, be enough to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: stamp him as a leader.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Mr. Tesla is only 35 years of age. He is tall and spare with a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: clean-cut, thin, refined face, and eyes that recall all the stories
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: one has read of keenness of vision and phenomenal ability to see
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: through things. He is an omnivorous reader, who never forgets; and he
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: possesses the peculiar facility in languages that enables the least
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: educated native of eastern Europe to talk and write in at least half a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: dozen tongues. A more congenial companion cannot be desired for the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: hours when one "pours out heart affluence in discursive talk," and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when the conversation, dealing at first with things near at hand and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: next to us, reaches out and rises to the greater questions of life,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: duty and destiny.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In the year 1890 he severed his connection with the Westinghouse
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Company, since which time he has devoted himself entirely to the study
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of alternating currents of high frequencies and very high potentials,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with which study he is at present engaged. No comment is necessary on
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: his interesting achievements in this field; the famous London lecture
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: published in this volume is a proof in itself. His first lecture on
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: his researches in this new branch of electricity, which he may be said
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to have created, was delivered before the American Institute of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Electrical Engineers on May 20, 1891, and remains one of the most
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: interesting papers read before that society. It will be found
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reprinted in full in _The Electrical World_, July 11, 1891. Its
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: publication excited such interest abroad that he received numerous
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: requests from English and French electrical engineers and scientists
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to repeat it in those countries, the result of which has been the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: interesting lecture published in this volume.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The present lecture presupposes a knowledge of the former, but it may
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be read and understood by any one even though he has not read the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: earlier one. It forms a sort of continuation of the latter, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: includes chiefly the results of his researches since that time.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: EXPERIMENTS WITH ALTERNATE CURRENTS OF HIGH POTENTIAL AND HIGH FREQUENCY
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I cannot find words to express how deeply I feel the honor of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: addressing some of the foremost thinkers of the present time, and so
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: many able scientific men, engineers and electricians, of the country
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: greatest in scientific achievements.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The results which I have the honor to present before such a gathering
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I cannot call my own. There are among you not a few who can lay better
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: claim than myself on any feature of merit which this work may contain.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I need not mention many names which are world-known--names of those
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: among you who are recognized as the leaders in this enchanting
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: science; but one, at least, I must mention--a name which could not be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: omitted in a demonstration of this kind. It is a name associated with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the most beautiful invention ever made: it is Crookes!
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When I was at college, a good time ago, I read, in a translation (for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: then I was not familiar with your magnificent language), the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: description of his experiments on radiant matter. I read it only once
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in my life--that time--yet every detail about that charming work I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: can remember this day. Few are the books, let me say, which can make
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: such an impression upon the mind of a student.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: But if, on the present occasion, I mention this name as one of many
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: your institution can boast of, it is because I have more than one
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reason to do so. For what I have to tell you and to show you this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: evening concerns, in a large measure, that same vague world which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Professor Crookes has so ably explored; and, more than this, when I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: trace back the mental process which led me to these advances--which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: even by myself cannot be considered trifling, since they are so
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: appreciated by you--I believe that their real origin, that which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: started me to work in this direction, and brought me to them, after a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: long period of constant thought, was that fascinating little book
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which I read many years ago.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: And now that I have made a feeble effort to express my homage and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: acknowledge my indebtedness to him and others among you, I will make a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: second effort, which I hope you will not find so feeble as the first,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to entertain you.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Give me leave to introduce the subject in a few words.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: A short time ago I had the honor to bring before our American
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Institute of Electrical Engineers[A] some results then arrived at by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: me in a novel line of work. I need not assure you that the many
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: evidences which I have received that English scientific men and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: engineers were interested in this work have been for me a great
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reward and encouragement. I will not dwell upon the experiments
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: already described, except with the view of completing, or more clearly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: expressing, some ideas advanced by me before, and also with the view
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of rendering the study here presented self-contained, and my remarks
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: on the subject of this evening's lecture consistent.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Footnote A: For Mr. Tesla's American lecture on this subject see THE
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ELECTRICAL WORLD of July 11, 1891, and for a report of his French
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: lecture see THE ELECTRICAL WORLD of March 26, 1892.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: This investigation, then, it goes without saying, deals with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alternating currents, and, to be more precise, with alternating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: currents of high potential and high frequency. Just in how much a very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: high frequency is essential for the production of the results
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: presented is a question which even with my present experience, would
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: embarrass me to answer. Some of the experiments may be performed with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: low frequencies; but very high frequencies are desirable, not only on
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: account of the many effects secured by their use, but also as a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: convenient means of obtaining, in the induction apparatus employed,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the high potentials, which in their turn are necessary to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: demonstration of most of the experiments here contemplated.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Of the various branches of electrical investigation, perhaps the most
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: interesting and immediately the most promising is that dealing with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alternating currents. The progress in this branch of applied science
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: has been so great in recent years that it justifies the most sanguine
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: hopes. Hardly have we become familiar with one fact, when novel
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiences are met with and new avenues of research are opened. Even
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: at this hour possibilities not dreamed of before are, by the use of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: these currents, partly realized. As in nature all is ebb and tide, all
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is wave motion, so it seems that; in all branches of industry
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alternating currents--electric wave motion--will have the sway.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: One reason, perhaps, why this branch of science is being so rapidly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: developed is to be found in the interest which is attached to its
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experimental study. We wind a simple ring of iron with coils; we
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: establish the connections to the generator, and with wonder and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: delight we note the effects of strange forces which we bring into
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: play, which allow us to transform, to transmit and direct energy at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: will. We arrange the circuits properly, and we see the mass of iron
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and wires behave as though it were endowed with life, spinning a heavy
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: armature, through invisible connections, with great speed and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: power--with the energy possibly conveyed from a great distance. We
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: observe how the energy of an alternating current traversing the wire
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: manifests itself--not so much in the wire as in the surrounding
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: space--in the most surprising manner, taking the forms of heat, light,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mechanical energy, and, most surprising of all, even chemical
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: affinity. All these observations fascinate us, and fill us with an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: intense desire to know more about the nature of these phenomena. Each
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: day we go to our work in the hope of discovering,--in the hope that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: some one, no matter who, may find a solution of one of the pending
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: great problems,--and each succeeding day we return to our task with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: renewed ardor; and even if we _are_ unsuccessful, our work has not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: been in vain, for in these strivings, in these efforts, we have found
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: hours of untold pleasure, and we have directed our energies to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: benefit of mankind.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: We may take--at random, if you choose--any of the many experiments
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which may be performed with alternating currents; a few of which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: only, and by no means the most striking, form the subject of this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: evening's demonstration: they are all equally interesting, equally
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: inciting to thought.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Here is a simple glass tube from which the air has been partially
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exhausted. I take hold of it; I bring my body in contact with a wire
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conveying alternating currents of high potential, and the tube in my
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: hand is brilliantly lighted. In whatever position I may put it,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wherever I may move it in space, as far as I can reach, its soft,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: pleasing light persists with undiminished brightness.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Here is an exhausted bulb suspended from a single wire. Standing on an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulated support. I grasp it, and a platinum button mounted in it is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: brought to vivid incandescence.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Here, attached to a leading wire, is another bulb, which, as I touch
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: its metallic socket, is filled with magnificent colors of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescent light.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Here still another, which by my fingers' touch casts a shadow--the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Crookes shadow, of the stem inside of it.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Here, again, insulated as I stand on this platform, I bring my body in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: contact with one of the terminals of the secondary of this induction
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coil--with the end of a wire many miles long--and you see streams of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: light break forth from its distant end, which is set in violent
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vibration.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Here, once more, I attach these two plates of wire gauze to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: terminals of the coil. I set them a distance apart, and I set the coil
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to work. You may see a small spark pass between the plates. I insert a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thick plate of one of the best dielectrics between them, and instead
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of rendering altogether impossible, as we are used to expect, I _aid_
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the passage of the discharge, which, as I insert the plate, merely
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: changes in appearance and assumes the form of luminous streams.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Is there, I ask, can there be, a more interesting study than that of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alternating currents?
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In all these investigations, in all these experiments, which are so
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: very, very interesting, for many years past--ever since the greatest
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experimenter who lectured in this hall discovered its principle--we
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: have had a steady companion, an appliance familiar to every one, a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: plaything once, a thing of momentous importance now--the induction
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coil. There is no dearer appliance to the electrician. From the ablest
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: among you, I dare say, down to the inexperienced student, to your
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: lecturer, we all have passed many delightful hours in experimenting
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with the induction coil. We have watched its play, and thought and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: pondered over the beautiful phenomena which it disclosed to our
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ravished eyes. So well known is this apparatus, so familiar are these
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phenomena to every one, that my courage nearly fails me when I think
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that I have ventured to address so able an audience, that I have
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ventured to entertain you with that same old subject. Here in reality
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is the same apparatus, and here are the same phenomena, only the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: apparatus is operated somewhat differently, the phenomena are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: presented in a different aspect. Some of the results we find as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: expected, others surprise us, but all captivate our attention, for in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: scientific investigation each novel result achieved may be the centre
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of a new departure, each novel fact learned may lead to important
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: developments.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Usually in operating an induction coil we have set up a vibration of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: moderate frequency in the primary, either by means of an interrupter
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: or break, or by the use of an alternator. Earlier English
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: investigators, to mention only Spottiswoode and J.E.H. Gordon, have
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: used a rapid break in connection with the coil. Our knowledge and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experience of to-day enables us to see clearly why these coils under
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the conditions of the tests did not disclose any remarkable phenomena,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and why able experimenters failed to perceive many of the curious
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: effects which have since been observed.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In the experiments such as performed this evening, we operate the coil
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: either from a specially constructed alternator capable of giving many
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thousands of reversals of current per second, or, by disruptively
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharging a condenser through the primary, we set up a vibration in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the secondary circuit of a frequency of many hundred thousand or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: millions per second, if we so desire; and in using either of these
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: means we enter a field as yet unexplored.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It is impossible to pursue an investigation in any novel line without
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: finally making some interesting observation or learning some useful
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fact. That this statement is applicable to the subject of this lecture
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the many curious and unexpected phenomena which we observe afford a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: convincing proof. By way of illustration, take for instance the most
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: obvious phenomena, those of the discharge of the induction coil.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Here is a coil which is operated by currents vibrating with extreme
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rapidity, obtained by disruptively discharging a Leyden jar. It would
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: not surprise a student were the lecturer to say that the secondary of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this coil consists of a small length of comparatively stout wire; it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would not surprise him were the lecturer to state that, in spite of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this, the coil is capable of giving any potential which the best
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulation of the turns is able to withstand: but although he may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: prepared, and even be indifferent as to the anticipated result, yet
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the aspect of the discharge of the coil will surprise and interest
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: him. Every one is familiar with the discharge of an ordinary coil; it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: need not be reproduced here. But, by way of contrast, here is a form
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of discharge of a coil, the primary current of which is vibrating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: several hundred thousand times per second. The discharge of an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ordinary coil appears as a simple line or band of light. The discharge
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of this coil appears in the form of powerful brushes and luminous
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: streams issuing from all points of the two straight wires attached to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the terminals of the secondary. (Fig. 1.)
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 1.--DISCHARGE BETWEEN TWO WIRES WITH FREQUENCIES
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: OF A FEW HUNDRED THOUSAND PER SECOND.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Now compare this phenomenon which you have just witnessed with the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge of a Holtz or Wimshurst machine--that other interesting
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: appliance so dear to the experimenter. What a difference there is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: between these phenomena! And yet, had I made the necessary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: arrangements--which could have been made easily, were it not that they
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would interfere with other experiments--I could have produced with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this coil sparks which, had I the coil hidden from your view and only
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: two knobs exposed, even the keenest observer among you would find it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: difficult, if not impossible, to distinguish from those of an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: influence or friction machine. This may be done in many ways--for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: instance, by operating the induction coil which charges the condenser
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: from an alternating-current machine of very low frequency, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: preferably adjusting the discharge circuit so that there are no
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: oscillations set up in it. We then obtain in the secondary circuit, if
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the knobs are of the required size and properly set, a more or less
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rapid succession of sparks of great intensity and small quantity,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which possess the same brilliancy, and are accompanied by the same
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sharp crackling sound, as those obtained from a friction or influence
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: machine.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Another way is to pass through two primary circuits, having a common
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: secondary, two currents of a slightly different period, which produce
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in the secondary circuit sparks occurring at comparatively long
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: intervals. But, even with the means at hand this evening, I may
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: succeed in imitating the spark of a Holtz machine. For this purpose I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: establish between the terminals of the coil which charges the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: condenser a long, unsteady arc, which is periodically interrupted by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the upward current of air produced by it. To increase the current of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: air I place on each side of the arc, and close to it, a large plate of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mica. The condenser charged from this coil discharges into the primary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: circuit of a second coil through a small air gap, which is necessary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to produce a sudden rush of current through the primary. The scheme of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: connections in the present experiment is indicated in Fig. 2.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 2.--IMITATING THE SPARK OF A HOLTZ MACHINE.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: G is an ordinarily constructed alternator, supplying the primary P of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: an induction coil, the secondary S of which charges the condensers or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: jars CC. The terminals of the secondary are connected to the inside
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coatings of the jars, the outer coatings being connected to the ends
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the primary pp of a second induction coil. This primary pp has a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small air gap ab.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The secondary s of this coil is provided with knobs or spheres KK of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the proper size and set at a distance suitable for the experiment.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: A long arc is established between the terminals AB of the first
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: induction coil. MM are the mica plates.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Each time the arc is broken between A and B the jars are quickly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: charged and discharged through the primary pp, producing a snapping
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: spark between the knobs KK. Upon the arc forming between A and B the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential falls, and the jars cannot be charged to such high potential
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as to break through the air gap ab until the arc is again broken by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the draught.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In this manner sudden impulses, at long intervals, are produced in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: primary pp, which in the secondary s give a corresponding number of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: impulses of great intensity. If the secondary knobs or spheres, KK,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are of the proper size, the sparks show much resemblance to those of a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Holtz machine.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: But these two effects, which to the eye appear so very different, are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: only two of the many discharge phenomena. We only need to change the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conditions of the test, and again we make other observations of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: interest.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When, instead of operating the induction coil as in the last two
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiments, we operate it from a high frequency alternator, as in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: next experiment, a systematic study of the phenomena is rendered much
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: more easy. In such case, in varying the strength and frequency of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: currents through the primary, we may observe five distinct forms of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge, which I have described in my former paper on the subject[A]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: before the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, May 20, 1891.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Footnote A: See THE ELECTRICAL WORLD, July 11, 1891.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It would take too much time, and it would lead us too far from the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: subject presented this evening, to reproduce all these forms, but it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: seems to me desirable to show you one of them. It is a brush
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge, which is interesting in more than one respect. Viewed from
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a near position it resembles much a jet of gas escaping under great
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: pressure. We know that the phenomenon is due to the agitation of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: molecules near the terminal, and we anticipate that some heat must be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: developed by the impact of the molecules against the terminal or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: against each other. Indeed, we find that the brush is hot, and only a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: little thought leads us to the conclusion that, could we but reach
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sufficiently high frequencies, we could produce a brush which would
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: give intense light and heat, and which would resemble in every
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: particular an ordinary flame, save, perhaps, that both phenomena might
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: not be due to the same agent--save, perhaps, that chemical affinity
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: might not be _electrical_ in its nature.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: As the production of heat and light is here due to the impact of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: molecules, or atoms of air, or something else besides, and, as we can
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: augment the energy simply by raising the potential, we might, even
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with frequencies obtained from a dynamo machine, intensify the action
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to such a degree as to bring the terminal to melting heat. But with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: such low frequencies we would have to deal always with something of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the nature of an electric current. If I approach a conducting object
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to the brush, a thin little spark passes, yet, even with the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequencies used this evening, the tendency to spark is not very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: great. So, for instance, if I hold a metallic sphere at some distance
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: above the terminal you may see the whole space between the terminal
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and sphere illuminated by the streams without the spark passing; and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with the much higher frequencies obtainable by the disruptive
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge of a condenser, were it not for the sudden impulses, which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are comparatively few in number, sparking would not occur even at very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small distances. However, with incomparably higher frequencies, which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: we may yet find means to produce efficiently, and provided that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electric impulses of such high frequencies could be transmitted
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: through a conductor, the electrical characteristics of the brush
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge would completely vanish--no spark would pass, no shock would
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be felt--yet we would still have to deal with an _electric_
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phenomenon, but in the broad, modern interpretation of the word. In my
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: first paper before referred to I have pointed out the curious
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: properties of the brush, and described the best manner of producing
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it, but I have thought it worth while to endeavor to express myself
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: more clearly in regard to this phenomenon, because of its absorbing
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: interest.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When a coil is operated with currents of very high frequency,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: beautiful brush effects may be produced, even if the coil be of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: comparatively small dimensions. The experimenter may vary them in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: many ways, and, if it were nothing else, they afford a pleasing sight.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: What adds to their interest is that they may be produced with one
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: single terminal as well as with two--in fact, often better with one
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: than with two.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: But of all the discharge phenomena observed, the most pleasing to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: eye, and the most instructive, are those observed with a coil which is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: operated by means of the disruptive discharge of a condenser. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: power of the brushes, the abundance of the sparks, when the conditions
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are patiently adjusted, is often amazing. With even a very small coil,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: if it be so well insulated as to stand a difference of potential of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: several thousand volts per turn, the sparks may be so abundant that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the whole coil may appear a complete mass of fire.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Curiously enough the sparks, when the terminals of the coil are set at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a considerable distance, seem to dart in every possible direction as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: though the terminals were perfectly independent of each other. As the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sparks would soon destroy the insulation it is necessary to prevent
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: them. This is best done by immersing the coil in a good liquid
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulator, such as boiled-out oil. Immersion in a liquid may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: considered almost an absolute necessity for the continued and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: successful working of such a coil.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It is of course out of the question, in an experimental lecture, with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: only a few minutes at disposal for the performance of each experiment,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to show these discharge phenomena to advantage, as to produce each
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phenomenon at its best a very careful adjustment is required. But even
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: if imperfectly produced, as they are likely to be this evening, they
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are sufficiently striking to interest an intelligent audience.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Before showing some of these curious effects I must, for the sake of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: completeness, give a short description of the coil and other apparatus
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: used in the experiments with the disruptive discharge this evening.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 3.--DISRUPTIVE DISCHARGE COIL.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It is contained in a box B (Fig. 3) of thick boards of hard wood,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: covered on the outside with zinc sheet Z, which is carefully soldered
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: all around. It might be advisable, in a strictly scientific
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: investigation, when accuracy is of great importance, to do away with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the metal cover, as it might introduce many errors, principally on
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: account of its complex action upon the coil, as a condenser of very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small capacity and as an electrostatic and electromagnetic screen.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When the coil is used for such experiments as are here contemplated,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the employment of the metal cover offers some practical advantages,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: but these are not of sufficient importance to be dwelt upon.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The coil should be placed symmetrically to the metal cover, and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: space between should, of course, not be too small, certainly not less
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: than, say, five centimetres, but much more if possible; especially the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: two sides of the zinc box, which are at right angles to the axis of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the coil, should be sufficiently remote from the latter, as otherwise
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: they might impair its action and be a source of loss.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The coil consists of two spools of hard rubber RR, held apart at a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: distance of 10 centimetres by bolts c and nuts n, likewise of hard
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rubber. Each spool comprises a tube T of approximately 8 centimetres
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: inside diameter, and 3 millimetres thick, upon which are screwed two
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: flanges FF, 24 centimetres square, the space between the flanges being
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: about 3 centimetres. The secondary, SS, of the best gutta
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: percha-covered wire, has 26 layers, 10 turns in each, giving for each
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: half a total of 260 turns. The two halves are wound oppositely and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: connected in series, the connection between both being made over the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: primary. This disposition, besides being convenient, has the advantage
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that when the coil is well balanced--that is, when both of its
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: terminals T_1 T_1 are connected to bodies or devices of equal
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: capacity--there is not much danger of breaking through to the primary,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and the insulation between the primary and the secondary need not be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thick. In using the coil it is advisable to attach to _both_ terminals
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: devices of nearly equal capacity, as, when the capacity of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: terminals is not equal, sparks will be apt to pass to the primary. To
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: avoid this, the middle point of the secondary may be connected to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: primary, but this is not always practicable.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The primary PP is wound in two parts, and oppositely, upon a wooden
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: spool W, and the four ends are led out of the oil through hard rubber
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tubes tt. The ends of the secondary T_1 T_1 are also led out of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: oil through rubber tubes t_1 t_1 of great thickness. The primary and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: secondary layers are insulated by cotton cloth, the thickness of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulation, of course, bearing some proportion to the difference of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential between the turns of the different layers. Each half of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: primary has four layers, 24 turns in each, this giving a total of 96
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: turns. When both the parts are connected in series, this gives a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ratio of conversion of about 1:2.7, and with the primaries in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: multiple, 1:5.4; but in operating with very rapidly alternating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: currents this ratio does not convey even an approximate idea of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ratio of the E.M.Fs. in the primary and secondary circuits. The coil
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is held in position in the oil on wooden supports, there being about 5
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: centimetres thickness of oil all round. Where the oil is not specially
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: needed, the space is filled with pieces of wood, and for this purpose
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: principally the wooden box B surrounding the whole is used.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The construction here shown is, of course, not the best on general
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: principles, but I believe it is a good and convenient one for the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: production of effects in which an excessive potential and a very small
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: current are needed.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In connection with the coil I use either the ordinary form of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharger or a modified form. In the former I have introduced two
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: changes which secure some advantages, and which are obvious. If they
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are mentioned, it is only in the hope that some experimenter may find
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: them of use.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 4.--ARRANGEMENT OF IMPROVED DISCHARGER AND
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: MAGNET.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: One of the changes is that the adjustable knobs A and B (Fig. 4),
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the discharger are held in jaws of brass, JJ, by spring pressure,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this allowing of turning them successively into different positions,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and so doing away with the tedious process of frequent polishing up.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The other change consists in the employment of a strong electromagnet
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: NS, which is placed with its axis at right angles to the line joining
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the knobs A and B, and produces a strong magnetic field between them.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The pole pieces of the magnet are movable and properly formed so as to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: protrude between the brass knobs, in order to make the field as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: intense as possible; but to prevent the discharge from jumping to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: magnet the pole pieces are protected by a layer of mica, MM, of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sufficient thickness. s_1 s_1 and s_2 s_2 are screws for fastening the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wires. On each side one of the screws is for large and the other for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small wires. LL are screws for fixing in position the rods RR, which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: support the knobs.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In another arrangement with the magnet I take the discharge between
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the rounded pole pieces themselves, which in such case are insulated
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and preferably provided with polished brass caps.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The employment of an intense magnetic field is of advantage
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: principally when the induction coil or transformer which charges the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: condenser is operated by currents of very low frequency. In such a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: case the number of the fundamental discharges between the knobs may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: so small as to render the currents produced in the secondary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: unsuitable for many experiments. The intense magnetic field then
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: serves to blow out the arc between the knobs as soon as it is formed,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and the fundamental discharges occur in quicker succession.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Instead of the magnet, a draught or blast of air may be employed with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: some advantage. In this case the arc is preferably established between
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the knobs AB, in Fig. 2 (the knobs ab being generally joined, or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: entirely done away with), as in this disposition the arc is long and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: unsteady, and is easily affected by the draught.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When a magnet is employed to break the arc, it is better to choose
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the connection indicated diagrammatically in Fig. 5, as in this case
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the currents forming the arc are much more powerful, and the magnetic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: field exercises a greater influence. The use of the magnet permits,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: however, of the arc being replaced by a vacuum tube, but I have
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: encountered great difficulties in working with an exhausted tube.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 5.--ARRANGEMENT WITH LOW-FREQUENCY ALTERNATOR AND
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: IMPROVED DISCHARGER.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 6.--DISCHARGER WITH MULTIPLE GAPS.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The other form of discharger used in these and similar experiments is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: indicated in Figs. 6 and 7. It consists of a number of brass pieces cc
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: (Fig. 6), each of which comprises a spherical middle portion m with an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: extension e below--which is merely used to fasten the piece in a lathe
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when polishing up the discharging surface--and a column above, which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: consists of a knurled flange f surmounted by a threaded stem l
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: carrying a nut n, by means of which a wire is fastened to the column.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The flange f conveniently serves for holding the brass piece when
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fastening the wire, and also for turning it in any position when it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: becomes necessary to present a fresh discharging surface. Two stout
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: strips of hard rubber RR, with planed grooves gg (Fig. 7) to fit the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: middle portion of the pieces cc, serve to clamp the latter and hold
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: them firmly in position by means of two bolts CC (of which only one is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: shown) passing through the ends of the strips.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 7.--DISCHARGER WITH MULTIPLE GAPS.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In the use of this kind of discharger I have found three principal
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: advantages over the ordinary form. First, the dielectric strength of a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: given total width of air space is greater when a great many small air
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gaps are used instead of one, which permits of working with a smaller
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: length of air gap, and that means smaller loss and less deterioration
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the metal; secondly by reason of splitting the arc up into smaller
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: arcs, the polished surfaces are made to last much longer; and,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thirdly, the apparatus affords some gauge in the experiments. I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: usually set the pieces by putting between them sheets of uniform
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thickness at a certain very small distance which is known from the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiments of Sir William Thomson to require a certain electromotive
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: force to be bridged by the spark.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It should, of course, be remembered that the sparking distance is much
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: diminished as the frequency is increased. By taking any number of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: spaces the experimenter has a rough idea of the electromotive force,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and he finds it easier to repeat an experiment, as he has not the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: trouble of setting the knobs again and again. With this kind of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharger I have been able to maintain an oscillating motion without
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: any spark being visible with the naked eye between the knobs, and they
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would not show a very appreciable rise in temperature. This form of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge also lends itself to many arrangements of condensers and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: circuits which are often very convenient and time-saving. I have used
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it preferably in a disposition similar to that indicated in Fig. 2,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when the currents forming the arc are small.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I may here mention that I have also used dischargers with single or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: multiple air gaps, in which the discharge surfaces were rotated with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: great speed. No particular advantage was, however, gained by this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: method, except in cases where the currents from the condenser were
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: large and the keeping cool of the surfaces was necessary, and in cases
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when, the discharge not being oscillating of itself, the arc as soon
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as established was broken by the air current, thus starting the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vibration at intervals in rapid succession. I have also used
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mechanical interrupters in many ways. To avoid the difficulties with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frictional contacts, the preferred plan adopted was to establish the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: arc and rotate through it at great speed a rim of mica provided with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: many holes and fastened to a steel plate. It is understood, of course,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that the employment of a magnet, air current, or other interrupter,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: produces no effect worth noticing, unless the self-induction, capacity
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and resistance are so related that there are oscillations set up upon
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: each interruption.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I will now endeavor to show you some of the most noteworthy of these
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge phenomena.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I have stretched across the room two ordinary cotton covered wires,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: each about 7 metres in length. They are supported on insulating cords
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: at a distance of about 30 centimetres. I attach now to each of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: terminals of the coil one of the wires and set the coil in action.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Upon turning the lights off in the room you see the wires strongly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: illuminated by the streams issuing abundantly from their whole surface
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in spite of the cotton covering, which may even be very thick. When
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the experiment is performed under good conditions, the light from the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wires is sufficiently intense to allow distinguishing the objects in a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: room. To produce the best result it is, of course, necessary to adjust
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: carefully the capacity of the jars, the arc between the knobs and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: length of the wires. My experience is that calculation of the length
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the wires leads, in such case, to no result whatever. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experimenter will do best to take the wires at the start very long,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and then adjust by cutting off first long pieces, and then smaller and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: smaller ones as he approaches the right length.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: A convenient way is to use an oil condenser of very small capacity,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: consisting of two small adjustable metal plates, in connection with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this and similar experiments. In such case I take wires rather short
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and set at the beginning the condenser plates at maximum distance. If
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the streams for the wires increase by approach of the plates, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: length of the wires is about right; if they diminish the wires are too
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: long for that frequency and potential. When a condenser is used in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: connection with experiments with such a coil, it should be an oil
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: condenser by all means, as in using an air condenser considerable
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: energy might be wasted. The wires leading to the plates in the oil
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: should be very thin, heavily coated with some insulating compound, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: provided with a conducting covering--this preferably extending under
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the surface of the oil. The conducting cover should not be too near
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the terminals, or ends, of the wire, as a spark would be apt to jump
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: from the wire to it. The conducting coating is used to diminish the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: air losses, in virtue of its action as an electrostatic screen. As to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the size of the vessel containing the oil, and the size of the plates,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the experimenter gains at once an idea from a rough trial. The size of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the plates _in oil_ is, however, calculable, as the dielectric losses
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are very small.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In the preceding experiment it is of considerable interest to know
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: what relation the quantity of the light emitted bears to the frequency
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and potential of the electric impulses. My opinion is that the heat as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: well as light effects produced should be proportionate, under
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: otherwise equal conditions of test, to the product of frequency and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: square of potential, but the experimental verification of the law,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: whatever it may be, would be exceedingly difficult. One thing is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: certain, at any rate, and that is, that in augmenting the potential
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and frequency we rapidly intensify the streams; and, though it may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: very sanguine, it is surely not altogether hopeless to expect that we
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: may succeed in producing a practical illuminant on these lines. We
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would then be simply using burners or flames, in which there would be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: no chemical process, no consumption of material, but merely a transfer
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of energy, and which would, in all probability emit more light and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: less heat than ordinary flames.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 8.--EFFECT PRODUCED BY CONCENTRATING STREAMS.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The luminous intensity of the streams is, of course, considerably
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: increased when they are focused upon a small surface. This may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: shown by the following experiment:
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I attach to one of the terminals of the coil a wire w (Fig. 8), bent
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in a circle of about 30 centimetres in diameter, and to the other
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: terminal I fasten a small brass sphere s, the surface of the wire
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: being preferably equal to the surface of the sphere, and the centre of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the latter being in a line at right angles to the plane of the wire
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: circle and passing through its centre. When the discharge is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: established under proper conditions, a luminous hollow cone is formed,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and in the dark one-half of the brass sphere is strongly illuminated,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as shown in the cut.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: By some artifice or other, it is easy to concentrate the streams upon
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small surfaces and to produce very strong light effects. Two thin
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wires may thus be rendered intensely luminous.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In order to intensify the streams the wires should be very thin and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: short; but as in this case their capacity would be generally too small
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: for the coil--at least, for such a one as the present--it is necessary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to augment the capacity to the required value, while, at the same
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: time, the surface of the wires remains very small. This may be done in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: many ways.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Here, for instance, I have two plates, RR, of hard rubber (Fig. 9),
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: upon which I have glued two very thin wires ww, so as to form a name.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The wires may be bare or covered with the best insulation--it is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: immaterial for the success of the experiment. Well insulated wires, if
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: anything, are preferable. On the back of each plate, indicated by the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: shaded portion, is a tinfoil coating tt. The plates are placed in line
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: at a sufficient distance to prevent a spark passing from one to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: other wire. The two tinfoil coatings I have joined by a conductor C,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and the two wires I presently connect to the terminals of the coil. It
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is now easy, by varying the strength and frequency of the currents
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: through the primary, to find a point at which, the capacity of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: system is best suited to the conditions, and the wires become so
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: strongly luminous that, when the light in the room is turned off the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: name formed by them appears in brilliant letters.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 9.--WIRES RENDERED INTENSELY LUMINOUS.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It is perhaps preferable to perform this experiment with a coil
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: operated from an alternator of high frequency, as then, owing to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: harmonic rise and fall, the streams are very uniform, though they are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: less abundant then when produced with such a coil as the present. This
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiment, however, may be performed with low frequencies, but much
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: less satisfactorily.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 10.--LUMINOUS DISCS.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When two wires, attached to the terminals of the coil, are set at the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: proper distance, the streams between them may be so intense as to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: produce a continuous luminous sheet. To show this phenomenon I have
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: here two circles, C and c (Fig. 10), of rather stout wire, one being
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: about 80 centimetres and the other 30 centimetres in diameter. To each
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the terminals of the coil I attach one of the circles. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: supporting wires are so bent that the circles may be placed in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: same plane, coinciding as nearly as possible. When the light in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: room is turned off and the coil set to work, you see the whole space
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: between the wires uniformly filled with streams, forming a luminous
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: disc, which could be seen from a considerable distance, such is the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: intensity of the streams. The outer circle could have been much larger
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: than the present one; in fact, with this coil I have used much larger
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: circles, and I have been able to produce a strongly luminous sheet,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: covering an area of more than one square metre, which is a remarkable
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: effect with this very small coil. To avoid uncertainty, the circle has
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: been taken smaller, and the area is now about 0.43 square metre.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The frequency of the vibration, and the quickness of succession of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sparks between the knobs, affect to a marked degree the appearance of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the streams. When the frequency is very low, the air gives way in more
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: or less the same manner, as by a steady difference of potential, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the streams consist of distinct threads, generally mingled with thin
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sparks, which probably correspond to the successive discharges
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: occurring between the knobs. But when the frequency is extremely high,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and the arc of the discharge produces a very _loud_ but _smooth_
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sound--showing both that oscillation takes place and that the sparks
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: succeed each other with great rapidity--then the luminous streams
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: formed are perfectly uniform. To reach this result very small coils
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and jars of small capacity should be used. I take two tubes of thick
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Bohemian glass, about 5 centimetres in diameter and 20 centimetres
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: long. In each of the tubes I slip a primary of very thick copper wire.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: On the top of each tube I wind a secondary of much thinner
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gutta-percha covered wire. The two secondaries I connect in series,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the primaries preferably in multiple arc. The tubes are then placed in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a large glass vessel, at a distance of 10 to 15 centimetres from each
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: other, on insulating supports, and the vessel is filled with boiled
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: out oil, the oil reaching about an inch above the tubes. The free ends
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the secondary are lifted out of the oil and placed parallel to each
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: other at a distance of about 10 centimetres. The ends which are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: scraped should be dipped in the oil. Two four-pint jars joined in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: series may be used to discharge through the primary. When the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: necessary adjustments in the length and distance of the wires above
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the oil and in the arc of discharge are made, a luminous sheet is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: produced between the wires which is perfectly smooth and textureless,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: like the ordinary discharge through a moderately exhausted tube.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I have purposely dwelt upon this apparently insignificant experiment.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In trials of this kind the experimenter arrives at the startling
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conclusion that, to pass ordinary luminous discharges through gases,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: no particular degree of exhaustion is needed, but that the gas may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: at ordinary or even greater pressure. To accomplish this, a very high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency is essential; a high potential is likewise required, but
author: Tesla, Nikola
