text: this is a merely incidental necessity. These experiments teach us
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that, in endeavoring to discover novel methods of producing light by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the agitation of atoms, or molecules, of a gas, we need not limit our
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: research to the vacuum tube, but may look forward quite seriously to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the possibility of obtaining the light effects without the use of any
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vessel whatever, with air at ordinary pressure.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Such discharges of very high frequency, which render luminous the air
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: at ordinary pressures, we have probably often occasion to witness in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Nature. I have no doubt that if, as many believe, the aurora borealis
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is produced by sudden cosmic disturbances, such as eruptions at the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sun's surface, which set the electrostatic charge of the earth in an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: extremely rapid vibration, the red glow observed is not confined to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the upper rarefied strata of the air, but the discharge traverses, by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reason of its very high frequency, also the dense atmosphere in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: form of a _glow_, such as we ordinarily produce in a slightly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exhausted tube. If the frequency were very low, or even more so, if
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the charge were not at all vibrating, the dense air would break down
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as in a lightning discharge. Indications of such breaking down of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: lower dense strata of the air have been repeatedly observed at the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: occurrence of this marvelous phenomenon; but if it does occur, it can
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: only be attributed to the fundamental disturbances, which are few in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: number, for the vibration produced by them would be far too rapid to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: allow a disruptive break. It is the original and irregular impulses
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which affect the instruments; the superimposed vibrations probably
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: pass unnoticed.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When an ordinary low frequency discharge is passed through moderately
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rarefied air, the air assumes a purplish hue. If by some means or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: other we increase the intensity of the molecular, or atomic,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vibration, the gas changes to a white color. A similar change occurs
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: at ordinary pressures with electric impulses of very high frequency.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: If the molecules of the air around a wire are moderately agitated, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: brush formed is reddish or violet; if the vibration is rendered
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sufficiently intense, the streams become white. We may accomplish this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in various ways. In the experiment before shown with the two wires
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: across the room, I have endeavored to secure the result by pushing to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a high value both the frequency and potential: in the experiment with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the thin wires glued on the rubber plate I have concentrated the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: action upon a very small surface--in other words, I have worked with a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: great electric density.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: A most curious form of discharge is observed with such a coil when the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency and potential are pushed to the extreme limit. To perform
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the experiment, every part of the coil should be heavily insulated,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and only two small spheres--or, better still, two sharp-edged metal
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discs (dd, Fig. 11) of no more than a few centimetres in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: diameter--should be exposed to the air. The coil here used is immersed
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in oil, and the ends of the secondary reaching out of the oil are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: covered with an air-tight cover of hard rubber of great thickness.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: All cracks, if there are any, should be carefully stopped up, so that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the brush discharge cannot form anywhere except on the small spheres
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: or plates which are exposed to the air. In this case, since there are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: no large plates or other bodies of capacity attached to the terminals,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the coil is capable of an extremely rapid vibration. The potential may
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be raised by increasing, as far as the experimenter judges proper, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rate of change of the primary current. With a coil not widely
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: differing from the present, it is best to connect the two primaries in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: multiple arc; but if the secondary should have a much greater number
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of turns the primaries should preferably be used in series, as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: otherwise the vibration might be too fast for the secondary. It occurs
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: under these conditions that misty white streams break forth from the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: edges of the discs and spread out phantom-like into space. With this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coil, when fairly well produced, they are about 25 to 30 centimetres
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: long. When the hand is held against them no sensation is produced, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a spark, causing a shock, jumps from the terminal only upon the hand
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: being brought much nearer. If the oscillation of the primary current
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is rendered intermittent by some means or other, there is a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: corresponding throbbing of the streams, and now the hand or other
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conducting object may be brought in still greater proximity to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: terminal without a spark being caused to jump.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 11.--PHANTOM STREAMS.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Among the many beautiful phenomena which may be produced with such a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coil I have here selected only those which appear to possess some
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: features of novelty, and lead us to some conclusions of interest. One
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: will not find it at all difficult to produce in the laboratory, by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: means of it, many other phenomena which appeal to the eye even more
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: than these here shown, but present no particular feature of novelty.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Early experimenters describe the display of sparks produced by an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ordinary large induction coil upon an insulating plate separating the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: terminals. Quite recently Siemens performed some experiments in which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fine effects were obtained, which were seen by many with interest. No
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: doubt large coils, even if operated with currents of low frequencies,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are capable of producing beautiful effects. But the largest coil ever
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: made could not, by far, equal the magnificent display of streams and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sparks obtained from such a disruptive discharge coil when properly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: adjusted. To give an idea, a coil such as the present one will cover
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: easily a plate of 1 metre in diameter completely with the streams. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: best way to perform such experiments is to take a very thin rubber or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a glass plate and glue on one side of it a narrow ring of tinfoil of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: very large diameter, and on the other a circular washer, the centre of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the latter coinciding with that of the ring, and the surfaces of both
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: being preferably equal, so as to keep the coil well balanced. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: washer and ring should be connected to the terminals by heavily
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulated thin wires. It is easy in observing the effect of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: capacity to produce a sheet of uniform streams, or a fine network of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thin silvery threads, or a mass of loud brilliant sparks, which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: completely cover the plate.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Since I have advanced the idea of the conversion by means of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: disruptive discharge, in my paper before the American Institute of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Electrical Engineers at the beginning of the past year, the interest
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: excited in it has been considerable. It affords us a means for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: producing any potentials by the aid of inexpensive coils operated from
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ordinary systems of distribution, and--what is perhaps more
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: appreciated--it enables us to convert currents of any frequency into
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: currents of any other lower or higher frequency. But its chief value
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: will perhaps be found in the help which it will afford us in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: investigations of the phenomena of phosphorescence, which a disruptive
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge coil is capable of exciting in innumerable cases where
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ordinary coils, even the largest, would utterly fail.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Considering its probable uses for many practical purposes, and its
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: possible introduction into laboratories for scientific research, a few
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: additional remarks as to the construction of such a coil will perhaps
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: not be found superfluous.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It is, of course, absolutely necessary to employ in such a coil wires
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: provided with the best insulation.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Good coils may be produced by employing wires covered with several
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: layers of cotton, boiling the coil a long time in pure wax, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: cooling under moderate pressure. The advantage of such a coil is that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it can be easily handled, but it cannot probably give as satisfactory
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: results as a coil immersed in pure oil. Besides, it seems that the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: presence of a large body of wax affects the coil disadvantageously,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: whereas this does not seem to be the case with oil. Perhaps it is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: because the dielectric losses in the liquid are smaller.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I have tried at first silk and cotton covered wires with oil
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: immersion, but I have been gradually led to use gutta-percha covered
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wires, which proved most satisfactory. Gutta-percha insulation adds,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of course, to the capacity of the coil, and this, especially if the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coil be large, is a great disadvantage when extreme frequencies are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: desired; but on the other hand, gutta-percha will withstand much more
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: than an equal thickness of oil, and this advantage should be secured
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: at any price. Once the coil has been immersed, it should never be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: taken out of the oil for more than a few hours, else the gutta-percha
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: will crack up and the coil will not be worth half as much as before.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Gutta-percha is probably slowly attacked by the oil, but after an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: immersion of eight to nine months I have found no ill effects.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I have obtained in commerce two kinds of gutta-percha wire: in one the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulation sticks tightly to the metal, in the other it does not.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Unless a special method is followed to expel all air, it is much safer
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to use the first kind. I wind the coil within an oil tank so that all
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: interstices are filled up with the oil. Between the layers I use cloth
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: boiled out thoroughly in oil, calculating the thickness according to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the difference of potential between the turns. There seems not to be a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: very great difference whatever kind of oil is used; I use paraffine or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: linseed oil.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: To exclude more perfectly the air, an excellent way to proceed, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: easily practicable with small coils, is the following: Construct a box
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of hard wood of very thick boards which have been for a long time
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: boiled in oil. The boards should be so joined as to safely withstand
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the external air pressure. The coil being placed and fastened in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: position within the box, the latter is closed with a strong lid, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: covered with closely fitting metal sheets, the joints of which are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: soldered very carefully. On the top two small holes are drilled,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: passing through the metal sheet and the wood, and in these holes two
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small glass tubes are inserted and the joints made air-tight. One of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the tubes is connected to a vacuum pump, and the other with a vessel
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: containing a sufficient quantity of boiled-out oil. The latter tube
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: has a very small hole at the bottom, and is provided with a stopcock.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When a fairly good vacuum has been obtained, the stopcock is opened
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and the oil slowly fed in. Proceeding in this manner, it is impossible
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that any big bubbles, which are the principal danger, should remain
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: between the turns. The air is most completely excluded, probably
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: better than by boiling out, which, however, when gutta-percha coated
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wires are used, is not practicable.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: For the primaries I use ordinary line wire with a thick cotton
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coating. Strands of very thin insulated wires properly interlaced
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would, of course, be the best to employ for the primaries, but they
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are not to be had.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In an experimental coil the size of the wires is not of great
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: importance. In the coil here used the primary is No. 12 and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: secondary No. 24 Brown & Sharpe gauge wire; but the sections may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: varied considerably. It would only imply different adjustments; the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: results aimed at would not be materially affected.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I have dwelt at some length upon the various forms of brush discharge
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: because, in studying them, we not only observe phenomena which please
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: our eye, but also afford us food for thought, and lead us to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conclusions of practical importance. In the use of alternating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: currents of very high tension, too much precaution cannot be taken to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: prevent the brush discharge. In a main conveying such currents, in an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: induction coil or transformer, or in a condenser, the brush discharge
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is a source of great danger to the insulation. In a condenser
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: especially the gaseous matter must be most carefully expelled, for in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it the charged surfaces are near each other, and if the potentials are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: high, just as sure as a weight will fall if let go, so the insulation
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: will give way if a single gaseous bubble of some size be present,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: whereas, if all gaseous matter were carefully excluded, the condenser
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would safely withstand a much higher difference of potential. A main
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conveying alternating currents of very high tension may be injured
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: merely by a blow hole or small crack in the insulation, the more so as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a blowhole is apt to contain gas at low pressure; and as it appears
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: almost impossible to completely obviate such little imperfections, I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: am led to believe that in our future distribution of electrical energy
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: by currents of very high tension liquid insulation will be used. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: cost is a great drawback, but if we employ an oil as an insulator the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: distribution of electrical energy with something like 100,000 volts,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and even more, become, at least with higher frequencies, so easy that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: they could be hardly called engineering feats. With oil insulation
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and alternate current motors transmissions of power can be effected
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with safety and upon an industrial basis at distances of as much as a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thousand miles.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: A peculiar property of oils, and liquid insulation in general, when
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: subjected to rapidly changing electric stresses, is to disperse any
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gaseous bubbles which may be present, and diffuse them through its
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mass, generally long before any injurious break can occur. This
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: feature may be easily observed with an ordinary induction coil by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: taking the primary out, plugging up the end of the tube upon which the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: secondary is wound, and filling it with some fairly transparent
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulator, such as paraffine oil. A primary of a diameter something
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: like six millimetres smaller than the inside of the tube may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: inserted in the oil. When the coil is set to work one may see, looking
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: from the top through the oil, many luminous points--air bubbles which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are caught by inserting the primary, and which are rendered luminous
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in consequence of the violent bombardment. The occluded air, by its
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: impact against the oil, heats it; the oil begins to circulate,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: carrying some of the air along with it, until the bubbles are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: dispersed and the luminous points disappear. In this manner, unless
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: large bubbles are occluded in such way that circulation is rendered
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: impossible, a damaging break is averted, the only effect being a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: moderate warming up of the oil. If, instead of the liquid, a solid
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulation, no matter how thick, were used, a breaking through and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: injury of the apparatus would be inevitable.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The exclusion of gaseous matter from any apparatus in which the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: dielectric is subjected to more or less rapidly changing electric
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: forces is, however, not only desirable in order to avoid a possible
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: injury of the apparatus, but also on account of economy. In a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: condenser, for instance, as long as only a solid or only a liquid
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: dielectric is used, the loss is small; but if a gas under ordinary or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small pressure be present the loss may be very great. Whatever the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: nature of the force acting in the dielectric may be, it seems that in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a solid or liquid the molecular displacement produced by the force is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small; hence the product of force and displacement is insignificant,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: unless the force be very great; but in a gas the displacement, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: therefore this product, is considerable; the molecules are free to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: move, they reach high speeds, and the energy of their impact is lost
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in heat or otherwise. If the gas be strongly compressed, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: displacement due to the force is made smaller, and the losses are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reduced.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In most of the succeeding experiments I prefer, chiefly on account of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the regular and positive action, to employ the alternator before
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: referred to. This is one of the several machines constructed by me for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the purposes of these investigations. It has 384 pole projections, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is capable of giving currents of a frequency of about 10,000 per
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: second. This machine has been illustrated and briefly described in my
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: first paper before the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, May
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: 20, 1891, to which I have already referred. A more detailed
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: description, sufficient to enable any engineer to build a similar
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: machine, will be found in several electrical journals of that period.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The induction coils operated from the machine are rather small,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: containing from 5,000 to 15,000 turns in the secondary. They are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: immersed in boiled-out linseed oil, contained in wooden boxes covered
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with zinc sheet.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I have found it advantageous to reverse the usual position of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wires, and to wind, in these coils, the primaries on the top; this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: allowing the use of a much bigger primary, which, of course, reduces
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the danger of overheating and increases the output of the coil. I make
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the primary on each side at least one centimetre shorter than the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: secondary, to prevent the breaking through on the ends, which would
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: surely occur unless the insulation on the top of the secondary be very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thick, and this, of course, would be disadvantageous.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When the primary is made movable, which is necessary in some
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiments, and many times convenient for the purposes of adjustment,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I cover the secondary with wax, and turn it off in a lathe to a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: diameter slightly smaller than the inside of the primary coil. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: latter I provide with a handle reaching out of the oil, which serves
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to shift it in any position along the secondary.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I will now venture to make, in regard to the general manipulation of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: induction coils, a few observations bearing upon points which have not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: been fully appreciated in earlier experiments with such coils, and are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: even now often overlooked.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The secondary of the coil possesses usually such a high self-induction
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that the current through the wire is inappreciable, and may be so even
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when the terminals are joined by a conductor of small resistance. If
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: capacity is added to the terminals, the self-induction is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: counteracted, and a stronger current is made to flow through the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: secondary, though its terminals are insulated from each other. To one
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: entirely unacquainted with the properties of alternating currents
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: nothing will look more puzzling. This feature was illustrated in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiment performed at the beginning with the top plates of wire
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gauze attached to the terminals and the rubber plate. When the plates
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of wire gauze were close together, and a small arc passed between
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: them, the arc _prevented_ a strong current from passing through the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: secondary, because it did away with the capacity on the terminals;
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when the rubber plate was inserted between, the capacity of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: condenser formed counteracted the self-induction of the secondary, a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: stronger current passed now, the coil performed more work, and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge was by far more powerful.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The first thing, then, in operating the induction coil is to combine
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: capacity with the secondary to overcome the self-induction. If the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequencies and potentials are very high gaseous matter should be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: carefully kept away from the charged surfaces. If Leyden jars are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: used, they should be immersed in oil, as otherwise considerable
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: dissipation may occur if the jars are greatly strained. When high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequencies are used, it is of equal importance to combine a condenser
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with the primary. One may use a condenser connected to the ends of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: primary or to the terminals of the alternator, but the latter is not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to be recommended, as the machine might be injured. The best way is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: undoubtedly to use the condenser in series with the primary and with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the alternator, and to adjust its capacity so as to annul the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: self-induction of both the latter. The condenser should be adjustable
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: by very small steps, and for a finer adjustment a small oil condenser
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with movable plates may be used conveniently.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I think it best at this juncture to bring before you a phenomenon,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: observed by me some time ago, which to the purely scientific
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: investigator may perhaps appear more interesting than any of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: results which I have the privilege to present to you this evening.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It may be quite properly ranked among the brush phenomena--in fact, it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is a brush, formed at, or near, a single terminal in high vacuum.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In bulbs provided with a conducting terminal, though it be of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: aluminium, the brush has but an ephemeral existence, and cannot,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: unfortunately, be indefinitely preserved in its most sensitive state,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: even in a bulb devoid of any conducting electrode. In studying the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phenomenon, by all means a bulb having no leading-in wire should be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: used. I have found it best to use bulbs constructed as indicated in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Figs. 12 and 13.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In Fig. 12 the bulb comprises an incandescent lamp globe L, in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: neck of which is sealed a barometer tube b, the end of which is blown
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: out to form a small sphere s. This sphere should be sealed as closely
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as possible in the centre of the large globe. Before sealing, a thin
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tube t, of aluminium sheet, may be slipped in the barometer tube, but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it is not important to employ it.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The small hollow sphere s is filled with some conducting powder, and a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wire w is cemented in the neck for the purpose of connecting the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conducting powder with the generator.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 12. FIG. 13. BULBS FOR PRODUCING ROTATING BRUSH.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The construction shown in Fig. 13 was chosen in order to remove from
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the brush any conducting body which might possibly affect it. The bulb
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: consists in this case of a lamp globe L, which has a neck n, provided
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with a tube b and small sphere s, sealed to it, so that two entirely
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: independent compartments are formed, as indicated in the drawing. When
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the bulb is in use, the neck n is provided with a tinfoil coating,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which is connected to the generator and acts inductively upon the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: moderately rarefied and highly conducting gas inclosed in the neck.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: From there the current passes through the tube b into the small sphere
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: s to act by induction upon the gas contained in the globe L.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It is of advantage to make the tube t very thick, the hole through it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: very small, and to blow the sphere s very thin. It is of the greatest
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: importance that the sphere s be placed in the centre of the globe L.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 14.--FORMS AND PHASES OF THE ROTATING BRUSH.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Figs. 14, 15 and 16 indicate different forms, or stages, of the brush.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Fig. 14 shows the brush as it first appears in a bulb provided with a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conducting terminal; but, as in such a bulb it very soon
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: disappears--often after a few minutes--I will confine myself to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: description of the phenomenon as seen in a bulb without conducting
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrode. It is observed under the following conditions:
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When the globe L (Figs. 12 and 13) is exhausted to a very high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: degree, generally the bulb is not excited upon connecting the wire w
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: (Fig. 12) or the tinfoil coating of the bulb (Fig. 13) to the terminal
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the induction coil. To excite it, it is usually sufficient to grasp
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the globe L with the hand. An intense phosphorescence then spreads at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: first over the globe, but soon gives place to a white, misty light.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Shortly afterward one may notice that the luminosity is unevenly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: distributed in the globe, and after passing the current for some time
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the bulb appears as in Fig. 15. From this stage the phenomenon will
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gradually pass to that indicated in Fig. 16, after some minutes,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: hours, days or weeks, according as the bulb is worked. Warming the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulb or increasing the potential hastens the transit.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 15. FIG. 16. FORMS AND PHASES OF THE ROTATING
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: BRUSH.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When the brush assumes the form indicated in Fig. 16, it maybe brought
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to a state of extreme sensitiveness to electrostatic and magnetic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: influence. The bulb hanging straight down from a wire, and all objects
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: being remote from it, the approach of the observer at a few paces from
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the bulb will cause the brush to fly to the opposite side, and if he
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: walks around the bulb it will always keep on the opposite side. It may
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: begin to spin around the terminal long before it reaches that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sensitive stage. When it begins to turn around principally, but also
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: before, it is affected by a magnet, and at a certain stage it is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: susceptible to magnetic influence to an astonishing degree. A small
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: permanent magnet, with its poles at a distance of no more than two
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: centimetres, will affect it visibly at a distance of two metres,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: slowing down or accelerating the rotation according to how it is held
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: relatively to the brush. I think I have observed that at the stage
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when it is most sensitive to magnetic, it is not most sensitive to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrostatic, influence. My explanation is, that the electrostatic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: attraction between the brush and the glass of the bulb, which retards
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the rotation, grows much quicker than the magnetic influence when the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: intensity of the stream is increased.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When the bulb hangs with the globe L down, the rotation is always
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: clockwise. In the southern hemisphere it would occur in the opposite
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: direction and on the equator the brush should not turn at all. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rotation may be reversed by a magnet kept at some distance. The brush
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rotates best, seemingly, when it is at right angles to the lines of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: force of the earth. It very likely rotates, when at its maximum speed,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in synchronism with the alternations, say 10,000 times a second. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rotation can be slowed down or accelerated by the approach or receding
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the observer, or any conducting body, but it cannot be reversed by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: putting the bulb in any position. When it is in the state of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: highest sensitiveness and the potential or frequency be varied the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sensitiveness is rapidly diminished. Changing either of these but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: little will generally stop the rotation. The sensitiveness is likewise
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: affected by the variations of temperature. To attain great
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sensitiveness it is necessary to have the small sphere s in the centre
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the globe L, as otherwise the electrostatic action of the glass of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the globe will tend to stop the rotation. The sphere s should be small
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and of uniform thickness; any dissymmetry of course has the effect to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: diminish the sensitiveness.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The fact that the brush rotates in a definite direction in a permanent
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: magnetic field seems to show that in alternating currents of very high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency the positive and negative impulses are not equal, but that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: one always preponderates over the other.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Of course, this rotation in one direction may be due to the action of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: two elements of the same current upon each other, or to the action of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the field produced by one of the elements upon the other, as in a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: series motor, without necessarily one impulse being stronger than the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: other. The fact that the brush turns, as far as I could observe, in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: any position, would speak for this view. In such case it would turn
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: at any point of the earth's surface. But, on the other hand, it is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: then hard to explain why a permanent magnet should reverse the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rotation, and one must assume the preponderance of impulses of one
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: kind.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: As to the causes of the formation of the brush or stream, I think it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is due to the electrostatic action of the globe and the dissymmetry of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the parts. If the small bulb s and the globe L were perfect concentric
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: spheres, and the glass throughout of the same thickness and quality, I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: think the brush would not form, as the tendency to pass would be equal
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: on all sides. That the formation of the stream is due to an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: irregularity is apparent from the fact that it has the tendency to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: remain in one position, and rotation occurs most generally only when
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it is brought out of this position by electrostatic or magnetic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: influence. When in an extremely sensitive state it rests in one
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: position, most curious experiments may be performed with it. For
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: instance, the experimenter may, by selecting a proper position,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: approach the hand at a certain considerable distance to the bulb, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: he may cause the brush to pass off by merely stiffening the muscles of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the arm. When it begins to rotate slowly, and the hands are held at a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: proper distance, it is impossible to make even the slightest motion
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: without producing a visible effect upon the brush. A metal plate
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: connected to the other terminal of the coil affects it at a great
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: distance, slowing down the rotation often to one turn a second.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I am firmly convinced that such a brush, when we learn how to produce
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it properly, will prove a valuable aid in the investigation of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: nature of the forces acting in an electrostatic or magnetic field. If
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: there is any motion which is measurable going on in the space, such a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: brush ought to reveal it. It is, so to speak, a beam of light,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frictionless, devoid of inertia.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I think that it may find practical applications in telegraphy. With
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: such a brush it would be possible to send dispatches across the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Atlantic, for instance, with any speed, since its sensitiveness may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: so great that the slightest changes will affect it. If it were
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: possible to make the stream more intense and very narrow, its
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: deflections could be easily photographed.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I have been interested to find whether there is a rotation of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: stream itself, or whether there is simply a stress traveling around in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the bulb. For this purpose I mounted a light mica fan so that its
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vanes were in the path of the brush. If the stream itself was rotating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the fan would be spun around. I could produce no distinct rotation of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the fan, although I tried the experiment repeatedly; but as the fan
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exerted a noticeable influence on the stream, and the apparent
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rotation of the latter was, in this case, never quite satisfactory,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the experiment did not appear to be conclusive.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I have been unable to produce the phenomenon with the disruptive
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge coil, although every other of these phenomena can be well
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: produced by it--many, in fact, much better than with coils operated
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: from an alternator.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It may be possible to produce the brush by impulses of one direction,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: or even by a steady potential, in which case it would be still more
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sensitive to magnetic influence.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In operating an induction coil with rapidly alternating currents, we
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: realize with astonishment, for the first time, the great importance
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the relation of capacity, self-induction and frequency as regards
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the general result. The effects of capacity are the most striking, for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in these experiments, since the self-induction and frequency both are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: high, the critical capacity is very small, and need be but slightly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: varied to produce a very considerable change. The experimenter may
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bring his body in contact with the terminals of the secondary of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coil, or attach to one or both terminals insulated bodies of very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small bulk, such as bulbs, and he may produce a considerable rise or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fall of potential, and greatly affect the flow of the current through
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the primary. In the experiment before shown, in which a brush appears
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: at a wire attached to one terminal, and the wire is vibrated when the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experimenter brings his insulated body in contact with the other
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: terminal of the coil, the sudden rise of potential was made evident.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I may show you the behavior of the coil in another manner which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: possesses a feature of some interest. I have here a little light fan
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of aluminium sheet, fastened to a needle and arranged to rotate freely
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in a metal piece screwed to one of the terminals of the coil. When the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coil is set to work, the molecules of the air are rhythmically
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: attracted and repelled. As the force with which they are repelled is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: greater than that with which they are attracted, it results that there
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is a repulsion exerted on the surfaces of the fan. If the fan were
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: made simply of a metal sheet, the repulsion would be equal on the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: opposite sides, and would produce no effect. But if one of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: opposing surfaces is screened, or if, generally speaking, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bombardment on this side is weakened in some way or other, there
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: remains the repulsion exerted upon the other, and the fan is set in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rotation. The screening is best effected by fastening upon one of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: opposing sides of the fan insulated conducting coatings, or, if the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fan is made in the shape of an ordinary propeller screw, by fastening
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: on one side, and close to it, an insulated metal plate. The static
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: screen may, however, be omitted, and simply a thickness of insulating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: material fastened to one of the sides of the fan.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: To show the behavior of the coil, the fan may be placed upon the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: terminal and it will readily rotate when the coil is operated by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: currents of very high frequency. With a steady potential, of course,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and even with alternating currents of very low frequency, it would not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: turn, because of the very slow exchange of air and, consequently,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: smaller bombardment; but in the latter case it might turn if the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential were excessive. With a pin wheel, quite the opposite rule
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: holds good; it rotates best with a steady potential, and the effort is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the smaller the higher the frequency. Now, it is very easy to adjust
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the conditions so that the potential is normally not sufficient to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: turn the fan, but that by connecting the other terminal of the coil
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with an insulated body it rises to a much greater value, so as to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rotate the fan, and it is likewise possible to stop the rotation by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: connecting to the terminal a body of different size, thereby
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: diminishing the potential.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Instead of using the fan in this experiment, we may use the "electric"
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: radiometer with similar effect. But in this case it will be found that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the vanes will rotate only at high exhaustion or at ordinary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: pressures; they will not rotate at moderate pressures, when the air is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: highly conducting. This curious observation was made conjointly by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Professor Crookes and myself. I attribute the result to the high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conductivity of the air, the molecules of which then do not act as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: independent carriers of electric charges, but act all together as a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: single conducting body. In such case, of course, if there is any
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: repulsion at all of the molecules from the vanes, it must be very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small. It is possible, however, that the result is in part due to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fact that the greater part of the discharge passes from the leading-in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wire through the highly conducting gas, instead of passing off from
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the conducting vanes.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In trying the preceding experiment with the electric radiometer the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential should not exceed a certain limit, as then the electrostatic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: attraction between the vanes and the glass of the bulb may be so great
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as to stop the rotation.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: A most curious feature of alternate currents of high frequencies and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potentials is that they enable us to perform many experiments by the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: use of one wire only. In many respects this feature is of great
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: interest.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In a type of alternate current motor invented by me some years ago I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: produced rotation by inducing, by means of a single alternating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: current passed through a motor circuit, in the mass or other circuits
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the motor, secondary currents, which, jointly with the primary or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: inducing current, created a moving field of force. A simple but crude
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: form of such a motor is obtained by winding upon an iron core a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: primary, and close to it a secondary coil, joining the ends of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: latter and placing a freely movable metal disc within the influence of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the field produced by both. The iron core is employed for obvious
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reasons, but it is not essential to the operation. To improve the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: motor, the iron core is made to encircle the armature. Again to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: improve, the secondary coil is made to overlap partly the primary, so
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that it cannot free itself from a strong inductive action of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: latter, repel its lines as it may. Once more to improve, the proper
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: difference of phase is obtained between the primary and secondary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: currents by a condenser, self-induction, resistance or equivalent
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: windings.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I had discovered, however, that rotation is produced by means of a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: single coil and core; my explanation of the phenomenon, and leading
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thought in trying the experiment, being that there must be a true time
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: lag in the magnetization of the core. I remember the pleasure I had
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when, in the writings of Professor Ayrton, which came later to my
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: hand, I found the idea of the time lag advocated. Whether there is a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: true time lag, or whether the retardation is due to eddy currents
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: circulating in minute paths, must remain an open question, but the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fact is that a coil wound upon an iron core and traversed by an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alternating current creates a moving field of force, capable of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: setting an armature in rotation. It is of some interest, in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conjunction with the historical Arago experiment, to mention that in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: lag or phase motors I have produced rotation in the opposite direction
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to the moving field, which means that in that experiment the magnet
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: may not rotate, or may even rotate in the opposite direction to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: moving disc. Here, then, is a motor (diagrammatically illustrated in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Fig. 17), comprising a coil and iron core, and a freely movable copper
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: disc in proximity to the latter.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 17.--SINGLE WIRE AND "NO-WIRE" MOTOR.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: To demonstrate a novel and interesting feature, I have, for a reason
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which I will explain, selected this type of motor. When the ends of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the coil are connected to the terminals of an alternator the disc is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: set in rotation. But it is not this experiment, now well known, which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I desire to perform. What I wish to show you is that this motor
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rotates with _one single_ connection between it and the generator;
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that is to say, one terminal of the motor is connected to one terminal
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the generator--in this case the secondary of a high-tension
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: induction coil--the other terminals of motor and generator being
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulated in space. To produce rotation it is generally (but not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: absolutely) necessary to connect the free end of the motor coil to an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulated body of some size. The experimenter's body is more than
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sufficient. If he touches the free terminal with an object held in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: hand, a current passes through the coil and the copper disc is set in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rotation. If an exhausted tube is put in series with the coil, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tube lights brilliantly, showing the passage of a strong current.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Instead of the experimenter's body, a small metal sheet suspended on a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: cord may be used with the same result. In this case the plate acts as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a condenser in series with the coil. It counteracts the self-induction
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the latter and allows a strong current to pass. In such a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: combination, the greater the self-induction of the coil the smaller
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: need be the plate, and this means that a lower frequency, or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: eventually a lower potential, is required to operate the motor. A
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: single coil wound upon a core has a high self-induction; for this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reason principally, this type of motor was chosen to perform the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiment. Were a secondary closed coil wound upon the core, it would
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tend to diminish the self-induction, and then it would be necessary to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: employ a much higher frequency and potential. Neither would be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: advisable, for a higher potential would endanger the insulation of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small primary coil, and a higher frequency would result in a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: materially diminished torque.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It should be remarked that when such a motor with a closed secondary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is used, it is not at all easy to obtain rotation with excessive
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequencies, as the secondary cuts off almost completely the lines of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the primary--and this, of course, the more, the higher the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency--and allows the passage of but a minute current. In such a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: case, unless the secondary is closed through a condenser, it is almost
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: essential, in order to produce rotation, to make the primary and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: secondary coils overlap each other more or less.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: But there is an additional feature of interest about this motor,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: namely, it is not necessary to have even a single connection between
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the motor and generator, except, perhaps, through the ground: for not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: only is an insulated plate capable of giving off energy into space,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: but it is likewise capable of deriving it from an alternating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrostatic field, though in the latter case the available energy is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: much smaller. In this instance one of the motor terminals is connected
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to the insulated plate or body located within the alternating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrostatic field, and the other terminal preferably to the ground.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It is quite possible, however, that such "no-wire" motors, as they
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: might be called, could be operated by conduction through the rarefied
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: air at considerable distances. Alternate currents, especially of high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequencies, pass with astonishing freedom through even slightly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rarefied gases. The upper strata of the air are rarefied. To reach a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: number of miles out into space requires the overcoming of difficulties
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of a merely mechanical nature. There is no doubt that with the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: enormous potentials obtainable by the use of high frequencies and oil
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulation luminous discharges might be passed through many miles of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rarefied air, and that, by thus directing the energy of many hundreds
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: or thousands of horse-power, motors or lamps might be operated at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: considerable distances from stationary sources. But such schemes are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mentioned merely as possibilities. We shall have no need to transmit
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: power in this way. We shall have no need to _transmit_ power at all.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Ere many generations pass, our machinery will be driven by a power
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: obtainable at any point of the universe. This idea is not novel. Men
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: have been led to it long ago by instinct or reason. It has been
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: expressed in many ways, and in many places, in the history of old and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: new. We find it in the delightful myth of Antheus, who derives power
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: from the earth; we find it among the subtile speculations of one of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: your splendid mathematicians, and in many hints and statements of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thinkers of the present time. Throughout space there is energy. Is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this energy static or kinetic? If static our hopes are in vain; if
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: kinetic--and this we know it is, for certain--then it is a mere
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: question of time when men will succeed in attaching their machinery to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the very wheelwork of nature. Of all, living or dead, Crookes came
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: nearest to doing it. His radiometer will turn in the light of day and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in the darkness of the night; it will turn everywhere where there is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: heat, and heat is everywhere. But, unfortunately, this beautiful
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: little machine, while it goes down to posterity as the most
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: interesting, must likewise be put on record as the most inefficient
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: machine ever invented!
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The preceding experiment is only one of many equally interesting
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiments which may be performed by the use of only one wire with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alternate currents of high potential and frequency. We may connect an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulated line to a source of such currents, we may pass an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: inappreciable current over the line, and on any point of the same we
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are able to obtain a heavy current, capable of fusing a thick copper
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wire. Or we may, by the help of some artifice, decompose a solution in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: any electrolytic cell by connecting only one pole of the cell to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: line or source of energy. Or we may, by attaching to the line, or only
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bringing into its vicinity, light up an incandescent lamp, an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exhausted tube, or a phosphorescent bulb.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: However impracticable this plan of working may appear in many cases,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it certainly seems practicable, and even recommendable, in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: production of light. A perfected lamp would require but little energy,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and if wires were used at all we ought to be able to supply that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: energy without a return wire.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It is now a fact that a body may be rendered incandescent or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescent by bringing it either in single contact or merely in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the vicinity of a source of electric impulses of the proper character,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and that in this manner a quantity of light sufficient to afford a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: practical illuminant may be produced. It is, therefore, to say the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: least, worth while to attempt to determine the best conditions and to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: invent the best appliances for attaining this object.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Some experiences have already been gained in this direction, and I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: will dwell on them briefly, in the hope that they might prove useful.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The heating of a conducting body inclosed in a bulb, and connected to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a source of rapidly alternating electric impulses, is dependent on so
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: many things of a different nature, that it would be difficult to give
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a generally applicable rule under which the maximum heating occurs. As
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: regards the size of the vessel, I have lately found that at ordinary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: or only slightly differing atmospheric pressures, when air is a good
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulator, and hence practically the same amount of energy by a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: certain potential and frequency is given off from the body, whether
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the bulb be small or large, the body is brought to a higher
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: temperature if inclosed in a small bulb, because of the better
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: confinement of heat in this case.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: At lower pressures, when air becomes more or less conducting, or if
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the air be sufficiently warmed as to become conducting, the body is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rendered more intensely incandescent in a large bulb, obviously
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: because, under otherwise equal conditions of test, more energy may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: given off from the body when the bulb is large.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: At very high degrees of exhaustion, when the matter in the bulb
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: becomes "radiant," a large bulb has still an advantage, but a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: comparatively slight one, over the small bulb.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Finally, at excessively high degrees of exhaustion, which cannot be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reached except by the employment of special means, there seems to be,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: beyond a certain and rather small size of vessel, no perceptible
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: difference in the heating.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: These observations were the result of a number of experiments, of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which one, showing the effect of the size of the bulb at a high degree
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of exhaustion, may be described and shown here, as it presents a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: feature of interest. Three spherical bulbs of 2 inches, 3 inches and 4
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: inches diameter were taken, and in the centre of each was mounted an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: equal length of an ordinary incandescent lamp filament of uniform
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thickness. In each bulb the piece of filament was fastened to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: leading-in wire of platinum, contained in a glass stem sealed in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulb; care being taken, of course, to make everything as nearly alike
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as possible. On each glass stem in the inside of the bulb was slipped
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a highly polished tube made of aluminium sheet, which fitted the stem
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and was held on it by spring pressure. The function of this aluminium
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tube will be explained subsequently. In each bulb an equal length of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: filament protruded above the metal tube. It is sufficient to say now
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that under these conditions equal lengths of filament of the same
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thickness--in other words, bodies of equal bulk--were brought to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescence. The three bulbs were sealed to a glass tube, which was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: connected to a Sprengel pump. When a high vacuum had been reached, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: glass tube carrying the bulbs was sealed off. A current was then
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: turned on successively on each bulb, and it was found that the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: filaments came to about the same brightness, and, if anything, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: smallest bulb, which was placed midway between the two larger ones,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: may have been slightly brighter. This result was expected, for when
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: either of the bulbs was connected to the coil the luminosity spread
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: through the other two, hence the three bulbs constituted really one
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vessel. When all the three bulbs were connected in multiple arc to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coil, in the largest of them the filament glowed brightest, in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: next smaller it was a little less bright, and in the smallest it only
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: came to redness. The bulbs were then sealed off and separately tried.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The brightness of the filaments was now such as would have been
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: expected on the supposition that the energy given off was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: proportionate to the surface of the bulb, this surface in each case
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: representing one of the coatings of a condenser. Accordingly, time
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: was less difference between the largest and the middle sized than
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: between the latter and the smallest bulb.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: An interesting observation was made in this experiment. The three
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulbs were suspended from a straight bare wire connected to a terminal
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the coil, the largest bulb being placed at the end of the wire, at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: some distance from it the smallest bulb, and an equal distance from
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the latter the middle-sized one. The carbons glowed then in both the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: larger bulbs about as expected, but the smallest did not get its share
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: by far. This observation led me to exchange the position of the bulbs,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and I then observed that whichever of the bulbs was in the middle it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: was by far less bright than it was in any other position. This
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mystifying result was, of course, found to be due to the electrostatic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: action between the bulbs. When they were placed at a considerable
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: distance, or when they were attached to the corners of an equilateral
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: triangle of copper wire, they glowed about in the order determined by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: their surfaces.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: As to the shape of the vessel, it is also of some importance,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: especially at high degrees of exhaustion. Of all the possible
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: constructions, it seems that a spherical globe with the refractory
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: body mounted in its centre is the best to employ. In experience it has
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: been demonstrated that in such a globe a refractory body of a given
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulk is more easily brought to incandescence than when otherwise
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: shaped bulbs are used. There is also an advantage in giving to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescent body the shape of a sphere, for self-evident reasons. In
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: any case the body should be mounted in the centre, where the atoms
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rebounding from the glass collide. This object is best attained in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the spherical bulb; but it is also attained in a cylindrical vessel
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with one or two straight filaments coinciding with its axis, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: possibly also in parabolical or spherical bulbs with the refractory
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: body or bodies placed in the focus or foci of the same; though the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: latter is not probable, as the electrified atoms should in all cases
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rebound normally from the surface they strike, unless the speed were
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: excessive, in which case they _would_ probably follow the general law
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of reflection. No matter what shape the vessel may have, if the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exhaustion be low, a filament mounted in the globe is brought to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: same degree of incandescence in all parts; but if the exhaustion be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: high and the bulb be spherical or pear-shaped, as usual, focal points
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: form and the filament is heated to a higher degree at or near such
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: points.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: To illustrate the effect, I have here two small bulbs which are alike,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: only one is exhausted to a low and the other to a very high degree.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When connected to the coil, the filament in the former glows uniformly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: throughout all its length; whereas in the latter, that portion of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: filament which is in the centre of the bulb glows far more intensely
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: than the rest. A curious point is that the phenomenon occurs even if
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: two filaments are mounted in a bulb, each being connected to one
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: terminal of the coil, and, what is still more curious, if they be very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: near together, provided the vacuum be very high. I noted in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiments with such bulbs that the filaments would give way usually
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: at a certain point, and in the first trials I attributed it to a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: defect in the carbon. But when the phenomenon occurred many times in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: succession I recognized its real cause.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In order to bring a refractory body inclosed in a bulb to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescence, it is desirable, on account of economy, that all the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: energy supplied to the bulb from the source should reach without loss
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the body to be heated; from there, and from nowhere else, it should be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: radiated. It is, of course, out of the question to reach this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: theoretical result, but it is possible by a proper construction of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: illuminating device to approximate it more or less.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: For many reasons, the refractory body is placed in the centre of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulb, and it is usually supported on a glass stem containing the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: leading-in wire. As the potential of this wire is alternated, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rarefied gas surrounding the stem is acted upon inductively, and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: glass stem is violently bombarded and heated. In this manner by far
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the greater portion of the energy supplied to the bulb--especially
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when exceedingly high frequencies are used--may be lost for the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: purpose contemplated. To obviate this loss, or at least to reduce it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to a minimum, I usually screen the rarefied gas surrounding the stem
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: from the inductive action of the leading-in wire by providing the stem
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with a tube or coating of conducting material. It seems beyond doubt
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that the best among metals to employ for this purpose is aluminium, on
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: account of its many remarkable properties. Its only fault is that it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is easily fusible, and, therefore, its distance from the incandescing
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: body should be properly estimated. Usually, a thin tube, of a diameter
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: somewhat smaller than that of the glass stem, is made of the finest
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: aluminium sheet, and slipped on the stem. The tube is conveniently
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: prepared by wrapping around a rod fastened in a lathe a piece of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: aluminium sheet of the proper size, grasping the sheet firmly with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: clean chamois leather or blotting paper, and spinning the rod very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fast. The sheet is wound tightly around the rod, and a highly polished
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tube of one or three layers of the sheet is obtained. When slipped on
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the stem, the pressure is generally sufficient to prevent it from
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: slipping off, but, for safety, the lower edge of the sheet may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: turned inside. The upper inside corner of the sheet--that is, the one
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which is nearest to the refractory incandescent body--should be cut
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: out diagonally, as it often happens that, in consequence of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: intense heat, this corner turns toward the inside and comes very near
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to, or in contact with, the wire, or filament, supporting the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: refractory body. The greater part of the energy supplied to the bulb
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is then used up in heating the metal tube, and the bulb is rendered
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: useless for the purpose. The aluminium sheet should project above the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: glass stem more or less--one inch or so--or else, if the glass be too
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: close to the incandescing body, it may be strongly heated and become
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: more or less conducting, whereupon it may be ruptured, or may, by its
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conductivity, establish a good electrical connection between the metal
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tube and the leading-in wire, in which case, again, most of the energy
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: will be lost in heating the former. Perhaps the best way is to make
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the top of the glass tube, for about an inch, of a much smaller
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: diameter. To still further reduce the danger arising from the heating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the glass stem, and also with the view of preventing an electrical
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: connection between the metal tube and the electrode, I preferably wrap
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the stem with several layers of thin mica, which extends at least as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: far as the metal tube. In some bulbs I have also used an outside
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulating cover.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The preceding remarks are only made to aid the experimenter in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: first trials, for the difficulties which he encounters he may soon
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: find means to overcome in his own way.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: To illustrate the effect of the screen, and the advantage of using it,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I have here two bulbs of the same size, with their stems, leading-in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wires and incandescent lamp filaments tied to the latter, as nearly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alike as possible. The stem of one bulb is provided with an aluminium
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tube, the stem of the other has none. Originally the two bulbs were
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: joined by a tube which was connected to a Sprengel pump. When a high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vacuum had been reached, first the connecting tube, and then the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulbs, were sealed off; they are therefore of the same degree of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exhaustion. When they are separately connected to the coil giving a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: certain potential, the carbon filament in the bulb provided with the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: aluminium screen is rendered highly incandescent, while the filament
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in the other bulb may, with the same potential, not even come to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: redness, although in reality the latter bulb takes generally more
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: energy than the former. When they are both connected together to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: terminal, the difference is even more apparent, showing the importance
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the screening. The metal tube placed on the stem containing the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: leading-in wire performs really two distinct functions: First: it acts
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: more or less as an electrostatic screen, thus economizing the energy
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: supplied to the bulb; and, second, to whatever extent it may fail to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: act electrostatically, it acts mechanically, preventing the
author: Tesla, Nikola
