text: bombardment, and consequently intense heating and possible
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: deterioration of the slender support of the refractory incandescent
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: body, or of the glass stem containing the leading-in wire. I say
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: _slender_ support, for it is evident that in order to confine the heat
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: more completely to the incandescing body its support should be very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thin, so as to carry away the smallest possible amount of heat by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conduction. Of all the supports used I have found an ordinary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescent lamp filament to be the best, principally because among
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conductors it can withstand the highest degrees of heat.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The effectiveness of the metal tube as an electrostatic screen depends
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: largely on the degree of exhaustion.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: At excessively high degrees of exhaustion--which are reached by using
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: great care and special means in connection with the Sprengel
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: pump--when the matter in the globe is in the ultra-radiant state, it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: acts most perfectly. The shadow of the upper edge of the tube is then
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sharply defined upon the bulb.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: At a somewhat lower degree of exhaustion, which is about the ordinary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: "non-striking" vacuum, and generally as long as the matter moves
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: predominantly in straight lines, the screen still does well. In
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: elucidation of the preceding remark it is necessary to state that what
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is a "non-striking" vacuum for a coil operated, as ordinarily, by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: impulses, or currents, of low-frequency, is not, by far, so when the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coil is operated by currents of very high frequency. In such case the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge may pass with great freedom through the rarefied gas through
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which a low-frequency discharge may not pass, even though the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential be much higher. At ordinary atmospheric pressures just the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reverse rule holds good: the higher the frequency, the less the spark
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge is able to jump between the terminals, especially if they
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are knobs or spheres of some size.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Finally, at very low degrees of exhaustion, when the gas is well
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conducting, the metal tube not only does not act as an electrostatic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: screen, but even is a drawback, aiding to a considerable extent the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: dissipation of the energy laterally from the leading-in wire. This, of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: course, is to be expected. In this case, namely, the metal tube is in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: good electrical connection with the leading-in wire, and most of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bombardment is directed upon the tube. As long as the electrical
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: connection is not good, the conducting tube is always of some
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: advantage, for although it may not greatly economize energy, still it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: protects the support of the refractory button, and is a means for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: concentrating more energy upon the same.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: To whatever extent the aluminium tube performs the function of a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: screen, its usefulness is therefore limited to very high degrees of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exhaustion when it is insulated from the electrode--that is, when the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gas as a whole is non-conducting, and the molecules, or atoms, act as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: independent carriers of electric charges.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In addition to acting as a more or less effective screen, in the true
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: meaning of the word, the conducting tube or coating may also act, by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reason of its conductivity, as a sort of equalizer or dampener of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bombardment against the stem. To be explicit, I assume the action as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: follows: Suppose a rhythmical bombardment to occur against the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conducting tube by reason of its imperfect action as a screen, it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: certainly must happen that some molecules, or atoms, strike the tube
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sooner than others. Those which come first in contact with it give up
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: their superfluous charge, and the tube is electrified, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrification instantly spreading over its surface. But this must
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: diminish the energy lost in the bombardment for two reasons: first,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the charge given up by the atoms spreads over a great area, and hence
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the electric density at any point is small, and the atoms are repelled
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with less energy than they would be if they would strike against a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: good insulator: secondly, as the tube is electrified by the atoms
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which first come in contact with it, the progress of the following
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: atoms against the tube is more or less checked by the repulsion which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the electrified tube must exert upon the similarly electrified atoms.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: This repulsion may perhaps be sufficient to prevent a large portion of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the atoms from striking the tube, but at any rate it must diminish the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: energy of their impact. It is clear that when the exhaustion is very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: low, and the rarefied gas well conducting, neither of the above
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: effects can occur, and, on the other hand, the fewer the atoms, with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the greater freedom they move; in other words, the higher the degree
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of exhaustion, up to a limit, the more telling will be both the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: effects.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: What I have just said may afford an explanation of the phenomenon
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: observed by Prof. Crookes, namely, that a discharge through a bulb is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: established with much greater facility when an insulator than when a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conductor is present in the same. In my opinion, the conductor acts as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a dampener of the motion of the atoms in the two ways pointed out;
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: hence, to cause a visible discharge to pass through the bulb, a much
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: higher potential is needed if a conductor, especially of much surface,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be present.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: For the sake of clearness of some of the remarks before made, I must
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: now refer to Figs. 18, 19 and 20, which illustrate various
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: arrangements with a type of bulb most generally used.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 18.--BULB WITH MICA TUBE AND ALUMINIUM SCREEN.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 19.--IMPROVED BULB WITH SOCKET AND SCREEN.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Fig. 18 is a section through a spherical bulb L, with the glass stem
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: s, containing the leading-in wire w; which has a lamp filament l
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fastened to it, serving to support the refractory button m in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: centre. M is a sheet of thin mica wound in several layers around the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: stem s, and a is the aluminium tube.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Fig. 19 illustrates such a bulb in a somewhat more advanced stage of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: perfection. A metallic tube S is fastened by means of some cement to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the neck of the tube. In the tube is screwed a plug P, of insulating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: material, in the centre of which is fastened a metallic terminal t,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: for the connection to the leading-in wire w. This terminal must be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: well insulated from the metal tube S, therefore, if the cement used is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conducting--and most generally it is sufficiently so--the space
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: between the plug P and the neck of the bulb should be filled with some
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: good insulating material, as mica powder.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 20.--BULB FOR EXPERIMENTS WITH CONDUCTING TUBE.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Fig. 20 shows a bulb made for experimental purposes. In this bulb the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: aluminium tube is provided with an external connection, which serves
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to investigate the effect of the tube under various conditions. It is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: referred to chiefly to suggest a line of experiment followed.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Since the bombardment against the stem containing the leading-in wire
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is due to the inductive action of the latter upon the rarefied gas, it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is of advantage to reduce this action as far as practicable by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: employing a very thin wire, surrounded by a very thick insulation of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: glass or other material, and by making the wire passing through the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rarefied gas as short as practicable. To combine these features I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: employ a large tube T (Fig. 21), which protrudes into the bulb to some
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: distance, and carries on the top a very short glass stem s, into which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is sealed the leading-in wire w, and I protect the top of the glass
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: stem against the heat by a small, aluminium tube a and a layer of mica
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: underneath the same, as usual. The wire w, passing through the large
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tube to the outside of the bulb, should be well insulated--with a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: glass tube, for instance--and the space between ought to be filled out
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with some excellent insulator. Among many insulating powders I have
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tried, I have found that mica powder is the best to employ. If this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: precaution is not taken, the tube T, protruding into the bulb, will
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: surely be cracked in consequence of the heating by the brushes which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are apt to form in the upper part of the tube, near the exhausted
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: globe, especially if the vacuum be excellent, and therefore the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential necessary to operate the lamp very high.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Fig. 22 illustrates a similar arrangement, with a large tube T
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: protruding in to the part of the bulb containing the refractors button
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: m. In this case the wire leading from the outside into the bulb is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: omitted, the energy required being supplied through condenser coatings
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: CC. The insulating packing P should in this construction be tightly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fitting to the glass, and rather wide, or otherwise the discharge
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: might avoid passing through the wire w, which connects the inside
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: condenser coating to the incandescent button m. The molecular
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bombardment against the glass stem in the bulb is a source of great
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: trouble. As illustration I will cite a phenomenon only too frequently
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and unwillingly observed. A bulb, preferably a large one, may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: taken, and a good conducting body, such as a piece of carbon, may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mounted in it upon a platinum wire sealed in the glass stem. The bulb
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: may be exhausted to a fairly high degree, nearly to the point when
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescence begins to appear.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 21.--IMPROVED BULB WITH NON-CONDUCTING BUTTON.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 22.--TYPE OF BULB WITHOUT LEADING-IN WIRE.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When the bulb is connected with the coil, the piece of carbon, if
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small, may become highly incandescent at first, but its brightness
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: immediately diminishes, and then the discharge may break through the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: glass somewhere in the middle of the stem, in the form of bright
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sparks, in spite of the fact that the platinum wire is in good
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrical connection with the rarefied gas through the piece of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: carbon or metal at the top. The first sparks are singularly bright,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: recalling those drawn from a clear surface of mercury. But, as they
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: heat the glass rapidly, they, of course, lose their brightness, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: cease when the glass at the ruptured place becomes incandescent, or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: generally sufficiently hot to conduct. When observed for the first
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: time the phenomenon must appear very curious, and shows in a striking
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: manner how radically different alternate currents, or impulses, of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: high frequency behave, as compared with steady currents, or currents
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of low frequency. With such currents--namely, the latter--the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phenomenon would of course not occur. When frequencies such as are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: obtained by mechanical means are used, I think that the rupture of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: glass is more or less the consequence of the bombardment, which warms
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it up and impairs its insulating power; but with frequencies
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: obtainable with condensers I have no doubt that the glass may give way
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: without previous heating. Although this appears most singular at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: first, it is in reality what we might expect to occur. The energy
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: supplied to the wire leading into the bulb is given off partly by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: direct action through the carbon button, and partly by inductive
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: action through the glass surrounding the wire. The case is thus
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: analogous to that in which a condenser shunted by a conductor of low
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: resistance is connected to a source of alternating currents. As long
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as the frequencies are low, the conductor gets the most, and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: condenser is perfectly safe: but when the frequency becomes excessive,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the _role_ of the conductor may become quite insignificant. In the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: latter case the difference of potential at the terminals of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: condenser may become so great as to rupture the dielectric,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: notwithstanding the fact that the terminals are joined by a conductor
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of low resistance.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 23.--EFFECT PRODUCED BY A RUBY DROP.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It is, of course, not necessary, when it is desired to produce the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescence of a body inclosed in a bulb by means of these currents,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that the body should be a conductor, for even a perfect non-conductor
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: may be quite as readily heated. For this purpose it is sufficient to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: surround a conducting electrode with a non-conducting material, as,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: for instance, in the bulb described before in Fig. 21, in which a thin
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescent lamp filament is coated with a non-conductor, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: supports a button of the same material on the top. At the start the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bombardment goes on by inductive action through the non-conductor,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: until the same is sufficiently heated to become conducting, when the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bombardment continues in the ordinary way.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: A different arrangement used in some of the bulbs constructed is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: illustrated in Fig. 23. In this instance a non-conductor m is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mounted in a piece of common arc light carbon so as to project some
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small distance above the latter. The carbon piece is connected to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: leading-in wire passing through a glass stem, which is wrapped with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: several layers of mica. An aluminium tube a is employed as usual for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: screening. It is so arranged that it reaches very nearly as high as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the carbon and only the non-conductor m projects a little above it.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The bombardment goes at first against the upper surface of carbon, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: lower parts being protected by the aluminium tube. As soon, however,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as the non-conductor m is heated it is rendered good conducting, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: then it becomes the centre of the bombardment, being most exposed to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the same.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I have also constructed during these experiments many such single-wire
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulbs with or without internal electrode, in which the radiant matter
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: was projected against, or focused upon, the body to be rendered
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescent. Fig. 24 illustrates one of the bulbs used. It consists
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of a spherical globe L, provided with a long neck n, on the top, for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: increasing the action in some cases by the application of an external
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conducting coating. The globe L is blown out on the bottom into a very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small bulb b, which serves to hold it firmly in a socket S of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulating material into which it is cemented. A fine lamp filament f,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: supported on a wire w, passes through the centre of the globe L. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: filament is rendered incandescent in the middle portion, where the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bombardment proceeding from the lower inside surface of the globe is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: most intense. The lower portion of the globe, as far as the socket S
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reaches, is rendered conducting, either by a tinfoil coating or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: otherwise, and the external electrode is connected to a terminal of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the coil.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The arrangement diagrammatically indicated in Fig. 24 was found to be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: an inferior one when it was desired to render incandescent a filament
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: or button supported in the centre of the globe, but it was convenient
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when the object was to excite phosphorescence.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In many experiments in which bodies of a different kind were mounted
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in the bulb as, for instance, indicated in Fig. 23, some observations
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of interest were made.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It was found, among other things, that in such cases, no matter where
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the bombardment began, just as soon as a high temperature was reached
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: there was generally one of the bodies which seemed to take most of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bombardment upon itself, the other, or others, being thereby relieved.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: This quality appeared to depend principally on the point of fusion,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and on the facility with which the body was "evaporated," or,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: generally speaking, disintegrated--meaning by the latter term not only
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the throwing off of atoms, but likewise of larger lumps. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: observation made was in accordance with generally accepted notions. In
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a highly exhausted bulb electricity is carried off from the electrode
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: by independent carriers, which are partly the atoms, or molecules, of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the residual atmosphere, and partly the atoms, molecules, or lumps
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thrown off from the electrode. If the electrode is composed of bodies
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of different character, and if one of these is more easily
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: disintegrated than the others, most of the electricity supplied is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: carried off from that body, which is then brought to a higher
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: temperature than the others, and this the more, as upon an increase of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the temperature the body is still more easily disintegrated.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It seems to me quite probable that a similar process takes place in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the bulb even with a homogeneous electrode, and I think it to be the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: principal cause of the disintegration. There is bound to be some
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: irregularity, even if the surface is highly polished, which, of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: course, is impossible with most of the refractory bodies employed as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrodes. Assume that a point of the electrode gets hotter,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: instantly most of the discharge passes through that point, and a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: minute patch is probably fused and evaporated. It is now possible that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in consequence of the violent disintegration the spot attacked sinks
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in temperature, or that a counter force is created, as in an arc; at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: any rate, the local tearing off meets with the limitations incident to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the experiment, whereupon the same process occurs on another place. To
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the eye the electrode appears uniformly brilliant, but there are upon
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it points constantly shifting and wandering around, of a temperature
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: far above the mean, and this materially hastens the process of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: deterioration. That some such thing occurs, at least when the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrode is at a lower temperature, sufficient experimental evidence
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: can be obtained in the following manner: Exhaust a bulb to a very high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: degree, so that with a fairly high potential the discharge cannot
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: pass--that is, not a _luminous_ one, for a weak invisible discharge
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: occurs always, in all probability. Now raise slowly and carefully the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential, leaving the primary current on no more than for an instant.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: At a certain point, two, three, or half a dozen phosphorescent spots
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: will appear on the globe. These places of the glass are evidently more
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: violently bombarded than others, this being due to the unevenly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: distributed electric density, necessitated, of course, by sharp
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: projections, or, generally speaking, irregularities of the electrode.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: But the luminous patches are constantly changing in position, which is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: especially well observable if one manages to produce very few, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this indicates that the configuration of the electrode is rapidly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: changing.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: From experiences of this kind I am led to infer that, in order to be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: most durable, the refractory button in the bulb should be in the form
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of a sphere with a highly polished surface. Such a small sphere could
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be manufactured from a diamond or some other crystal, but a better way
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would be to fuse, by the employment of extreme degrees of temperature,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: some oxide--as, for instance, zirconia--into a small drop, and then
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: keep it in the bulb at a temperature somewhat below its point of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fusion.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Interesting and useful results can no doubt be reached in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: direction of extreme degrees of heat. How can such high temperatures
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be arrived at? How are the highest degrees of heat reached in nature?
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: By the impact of stars, by high speeds and collisions. In a collision
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: any rate of heat generation may be attained. In a chemical process we
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are limited. When oxygen and hydrogen combine, they fall,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: metaphorically speaking, from a definite height. We cannot go very far
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with a blast, nor by confining heat in a furnace, but in an exhausted
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulb we can concentrate any amount of energy upon a minute button.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Leaving practicability out of consideration, this, then, would be the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: means which, in my opinion, would enable us to reach the highest
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: temperature. But a great difficulty when proceeding in this way is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: encountered, namely, in most cases the body is carried off before it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: can fuse and form a drop. This difficulty exists principally with an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: oxide such as zirconia, because it cannot be compressed in so hard a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: cake that it would not be carried off quickly. I endeavored repeatedly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to fuse zirconia, placing it in a cup or arc light carbon as indicated
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in Fig. 23. It glowed with a most intense light, and the stream of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: particles projected out of the carbon cup was of a vivid white: but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: whether it was compressed in a cake or made into a paste with carbon,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it was carried off before it could be fused. The carbon cup containing
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the zirconia had to be mounted very low in the neck of a large bulb,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as the heating of the glass by the projected particles of the oxide
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: was so rapid that in the first trial the bulb was cracked almost in an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: instant when the current was turned on. The heating of the glass by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the projected particles was found to be always greater when the carbon
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: cup contained a body which was rapidly carried off--I presume because
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in such cases, with the same potential, higher speeds were reached,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and also because, per unit of time, more matter was projected--that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is, more particles would strike the glass.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The before mentioned difficulty did not exist, however, when the body
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mounted in the carbon cup offered great resistance to deterioration.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: For instance, when an oxide was first fused in an oxygen blast and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: then mounted in the bulb, it melted very readily into a drop.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Generally during the process of fusion magnificent light effects were
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: noted, of which it would be difficult to give an adequate idea. Fig.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: 23 is intended to illustrate the effect observed with a ruby drop. At
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: first one may see a narrow funnel of white light projected against the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: top of the globe, where it produces an irregularly outlined
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescent patch. When the point of the ruby fuses the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescence becomes very powerful; but as the atoms are projected
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with much greater speed from the surface of the drop, soon the glass
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gets hot and "tired," and now only the outer edge of the patch glows.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In this manner an intensely phosphorescent, sharply defined line, _l_,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: corresponding to the outline of the drop, is produced, which spreads
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: slowly over the globe as the drop gets larger. When the mass begins to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: boil, small bubbles and cavities are formed, which cause dark colored
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: spots to sweep across the globe. The bulb may be turned downward
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: without fear of the drop falling off, as the mass possesses
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: considerable viscosity.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I may mention here another feature of some interest, which I believe
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to have noted in the course of these experiments, though the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: observations do not amount to a certitude. It _appeared_ that under
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the molecular impact caused by the rapidly alternating potential the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: body was fused and maintained in that state at a lower temperature in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a highly exhausted bulb than was the case at normal pressure and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: application of heat in the ordinary way--that is, at least, judging
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: from the quantity of the light emitted. One of the experiments
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: performed may be mentioned here by way of illustration. A small piece
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of pumice stone was stuck on a platinum wire, and first melted to it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in a gas burner. The wire was next placed between two pieces of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: charcoal and a burner applied so as to produce an intense heat,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sufficient to melt down the pumice stone into a small glass-like
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: button. The platinum wire had to be taken of sufficient thickness to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: prevent its melting in the fire. While in the charcoal fire, or when
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: held in a burner to get a better idea of the degree of heat, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: button glowed with great brilliancy. The wire with the button was then
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mounted in a bulb, and upon exhausting the same to a high degree, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: current was turned on slowly so as to prevent the cracking of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: button. The button was heated to the point of fusion, and when it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: melted it did not, apparently, glow with the same brilliancy as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: before, and this would indicate a lower temperature. Leaving out of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: consideration the observer's possible, and even probable, error, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: question is, can a body under these conditions be brought from a solid
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to a liquid state with evolution of _less_ light?
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When the potential of a body is rapidly alternated it is certain that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the structure is jarred. When the potential is very high, although the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vibrations may be few--say 20,000 per second--the effect upon the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: structure may be considerable. Suppose, for example, that a ruby is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: melted into a drop by a steady application of energy. When it forms a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: drop it will emit visible and invisible waves, which will be in a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: definite ratio, and to the eye the drop will appear to be of a certain
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: brilliancy. Next, suppose we diminish to any degree we choose the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: energy steadily supplied, and, instead, supply energy which rises and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: falls according to a certain law. Now, when the drop is formed, there
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: will be emitted from it three different kinds of vibrations--the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ordinary visible, and two kinds of invisible waves: that is, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ordinary dark waves of all lengths, and, in addition, waves of a well
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: defined character. The latter would not exist by a steady supply of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the energy; still they help to jar and loosen the structure. If this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: really be the case, then the ruby drop will emit relatively less
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: visible and more invisible waves than before. Thus it would seem that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when a platinum wire, for instance, is fused by currents alternating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with extreme rapidity, it emits at the point of fusion less light and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: more invisible radiation than it does when melted by a steady current,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: though the total energy used up in the process of fusion is the same
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in both cases. Or, to cite another example, a lamp filament is not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: capable of withstanding as long with currents of extreme frequency as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it does with steady currents, assuming that it be worked at the same
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: luminous intensity. This means that for rapidly alternating currents
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the filament should be shorter and thicker. The higher the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency--that is, the greater the departure from the steady
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: flow--the worse it would be for the filament. But if the truth of this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: remark were demonstrated, it would be erroneous to conclude that such
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a refractory button as used in these bulbs would be deteriorated
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: quicker by currents of extremely high frequency than by steady or low
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency currents. From experience I may say that just the opposite
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: holds good: the button withstands the bombardment better with currents
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of very high frequency. But this is due to the fact that a high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency discharge passes through a rarefied gas with much greater
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: freedom than a steady or low frequency discharge, and this will say
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that with the former we can work with a lower potential or with a less
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: violent impact. As long, then, as the gas is of no consequence, a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: steady or low frequency current is better; but as soon as the action
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the gas is desired and important, high frequencies are preferable.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In the course of these experiments a great many trials were made with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: all kinds of carbon buttons. Electrodes made of ordinary carbon
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: buttons were decidedly more durable when the buttons were obtained by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the application of enormous pressure. Electrodes prepared by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: depositing carbon in well known ways did not show up well; they
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: blackened the globe very quickly. From many experiences I conclude
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that lamp filaments obtained in this manner can be advantageously used
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: only with low potentials and low frequency currents. Some kinds of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: carbon withstand so well that, in order to bring them to the point of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fusion, it is necessary to employ very small buttons. In this case the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: observation is rendered very difficult on account of the intense heat
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: produced. Nevertheless there can be no doubt that all kinds of carbon
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are fused under the molecular bombardment, but the liquid state must
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be one of great instability. Of all the bodies tried there were two
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which withstood best--diamond and carborundum. These two showed up
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: about equally, but the latter was preferable, for many reasons. As it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is more than likely that this body is not yet generally known, I will
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: venture to call your attention to it.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It has been recently produced by Mr. E.G. Acheson, of Monongahela
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: City, Pa., U.S.A. It is intended to replace ordinary diamond powder
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: for polishing precious stones, etc., and I have been informed that it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: accomplishes this object quite successfully. I do not know why the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: name "carborundum" has been given to it, unless there is something in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the process of its manufacture which justifies this selection. Through
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the kindness of the inventor, I obtained a short while ago some
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: samples which I desired to test in regard to their qualities of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescence and capability of withstanding high degrees of heat.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Carborundum can be obtained in two forms--in the form of "crystals"
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and of powder. The former appear to the naked eye dark colored, but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are very brilliant; the latter is of nearly the same color as ordinary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: diamond powder, but very much finer. When viewed under a microscope
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the samples of crystals given to me did not appear to have any
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: definite form, but rather resembled pieces of broken up egg coal of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fine quality. The majority were opaque, but there were some which were
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: transparent and colored. The crystals are a kind of carbon containing
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: some impurities; they are extremely hard, and withstand for a long
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: time even an oxygen blast. When the blast is directed against them
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: they at first form a cake of some compactness, probably in consequence
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the fusion of impurities they contain. The mass withstands for a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: very long time the blast without further fusion; but a slow carrying
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: off, or burning, occurs, and, finally, a small quantity of a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: glass-like residue is left, which, I suppose, is melted alumina. When
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: compressed strongly they conduct very well, but not as well as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ordinary carbon. The powder, which is obtained from the crystals in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: some way, is practically non-conducting. It affords a magnificent
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: polishing material for stones.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The time has been too short to make a satisfactory study of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: properties of this product, but enough experience has been gained in a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: few weeks I have experimented upon it to say that it does possess some
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: remarkable properties in many respects. It withstands excessively high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: degrees of heat, it is little deteriorated by molecular bombardment,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and it does not blacken the globe as ordinary carbon does. The only
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: difficulty which I have found in its use in connection with these
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiments was to find some binding material which would resist the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: heat and the effect of the bombardment as successfully as carborundum
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: itself does.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I have here a number of bulbs which I have provided with buttons of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: carborundum. To make such a button of carborundum crystals I proceed
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in the following manner: I take an ordinary lamp filament and dip its
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: point in tar, or some other thick substance or paint which may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: readily carbonized. I next pass the point of the filament through the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: crystals, and then hold it vertically over a hot plate. The tar
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: softens and forms a drop on the point of the filament, the crystals
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: adhering to the surface of the drop. By regulating the distance from
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the plate the tar is slowly dried out and the button becomes solid. I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: then once more dip the button in tar and hold it again over a plate
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: until the tar is evaporated, leaving only a hard mass which firmly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: binds the crystals. When a larger button is required I repeat the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: process several times, and I generally also cover the filament a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: certain distance below the button with crystals. The button being
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mounted in a bulb, when a good vacuum has been reached, first a weak
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and then a strong discharge is passed through the bulb to carbonize
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the tar and expel all gases, and later it is brought to a very intense
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescence.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When the powder is used I have found it best to proceed as follows: I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: make a thick paint of carborundum and tar, and pass a lamp filament
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: through the paint. Taking then most of the paint off by rubbing the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: filament against a piece of chamois leather, I hold it over a hot
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: plate until the tar evaporates and the coating becomes firm. I repeat
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this process as many times as it is necessary to obtain a certain
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thickness of coating. On the point of the coated filament I form a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: button in the same manner.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: There is no doubt that such a button--properly prepared under great
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: pressure--of carborundum, especially of powder of the best quality,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: will withstand the effect of the bombardment fully as well as anything
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: we know. The difficulty is that the binding material gives way, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the carborundum is slowly thrown off after some time. As it does not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: seem to blacken the globe in the least, it might be found useful for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coating the filaments of ordinary incandescent lamps, and I think that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it is even possible to produce thin threads or sticks of carborundum
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which will replace the ordinary filaments in an incandescent lamp. A
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: carborundum coating seems to be more durable than other coatings, not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: only because the carborundum can withstand high degrees of heat, but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: also because it seems to unite with the carbon better than any other
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: material I have tried. A coating of zirconia or any other oxide, for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: instance, is far more quickly destroyed. I prepared buttons of diamond
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: dust in the same manner as of carborundum, and these came in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: durability nearest to those prepared of carborundum, but the binding
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: paste gave way much more quickly in the diamond buttons: this,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: however, I attributed to the size and irregularity of the grains of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the diamond.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It was of interest to find whether carborundum possesses the quality
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of phosphorescence. One is, of course, prepared to encounter two
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: difficulties: first, as regards the rough product, the "crystals,"
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: they are good conducting, and it is a fact that conductors do not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphoresce; second, the powder, being exceedingly fine, would not be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: apt to exhibit very prominently this quality, since we know that when
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: crystals, even such as diamond or ruby, are finely powdered, they lose
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the property of phosphorescence to a considerable degree.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The question presents itself here, can a conductor phosphoresce? What
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is there in such a body as a metal, for instance, that would deprive
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it of the quality of phosphorescence, unless it is that property which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: characterizes it as a conductor? for it is a fact that most of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescent bodies lose that quality when they are sufficiently
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: heated to become more or less conducting. Then, if a metal be in a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: large measure, or perhaps entirely, deprived of that property, it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: should be capable of phosphorescence. Therefore it is quite possible
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that at some extremely high frequency, when behaving practically as a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: non-conductor, a metal or any other conductor might exhibit the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: quality of phosphorescence, even though it be entirely incapable of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescing under the impact of a low-frequency discharge. There
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is, however, another possible way how a conductor might at least
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: _appear_ to phosphoresce.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Considerable doubt still exists as to what really is phosphorescence,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and as to whether the various phenomena comprised under this head are
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: due to the same causes. Suppose that in an exhausted bulb, under the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: molecular impact, the surface of a piece of metal or other conductor
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is rendered strongly luminous, but at the same time it is found that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it remains comparatively cool, would not this luminosity be called
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescence? Now such a result, theoretically at least, is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: possible, for it is a mere question of potential or speed. Assume the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential of the electrode, and consequently the speed of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: projected atoms, to be sufficiently high, the surface of the metal
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: piece against which the atoms are projected would be rendered highly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescent, since the process of heat generation would be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incomparably faster than that of radiating or conducting away from the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: surface of the collision. In the eye of the observer a single impact
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the atoms would cause an instantaneous flash, but if the impacts
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: were repeated with sufficient rapidity they would produce a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: continuous impression upon his retina. To him then the surface of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: metal would appear continuously incandescent and of constant luminous
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: intensity, while in reality the light would be either intermittent or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: at least changing periodically in intensity. The metal piece would
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rise in temperature until equilibrium was attained--that is until the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: energy continuously radiated would equal that intermittently supplied.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: But the supplied energy might under such conditions not be sufficient
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to bring the body to any more than a very moderate mean temperature,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: especially if the frequency of the atomic impacts be very low--just
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: enough that the fluctuation of the intensity of the light emitted
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: could not be detected by the eye. The body would now, owing to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: manner in which the energy is supplied, emit a strong light, and yet
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be at a comparatively very low mean temperature. How could the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: observer call the luminosity thus produced? Even if the analysis of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the light would teach him something definite, still he would probably
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rank it under the phenomena of phosphorescence. It is conceivable that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in such a way both conducting and non-conducting bodies may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: maintained at a certain luminous intensity, but the energy required
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would very greatly vary with the nature and properties of the bodies.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: These and some foregoing remarks of a speculative nature were made
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: merely to bring out curious features of alternate currents or electric
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: impulses. By their help we may cause a body to emit _more_ light,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: while at a certain mean temperature, than it would emit if brought to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that temperature by a steady supply; and, again, we may bring a body
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to the point of fusion, and cause it to emit _less_ light than when
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fused by the application of energy in ordinary ways. It all depends on
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: how we supply the energy, and what kind of vibrations we set up: in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: one case the vibrations are more, in the other less, adapted to affect
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: our sense of vision.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Some effects, which I had not observed before, obtained with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: carborundum in the first trials, I attributed to phosphorescence, but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in subsequent experiments it appeared that it was devoid of that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: quality. The crystals possess a noteworthy feature. In a bulb provided
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with a single electrode in the shape of a small circular metal disc,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: for instance, at a certain degree of exhaustion the electrode is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: covered with a milky film, which is separated by a dark space from the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: glow filling the bulb. When the metal disc is covered with carborundum
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: crystals, the film is far more intense, and snow-white. This I found
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: later to be merely an effect of the bright surface of the crystals,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: for when an aluminium electrode was highly polished it exhibited more
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: or less the same phenomenon. I made a number of experiments with the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: samples of crystals obtained, principally because it would have been
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of special interest to find that they are capable of phosphorescence,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: on account of their being conducting. I could not produce
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescence distinctly, but I must remark that a decisive opinion
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: cannot be formed until other experimenters have gone over the same
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ground.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The powder behaved in some experiments as though it contained alumina,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: but it did not exhibit with sufficient distinctness the red of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: latter. Its dead color brightens considerably under the molecular
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: impact, but I am now convinced it does not phosphoresce. Still, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tests with the powder are not conclusive, because powdered carborundum
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: probably does not behave like a phosphorescent sulphide, for example,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which could be finely powdered without impairing the phosphorescence,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: but rather like powdered ruby or diamond, and therefore it would be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: necessary, in order to make a decisive test, to obtain it in a large
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: lump and polish up the surface.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: If the carborundum proves useful in connection with these and similar
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiments, its chief value will be found in the production of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coatings, thin conductors, buttons, or other electrodes capable of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: withstanding extremely high degrees of heat.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The production of a small electrode capable of withstanding enormous
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: temperatures I regard as of the greatest importance in the manufacture
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of light. It would enable us to obtain, by means of currents of very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: high frequencies, certainly 20 times, if not more, the quantity of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: light which is obtained in the present incandescent lamp by the same
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: expenditure of energy. This estimate may appear to many exaggerated,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: but in reality I think it is far from being so. As this statement
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: might be misunderstood I think it necessary to expose clearly the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: problem with which in this line of work we are confronted, and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: manner in which, in my opinion, a solution will be arrived at.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Any one who begins a study of the problem will be apt to think that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: what is wanted in a lamp with an electrode is a very high degree of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescence of the electrode. There he will be mistaken. The high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescence of the button is a necessary evil, but what is really
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wanted is the high incandescence of the gas surrounding the button. In
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: other words, the problem in such a lamp is to bring a mass of gas to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the highest possible incandescence. The higher the incandescence, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: quicker the mean vibration, the greater is the economy of the light
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: production. But to maintain a mass of gas at a high degree of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescence in a glass vessel, it will always be necessary to keep
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the incandescent mass away from the glass; that is, to confine it as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: much as possible to the central portion of the globe.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In one of the experiments this evening a brush was produced at the end
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of a wire. This brush was a flame, a source of heat and light. It did
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: not emit much perceptible heat, nor did it glow with an intense light;
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: but is it the less a flame because it does not scorch my hand? Is it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the less a flame because it does not hurt my eye by its brilliancy?
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The problem is precisely to produce in the bulb such a flame, much
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: smaller in size, but incomparably more powerful. Were there means at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: hand for producing electric impulses of a sufficiently high frequency,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and for transmitting them, the bulb could be done away with, unless it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: were used to protect the electrode, or to economize the energy by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: confining the heat. But as such means are not at disposal, it becomes
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: necessary to place the terminal in a bulb and rarefy the air in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: same. This is done merely to enable the apparatus to perform the work
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which it is not capable of performing at ordinary air pressure. In the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulb we are able to intensify the action to any degree--so far that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the brush emits a powerful light.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The intensity of the light emitted depends principally on the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency and potential of the impulses, and on the electric density
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the surface of the electrode. It is of the greatest importance to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: employ the smallest possible button, in order to push the density very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: far. Under the violent impact of the molecules of the gas surrounding
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it, the small electrode is of course brought to an extremely high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: temperature, but around it is a mass of highly incandescent gas, a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: flame photosphere, many hundred times the volume of the electrode.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: With a diamond, carborundum or zirconia button the photosphere can be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as much as one thousand times the volume of the button. Without much
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reflecting one would think that in pushing so far the incandescence of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the electrode it would be instantly volatilized. But after a careful
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: consideration he would find that, theoretically, it should not occur,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and in this fact--which, however, is experimentally demonstrated--lies
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: principally the future value of such a lamp.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: At first, when the bombardment begins, most of the work is performed
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: on the surface of the button, but when a highly conducting photosphere
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is formed the button is comparatively relieved. The higher the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescence of the photosphere the more it approaches in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conductivity to that of the electrode, and the more, therefore, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: solid and the gas form one conducting body. The consequence is that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the further is forced the incandescence the more work, comparatively,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is performed on the gas, and the less on the electrode. The formation
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of a powerful photosphere is consequently the very means for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: protecting the electrode. This protection, of course, is a relative
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: one, and it should not be thought that by pushing the incandescence
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: higher the electrode is actually less deteriorated. Still,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: theoretically, with extreme frequencies, this result must be reached,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: but probably at a temperature too high for most of the refractory
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bodies known. Given, then, an electrode which can withstand to a very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: high limit the effect of the bombardment and outward strain, it would
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be safe no matter how much it is forced beyond that limit. In an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescent lamp quite different considerations apply. There the gas
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is not at all concerned: the whole of the work is performed on the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: filament; and the life of the lamp diminishes so rapidly with the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: increase of the degree of incandescence that economical reasons compel
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: us to work it at a low incandescence. But if an incandescent lamp is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: operated with currents of very high frequency, the action of the gas
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: cannot be neglected, and the rules for the most economical working
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: must be considerably modified.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In order to bring such a lamp with one or two electrodes to a great
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: perfection, it is necessary to employ impulses of very high frequency.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The high frequency secures, among others, two chief advantages, which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: have a most important bearing upon the economy of the light
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: production. First, the deterioration of the electrode is reduced by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reason of the fact that we employ a great many small impacts, instead
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of a few violent ones, which shatter quickly the structure; secondly,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the formation of a large photosphere is facilitated.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In order to reduce the deterioration of the electrode to the minimum,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it is desirable that the vibration be harmonic, for any suddenness
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: hastens the process of destruction. An electrode lasts much longer
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when kept at incandescence by currents, or impulses, obtained from a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: high-frequency alternator, which rise and fall more or less
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: harmonically, than by impulses obtained from a disruptive discharge
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coil. In the latter case there is no doubt that most of the damage is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: done by the fundamental sudden discharges.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: One of the elements of loss in such a lamp is the bombardment of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: globe. As the potential is very high, the molecules are projected with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: great speed; they strike the glass, and usually excite a strong
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescence. The effect produced is very pretty, but for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: economical reasons it would be perhaps preferable to prevent, or at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: least reduce to the minimum, the bombardment against the globe, as in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: such case it is, as a rule, not the object to excite phosphorescence,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and as some loss of energy results from the bombardment. This loss in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the bulb is principally dependent on the potential of the impulses and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: on the electric density on the surface of the electrode. In employing
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: very high frequencies the loss of energy by the bombardment is greatly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reduced, for, first, the potential needed to perform a given amount of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: work is much smaller; and, secondly, by producing a highly conducting
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: photosphere around the electrode, the same result is obtained as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: though the electrode were much larger, which is equivalent to a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: smaller electric density. But be it by the diminution of the maximum
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential or of the density, the gain is effected in the same manner,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: namely, by avoiding violent shocks, which strain the glass much beyond
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: its limit of elasticity. If the frequency could be brought high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: enough, the loss due to the imperfect elasticity of the glass would be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: entirely negligible. The loss due to bombardment of the globe may,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: however, be reduced by using two electrodes instead of one. In such
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: case each of the electrodes may be connected to one of the terminals;
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: or else, if it is preferable to use only one wire, one electrode may
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be connected to one terminal and the other to the ground or to an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulated body of some surface, as, for instance, a shade on the lamp.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In the latter case, unless some judgment is used, one of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrodes might glow more intensely than the other.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: But on the whole I find it preferable when using such high frequencies
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to employ only one electrode and one connecting wire. I am convinced
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that the illuminating device of the near future will not require for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: its operation more than one lead, and, at any rate, it will have no
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: leading-in wire, since the energy required can be as well transmitted
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: through the glass. In experimental bulbs the leading-in wire is most
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: generally used on account of convenience, as in employing condenser
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coatings in the manner indicated in Fig. 22, for example, there is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: some difficulty in fitting the parts, but these difficulties would not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exist if a great many bulbs were manufactured; otherwise the energy
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: can be conveyed through the glass as well as through a wire, and with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: these high frequencies the losses are very small. Such illuminating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: devices will necessarily involve the use of very high potentials, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this, in the eyes of practical men, might be an objectionable feature.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Yet, in reality, high potentials are not objectionable--certainly not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in the least as far as the safety of the devices is concerned.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: There are two ways of rendering an electric appliance safe. One is to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: use low potentials, the other is to determine the dimensions of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: apparatus so that it is safe no matter how high a potential is used.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Of the two the latter seems to me the better way, for then the safety
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is absolute, unaffected by any possible combination of circumstances
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which might render even a low-potential appliance dangerous to life
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and property. But the practical conditions require not only the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: judicious determination of the dimensions of the apparatus; they
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: likewise necessitate the employment of energy of the proper kind. It
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is easy, for instance, to construct a transformer capable of giving,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when operated from an ordinary alternate current machine of low
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tension, say 50,000 volts, which might be required to light a highly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exhausted phosphorescent tube, so that, in spite of the high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential, it is perfectly safe, the shock from it producing no
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: inconvenience. Still, such a transformer would be expensive, and in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: itself inefficient; and, besides, what energy was obtained from it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would not be economically used for the production of light. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: economy demands the employment of energy in the form of extremely
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rapid vibrations. The problem of producing light has been likened to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that of maintaining a certain high-pitch note by means of a bell. It
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: should be said a _barely audible_ note; and even these words would not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: express it, so wonderful is the sensitiveness of the eye. We may
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: deliver powerful blows at long intervals, waste a good deal of energy,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and still not get what we want; or we may keep up the note by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: delivering frequent gentle taps, and get nearer to the object sought
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: by the expenditure of much less energy. In the production of light, as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: far as the illuminating device is concerned, there can be only one
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rule--that is, to use as high frequencies as can be obtained; but the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: means for the production and conveyance of impulses of such character
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: impose, at present at least, great limitations. Once it is decided to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: use very high frequencies, the return wire becomes unnecessary, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: all the appliances are simplified. By the use of obvious means the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: same result is obtained as though the return wire were used. It is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sufficient for this purpose to bring in contact with the bulb, or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: merely in the vicinity of the same, an insulated body of some surface.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The surface need, of course, be the smaller, the higher the frequency
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and potential used, and necessarily, also, the higher the economy of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the lamp or other device.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: This plan of working has been resorted to on several occasions this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: evening. So, for instance, when the incandescence of a button was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: produced by grasping the bulb with the hand, the body of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experimenter merely served to intensify the action. The bulb used was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: similar to that illustrated in Fig. 19, and the coil was excited to a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small potential, not sufficient to bring the button to incandescence
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when the bulb was hanging from the wire; and incidentally, in order to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: perform the experiment in a more suitable manner, the button was taken
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: so large that a perceptible time had to elapse before, upon grasping
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the bulb, it could be rendered incandescent. The contact with the bulb
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: was, of course, quite unnecessary. It is easy, by using a rather large
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulb with an exceedingly small electrode, to adjust the conditions so
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that the latter is brought to bright incandescence by the mere
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: approach of the experimenter within a few feet of the bulb, and that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the incandescence subsides upon his receding.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 24.--BULB WITHOUT LEADING-IN WIRE, SHOWING EFFECT
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: OF PROJECTED MATTER.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In another experiment, when phosphorescence was excited, a similar
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulb was used. Here again, originally, the potential was not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sufficient to excite phosphorescence until the action was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: intensified--in this case, however, to present a different feature, by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: touching the socket with a metallic object held in the hand. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrode in the bulb was a carbon button so large that it could not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be brought to incandescence, and thereby spoil the effect produced by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescence.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 25.--IMPROVED EXPERIMENTAL BULB.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Again, in another of the early experiments, a bulb was used as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: illustrated in Fig. 12. In this instance, by touching the bulb with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: one or two fingers, one or two shadows of the stem inside were
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: projected against the glass, the touch of the finger producing the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: same result as the application of an external negative electrode under
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ordinary circumstances.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In all these experiments the action was intensified by augmenting the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: capacity at the end of the lead connected to the terminal. As a rule,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it is not necessary to resort to such means, and would be quite
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: unnecessary with still higher frequencies; but when it _is_ desired,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the bulb, or tube, can be easily adapted to the purpose.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 26.--IMPROVED BULB WITH INTENSIFYING REFLECTOR.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In Fig. 24, for example, an experimental bulb L is shown, which is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: provided with a neck n on the top for the application of an external
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tinfoil coating, which may be connected to a body of larger surface.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Such a lamp as illustrated in Fig. 25 may also be lighted by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: connecting the tinfoil coating on the neck n to the terminal, and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: leading-in wire w to an insulated plate. If the bulb stands in a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: socket upright, as shown in the cut, a shade of conducting material
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: may be slipped in the neck n, and the action thus magnified.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: A more perfected arrangement used in some of these bulbs is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: illustrated in Fig. 26. In this case the construction of the bulb is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as shown and described before, when reference was made to Fig. 19. A
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: zinc sheet Z, with a tubular extension T, is slipped over the metallic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: socket S. The bulb hangs downward from the terminal t, the zinc sheet
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Z, performing the double office of intensifier and reflector. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reflector is separated from the terminal t by an extension of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulating plug P.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 27.--PHOSPHORESCENT TUBE WITH INTENSIFYING
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: REFLECTOR.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: A similar disposition with a phosphorescent tube is illustrated in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Fig. 27. The tube T is prepared from two short tubes of a different
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: diameter, which are sealed on the ends. On the lower end is placed an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: outside conducting coating C, which connects to the wire w. The wire
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: has a hook on the upper end for suspension, and passes through the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: centre of the inside tube, which is filled with some good and tightly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: packed insulator. On the outside of the upper end of the tube T is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: another conducting coating C_1 upon which is slipped a metallic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reflector Z, which should be separated by a thick insulation from the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: end of wire w.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The economical use of such a reflector or intensifier would require
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that all energy supplied to an air condenser should be recoverable,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: or, in other words, that there should not be any losses, neither in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the gaseous medium nor through its action elsewhere. This is far from
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: being so, but, fortunately, the losses may be reduced to anything
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: desired. A few remarks are necessary on this subject, in order to make
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the experiences gathered in the course of these investigations
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: perfectly clear.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Suppose a small helix with many well insulated turns, as in experiment
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Fig. 17, has one of its ends connected to one of the terminals of the
