author: Tesla, Nikola

text: induction coil, and the other to a metal plate, or, for the sake of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: simplicity, a sphere, insulated in space. When the coil is set to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: work, the potential of the sphere is alternated, and the small helix
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: now behaves as though its free end were connected to the other
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: terminal of the induction coil. If an iron rod be held within the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small helix it is quickly brought to a high temperature, indicating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the passage of a strong current through the helix. How does the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulated sphere act in this case? It can be a condenser, storing and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: returning the energy supplied to it, or it can be a mere sink of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: energy, and the conditions of the experiment determine whether it is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: more one or the other. The sphere being charged to a high potential,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it acts inductively upon the surrounding air, or whatever gaseous
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: medium there might be. The molecules, or atoms, which are near the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sphere are of course more attracted, and move through a greater
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: distance than the farther ones. When the nearest molecules strike the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sphere they are repelled, and collisions occur at all distances within
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the inductive action of the sphere. It is now clear that, if the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential be steady, but little loss of energy can be caused in this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: way, for the molecules which are nearest to the sphere, having had an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: additional charge imparted to them by contact, are not attracted until
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: they have parted, if not with all, at least with most of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: additional charge, which can be accomplished only after a great many
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: collisions. From the fact that with a steady potential there is but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: little loss in dry air, one must come to such a conclusion. When the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential of the sphere, instead of being steady, is alternating, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conditions are entirely different. In this case a rhythmical
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bombardment occurs, no matter whether the molecules after coming in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: contact with the sphere lose the imparted charge or not; what is more,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: if the charge is not lost, the impacts are only the more violent.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Still if the frequency of the impulses be very small, the loss caused
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: by the impacts and collisions would not be serious unless the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential were excessive. But when extremely high frequencies and more
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: or less high potentials are used, the loss may be very great. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: total energy lost per unit of time is proportionate to the product of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the number of impacts per second, or the frequency and the energy lost
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in each impact. But the energy of an impact must be proportionate to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the square of the electric density of the sphere, since the charge
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: imparted to the molecule is proportionate to that density. I conclude
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: from this that the total energy lost must be proportionate to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: product of the frequency and the square of the electric density; but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this law needs experimental confirmation. Assuming the preceding
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: considerations to be true, then, by rapidly alternating the potential
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of a body immersed in an insulating gaseous medium, any amount of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: energy may be dissipated into space. Most of that energy then, I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: believe, is not dissipated in the form of long ether waves, propagated
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to considerable distance, as is thought most generally, but is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: consumed--in the case of an insulated sphere, for example--in impact
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and collisional losses--that is, heat vibrations--on the surface and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in the vicinity of the sphere. To reduce the dissipation it is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: necessary to work with a small electric density--the smaller the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: higher the frequency.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: But since, on the assumption before made, the loss is diminished with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the square of the density, and since currents of very high frequencies
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: involve considerable waste when transmitted through conductors, it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: follows that, on the whole, it is better to employ one wire than two.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Therefore, if motors, lamps, or devices of any kind are perfected,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: capable of being advantageously operated by currents of extremely high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency, economical reasons will make it advisable to use only one
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wire, especially if the distances are great.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When energy is absorbed in a condenser the same behaves as though its
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: capacity were increased. Absorption always exists more or less, but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: generally it is small and of no consequence as long as the frequencies
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are not very great. In using extremely high frequencies, and,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: necessarily in such case, also high potentials, the absorption--or,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: what is here meant more particularly by this term, the loss of energy
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: due to the presence of a gaseous medium--is an important factor to be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: considered, as the energy absorbed in the air condenser may be any
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fraction of the supplied energy. This would seem to make it very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: difficult to tell from the measured or computed capacity of an air
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: condenser its actual capacity or vibration period, especially if the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: condenser is of very small surface and is charged to a very high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential. As many important results are dependent upon the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: correctness of the estimation of the vibration period, this subject
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: demands the most careful scrutiny of other investigators. To reduce
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the probable error as much as possible in experiments of the kind
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alluded to, it is advisable to use spheres or plates of large surface,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: so as to make the density exceedingly small. Otherwise, when it is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: practicable, an oil condenser should be used in preference. In oil or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: other liquid dielectrics there are seemingly no such losses as in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gaseous media. It being impossible to exclude entirely the gas in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: condensers with solid dielectrics, such condensers should be immersed
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in oil, for economical reasons if nothing else; they can then be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: strained to the utmost and will remain cool. In Leyden jars the loss
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: due to air is comparatively small, as the tinfoil coatings are large,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: close together, and the charged surfaces not directly exposed; but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when the potentials are very high, the loss may be more or less
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: considerable at, or near, the upper edge of the foil, where the air is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: principally acted upon. If the jar be immersed in boiled-out oil, it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: will be capable of performing four times the amount of work which it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: can for any length of time when used in the ordinary way, and the loss
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: will be inappreciable.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It should not be thought that the loss in heat in an air condenser is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: necessarily associated with the formation of _visible_ streams or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: brushes. If a small electrode, inclosed in an unexhausted bulb, is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: connected to one of the terminals of the coil, streams can be seen to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: issue from the electrode and the air in the bulb is heated; if,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: instead of a small electrode, a large sphere is inclosed in the bulb,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: no streams are observed, still the air is heated.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Nor should it be thought that the temperature of an air condenser
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would give even an approximate idea of the loss in heat incurred, as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in such case heat must be given off much more quickly, since there is,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in addition to the ordinary radiation, a very active carrying away of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: heat by independent carriers going on, and since not only the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: apparatus, but the air at some distance from it is heated in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: consequence of the collisions which must occur.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Owing to this, in experiments with such a coil, a rise of temperature
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: can be distinctly observed only when the body connected to the coil is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: very small. But with apparatus on a larger scale, even a body of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: considerable bulk would be heated, as, for instance, the body of a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: person; and I think that skilled physicians might make observations of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: utility in such experiments, which, if the apparatus were judiciously
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: designed, would not present the slightest danger.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: A question of some interest, principally to meteorologists, presents
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: itself here. How does the earth behave? The earth is an air condenser,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: but is it a perfect or a very imperfect one--a mere sink of energy?
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: There can be little doubt that to such small disturbance as might be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: caused in an experiment the earth behaves as an almost perfect
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: condenser. But it might be different when its charge is set in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vibration by some sudden disturbance occurring in the heavens. In such
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: case, as before stated, probably only little of the energy of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vibrations set up would be lost into space in the form of long ether
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: radiations, but most of the energy, I think, would spend itself in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: molecular impacts and collisions, and pass off into space in the form
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of short heat, and possibly light, waves. As both the frequency of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vibrations of the charge and the potential are in all probability
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: excessive, the energy converted into heat may be considerable. Since
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the density must be unevenly distributed, either in consequence of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: irregularity of the earth's surface, or on account of the condition of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the atmosphere in various places, the effect produced would
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: accordingly vary from place to place. Considerable variations in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: temperature and pressure of the atmosphere may in this manner be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: caused at any point of the surface of the earth. The variations may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gradual or very sudden, according to the nature of the general
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: disturbance, and may produce rain and storms, or locally modify the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: weather in any way.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: From the remarks before made one may see what an important factor of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: loss the air in the neighborhood of a charged surface becomes when the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electric density is great and the frequency of the impulses excessive.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: But the action as explained implies that the air is insulating--that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is, that it is composed of independent carriers immersed in an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulating medium. This is the case only when the air is at something
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: like ordinary or greater, or at extremely small, pressure. When the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: air is slightly rarefied and conducting, then true conduction losses
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: occur also. In such case, of course, considerable energy may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: dissipated into space even with a steady potential, or with impulses
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of low frequency, if the density is very great.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When the gas is at very low pressure, an electrode is heated more
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: because higher speeds can be reached. If the gas around the electrode
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is strongly compressed, the displacements, and consequently the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: speeds, are very small, and the heating is insignificant. But if in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: such case the frequency could be sufficiently increased, the electrode
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would be brought to a high temperature as well as if the gas were at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: very low pressure; in fact, exhausting the bulb is only necessary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: because we cannot produce (and possibly not convey) currents of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: required frequency.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Returning to the subject of electrode lamps, it is obviously of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: advantage in such a lamp to confine as much as possible the heat to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the electrode by preventing the circulation of the gas in the bulb. If
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a very small bulb be taken, it would confine the heat better than a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: large one, but it might not be of sufficient capacity to be operated
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: from the coil, or, if so, the glass might get too hot. A simple way to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: improve in this direction is to employ a globe of the required size,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: but to place a small bulb, the diameter of which is properly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: estimated, over the refractory button contained in the globe. This
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: arrangement is illustrated in Fig. 28.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 28.--LAMP WITH AUXILIARY BULB FOR CONFINING THE
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ACTION TO THE CENTRE.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The globe L has in this case a large neck n, allowing the small bulb b
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to slip through. Otherwise the construction is the same as shown in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Fig. 18, for example. The small bulb is conveniently supported upon
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the stem s, carrying the refractory button m. It is separated from the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: aluminium tube a by several layers of mica M, in order to prevent the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: cracking of the neck by the rapid heating of the aluminium tube upon a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sudden turning on of the current. The inside bulb should be as small
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as possible when it is desired to obtain light only by incandescence
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the electrode. If it is desired to produce phosphorescence, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulb should be larger, else it would be apt to get too hot, and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescence would cease. In this arrangement usually only the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small bulb shows phosphorescence, as there is practically no
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bombardment against the outer globe. In some of these bulbs
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: constructed as illustrated in Fig. 28 the small tube was coated with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescent paint, and beautiful effects were obtained. Instead of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: making the inside bulb large, in order to avoid undue heating, it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: answers the purpose to make the electrode m larger. In this case the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bombardment is weakened by reason of the smaller electric density.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Many bulbs were constructed on the plan illustrated in Fig. 29. Here a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small bulb b, containing the refractory button m, upon being exhausted
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to a very high degree was sealed in a large globe L, which was then
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: moderately exhausted and sealed off. The principal advantage of this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: construction was that it allowed of reaching extremely high vacua,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and, at the same time use a large bulb. It was found, in the course of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiences with bulbs such as illustrated in Fig. 29, that it was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: well to make the stem s near the seal at e very thick, and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: leading-in wire w thin, as it occurred sometimes that the stem at e
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: was heated and the bulb was cracked. Often the outer globe L was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exhausted only just enough to allow the discharge to pass through, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the space between the bulbs appeared crimson, producing a curious
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: effect. In some cases, when the exhaustion in globe L was very low,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and the air good conducting, it was found necessary, in order to bring
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the button m to high incandescence, to place, preferably on the upper
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: part of the neck of the globe, a tinfoil coating which was connected
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to an insulated body, to the ground, or to the other terminal of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coil, as the highly conducting air weakened the effect somewhat,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: probably by being acted upon inductively from the wire w, where it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: entered the bulb at e. Another difficulty--which, however, is always
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: present when the refractory button is mounted in a very small
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulb--existed in the construction illustrated in Fig. 29, namely, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vacuum in the bulb b would be impaired in a comparatively short time.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 29.--LAMP WITH INDEPENDENT AUXILIARY BULB.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The chief idea in the two last described constructions was to confine
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the heat to the central portion of the globe by preventing the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exchange of air. An advantage is secured, but owing to the heating of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the inside bulb and slow evaporation of the glass the vacuum is hard
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to maintain, even if the construction illustrated in Fig. 28 be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: chosen, in which both bulbs communicate.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: But by far the better way--the ideal way--would be to reach
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sufficiently high frequencies. The higher the frequency the slower
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would be the exchange of the air, and I think that a frequency may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reached at which there would be no exchange whatever of the air
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: molecules around the terminal. We would then produce a flame in which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: there would be no carrying away of material, and a queer flame it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would be, for it would be rigid! With such high frequencies the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: inertia of the particles would come into play. As the brush, or flame,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would gain rigidity in virtue of the inertia of the particles, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exchange of the latter would be prevented. This would necessarily
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: occur, for, the number of the impulses being augmented, the potential
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: energy of each would diminish, so that finally only atomic vibrations
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: could be set up, and the motion of translation through measurable
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: space would cease. Thus an ordinary gas burner connected to a source
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of rapidly alternating potential might have its efficiency augmented
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to a certain limit, and this for two reasons--because of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: additional vibration imparted, and because of a slowing down of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: process of carrying off. But the renewal being rendered difficult, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: renewal being necessary to maintain the _burner_, a continued increase
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the frequency of the impulses, assuming they could be transmitted
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to and impressed upon the flame, would result in the "extinction" of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the latter, meaning by this term only the cessation of the chemical
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: process.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I think, however, that in the case of an electrode immersed in a fluid
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulating medium, and surrounded by independent carriers of electric
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: charges, which can be acted upon inductively, a sufficiently high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency of the impulses would probably result in a gravitation of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the gas all around toward the electrode. For this it would be only
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: necessary to assume that the independent bodies are irregularly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: shaped; they would then turn toward the electrode their side of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: greatest electric density, and this would be a position in which the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fluid resistance to approach would be smaller than that offered to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: receding.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The general opinion, I do not doubt, is that it is out of the question
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to reach any such frequencies as might--assuming some of the views
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: before expressed to be true--produce any of the results which I have
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: pointed out as mere possibilities. This may be so, but in the course
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of these investigations, from the observation of many phenomena I have
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gained the conviction that these frequencies would be much lower than
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: one is apt to estimate at first. In a flame we set up light vibrations
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: by causing molecules, or atoms, to collide. But what is the ratio of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the frequency of the collisions and that of the vibrations set up?
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Certainly it must be incomparably smaller than that of the knocks of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the bell and the sound vibrations, or that of the discharges and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: oscillations of the condenser. We may cause the molecules of the gas
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to collide by the use of alternate electric impulses of high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency, and so we may imitate the process in a flame; and from
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiments with frequencies which we are now able to obtain, I think
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that the result is producible with impulses which are transmissible
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: through a conductor.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In connection with thoughts of a similar nature, it appeared to me of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: great interest to demonstrate the rigidity of a vibrating gaseous
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: column. Although with such low frequencies as, say 10,000 per second,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which I was able to obtain without difficulty from a specially
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: constructed alternator, the task looked discouraging at first, I made
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a series of experiments. The trials with air at ordinary pressure led
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to no result, but with air moderately rarefied I obtain what I think
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to be an unmistakable experimental evidence of the property sought
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: for. As a result of this kind might lead able investigators to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conclusions of importance I will describe one of the experiments
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: performed.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It is well known that when a tube is slightly exhausted the discharge
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: may be passed through it in the form of a thin luminous thread. When
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: produced with currents of low frequency, obtained from a coil operated
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as usual, this thread is inert. If a magnet be approached to it, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: part near the same is attracted or repelled, according to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: direction of the lines of force of the magnet. It occurred to me that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: if such a thread would be produced with currents of very high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency, it should be more or less rigid, and as it was visible it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: could be easily studied. Accordingly I prepared a tube about 1 inch in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: diameter and 1 metre long, with outside coating at each end. The tube
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: was exhausted to a point at which by a little working the thread
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge could be obtained. It must be remarked here that the general
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: aspect of the tube, and the degree of exhaustion, are quite different
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: than when ordinary low frequency currents are used. As it was found
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: preferable to work with one terminal, the tube prepared was suspended
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: from the end of a wire connected to the terminal, the tinfoil coating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: being connected to the wire, and to the lower coating sometimes a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small insulated plate was attached. When the thread was formed it
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: extended through the upper part of the tube and lost itself in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: lower end. If it possessed rigidity it resembled, not exactly an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: elastic cord stretched tight between two supports, but a cord
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: suspended from a height with a small weight attached at the end. When
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the finger or a magnet was approached to the upper end of the luminous
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thread, it could be brought locally out of position by electrostatic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: or magnetic action; and when the disturbing object was very quickly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: removed, an analogous result was produced, as though a suspended cord
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would be displaced and quickly released near the point of suspension.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In doing this the luminous thread was set in vibration, and two very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sharply marked nodes, and a third indistinct one, were formed. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vibration, once set up, continued for fully eight minutes, dying
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gradually out. The speed of the vibration often varied perceptibly,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and it could be observed that the electrostatic attraction of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: glass affected the vibrating thread; but it was clear that the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrostatic action was not the cause of the vibration, for the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thread was most generally stationary, and could always be set in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vibration by passing the finger quickly near the upper part of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tube. With a magnet the thread could be split in two and both parts
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vibrated. By approaching the hand to the lower coating of the tube, or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulated plate if attached, the vibration was quickened; also, as far
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as I could see, by raising the potential or frequency. Thus, either
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: increasing the frequency or passing a stronger discharge of the same
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency corresponded to a tightening of the cord. I did not obtain
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: any experimental evidence with condenser discharges. A luminous band
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: excited in a bulb by repeated discharges of a Leyden jar must possess
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rigidity, and if deformed and suddenly released should vibrate. But
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: probably the amount of vibrating matter is so small that in spite of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the extreme speed the inertia cannot prominently assert itself.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Besides, the observation in such a case is rendered extremely
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: difficult on account of the fundamental vibration.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The demonstration of the fact--which still needs better experimental
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: confirmation--that a vibrating gaseous column possesses rigidity,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: might greatly modify the views of thinkers. When with low frequencies
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and insignificant potentials indications of that property may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: noted, how must a gaseous medium behave under the influence of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: enormous electrostatic stresses which may be active in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: interstellar space, and which may alternate with inconceivable
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rapidity? The existence of such an electrostatic, rhythmically
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: throbbing force--of a vibrating electrostatic field--would show a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: possible way how solids might have formed from the ultra-gaseous
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: uterus, and how transverse and all kinds of vibrations may be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: transmitted through a gaseous medium filling all space. Then, ether
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: might be a true fluid, devoid of rigidity, and at rest, it being
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: merely necessary as a connecting link to enable interaction. What
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: determines the rigidity of a body? It must be the speed and the amount
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of moving matter. In a gas the speed may be considerable, but the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: density is exceedingly small; in a liquid the speed would be likely to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be small, though the density may be considerable; and in both cases
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the inertia resistance offered to displacement is practically _nil_.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: But place a gaseous (or liquid) column in an intense, rapidly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alternating electrostatic field, set the particles vibrating with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: enormous speeds, then the inertia resistance asserts itself. A body
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: might move with more or less freedom through the vibrating mass, but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as a whole it would be rigid.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: There is a subject which I must mention in connection with these
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiments: it is that of high vacua. This is a subject the study of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which is not only interesting, but useful, for it may lead to results
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of great practical importance. In commercial apparatus, such as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescent lamps, operated from ordinary systems of distribution, a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: much higher vacuum than obtained at present would not secure a very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: great advantage. In such a case the work is performed on the filament
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and the gas is little concerned; the improvement, therefore, would be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: but trifling. But when we begin to use very high frequencies and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potentials, the action of the gas becomes all important, and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: degree of exhaustion materially modifies the results. As long as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ordinary coils, even very large ones, were used, the study of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: subject was limited, because just at a point when it became most
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: interesting it had to be interrupted on account of the "non-striking"
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vacuum being reached. But presently we are able to obtain from a small
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: disruptive discharge coil potentials much higher than even the largest
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coil was capable of giving, and, what is more, we can make the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential alternate with great rapidity. Both of these results enable
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: us now to pass a luminous discharge through almost any vacua
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: obtainable, and the field of our investigations is greatly extended.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Think we as we may, of all the possible directions to develop a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: practical illuminant, the line of high vacua seems to be the most
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: promising at present. But to reach extreme vacua the appliances must
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be much more improved, and ultimate perfection will not be attained
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: until we shall have discarded the mechanical and perfected an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: _electrical_ vacuum pump. Molecules and atoms can be thrown out of a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bulb under the action of an enormous potential: _this_ will be the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: principle of the vacuum pump of the future. For the present, we must
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: secure the best results we can with mechanical appliances. In this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: respect, it might not be out of the way to say a few words about the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: method of, and apparatus for, producing excessively high degrees of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exhaustion of which I have availed myself in the course of these
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: investigations. It is very probable that other experimenters have used
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: similar arrangements; but as it is possible that there may be an item
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of interest in their description, a few remarks, which will render
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this investigation more complete, might be permitted.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 30.--APPARATUS USED FOR OBTAINING HIGH DEGREES OF
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: EXHAUSTION.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The apparatus is illustrated in a drawing shown in Fig. 30. S
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: represents a Sprengel pump, which has been specially constructed to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: better suit the work required. The stop-cock which is usually employed
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: has been omitted, and instead of it a hollow stopper s has been fitted
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in the neck of the reservoir R. This stopper has a small hole h,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: through which the mercury descends; the size of the outlet o being
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: properly determined with respect to the section of the fall tube t,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which is sealed to the reservoir instead of being connected to it in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the usual manner. This arrangement overcomes the imperfections and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: troubles which often arise from the use of the stopcock on the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reservoir and the connection of the latter with the fall tube.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The pump is connected through a U-shaped tube t to a very large
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reservoir R_1. Especial care was taken in fitting the grinding
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: surfaces of the stoppers p and p_1, and both of these and the mercury
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: caps above them were made exceptionally long. After the U-shaped tube
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: was fitted and put in place, it was heated, so as to soften and take
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: off the strain resulting from imperfect fitting. The U-shaped tube was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: provided with a stopcock C, and two ground connections g and g_1--one
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: for a small bulb b, usually containing caustic potash, and the other
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: for the receiver r, to be exhausted.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The reservoir R_1 was connected by means of a rubber tube to a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: slightly larger reservoir R_2, each of the two reservoirs being
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: provided with a stopcock C_1 and C_2, respectively. The reservoir R_2
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: could be raised and lowered by a wheel and rack, and the range of its
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: motion was so determined that when it was filled with mercury and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: stopcock C_2 closed, so as to form a Torricellian vacuum in it when
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: raised, it could be lifted so high that the mercury in reservoir R_1
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would stand a little above stopcock C_1; and when this stopcock was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: closed and the reservoir R_2 descended, so as to form a Torricellian
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vacuum in reservoir R_1, it could be lowered so far as to completely
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: empty the latter, the mercury filling the reservoir R_2 up to a little
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: above stopcock C_2.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The capacity of the pump and of the connections was taken as small as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: possible relatively to the volume of reservoir R_1, since, of course,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the degree of exhaustion depended upon the ratio of these quantities.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: With this apparatus I combined the usual means indicated by former
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiments for the production of very high vacua. In most of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiments it was convenient to use caustic potash. I may venture to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: say, in regard to its use, that much time is saved and a more perfect
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: action of the pump insured by fusing and boiling the potash as soon
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as, or even before, the pump settles down. If this course is not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: followed the sticks, as ordinarily employed, may give moisture off at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a certain very slow rate, and the pump may work for many hours without
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reaching a very high vacuum. The potash was heated either by a spirit
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: lamp or by passing a discharge through it, or by passing a current
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: through a wire contained in it. The advantage in the latter case was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that the heating could be more rapidly repeated.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Generally the process of exhaustion was the following:--At the start,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the stop-cocks C and C_1 being open, and all other connections closed,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the reservoir R_2 was raised so far that the mercury filled the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reservoir R_1 and a part of the narrow connecting U-shaped tube. When
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the pump was set to work, the mercury would, of course, quickly rise
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in the tube, and reservoir R_2 was lowered, the experimenter keeping
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the mercury at about the same level. The reservoir R_2 was balanced
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: by a long spring which facilitated the operation, and the friction of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the parts was generally sufficient to keep it almost in any position.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When the Sprengel pump had done its work, the reservoir R_2 was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: further lowered and the mercury descended in R_1 and filled R_2,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: whereupon stopcock C_2 was closed. The air adhering to the walls of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: R_1 and that absorbed by the mercury was carried off, and to free the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mercury of all air the reservoir R_2 was for a long time worked up and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: down. During this process some air, which would gather below stopcock
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: C_2, was expelled from R_2 by lowering it far enough and opening the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: stopcock, closing the latter again before raising the reservoir. When
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: all the air had been expelled from the mercury, and no air would
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gather in R_2 when it was lowered, the caustic potash was resorted to.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The reservoir R_2 was now again raised until the mercury in R_1 stood
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: above stopcock C_1. The caustic potash was fused and boiled, and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: moisture partly carried off by the pump and partly re-absorbed; and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this process of heating and cooling was repeated many times, and each
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: time, upon the moisture being absorbed or carried off, the reservoir
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: R_2 was for a long time raised and lowered. In this manner all the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: moisture was carried off from the mercury, and both the reservoirs
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: were in proper condition to be used. The reservoir R_2 was then again
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: raised to the top, and the pump was kept working for a long time. When
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the highest vacuum obtainable with the pump had been reached the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potash bulb was usually wrapped with cotton which was sprinkled with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ether so as to keep the potash at a very low temperature, then the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reservoir R_2 was lowered, and upon reservoir R_1 being emptied the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: receiver r was quickly sealed up.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: When a new bulb was put on, the mercury was always raised above
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: stopcock C_1 which was closed, so as to always keep the mercury and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: both the reservoirs in fine condition, and the mercury was never
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: withdrawn from R_1 except when the pump had reached the highest degree
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of exhaustion. It is necessary to observe this rule if it is desired
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to use the apparatus to advantage.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: By means of this arrangement I was able to proceed very quickly, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when the apparatus was in perfect order it was possible to reach the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescent stage in a small bulb in less than 15 minutes, which is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: certainly very quick work for a small laboratory arrangement requiring
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: all in all about 100 pounds of mercury. With ordinary small bulbs the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ratio of the capacity of the pump, receiver, and connections, and that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of reservoir R was about 1-20, and the degrees of exhaustion reached
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: were necessarily very high, though I am unable to make a precise and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reliable statement how far the exhaustion was carried.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: What impresses the investigator most in the course of these
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiences is the behavior of gases when subjected to great rapidly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alternating electrostatic stresses. But he must remain in doubt as to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: whether the effects observed are due wholly to the molecules, or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: atoms, of the gas which chemical analysis discloses to us, or whether
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: there enters into play another medium of a gaseous nature, comprising
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: atoms, or molecules, immersed in a fluid pervading the space. Such a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: medium surely must exist, and I am convinced that, for instance, even
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: if air were absent, the surface and neighborhood of a body in space
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would be heated by rapidly alternating the potential of the body; but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: no such heating of the surface or neighborhood could occur if all free
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: atoms were removed and only a homogeneous, incompressible, and elastic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fluid--such as ether is supposed to be--would remain, for then there
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: would be no impacts, no collisions. In such a case, as far as the body
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: itself is concerned, only frictional losses in the inside could occur.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It is a striking fact that the discharge through a gas is established
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with ever increasing freedom as the frequency of the impulses is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: augmented. It behaves in this respect quite contrarily to a metallic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conductor. In the latter the impedance enters prominently into play as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the frequency is increased, but the gas acts much as a series of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: condensers would: the facility with which the discharge passes through
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: seems to depend on the rate of change of potential. If it act so, then
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in a vacuum tube even of great length, and no matter how strong the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: current, self-induction could not assert itself to any appreciable
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: degree. We have, then, as far as we can now see, in the gas a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conductor which is capable of transmitting electric impulses of any
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency which we may be able to produce. Could the frequency be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: brought high enough, then a queer system of electric distribution,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which would be likely to interest gas companies, might be realized:
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: metal pipes filled with gas--the metal being the insulator, the gas
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the conductor--supplying phosphorescent bulbs, or perhaps devices as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: yet uninvented. It is certainly possible to take a hollow core of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: copper, rarefy the gas in the same, and by passing impulses of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sufficiently high frequency through a circuit around it, bring the gas
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: inside to a high degree of incandescence; but as to the nature of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: forces there would be considerable uncertainty, for it would be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: doubtful whether with such impulses the copper core would act as a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: static screen. Such paradoxes and apparent impossibilities we
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: encounter at every step in this line of work, and therein lies, to a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: great extent, the claim of the study.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I have here a short and wide tube which is exhausted to a high degree
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and covered with a substantial coating of bronze, the coating allowing
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: barely the light to shine through. A metallic clasp, with a hook for
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: suspending the tube, is fastened around the middle portion of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: latter, the clasp being in contact with the bronze coating. I now want
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to light the gas inside by suspending the tube on a wire connected to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the coil. Any one who would try the experiment for the first time, not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: having any previous experience, would probably take care to be quite
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alone when making the trial, for fear that he might become the joke of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: his assistants. Still, the bulb lights in spite of the metal coating,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and the light can be distinctly perceived through the latter. A long
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tube covered with aluminium bronze lights when held in one hand--the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: other touching the terminal of the coil--quite powerfully. It might be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: objected that the coatings are not sufficiently conducting; still,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: even if they were highly resistant, they ought to screen the gas. They
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: certainly screen it perfectly in a condition of rest, but not by far
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: perfectly when the charge is surging in the coating. But the loss of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: energy which occurs within the tube, notwithstanding the screen, is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: occasioned principally by the presence of the gas. Were we to take a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: large hollow metallic sphere and fill it with a perfect incompressible
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fluid dielectric, there would be no loss inside of the sphere, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: consequently the inside might be considered as perfectly screened,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: though the potential be very rapidly alternating. Even were the sphere
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: filled with oil, the loss would be incomparably smaller than when the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fluid is replaced by a gas, for in the latter case the force produces
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: displacements; that means impact and collisions in the inside.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: No matter what the pressure of the gas may be, it becomes an important
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: factor in the heating of a conductor when the electric density is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: great and the frequency very high. That in the heating of conductors
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: by lightning discharges air is an element of great importance, is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: almost as certain as an experimental fact. I may illustrate the action
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the air by the following experiment: I take a short tube which is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exhausted to a moderate degree and has a platinum wire running through
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the middle from one end to the other. I pass a steady or low frequency
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: current through the wire, and it is heated uniformly in all parts. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: heating here is due to conduction, or frictional losses, and the gas
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: around the wire has--as far as we can see--no function to perform. But
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: now let me pass sudden discharges, or a high frequency current,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: through the wire. Again the wire is heated, this time principally on
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the ends and least in the middle portion; and if the frequency of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: impulses, or the rate of change, is high enough, the wire might as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: well be cut in the middle as not, for practically all the heating is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: due to the rarefied gas. Here the gas might only act as a conductor of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: no impedance diverting the current from the wire as the impedance of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the latter is enormously increased, and merely heating the ends of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wire by reason of their resistance to the passage of the discharge.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: But it is not at all necessary that the gas in the tube should he
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conducting; it might be at an extremely low pressure, still the ends
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the wire would be heated--as, however, is ascertained by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experience--only the two ends would in such, case not be electrically
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: connected through the gaseous medium. Now what with these frequencies
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and potentials occurs in an exhausted tube occurs in the lightning
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharges at ordinary pressure. We only need remember one of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: facts arrived at in the course of these investigations, namely, that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to impulses of very high frequency the gas at ordinary pressure
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: behaves much in the same manner as though it were at moderately low
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: pressure. I think that in lightning discharges frequently wires or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conducting objects are volatilized merely because air is present and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that, were the conductor immersed in an insulating liquid, it would be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: safe, for then the energy would have to spend itself somewhere else.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: From the behavior of gases to sudden impulses of high potential I am
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: led to conclude that there can be no surer way of diverting a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: lightning discharge than by affording it a passage through a volume of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gas, if such a thing can be done in a practical manner.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: There are two more features upon which I think it necessary to dwell
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in connection with these experiments--the "radiant state" and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: "non-striking vacuum."
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Any one who has studied Crookes' work must have received the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: impression that the "radiant state" is a property of the gas
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: inseparably connected with an extremely high degree of exhaustion. But
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it should be remembered that the phenomena observed in an exhausted
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vessel are limited to the character and capacity of the apparatus
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which is made use of. I think that in a bulb a molecule, or atom, does
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: not precisely move in a straight line because it meets no obstacle,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: but because the velocity imparted to it is sufficient to propel it in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a sensibly straight line. The mean free path is one thing, but the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: velocity--the energy associated with the moving body--is another, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: under ordinary circumstances I believe that it is a mere question of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential or speed. A disruptive discharge coil, when the potential is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: pushed very far, excites phosphorescence and projects shadows, at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: comparatively low degrees of exhaustion. In a lightning discharge,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: matter moves in straight lines as ordinary pressure when the mean free
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: path is exceedingly small, and frequently images of wires or other
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: metallic objects have been produced by the particles thrown off in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: straight lines.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 31.--BULB SHOWING RADIANT LIME STREAM AT LOW
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: EXHAUSTION.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I have prepared a bulb to illustrate by an experiment the correctness
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of these assertions. In a globe L (Fig. 31) I have mounted upon a lamp
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: filament f a piece of lime l. The lamp filament is connected with a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wire which leads into the bulb, and the general construction of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: latter is as indicated in Fig. 19, before described. The bulb being
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: suspended from a wire connected to the terminal of the coil, and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: latter being set to work, the lime piece l and the projecting parts of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the filament f are bombarded. The degree of exhaustion is just such
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: that with the potential the coil is capable of giving phosphorescence
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of the glass is produced, but disappears as soon as the vacuum is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: impaired. The lime containing moisture, and moisture being given off
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as soon as heating occurs, the phosphorescence lasts only for a few
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: moments. When the lime has been sufficiently heated, enough moisture
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: has been given off to impair materially the vacuum of the bulb. As the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bombardment goes on, one point of the lime piece is more heated than
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: other points, and the result is that finally practically all the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge passes through that point which is intensely heated, and a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: white stream of lime particles (Fig. 31) then breaks forth from that
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: point. This stream is composed of "radiant" matter, yet the degree of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exhaustion is low. But the particles move in straight lines because
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the velocity imparted to them is great, and this is due to three
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: causes--to the great electric density, the high temperature of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small point, and the fact that the particles of the lime are easily
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: torn and thrown off--far more easily than those of carbon. With
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequencies such as we are able to obtain, the particles are bodily
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thrown off and projected to a considerable distance; but with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sufficiently high frequencies no such thing would occur: in such case
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: only a stress would spread or a vibration would be propagated through
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the bulb. It would be out of the question to reach any such frequency
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: on the assumption that the atoms move with the speed of light; but I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: believe that such a thing is impossible; for this an enormous
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: potential would be required. With potentials which we are able to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: obtain, even with a disruptive discharge coil, the speed must be quite
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insignificant.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: As to the "non-striking vacuum," the point to be noted is that it can
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: occur only with low frequency impulses, and it is necessitated by the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: impossibility of carrying off enough energy with such impulses in high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vacuum since the few atoms which are around the terminal upon coming
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in contact with the same are repelled and kept at a distance for a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: comparatively long period of time, and not enough work can be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: performed to render the effect perceptible to the eye. If the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: difference of potential between the terminals is raised, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: dielectric breaks down. But with very high frequency impulses there
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is no necessity for such breaking down, since any amount of work can
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be performed by continually agitating the atoms in the exhausted
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vessel, provided the frequency is high enough. It is easy to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reach--even with frequencies obtained from an alternator as here
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: used--a stage at which the discharge does not pass between two
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrodes in a narrow tube, each of these being connected to one of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the terminals of the coil, but it is difficult to reach a point at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which a luminous discharge would not occur around each electrode.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: A thought which naturally presents itself in connection with high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency currents, is to make use of their powerful electro-dynamic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: inductive action to produce light effects in a sealed glass globe. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: leading-in wire is one of the defects of the present incandescent
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: lamp, and if no other improvement were made, that imperfection at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: least should be done away with. Following this thought, I have carried
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: on experiments in various directions, of which some were indicated in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: my former paper. I may here mention one or two more lines of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiment which have been followed up.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Many bulbs were constructed as shown in Fig. 32 and Fig. 33.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In Fig. 32 a wide tube T was sealed to a smaller W-shaped tube U, of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phosphorescent glass. In the tube T was placed a coil C of aluminium
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wire, the ends of which were provided with small spheres t and t_1 of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: aluminium, and reached into the U tube. The tube T was slipped into a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: socket containing a primary coil through which usually the discharges
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of Leyden jars were directed, and the rarefied gas in the small U tube
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: was excited to strong luminosity by the high-tension currents induced
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in the coil C. When Leyden jar discharges were used to induce currents
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in the coil C, it was found necessary to pack the tube T tightly with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: insulating powder, as a discharge would occur frequently between the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: turns of the coil, especially when the primary was thick and the air
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gap, through which the jars discharged, large, and no little trouble
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: was experienced in this way.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 32.--ELECTRO-DYNAMIC INDUCTION TUBE.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 33--ELECTRO-DYNAMIC INDUCTION LAMP.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In Fig. 33 is illustrated another form of the bulb constructed. In
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this case a tube T is sealed to a globe L. The tube contains a coil C,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the ends of which pass through two small glass tubes t and t_1, which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are sealed to the tube T. Two refractory buttons m and m_1 are mounted
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: on lamp filaments which are fastened to the ends of the wires passing
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: through the glass tubes t and t_1. Generally in bulbs made on this
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: plan the globe L communicated with the tube T. For this purpose the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ends of the small tubes t and t_1 were just a trifle heated in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: burner, merely to hold the wires, but not to interfere with the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: communication. The tube T, with the small tubes, wires through the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: same, and the refractory buttons m and m_1, was first prepared, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: then sealed to globe L, whereupon the coil C was slipped in and the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: connections made to its ends. The tube was then packed with insulating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: powder, jamming the latter as tight as possible up to very nearly the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: end, then it was closed and only a small hole left through which the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: remainder of the powder was introduced, and finally the end of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tube was closed. Usually in bulbs constructed as shown in Fig. 33 an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: aluminium tube a was fastened to the upper end s of each of the tubes
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: t and t_1, in order to protect that end against the heat. The buttons
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: m and m_1 could be brought to any degree of incandescence by passing
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the discharges of Leyden jars around the coil C. In such bulbs with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: two buttons a very curious effect is produced by the formation of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: shadows of each of the two buttons.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Another line of experiment, which has been assiduously followed, was
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to induce by electro-dynamic induction a current or luminous discharge
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: in an exhausted tube or bulb. This matter has received such able
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: treatment at the hands of Prof. J.J. Thomson that I could add but
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: little to what he has made known, even had I made it the special
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: subject of this lecture. Still, since experiences in this line have
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: gradually led me to the present views and results, a few words must be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: devoted here to this subject.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It has occurred, no doubt, to many that as a vacuum tube is made
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: longer the electromotive force per unit length of the tube, necessary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to pass a luminous discharge through the latter, gets continually
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: smaller; therefore, if the exhausted tube be made long enough, even
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with low frequencies a luminous discharge could be induced in such a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: tube closed upon itself. Such a tube might be placed around a ball or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: on a ceiling, and at once a simple appliance capable of giving
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: considerable light would be obtained. But this would be an appliance
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: hard to manufacture and extremely unmanageable. It would not do to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: make the tube up of small lengths, because there would be with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ordinary frequencies considerable loss in the coatings, and besides,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: if coatings were used, it would be better to supply the current
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: directly to the tube by connecting the coatings to a transformer. But
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: even if all objections of such nature were removed, still, with low
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequencies the light conversion itself would be inefficient, as I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: have before stated. In using extremely high frequencies the length of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the secondary--in other words, the size of the vessel--can be reduced
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: as far as desired, and the efficiency of the light conversion is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: increased, provided that means are invented for efficiently obtaining
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: such high frequencies. Thus one is led, from theoretical and practical
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: considerations, to the use of high frequencies, and this means high
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electromotive forces and small currents in the primary. When he works
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with condenser charges--and they are the only means up to the present
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: known for reaching these extreme frequencies--he gets to electromotive
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: forces of several thousands of volts per turn of the primary. He
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: cannot multiply the electro-dynamic inductive effect by taking more
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: turns in the primary, for he arrives at the conclusion that the best
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: way is to work with one single turn--though he must sometimes depart
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: from this rule--and he must get along with whatever inductive effect
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: he can obtain with one turn. But before he has long experimented with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the extreme frequencies required to set up in a small bulb an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electromotive force of several thousands of volts he realizes the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: great importance of electrostatic effects, and these effects grow
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: relatively to the electro-dynamic in significance as the frequency is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: increased.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Now, if anything is desirable in this case, it is to increase the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency, and this would make it still worse for the electro-dynamic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: effects. On the other hand, it is easy to exalt the electrostatic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: action as far as one likes by taking more turns on the secondary, or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: combining self-induction and capacity to raise the potential. It
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: should also be remembered that, in reducing the current to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: smallest value and increasing the potential, the electric impulses of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: high frequency can be more easily transmitted through a conductor.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: These and similar thoughts determined me to devote more attention to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the electrostatic phenomena, and to endeavor to produce potentials as
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: high as possible, and alternating as fast as they could be made to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alternate. I then found that I could excite vacuum tubes at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: considerable distance from a conductor connected to a properly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: constructed coil, and that I could, by converting the oscillatory
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: current of a condenser to a higher potential, establish electrostatic
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: alternating fields which acted through the whole extent of a room,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: lighting up a tube no matter where it was held in space. I thought I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: recognized that I had made a step in advance, and I have persevered in
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this line; but I wish to say that I share with all lovers of science
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and progress the one and only desire--to reach a result of utility to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: men in any direction to which thought or experiment may lead me. I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: think that this departure is the right one, for I cannot see, from the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: observation of the phenomena which manifest themselves as the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequency is increased, what there would remain to act between two
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: circuits conveying, for instance, impulses of several hundred millions
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: per second, except electrostatic forces. Even with such trifling
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: frequencies the energy would be practically all potential, and my
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conviction has grown strong that, to whatever kind of motion light may
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be due, it is produced by tremendous electrostatic stresses vibrating
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with extreme rapidity.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Of all these phenomena observed with currents, or electric impulses,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of high frequency, the most fascinating for an audience are certainly
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: those which are noted in an electrostatic field acting through
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: considerable distance, and the best an unskilled lecturer can do is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: to begin and finish with the exhibition of these singular effects. I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: take a tube in the hand and move it about, and it is lighted wherever
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I may hold it; throughout space the invisible forces act. But I may
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: take another tube and it might not light, the vacuum being very high.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: I excite it by means of a disruptive discharge coil, and now it will
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: light in the electrostatic field. I may put it away for a few weeks or
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: months, still it retains the faculty of being excited. What change
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: have I produced in the tube in the act of exciting it? If a motion
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: imparted to the atoms, it is difficult to perceive how it can persist
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: so long without being arrested by frictional losses; and if a strain
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: exerted in the dielectric, such as a simple electrification would
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: produce, it is easy to see how it may persist indefinitely, but very
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: difficult to understand why such a condition should aid the excitation
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when we have to deal with potentials which are rapidly alternating.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Since I have exhibited these phenomena for the first time, I have
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: obtained some other interesting effects. For instance, I have produced
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the incandescence of a button, filament, or wire enclosed in a tube.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: To get to this result it was necessary to economize the energy which
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is obtained from the field and direct most of it on the small body to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be rendered incandescent. At the beginning the task appeared
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: difficult, but the experiences gathered permitted me to reach the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: result easily. In Fig. 34 and Fig. 35 two such tubes are illustrated
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: which are prepared for the occasion. In Fig. 34 a short tube T_1,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sealed to another long tube T, is provided with a stem s, with a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: platinum wire sealed in the latter. A very thin lamp filament l is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: fastened to this wire, and connection to the outside is made through a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thin copper wire w. The tube is provided with outside and inside
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coatings, C and C_1 respectively, and is filled as far as the coatings
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: reach with conducting, and the space above with insulating powder.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: These coatings are merely used to enable me to perform two experiments
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with the tube--namely, to produce the effect desired either by direct
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: connection of the body of the experimenter or of another body to the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wire w, or by acting inductively through the glass. The stem s is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: provided with an aluminium tube a, for purposes before explained, and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: only a small part of the filament reaches out of this tube. By holding
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the tube T_1 anywhere in the electrostatic field the filament is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: rendered incandescent.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 34.--TUBE WITH FILAMENT RENDERED INCANDESCENT IN
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: AN ELECTROSTATIC FIELD.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: [Illustration: FIG. 35.--CROOKES' EXPERIMENT IN ELECTROSTATIC FIELD.]
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: A more interesting piece of apparatus is illustrated in Fig. 35. The
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: construction is the same as before, only instead of the lamp filament
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a small platinum wire p, sealed in a stem s, and bent above it in a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: circle, is connected to the copper wire w, which is joined to an
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: inside coating C. A small stem s_1 is provided with a needle, on the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: point of which is arranged to rotate very freely a very light fan of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mica v. To prevent the fan from falling out, a thin stem of glass g is
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: bent properly and fastened to the aluminium tube. When the glass tube
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is held anywhere in the electrostatic field the platinum wire becomes
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescent, and the mica vanes are rotated very fast.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Intense phosphorescence may be excited in a bulb by merely connecting
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it to a plate within the field, and the plate need not be any larger
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: than an ordinary lamp shade. The phosphorescence excited with these
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: currents is incomparably more powerful than with ordinary apparatus. A
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: small phosphorescent bulb, when attached to a wire connected to a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coil, emits sufficient light to allow reading ordinary print at a
