author: Tesla, Nikola

text: distance of five to six paces. It was of interest to see how some of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the phosphorescent bulbs of Professor Crookes would behave with these
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: currents, and he has had the kindness to lend me a few for the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: occasion. The effects produced are magnificent, especially by the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: sulphide of calcium and sulphide of zinc. From the disruptive
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: discharge coil they glow intensely merely by holding them in the hand
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and connecting the body to the terminal of the coil.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: To whatever results investigations of this kind may lead, their chief
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: interest lies for the present in the possibilities they offer for the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: production of an efficient illuminating device. In no branch of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electric industry is an advance more desired than in the manufacture
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of light. Every thinker, when considering the barbarous methods
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: employed, the deplorable losses incurred in our best systems of light
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: production, must have asked himself, What is likely to be the light of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the future? Is it to be an incandescent solid, as in the present lamp,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: or an incandescent gas, or a phosphorescent body, or something like a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: burner, but incomparably more efficient?
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: There is little chance to perfect a gas burner; not, perhaps, because
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: human ingenuity has been bent upon that problem for centuries without
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a radical departure having been made--though this argument is not
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: devoid of force-but because in a burner the higher vibrations can
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: never be reached except by passing through all the low ones. For how
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: is a flame produced unless by a fall of lifted weights? Such process
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: cannot be maintained without renewal, and renewal is repeated passing
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: from low to high vibrations. One way only seems to be open to improve
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a burner, and that is by trying to reach higher degrees of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescence. Higher incandescence is equivalent to a quicker
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vibration; that means more light from the same material, and that,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: again, means more economy. In this direction some improvements have
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: been made, but the progress is hampered by many limitations.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Discarding, then, the burner, there remain the three ways first
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: mentioned, which are essentially electrical.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Suppose the light of the immediate future to be a solid rendered
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescent by electricity. Would it not seem that it is better to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: employ a small button than a frail filament? From many considerations
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: it certainly must be concluded that a button is capable of a higher
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: economy, assuming, of course, the difficulties connected with the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: operation of such a lamp to be effectively overcome. But to light such
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a lamp we require a high potential; and to get this economically we
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: must use high frequencies.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Such considerations apply even more to the production of light by the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: incandescence of a gas, or by phosphorescence. In all cases we require
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: high frequencies and high potentials. These thoughts occurred to me a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: long time ago.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: Incidentally we gain, by the use of very high frequencies, many
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: advantages, such as a higher economy in the light production, the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: possibility of working with one lead, the possibility of doing away
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: with the leading-in wire, etc.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The question is, how far can we go with frequencies? Ordinary
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conductors rapidly lose the facility of transmitting electric impulses
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: when the frequency is greatly increased. Assume the means for the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: production of impulses of very great frequency brought to the utmost
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: perfection, every one will naturally ask how to transmit them when the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: necessity arises. In transmitting such impulses through conductors we
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: must remember that we have to deal with _pressure_ and _flow_, in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ordinary interpretation of these terms. Let the pressure increase to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: an enormous value, and let the flow correspondingly diminish, then
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: such impulses--variations merely of pressure, as it were--can no doubt
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be transmitted through a wire even if their frequency be many hundreds
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of millions per second. It would, of course, be out of question to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: transmit such impulses through a wire immersed in a gaseous medium,
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: even if the wire were provided with a thick and excellent insulation
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: for most of the energy would be lost in molecular bombardment and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: consequent heating. The end of the wire connected to the source would
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be heated, and the remote end would receive but a trifling part of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: energy supplied. The prime necessity, then, if such electric impulses
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: are to be used, is to find means to reduce as much as possible the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: dissipation.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: The first thought is, employ the thinnest possible wire surrounded by
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the thickest practicable insulation. The next thought is to employ
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrostatic screens. The insulation of the wire may be covered with
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a thin conducting coating and the latter connected to the ground. But
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: this would not do, as then all the energy would pass through the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conducting coating to the ground and nothing would get to the end of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the wire. If a ground connection is made it can only be made through a
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conductor offering an enormous impedance, or though a condenser of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: extremely small capacity. This, however, does not do away with other
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: difficulties.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: If the wave length of the impulses is much smaller than the length of
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the wire, then corresponding short waves will be sent up in the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conducting coating, and it will be more or less the same as though the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: coating were directly connected to earth. It is therefore necessary to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: cut up the coating in sections much shorter than the wave length. Such
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: an arrangement does not still afford a perfect screen, but it is ten
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: thousand times better than none. I think it preferable to cut up the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conducting coating in small sections, even if the current waves be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: much longer than the coating.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: If a wire were provided with a perfect electrostatic screen, it would
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be the same as though all objects were removed from it at infinite
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: distance. The capacity would then be reduced to the capacity of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wire itself, which would be very small. It would then be possible to
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: send over the wire current vibrations of very high frequencies at
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: enormous distance without affecting greatly the character of the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: vibrations. A perfect screen is of course out of the question, but I
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: believe that with a screen such as I have just described telephony
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: could be rendered practicable across the Atlantic. According to my
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: ideas, the gutta-percha covered wire should be provided with a third
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: conducting coating subdivided in sections. On the top of this should
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: be again placed a layer of gutta-percha and other insulation, and on
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the top of the whole the armor. But such cables will not be
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: constructed, for ere long intelligence--transmitted without
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: wires--will throb through the earth like a pulse through a living
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: organism. The wonder is that, with the present state of knowledge and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: the experiences gained, no attempt is being made to disturb the
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: electrostatic or magnetic condition of the earth, and transmit, if
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: nothing else, intelligence.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: It has been my chief aim in presenting these results to point out
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: phenomena or features of novelty, and to advance ideas which I am
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: hopeful will serve as starting points of new departures. It has been
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: my chief desire this evening to entertain you with some novel
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: experiments. Your applause, so frequently and generously accorded, has
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: told me that I have succeeded.
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: In conclusion, let me thank you most heartily for your kindness and
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: attention, and assure you that the honor I have had in addressing such
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: a distinguished audience, the pleasure I have had in presenting these
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: results to a gathering of so many able men--and among them also some
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: of those in whose work for many years past I have found enlightenment
author: Tesla, Nikola

text: and constant pleasure--I shall never forget.
author: Tesla, Nikola

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CHRISTIAAN HUYGENS
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: PREFACE
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I wrote this Treatise during my sojourn in France twelve years ago,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and I communicated it in the year 1678 to the learned persons who then
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: composed the Royal Academy of Science, to the membership of which the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: King had done me the honour of calling, me. Several of that body who
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: are still alive will remember having been present when I read it, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: above the rest those amongst them who applied themselves particularly
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to the study of Mathematics; of whom I cannot cite more than the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: celebrated gentlemen Cassini, Roemer, and De la Hire. And, although I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: have since corrected and changed some parts, the copies which I had
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: made of it at that time may serve for proof that I have yet added
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: nothing to it save some conjectures touching the formation of Iceland
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Crystal, and a novel observation on the refraction of Rock Crystal. I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: have desired to relate these particulars to make known how long I have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: meditated the things which now I publish, and not for the purpose of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: detracting from the merit of those who, without having seen anything
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that I have written, may be found to have treated of like matters: as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: has in fact occurred to two eminent Geometricians, Messieurs Newton
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and Leibnitz, with respect to the Problem of the figure of glasses for
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: collecting rays when one of the surfaces is given.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: One may ask why I have so long delayed to bring this work to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: light. The reason is that I wrote it rather carelessly in the Language
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in which it appears, with the intention of translating it into Latin,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: so doing in order to obtain greater attention to the thing. After
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which I proposed to myself to give it out along with another Treatise
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: on Dioptrics, in which I explain the effects of Telescopes and those
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: things which belong more to that Science. But the pleasure of novelty
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: being past, I have put off from time to time the execution of this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: design, and I know not when I shall ever come to an end if it, being
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: often turned aside either by business or by some new study.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Considering which I have finally judged that it was better worth while
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to publish this writing, such as it is, than to let it run the risk,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: by waiting longer, of remaining lost.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: There will be seen in it demonstrations of those kinds which do not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: produce as great a certitude as those of Geometry, and which even
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: differ much therefrom, since whereas the Geometers prove their
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Propositions by fixed and incontestable Principles, here the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Principles are verified by the conclusions to be drawn from them; the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: nature of these things not allowing of this being done otherwise.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It is always possible to attain thereby to a degree of probability
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which very often is scarcely less than complete proof. To wit, when
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: things which have been demonstrated by the Principles that have been
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: assumed correspond perfectly to the phenomena which experiment has
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: brought under observation; especially when there are a great number of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: them, and further, principally, when one can imagine and foresee new
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: phenomena which ought to follow from the hypotheses which one employs,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and when one finds that therein the fact corresponds to our prevision.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But if all these proofs of probability are met with in that which I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: propose to discuss, as it seems to me they are, this ought to be a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: very strong confirmation of the success of my inquiry; and it must be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ill if the facts are not pretty much as I represent them. I would
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: believe then that those who love to know the Causes of things and who
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: are able to admire the marvels of Light, will find some satisfaction
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in these various speculations regarding it, and in the new explanation
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of its famous property which is the main foundation of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: construction of our eyes and of those great inventions which extend so
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: vastly the use of them.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I hope also that there will be some who by following these beginnings
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will penetrate much further into this question than I have been able
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to do, since the subject must be far from being exhausted. This
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: appears from the passages which I have indicated where I leave certain
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: difficulties without having resolved them, and still more from matters
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which I have not touched at all, such as Luminous Bodies of several
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sorts, and all that concerns Colours; in which no one until now can
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: boast of having succeeded. Finally, there remains much more to be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: investigated touching the nature of Light which I do not pretend to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: have disclosed, and I shall owe much in return to him who shall be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: able to supplement that which is here lacking to me in knowledge. The
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Hague. The 8 January 1690.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: NOTE BY THE TRANSLATOR
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Considering the great influence which this Treatise has exercised in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the development of the Science of Optics, it seems strange that two
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: centuries should have passed before an English edition of the work
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: appeared. Perhaps the circumstance is due to the mistaken zeal with
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which formerly everything that conflicted with the cherished ideas of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Newton was denounced by his followers. The Treatise on Light of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Huygens has, however, withstood the test of time: and even now the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: exquisite skill with which he applied his conception of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: propagation of waves of light to unravel the intricacies of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: phenomena of the double refraction of crystals, and of the refraction
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the atmosphere, will excite the admiration of the student of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Optics. It is true that his wave theory was far from the complete
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: doctrine as subsequently developed by Thomas Young and Augustin
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Fresnel, and belonged rather to geometrical than to physical Optics.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: If Huygens had no conception of transverse vibrations, of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: principle of interference, or of the existence of the ordered sequence
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of waves in trains, he nevertheless attained to a remarkably clear
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: understanding of the principles of wave-propagation; and his
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: exposition of the subject marks an epoch in the treatment of Optical
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: problems. It has been needful in preparing this translation to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: exercise care lest one should import into the author's text ideas of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: subsequent date, by using words that have come to imply modern
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: conceptions. Hence the adoption of as literal a rendering as possible.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: A few of the author's terms need explanation. He uses the word
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: "refraction," for example, both for the phenomenon or process usually
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: so denoted, and for the result of that process: thus the refracted ray
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: he habitually terms "the refraction" of the incident ray. When a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: wave-front, or, as he terms it, a "wave," has passed from some initial
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: position to a subsequent one, he terms the wave-front in its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: subsequent position "the continuation" of the wave. He also speaks of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the envelope of a set of elementary waves, formed by coalescence of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: those elementary wave-fronts, as "the termination" of the wave; and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the elementary wave-fronts he terms "particular" waves. Owing to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: circumstance that the French word _rayon_ possesses the double
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: signification of ray of light and radius of a circle, he avoids its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: use in the latter sense and speaks always of the semi-diameter, not of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the radius. His speculations as to the ether, his suggestive views of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the structure of crystalline bodies, and his explanation of opacity,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: slight as they are, will possibly surprise the reader by their seeming
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: modernness. And none can read his investigation of the phenomena found
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in Iceland spar without marvelling at his insight and sagacity.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: S.P.T.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: June, 1912.

text: CHAPTER I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ON RAYS PROPAGATED IN STRAIGHT LINES
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: As happens in all the sciences in which Geometry is applied to matter,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the demonstrations concerning Optics are founded on truths drawn from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: experience. Such are that the rays of light are propagated in straight
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: lines; that the angles of reflexion and of incidence are equal; and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that in refraction the ray is bent according to the law of sines, now
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: so well known, and which is no less certain than the preceding laws.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: The majority of those who have written touching the various parts of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Optics have contented themselves with presuming these truths. But
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: some, more inquiring, have desired to investigate the origin and the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: causes, considering these to be in themselves wonderful effects of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Nature. In which they advanced some ingenious things, but not however
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: such that the most intelligent folk do not wish for better and more
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: satisfactory explanations. Wherefore I here desire to propound what I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: have meditated on the subject, so as to contribute as much as I can
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to the explanation of this department of Natural Science, which, not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: without reason, is reputed to be one of its most difficult parts. I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: recognize myself to be much indebted to those who were the first to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: begin to dissipate the strange obscurity in which these things were
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: enveloped, and to give us hope that they might be explained by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: intelligible reasoning. But, on the other hand I am astonished also
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that even here these have often been willing to offer, as assured and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: demonstrative, reasonings which were far from conclusive. For I do not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: find that any one has yet given a probable explanation of the first
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and most notable phenomena of light, namely why it is not propagated
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: except in straight lines, and how visible rays, coming from an
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: infinitude of diverse places, cross one another without hindering one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: another in any way.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I shall therefore essay in this book, to give, in accordance with the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: principles accepted in the Philosophy of the present day, some clearer
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and more probable reasons, firstly of these properties of light
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: propagated rectilinearly; secondly of light which is reflected on
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: meeting other bodies. Then I shall explain the phenomena of those rays
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which are said to suffer refraction on passing through transparent
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: bodies of different sorts; and in this part I shall also explain the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: effects of the refraction of the air by the different densities of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Atmosphere.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Thereafter I shall examine the causes of the strange refraction of a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: certain kind of Crystal which is brought from Iceland. And finally I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: shall treat of the various shapes of transparent and reflecting bodies
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: by which rays are collected at a point or are turned aside in various
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ways. From this it will be seen with what facility, following our new
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Theory, we find not only the Ellipses, Hyperbolas, and other curves
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which Mr. Des Cartes has ingeniously invented for this purpose; but
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: also those which the surface of a glass lens ought to possess when its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: other surface is given as spherical or plane, or of any other figure
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that may be.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It is inconceivable to doubt that light consists in the motion of some
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sort of matter. For whether one considers its production, one sees
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that here upon the Earth it is chiefly engendered by fire and flame
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which contain without doubt bodies that are in rapid motion, since
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: they dissolve and melt many other bodies, even the most solid; or
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: whether one considers its effects, one sees that when light is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: collected, as by concave mirrors, it has the property of burning as a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: fire does, that is to say it disunites the particles of bodies. This
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is assuredly the mark of motion, at least in the true Philosophy, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which one conceives the causes of all natural effects in terms of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: mechanical motions. This, in my opinion, we must necessarily do, or
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: else renounce all hopes of ever comprehending anything in Physics.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And as, according to this Philosophy, one holds as certain that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sensation of sight is excited only by the impression of some movement
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of a kind of matter which acts on the nerves at the back of our eyes,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there is here yet one reason more for believing that light consists in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: a movement of the matter which exists between us and the luminous
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: body.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Further, when one considers the extreme speed with which light spreads
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: on every side, and how, when it comes from different regions, even
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: from those directly opposite, the rays traverse one another without
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hindrance, one may well understand that when we see a luminous object,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it cannot be by any transport of matter coming to us from this object,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in the way in which a shot or an arrow traverses the air; for
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: assuredly that would too greatly impugn these two properties of light,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: especially the second of them. It is then in some other way that light
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spreads; and that which can lead us to comprehend it is the knowledge
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which we have of the spreading of Sound in the air.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: We know that by means of the air, which is an invisible and impalpable
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: body, Sound spreads around the spot where it has been produced, by a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: movement which is passed on successively from one part of the air to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: another; and that the spreading of this movement, taking place equally
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rapidly on all sides, ought to form spherical surfaces ever enlarging
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and which strike our ears. Now there is no doubt at all that light
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: also comes from the luminous body to our eyes by some movement
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: impressed on the matter which is between the two; since, as we have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: already seen, it cannot be by the transport of a body which passes
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: from one to the other. If, in addition, light takes time for its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: passage--which we are now going to examine--it will follow that this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: movement, impressed on the intervening matter, is successive; and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: consequently it spreads, as Sound does, by spherical surfaces and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: waves: for I call them waves from their resemblance to those which are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: seen to be formed in water when a stone is thrown into it, and which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: present a successive spreading as circles, though these arise from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: another cause, and are only in a flat surface.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: To see then whether the spreading of light takes time, let us consider
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: first whether there are any facts of experience which can convince us
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to the contrary. As to those which can be made here on the Earth, by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: striking lights at great distances, although they prove that light
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: takes no sensible time to pass over these distances, one may say with
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: good reason that they are too small, and that the only conclusion to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be drawn from them is that the passage of light is extremely rapid.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Mr. Des Cartes, who was of opinion that it is instantaneous, founded
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: his views, not without reason, upon a better basis of experience,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: drawn from the Eclipses of the Moon; which, nevertheless, as I shall
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: show, is not at all convincing. I will set it forth, in a way a little
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: different from his, in order to make the conclusion more
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: comprehensible.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let A be the place of the sun, BD a part of the orbit or annual path
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the Earth: ABC a straight line which I suppose to meet the orbit of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the Moon, which is represented by the circle CD, at C.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now if light requires time, for example one hour, to traverse the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: space which is between the Earth and the Moon, it will follow that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Earth having arrived at B, the shadow which it casts, or the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: interruption of the light, will not yet have arrived at the point C,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: but will only arrive there an hour after. It will then be one hour
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: after, reckoning from the moment when the Earth was at B, that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Moon, arriving at C, will be obscured: but this obscuration or
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: interruption of the light will not reach the Earth till after another
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hour. Let us suppose that the Earth in these two hours will have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: arrived at E. The Earth then, being at E, will see the Eclipsed Moon
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: at C, which it left an hour before, and at the same time will see the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sun at A. For it being immovable, as I suppose with Copernicus, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the light moving always in straight lines, it must always appear where
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it is. But one has always observed, we are told, that the eclipsed
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Moon appears at the point of the Ecliptic opposite to the Sun; and yet
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: here it would appear in arrear of that point by an amount equal to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angle GEC, the supplement of AEC. This, however, is contrary to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: experience, since the angle GEC would be very sensible, and about 33
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: degrees. Now according to our computation, which is given in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Treatise on the causes of the phenomena of Saturn, the distance BA
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: between the Earth and the Sun is about twelve thousand diameters of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the Earth, and hence four hundred times greater than BC the distance
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the Moon, which is 30 diameters. Then the angle ECB will be nearly
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: four hundred times greater than BAE, which is five minutes; namely,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the path which the earth travels in two hours along its orbit; and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: thus the angle BCE will be nearly 33 degrees; and likewise the angle
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CEG, which is greater by five minutes.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But it must be noted that the speed of light in this argument has been
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: assumed such that it takes a time of one hour to make the passage from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: here to the Moon. If one supposes that for this it requires only one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: minute of time, then it is manifest that the angle CEG will only be 33
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: minutes; and if it requires only ten seconds of time, the angle will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be less than six minutes. And then it will not be easy to perceive
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: anything of it in observations of the Eclipse; nor, consequently, will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it be permissible to deduce from it that the movement of light is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: instantaneous.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It is true that we are here supposing a strange velocity that would be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: a hundred thousand times greater than that of Sound. For Sound,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: according to what I have observed, travels about 180 Toises in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: time of one Second, or in about one beat of the pulse. But this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: supposition ought not to seem to be an impossibility; since it is not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: a question of the transport of a body with so great a speed, but of a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: successive movement which is passed on from some bodies to others. I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: have then made no difficulty, in meditating on these things, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: supposing that the emanation of light is accomplished with time,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: seeing that in this way all its phenomena can be explained, and that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in following the contrary opinion everything is incomprehensible. For
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it has always seemed tome that even Mr. Des Cartes, whose aim has been
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to treat all the subjects of Physics intelligibly, and who assuredly
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: has succeeded in this better than any one before him, has said nothing
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that is not full of difficulties, or even inconceivable, in dealing
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: with Light and its properties.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But that which I employed only as a hypothesis, has recently received
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: great seemingness as an established truth by the ingenious proof of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Mr. Roemer which I am going here to relate, expecting him himself to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: give all that is needed for its confirmation. It is founded as is the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: preceding argument upon celestial observations, and proves not only
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that Light takes time for its passage, but also demonstrates how much
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: time it takes, and that its velocity is even at least six times
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: greater than that which I have just stated.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: For this he makes use of the Eclipses suffered by the little planets
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which revolve around Jupiter, and which often enter his shadow: and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: see what is his reasoning. Let A be the Sun, BCDE the annual orbit of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the Earth, F Jupiter, GN the orbit of the nearest of his Satellites,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: for it is this one which is more apt for this investigation than any
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the other three, because of the quickness of its revolution. Let G
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be this Satellite entering into the shadow of Jupiter, H the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Satellite emerging from the shadow.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let it be then supposed, the Earth being at B some time before the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: last quadrature, that one has seen the said Satellite emerge from the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: shadow; it must needs be, if the Earth remains at the same place,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that, after 42-1/2 hours, one would again see a similar emergence,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: because that is the time in which it makes the round of its orbit, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: when it would come again into opposition to the Sun. And if the Earth,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: for instance, were to remain always at B during 30 revolutions of this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Satellite, one would see it again emerge from the shadow after 30
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: times 42-1/2 hours. But the Earth having been carried along during
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this time to C, increasing thus its distance from Jupiter, it follows
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that if Light requires time for its passage the illumination of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: little planet will be perceived later at C than it would have been at
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: B, and that there must be added to this time of 30 times 42-1/2 hours
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that which the Light has required to traverse the space MC, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: difference of the spaces CH, BH. Similarly at the other quadrature
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: when the earth has come to E from D while approaching toward Jupiter,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the immersions of the Satellite ought to be observed at E earlier than
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: they would have been seen if the Earth had remained at D.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now in quantities of observations of these Eclipses, made during ten
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: consecutive years, these differences have been found to be very
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: considerable, such as ten minutes and more; and from them it has been
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: concluded that in order to traverse the whole diameter of the annual
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: orbit KL, which is double the distance from here to the sun, Light
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: requires about 22 minutes of time.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: The movement of Jupiter in his orbit while the Earth passed from B to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: C, or from D to E, is included in this calculation; and this makes it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: evident that one cannot attribute the retardation of these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: illuminations or the anticipation of the eclipses, either to any
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: irregularity occurring in the movement of the little planet or to its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: eccentricity.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: If one considers the vast size of the diameter KL, which according to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: me is some 24 thousand diameters of the Earth, one will acknowledge
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the extreme velocity of Light. For, supposing that KL is no more than
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 22 thousand of these diameters, it appears that being traversed in 22
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: minutes this makes the speed a thousand diameters in one minute, that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is 16-2/3 diameters in one second or in one beat of the pulse, which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: makes more than 11 hundred times a hundred thousand toises; since the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: diameter of the Earth contains 2,865 leagues, reckoned at 25 to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: degree, and each each league is 2,282 Toises, according to the exact
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: measurement which Mr. Picard made by order of the King in 1669. But
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Sound, as I have said above, only travels 180 toises in the same time
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of one second: hence the velocity of Light is more than six hundred
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: thousand times greater than that of Sound. This, however, is quite
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: another thing from being instantaneous, since there is all the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: difference between a finite thing and an infinite. Now the successive
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: movement of Light being confirmed in this way, it follows, as I have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: said, that it spreads by spherical waves, like the movement of Sound.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But if the one resembles the other in this respect, they differ in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: many other things; to wit, in the first production of the movement
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which causes them; in the matter in which the movement spreads; and in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the manner in which it is propagated. As to that which occurs in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: production of Sound, one knows that it is occasioned by the agitation
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: undergone by an entire body, or by a considerable part of one, which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: shakes all the contiguous air. But the movement of the Light must
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: originate as from each point of the luminous object, else we should
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: not be able to perceive all the different parts of that object, as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will be more evident in that which follows. And I do not believe that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this movement can be better explained than by supposing that all those
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the luminous bodies which are liquid, such as flames, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: apparently the sun and the stars, are composed of particles which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: float in a much more subtle medium which agitates them with great
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rapidity, and makes them strike against the particles of the ether
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which surrounds them, and which are much smaller than they. But I hold
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: also that in luminous solids such as charcoal or metal made red hot in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the fire, this same movement is caused by the violent agitation of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the particles of the metal or of the wood; those of them which are on
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the surface striking similarly against the ethereal matter. The
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: agitation, moreover, of the particles which engender the light ought
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to be much more prompt and more rapid than is that of the bodies which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: cause sound, since we do not see that the tremors of a body which is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: giving out a sound are capable of giving rise to Light, even as the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: movement of the hand in the air is not capable of producing Sound.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now if one examines what this matter may be in which the movement
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: coming from the luminous body is propagated, which I call Ethereal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: matter, one will see that it is not the same that serves for the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: propagation of Sound. For one finds that the latter is really that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which we feel and which we breathe, and which being removed from any
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: place still leaves there the other kind of matter that serves to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: convey Light. This may be proved by shutting up a sounding body in a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: glass vessel from which the air is withdrawn by the machine which Mr.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Boyle has given us, and with which he has performed so many beautiful
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: experiments. But in doing this of which I speak, care must be taken to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: place the sounding body on cotton or on feathers, in such a way that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it cannot communicate its tremors either to the glass vessel which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: encloses it, or to the machine; a precaution which has hitherto been
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: neglected. For then after having exhausted all the air one hears no
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Sound from the metal, though it is struck.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: One sees here not only that our air, which does not penetrate through
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: glass, is the matter by which Sound spreads; but also that it is not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the same air but another kind of matter in which Light spreads; since
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: if the air is removed from the vessel the Light does not cease to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: traverse it as before.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And this last point is demonstrated even more clearly by the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: celebrated experiment of Torricelli, in which the tube of glass from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which the quicksilver has withdrawn itself, remaining void of air,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transmits Light just the same as when air is in it. For this proves
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that a matter different from air exists in this tube, and that this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: matter must have penetrated the glass or the quicksilver, either one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: or the other, though they are both impenetrable to the air. And when,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in the same experiment, one makes the vacuum after putting a little
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: water above the quicksilver, one concludes equally that the said
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: matter passes through glass or water, or through both.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: As regards the different modes in which I have said the movements of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Sound and of Light are communicated, one may sufficiently comprehend
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: how this occurs in the case of Sound if one considers that the air is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of such a nature that it can be compressed and reduced to a much
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: smaller space than that which it ordinarily occupies. And in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: proportion as it is compressed the more does it exert an effort to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: regain its volume; for this property along with its penetrability,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which remains notwithstanding its compression, seems to prove that it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is made up of small bodies which float about and which are agitated
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: very rapidly in the ethereal matter composed of much smaller parts. So
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that the cause of the spreading of Sound is the effort which these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: little bodies make in collisions with one another, to regain freedom
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: when they are a little more squeezed together in the circuit of these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: waves than elsewhere.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But the extreme velocity of Light, and other properties which it has,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: cannot admit of such a propagation of motion, and I am about to show
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: here the way in which I conceive it must occur. For this, it is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: needful to explain the property which hard bodies must possess to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transmit movement from one to another.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: When one takes a number of spheres of equal size, made of some very
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hard substance, and arranges them in a straight line, so that they
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: touch one another, one finds, on striking with a similar sphere
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: against the first of these spheres, that the motion passes as in an
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: instant to the last of them, which separates itself from the row,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: without one's being able to perceive that the others have been
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: stirred. And even that one which was used to strike remains motionless
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: with them. Whence one sees that the movement passes with an extreme
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: velocity which is the greater, the greater the hardness of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: substance of the spheres.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But it is still certain that this progression of motion is not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: instantaneous, but successive, and therefore must take time. For if
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the movement, or the disposition to movement, if you will have it so,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: did not pass successively through all these spheres, they would all
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: acquire the movement at the same time, and hence would all advance
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: together; which does not happen. For the last one leaves the whole row
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and acquires the speed of the one which was pushed. Moreover there are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: experiments which demonstrate that all the bodies which we reckon of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the hardest kind, such as quenched steel, glass, and agate, act as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: springs and bend somehow, not only when extended as rods but also when
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: they are in the form of spheres or of other shapes. That is to say
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: they yield a little in themselves at the place where they are struck,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and immediately regain their former figure. For I have found that on
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: striking with a ball of glass or of agate against a large and quite
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: thick thick piece of the same substance which had a flat surface,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: slightly soiled with breath or in some other way, there remained round
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: marks, of smaller or larger size according as the blow had been weak
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: or strong. This makes it evident that these substances yield where
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: they meet, and spring back: and for this time must be required.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now in applying this kind of movement to that which produces Light
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there is nothing to hinder us from estimating the particles of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ether to be of a substance as nearly approaching to perfect hardness
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and possessing a springiness as prompt as we choose. It is not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: necessary to examine here the causes of this hardness, or of that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: springiness, the consideration of which would lead us too far from our
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: subject. I will say, however, in passing that we may conceive that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particles of the ether, notwithstanding their smallness, are in turn
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: composed of other parts and that their springiness consists in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: very rapid movement of a subtle matter which penetrates them from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: every side and constrains their structure to assume such a disposition
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: as to give to this fluid matter the most overt and easy passage
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: possible. This accords with the explanation which Mr. Des Cartes gives
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: for the spring, though I do not, like him, suppose the pores to be in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the form of round hollow canals. And it must not be thought that in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this there is anything absurd or impossible, it being on the contrary
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: quite credible that it is this infinite series of different sizes of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: corpuscles, having different degrees of velocity, of which Nature
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: makes use to produce so many marvellous effects.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But though we shall ignore the true cause of springiness we still see
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that there are many bodies which possess this property; and thus there
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is nothing strange in supposing that it exists also in little
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: invisible bodies like the particles of the Ether. Also if one wishes
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to seek for any other way in which the movement of Light is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: successively communicated, one will find none which agrees better,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: with uniform progression, as seems to be necessary, than the property
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of springiness; because if this movement should grow slower in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: proportion as it is shared over a greater quantity of matter, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: moving away from the source of the light, it could not conserve this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: great velocity over great distances. But by supposing springiness in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the ethereal matter, its particles will have the property of equally
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rapid restitution whether they are pushed strongly or feebly; and thus
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the propagation of Light will always go on with an equal velocity.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And it must be known that although the particles of the ether are not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ranged thus in straight lines, as in our row of spheres, but
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: confusedly, so that one of them touches several others, this does not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hinder them from transmitting their movement and from spreading it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: always forward. As to this it is to be remarked that there is a law of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: motion serving for this propagation, and verifiable by experiment. It
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is that when a sphere, such as A here, touches several other similar
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheres CCC, if it is struck by another sphere B in such a way as to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: exert an impulse against all the spheres CCC which touch it, it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transmits to them the whole of its movement, and remains after that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: motionless like the sphere B. And without supposing that the ethereal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particles are of spherical form (for I see indeed no need to suppose
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: them so) one may well understand that this property of communicating
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: an impulse does not fail to contribute to the aforesaid propagation
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of movement.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Equality of size seems to be more necessary, because otherwise there
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ought to be some reflexion of movement backwards when it passes from a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: smaller particle to a larger one, according to the Laws of Percussion
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which I published some years ago.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: However, one will see hereafter that we have to suppose such an
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equality not so much as a necessity for the propagation of light as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: for rendering that propagation easier and more powerful; for it is not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: beyond the limits of probability that the particles of the ether have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: been made equal for a purpose so important as that of light, at least
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in that vast space which is beyond the region of atmosphere and which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: seems to serve only to transmit the light of the Sun and the Stars.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I have then shown in what manner one may conceive Light to spread
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: successively, by spherical waves, and how it is possible that this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spreading is accomplished with as great a velocity as that which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: experiments and celestial observations demand. Whence it may be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: further remarked that although the particles are supposed to be in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: continual movement (for there are many reasons for this) the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: successive propagation of the waves cannot be hindered by this;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: because the propagation consists nowise in the transport of those
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particles but merely in a small agitation which they cannot help
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: communicating to those surrounding, notwithstanding any movement which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: may act on them causing them to be changing positions amongst
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: themselves.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But we must consider still more particularly the origin of these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: waves, and the manner in which they spread. And, first, it follows
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: from what has been said on the production of Light, that each little
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: region of a luminous body, such as the Sun, a candle, or a burning
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: coal, generates its own waves of which that region is the centre. Thus
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in the flame of a candle, having distinguished the points A, B, C,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: concentric circles described about each of these points represent the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: waves which come from them. And one must imagine the same about every
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: point of the surface and of the part within the flame.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But as the percussions at the centres of these waves possess no
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: regular succession, it must not be supposed that the waves themselves
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: follow one another at equal distances: and if the distances marked in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the figure appear to be such, it is rather to mark the progression of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: one and the same wave at equal intervals of time than to represent
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: several of them issuing from one and the same centre.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: After all, this prodigious quantity of waves which traverse one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: another without confusion and without effacing one another must not be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: deemed inconceivable; it being certain that one and the same particle
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of matter can serve for many waves coming from different sides or even
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: from contrary directions, not only if it is struck by blows which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: follow one another closely but even for those which act on it at the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: same instant. It can do so because the spreading of the movement is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: successive. This may be proved by the row of equal spheres of hard
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: matter, spoken of above. If against this row there are pushed from two
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: opposite sides at the same time two similar spheres A and D, one will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: see each of them rebound with the same velocity which it had in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: striking, yet the whole row will remain in its place, although the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: movement has passed along its whole length twice over. And if these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: contrary movements happen to meet one another at the middle sphere, B,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: or at some other such as C, that sphere will yield and act as a spring
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: at both sides, and so will serve at the same instant to transmit these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: two movements.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But what may at first appear full strange and even incredible is that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the undulations produced by such small movements and corpuscles,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: should spread to such immense distances; as for example from the Sun
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: or from the Stars to us. For the force of these waves must grow feeble
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in proportion as they move away from their origin, so that the action
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of each one in particular will without doubt become incapable of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: making itself felt to our sight. But one will cease to be astonished
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: by considering how at a great distance from the luminous body an
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: infinitude of waves, though they have issued from different points of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this body, unite together in such a way that they sensibly compose one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: single wave only, which, consequently, ought to have enough force to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: make itself felt. Thus this infinite number of waves which originate
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: at the same instant from all points of a fixed star, big it may be as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the Sun, make practically only one single wave which may well have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: force enough to produce an impression on our eyes. Moreover from each
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: luminous point there may come many thousands of waves in the smallest
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: imaginable time, by the frequent percussion of the corpuscles which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: strike the Ether at these points: which further contributes to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rendering their action more sensible.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: There is the further consideration in the emanation of these waves,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that each particle of matter in which a wave spreads, ought not to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: communicate its motion only to the next particle which is in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight line drawn from the luminous point, but that it also imparts
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: some of it necessarily to all the others which touch it and which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: oppose themselves to its movement. So it arises that around each
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particle there is made a wave of which that particle is the centre.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Thus if DCF is a wave emanating from the luminous point A, which is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: its centre, the particle B, one of those comprised within the sphere
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: DCF, will have made its particular or partial wave KCL, which will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: touch the wave DCF at C at the same moment that the principal wave
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: emanating from the point A has arrived at DCF; and it is clear that it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will be only the region C of the wave KCL which will touch the wave
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: DCF, to wit, that which is in the straight line drawn through AB.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Similarly the other particles of the sphere DCF, such as _bb_, _dd_,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: etc., will each make its own wave. But each of these waves can be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: infinitely feeble only as compared with the wave DCF, to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: composition of which all the others contribute by the part of their
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surface which is most distant from the centre A.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: One sees, in addition, that the wave DCF is determined by the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: distance attained in a certain space of time by the movement which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: started from the point A; there being no movement beyond this wave,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: though there will be in the space which it encloses, namely in parts
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the particular waves, those parts which do not touch the sphere
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: DCF. And all this ought not to seem fraught with too much minuteness
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: or subtlety, since we shall see in the sequel that all the properties
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of Light, and everything pertaining to its reflexion and its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction, can be explained in principle by this means. This is a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: matter which has been quite unknown to those who hitherto have begun
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to consider the waves of light, amongst whom are Mr. Hooke in his
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: _Micrographia_, and Father Pardies, who, in a treatise of which he let
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: me see a portion, and which he was unable to complete as he died
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: shortly afterward, had undertaken to prove by these waves the effects
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of reflexion and refraction. But the chief foundation, which consists
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in the remark I have just made, was lacking in his demonstrations; and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: for the rest he had opinions very different from mine, as may be will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: appear some day if his writing has been preserved.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: To come to the properties of Light. We remark first that each portion
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of a wave ought to spread in such a way that its extremities lie
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: always between the same straight lines drawn from the luminous point.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Thus the portion BG of the wave, having the luminous point A as its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: centre, will spread into the arc CE bounded by the straight lines ABC,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AGE. For although the particular waves produced by the particles
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: comprised within the space CAE spread also outside this space, they
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: yet do not concur at the same instant to compose a wave which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: terminates the movement, as they do precisely at the circumference
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CE, which is their common tangent.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And hence one sees the reason why light, at least if its rays are not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reflected or broken, spreads only by straight lines, so that it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: illuminates no object except when the path from its source to that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: object is open along such lines.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: For if, for example, there were an opening BG, limited by opaque
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: bodies BH, GI, the wave of light which issues from the point A will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: always be terminated by the straight lines AC, AE, as has just been
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: shown; the parts of the partial waves which spread outside the space
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ACE being too feeble to produce light there.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now, however small we make the opening BG, there is always the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reason causing the light there to pass between straight lines; since
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this opening is always large enough to contain a great number of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particles of the ethereal matter, which are of an inconceivable
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: smallness; so that it appears that each little portion of the wave
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: necessarily advances following the straight line which comes from the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: luminous point. Thus then we may take the rays of light as if they
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: were straight lines.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It appears, moreover, by what has been remarked touching the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: feebleness of the particular waves, that it is not needful that all
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the particles of the Ether should be equal amongst themselves, though
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equality is more apt for the propagation of the movement. For it is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: true that inequality will cause a particle by pushing against another
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: larger one to strive to recoil with a part of its movement; but it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will thereby merely generate backwards towards the luminous point some
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: partial waves incapable of causing light, and not a wave compounded of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: many as CE was.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Another property of waves of light, and one of the most marvellous,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is that when some of them come from different or even from opposing
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sides, they produce their effect across one another without any
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hindrance. Whence also it comes about that a number of spectators may
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: view different objects at the same time through the same opening, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that two persons can at the same time see one another's eyes. Now
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: according to the explanation which has been given of the action of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: light, how the waves do not destroy nor interrupt one another when
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: they cross one another, these effects which I have just mentioned are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: easily conceived. But in my judgement they are not at all easy to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: explain according to the views of Mr. Des Cartes, who makes Light to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: consist in a continuous pressure merely tending to movement. For this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: pressure not being able to act from two opposite sides at the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: time, against bodies which have no inclination to approach one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: another, it is impossible so to understand what I have been saying
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: about two persons mutually seeing one another's eyes, or how two
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: torches can illuminate one another.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CHAPTER II
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ON REFLEXION
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Having explained the effects of waves of light which spread in a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: homogeneous matter, we will examine next that which happens to them on
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: encountering other bodies. We will first make evident how the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Reflexion of light is explained by these same waves, and why it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: preserves equality of angles.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let there be a surface AB; plane and polished, of some metal, glass,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: or other body, which at first I will consider as perfectly uniform
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: (reserving to myself to deal at the end of this demonstration with the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: inequalities from which it cannot be exempt), and let a line AC,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: inclined to AD, represent a portion of a wave of light, the centre of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which is so distant that this portion AC may be considered as a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight line; for I consider all this as in one plane, imagining to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: myself that the plane in which this figure is, cuts the sphere of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: wave through its centre and intersects the plane AB at right angles.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: This explanation will suffice once for all.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: The piece C of the wave AC, will in a certain space of time advance as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: far as the plane AB at B, following the straight line CB, which may be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: supposed to come from the luminous centre, and which in consequence is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to AC. Now in this same space of time the portion A of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the same wave, which has been hindered from communicating its movement
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: beyond the plane AB, or at least partly so, ought to have continued
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: its movement in the matter which is above this plane, and this along a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: distance equal to CB, making its own partial spherical wave,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: according to what has been said above. Which wave is here represented
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: by the circumference SNR, the centre of which is A, and its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: semi-diameter AN equal to CB.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: If one considers further the other pieces H of the wave AC, it appears
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that they will not only have reached the surface AB by straight lines
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: HK parallel to CB, but that in addition they will have generated in
author: Huygens, Christiaan
