text: the transparent air, from the centres K, K, K, particular spherical
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: waves, represented here by circumferences the semi-diameters of which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: are equal to KM, that is to say to the continuations of HK as far as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the line BG parallel to AC. But all these circumferences have as a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: common tangent the straight line BN, namely the same which is drawn
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: from B as a tangent to the first of the circles, of which A is the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: centre, and AN the semi-diameter equal to BC, as is easy to see.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It is then the line BN (comprised between B and the point N where the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular from the point A falls) which is as it were formed by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: all these circumferences, and which terminates the movement which is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: made by the reflexion of the wave AC; and it is also the place where
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the movement occurs in much greater quantity than anywhere else.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Wherefore, according to that which has been explained, BN is the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: propagation of the wave AC at the moment when the piece C of it has
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: arrived at B. For there is no other line which like BN is a common
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: tangent to all the aforesaid circles, except BG below the plane AB;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which line BG would be the propagation of the wave if the movement
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: could have spread in a medium homogeneous with that which is above the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: plane. And if one wishes to see how the wave AC has come successively
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to BN, one has only to draw in the same figure the straight lines KO
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parallel to BN, and the straight lines KL parallel to AC. Thus one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will see that the straight wave AC has become broken up into all the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: OKL parts successively, and that it has become straight again at NB.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now it is apparent here that the angle of reflexion is made equal to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the angle of incidence. For the triangles ACB, BNA being rectangular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and having the side AB common, and the side CB equal to NA, it follows
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that the angles opposite to these sides will be equal, and therefore
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: also the angles CBA, NAB. But as CB, perpendicular to CA, marks the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: direction of the incident ray, so AN, perpendicular to the wave BN,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: marks the direction of the reflected ray; hence these rays are equally
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: inclined to the plane AB.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But in considering the preceding demonstration, one might aver that it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is indeed true that BN is the common tangent of the circular waves in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the plane of this figure, but that these waves, being in truth
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spherical, have still an infinitude of similar tangents, namely all
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the straight lines which are drawn from the point B in the surface
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: generated by the straight line BN about the axis BA. It remains,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: therefore, to demonstrate that there is no difficulty herein: and by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the same argument one will see why the incident ray and the reflected
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ray are always in one and the same plane perpendicular to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reflecting plane. I say then that the wave AC, being regarded only as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: a line, produces no light. For a visible ray of light, however narrow
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it may be, has always some width, and consequently it is necessary, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: representing the wave whose progression constitutes the ray, to put
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: instead of a line AC some plane figure such as the circle HC in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: following figure, by supposing, as we have done, the luminous point to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be infinitely distant. Now it is easy to see, following the preceding
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: demonstration, that each small piece of this wave HC having arrived at
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the plane AB, and there generating each one its particular wave, these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will all have, when C arrives at B, a common plane which will touch
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: them, namely a circle BN similar to CH; and this will be intersected
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: at its middle and at right angles by the same plane which likewise
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: intersects the circle CH and the ellipse AB.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: One sees also that the said spheres of the partial waves cannot have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: any common tangent plane other than the circle BN; so that it will be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this plane where there will be more reflected movement than anywhere
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: else, and which will therefore carry on the light in continuance from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the wave CH.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I have also stated in the preceding demonstration that the movement of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the piece A of the incident wave is not able to communicate itself
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: beyond the plane AB, or at least not wholly. Whence it is to be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: remarked that though the movement of the ethereal matter might
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: communicate itself partly to that of the reflecting body, this could
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in nothing alter the velocity of progression of the waves, on which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the angle of reflexion depends. For a slight percussion ought to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: generate waves as rapid as strong percussion in the same matter. This
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: comes about from the property of bodies which act as springs, of which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: we have spoken above; namely that whether compressed little or much
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: they recoil in equal times. Equally so in every reflexion of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: light, against whatever body it may be, the angles of reflexion and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: incidence ought to be equal notwithstanding that the body might be of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: such a nature that it takes away a portion of the movement made by the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: incident light. And experiment shows that in fact there is no polished
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: body the reflexion of which does not follow this rule.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But the thing to be above all remarked in our demonstration is that it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: does not require that the reflecting surface should be considered as a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: uniform plane, as has been supposed by all those who have tried to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: explain the effects of reflexion; but only an evenness such as may be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: attained by the particles of the matter of the reflecting body being
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: set near to one another; which particles are larger than those of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ethereal matter, as will appear by what we shall say in treating of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the transparency and opacity of bodies. For the surface consisting
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: thus of particles put together, and the ethereal particles being
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: above, and smaller, it is evident that one could not demonstrate the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equality of the angles of incidence and reflexion by similitude to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that which happens to a ball thrown against a wall, of which writers
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: have always made use. In our way, on the other hand, the thing is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: explained without difficulty. For the smallness of the particles of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: quicksilver, for example, being such that one must conceive millions
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of them, in the smallest visible surface proposed, arranged like a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: heap of grains of sand which has been flattened as much as it is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: capable of being, this surface then becomes for our purpose as even
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: as a polished glass is: and, although it always remains rough with
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: respect to the particles of the Ether it is evident that the centres
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of all the particular spheres of reflexion, of which we have spoken,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: are almost in one uniform plane, and that thus the common tangent can
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: fit to them as perfectly as is requisite for the production of light.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And this alone is requisite, in our method of demonstration, to cause
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equality of the said angles without the remainder of the movement
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reflected from all parts being able to produce any contrary effect.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CHAPTER III
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ON REFRACTION
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: In the same way as the effects of Reflexion have been explained by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: waves of light reflected at the surface of polished bodies, we will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: explain transparency and the phenomena of refraction by waves which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spread within and across diaphanous bodies, both solids, such as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: glass, and liquids, such as water, oils, etc. But in order that it may
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: not seem strange to suppose this passage of waves in the interior of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: these bodies, I will first show that one may conceive it possible in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: more than one mode.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: First, then, if the ethereal matter cannot penetrate transparent
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: bodies at all, their own particles would be able to communicate
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: successively the movement of the waves, the same as do those of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Ether, supposing that, like those, they are of a nature to act as a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spring. And this is easy to conceive as regards water and other
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparent liquids, they being composed of detached particles. But it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: may seem more difficult as regards glass and other transparent and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hard bodies, because their solidity does not seem to permit them to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: receive movement except in their whole mass at the same time. This,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: however, is not necessary because this solidity is not such as it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: appears to us, it being probable rather that these bodies are composed
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of particles merely placed close to one another and held together by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: some pressure from without of some other matter, and by the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: irregularity of their shapes. For primarily their rarity is shown by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the facility with which there passes through them the matter of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: vortices of the magnet, and that which causes gravity. Further, one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: cannot say that these bodies are of a texture similar to that of a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sponge or of light bread, because the heat of the fire makes them flow
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and thereby changes the situation of the particles amongst themselves.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It remains then that they are, as has been said, assemblages of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particles which touch one another without constituting a continuous
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: solid. This being so, the movement which these particles receive to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: carry on the waves of light, being merely communicated from some of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: them to others, without their going for that purpose out of their
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: places or without derangement, it may very well produce its effect
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: without prejudicing in any way the apparent solidity of the compound.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: By pressure from without, of which I have spoken, must not be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: understood that of the air, which would not be sufficient, but that of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: some other more subtle matter, a pressure which I chanced upon by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: experiment long ago, namely in the case of water freed from air, which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: remains suspended in a tube open at its lower end, notwithstanding
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that the air has been removed from the vessel in which this tube is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: enclosed.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: One can then in this way conceive of transparency in a solid without
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: any necessity that the ethereal matter which serves for light should
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: pass through it, or that it should find pores in which to insinuate
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: itself. But the truth is that this matter not only passes through
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: solids, but does so even with great facility; of which the experiment
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of Torricelli, above cited, is already a proof. Because on the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: quicksilver and the water quitting the upper part of the glass tube,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it appears that it is immediately filled with ethereal matter, since
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: light passes across it. But here is another argument which proves this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ready penetrability, not only in transparent bodies but also in all
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: others.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: When light passes across a hollow sphere of glass, closed on all
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sides, it is certain that it is full of ethereal matter, as much as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the spaces outside the sphere. And this ethereal matter, as has been
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: shown above, consists of particles which just touch one another. If
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: then it were enclosed in the sphere in such a way that it could not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: get out through the pores of the glass, it would be obliged to follow
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the movement of the sphere when one changes its place: and it would
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: require consequently almost the same force to impress a certain
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: velocity on this sphere, when placed on a horizontal plane, as if it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: were full of water or perhaps of quicksilver: because every body
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: resists the velocity of the motion which one would give to it, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: proportion to the quantity of matter which it contains, and which is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: obliged to follow this motion. But on the contrary one finds that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sphere resists the impress of movement only in proportion to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: quantity of matter of the glass of which it is made. Then it must be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that the ethereal matter which is inside is not shut up, but flows
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: through it with very great freedom. We shall demonstrate hereafter
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that by this process the same penetrability may be inferred also as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: relating to opaque bodies.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: The second mode then of explaining transparency, and one which appears
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: more probably true, is by saying that the waves of light are carried
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: on in the ethereal matter, which continuously occupies the interstices
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: or pores of transparent bodies. For since it passes through them
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: continuously and freely, it follows that they are always full of it.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And one may even show that these interstices occupy much more space
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: than the coherent particles which constitute the bodies. For if what
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: we have just said is true: that force is required to impress a certain
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: horizontal velocity on bodies in proportion as they contain coherent
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: matter; and if the proportion of this force follows the law of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: weights, as is confirmed by experiment, then the quantity of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: constituent matter of bodies also follows the proportion of their
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: weights. Now we see that water weighs only one fourteenth part as much
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: as an equal portion of quicksilver: therefore the matter of the water
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: does not occupy the fourteenth part of the space which its mass
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: obtains. It must even occupy much less of it, since quicksilver is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: less heavy than gold, and the matter of gold is by no means dense, as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: follows from the fact that the matter of the vortices of the magnet
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and of that which is the cause of gravity pass very freely through it.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But it may be objected here that if water is a body of so great
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rarity, and if its particles occupy so small a portion of the space of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: its apparent bulk, it is very strange how it yet resists Compression
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: so strongly without permitting itself to be condensed by any force
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which one has hitherto essayed to employ, preserving even its entire
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: liquidity while subjected to this pressure.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: This is no small difficulty. It may, however, be resolved by saying
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that the very violent and rapid motion of the subtle matter which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: renders water liquid, by agitating the particles of which it is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: composed, maintains this liquidity in spite of the pressure which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hitherto any one has been minded to apply to it.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: The rarity of transparent bodies being then such as we have said, one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: easily conceives that the waves might be carried on in the ethereal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: matter which fills the interstices of the particles. And, moreover,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: one may believe that the progression of these waves ought to be a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: little slower in the interior of bodies, by reason of the small
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: detours which the same particles cause. In which different velocity of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: light I shall show the cause of refraction to consist.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Before doing so, I will indicate the third and last mode in which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparency may be conceived; which is by supposing that the movement
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the waves of light is transmitted indifferently both in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particles of the ethereal matter which occupy the interstices of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: bodies, and in the particles which compose them, so that the movement
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: passes from one to the other. And it will be seen hereafter that this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hypothesis serves excellently to explain the double refraction of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: certain transparent bodies.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Should it be objected that if the particles of the ether are smaller
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: than those of transparent bodies (since they pass through their
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: intervals), it would follow that they can communicate to them but
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: little of their movement, it may be replied that the particles of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: these bodies are in turn composed of still smaller particles, and so
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it will be these secondary particles which will receive the movement
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: from those of the ether.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Furthermore, if the particles of transparent bodies have a recoil a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: little less prompt than that of the ethereal particles, which nothing
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hinders us from supposing, it will again follow that the progression
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the waves of light will be slower in the interior of such bodies
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: than it is outside in the ethereal matter.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: All this I have found as most probable for the mode in which the waves
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of light pass across transparent bodies. To which it must further be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: added in what respect these bodies differ from those which are opaque;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and the more so since it might seem because of the easy penetration of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: bodies by the ethereal matter, of which mention has been made, that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there would not be any body that was not transparent. For by the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reasoning about the hollow sphere which I have employed to prove the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: smallness of the density of glass and its easy penetrability by the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ethereal matter, one might also prove that the same penetrability
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: obtains for metals and for every other sort of body. For this sphere
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: being for example of silver, it is certain that it contains some of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the ethereal matter which serves for light, since this was there as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: well as in the air when the opening of the sphere was closed. Yet,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: being closed and placed upon a horizontal plane, it resists the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: movement which one wishes to give to it, merely according to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: quantity of silver of which it is made; so that one must conclude, as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: above, that the ethereal matter which is enclosed does not follow the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: movement of the sphere; and that therefore silver, as well as glass,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is very easily penetrated by this matter. Some of it is therefore
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: present continuously and in quantities between the particles of silver
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and of all other opaque bodies: and since it serves for the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: propagation of light it would seem that these bodies ought also to be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparent, which however is not the case.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Whence then, one will say, does their opacity come? Is it because the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particles which compose them are soft; that is to say, these particles
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: being composed of others that are smaller, are they capable of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: changing their figure on receiving the pressure of the ethereal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particles, the motion of which they thereby damp, and so hinder the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: continuance of the waves of light? That cannot be: for if the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particles of the metals are soft, how is it that polished silver and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: mercury reflect light so strongly? What I find to be most probable
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: herein, is to say that metallic bodies, which are almost the only
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: really opaque ones, have mixed amongst their hard particles some soft
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ones; so that some serve to cause reflexion and the others to hinder
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparency; while, on the other hand, transparent bodies contain
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: only hard particles which have the faculty of recoil, and serve
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: together with those of the ethereal matter for the propagation of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: waves of light, as has been said.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let us pass now to the explanation of the effects of Refraction,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: assuming, as we have done, the passage of waves of light through
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparent bodies, and the diminution of velocity which these same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: waves suffer in them.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: The chief property of Refraction is that a ray of light, such as AB,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: being in the air, and falling obliquely upon the polished surface of a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparent body, such as FG, is broken at the point of incidence B,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in such a way that with the straight line DBE which cuts the surface
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicularly it makes an angle CBE less than ABD which it made with
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the same perpendicular when in the air. And the measure of these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angles is found by describing, about the point B, a circle which cuts
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the radii AB, BC. For the perpendiculars AD, CE, let fall from the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: points of intersection upon the straight line DE, which are called the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Sines of the angles ABD, CBE, have a certain ratio between themselves;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which ratio is always the same for all inclinations of the incident
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ray, at least for a given transparent body. This ratio is, in glass,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: very nearly as 3 to 2; and in water very nearly as 4 to 3; and is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: likewise different in other diaphanous bodies.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Another property, similar to this, is that the refractions are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reciprocal between the rays entering into a transparent body and those
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which are leaving it. That is to say that if the ray AB in entering
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the transparent body is refracted into BC, then likewise CB being
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: taken as a ray in the interior of this body will be refracted, on
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: passing out, into BA.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: To explain then the reasons of these phenomena according to our
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: principles, let AB be the straight line which represents a plane
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surface bounding the transparent substances which lie towards C and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: towards N. When I say plane, that does not signify a perfect evenness,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: but such as has been understood in treating of reflexion, and for the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: same reason. Let the line AC represent a portion of a wave of light,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the centre of which is supposed so distant that this portion may be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: considered as a straight line. The piece C, then, of the wave AC, will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in a certain space of time have advanced as far as the plane AB
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: following the straight line CB, which may be imagined as coming from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the luminous centre, and which consequently will cut AC at right
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angles. Now in the same time the piece A would have come to G along
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the straight line AG, equal and parallel to CB; and all the portion of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: wave AC would be at GB if the matter of the transparent body
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transmitted the movement of the wave as quickly as the matter of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Ether. But let us suppose that it transmits this movement less
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: quickly, by one-third, for instance. Movement will then be spread from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the point A, in the matter of the transparent body through a distance
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equal to two-thirds of CB, making its own particular spherical wave
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: according to what has been said before. This wave is then represented
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: by the circumference SNR, the centre of which is A, and its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: semi-diameter equal to two-thirds of CB. Then if one considers in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: order the other pieces H of the wave AC, it appears that in the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: time that the piece C reaches B they will not only have arrived at the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surface AB along the straight lines HK parallel to CB, but that, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: addition, they will have generated in the diaphanous substance from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the centres K, partial waves, represented here by circumferences the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: semi-diameters of which are equal to two-thirds of the lines KM, that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is to say, to two-thirds of the prolongations of HK down to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight line BG; for these semi-diameters would have been equal to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: entire lengths of KM if the two transparent substances had been of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: same penetrability.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now all these circumferences have for a common tangent the straight
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: line BN; namely the same line which is drawn as a tangent from the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: point B to the circumference SNR which we considered first. For it is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: easy to see that all the other circumferences will touch the same BN,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: from B up to the point of contact N, which is the same point where AN
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: falls perpendicularly on BN.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It is then BN, which is formed by small arcs of these circumferences,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which terminates the movement that the wave AC has communicated within
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the transparent body, and where this movement occurs in much greater
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: amount than anywhere else. And for that reason this line, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: accordance with what has been said more than once, is the propagation
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the wave AC at the moment when its piece C has reached B. For there
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is no other line below the plane AB which is, like BN, a common
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: tangent to all these partial waves. And if one would know how the wave
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AC has come progressively to BN, it is necessary only to draw in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: same figure the straight lines KO parallel to BN, and all the lines KL
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parallel to AC. Thus one will see that the wave CA, from being a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight line, has become broken in all the positions LKO
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: successively, and that it has again become a straight line at BN. This
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: being evident by what has already been demonstrated, there is no need
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to explain it further.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now, in the same figure, if one draws EAF, which cuts the plane AB at
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: right angles at the point A, since AD is perpendicular to the wave AC,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it will be DA which will mark the ray of incident light, and AN which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: was perpendicular to BN, the refracted ray: since the rays are nothing
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: else than the straight lines along which the portions of the waves
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: advance.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Whence it is easy to recognize this chief property of refraction,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: namely that the Sine of the angle DAE has always the same ratio to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Sine of the angle NAF, whatever be the inclination of the ray DA: and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that this ratio is the same as that of the velocity of the waves in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the transparent substance which is towards AE to their velocity in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparent substance towards AF. For, considering AB as the radius of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: a circle, the Sine of the angle BAC is BC, and the Sine of the angle
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ABN is AN. But the angle BAC is equal to DAE, since each of them added
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to CAE makes a right angle. And the angle ABN is equal to NAF, since
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: each of them with BAN makes a right angle. Then also the Sine of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angle DAE is to the Sine of NAF as BC is to AN. But the ratio of BC to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AN was the same as that of the velocities of light in the substance
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which is towards AE and in that which is towards AF; therefore also
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the Sine of the angle DAE will be to the Sine of the angle NAF the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: same as the said velocities of light.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: To see, consequently, what the refraction will be when the waves of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: light pass into a substance in which the movement travels more quickly
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: than in that from which they emerge (let us again assume the ratio of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 3 to 2), it is only necessary to repeat all the same construction and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: demonstration which we have just used, merely substituting everywhere
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 3/2 instead of 2/3. And it will be found by the same reasoning, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this other figure, that when the piece C of the wave AC shall have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reached the surface AB at B, all the portions of the wave AC will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: have advanced as far as BN, so that BC the perpendicular on AC is to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AN the perpendicular on BN as 2 to 3. And there will finally be this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: same ratio of 2 to 3 between the Sine of the angle BAD and the Sine of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the angle FAN.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Hence one sees the reciprocal relation of the refractions of the ray
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: on entering and on leaving one and the same transparent body: namely
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that if NA falling on the external surface AB is refracted into the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: direction AD, so the ray AD will be refracted on leaving the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparent body into the direction AN.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: One sees also the reason for a noteworthy accident which happens in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this refraction: which is this, that after a certain obliquity of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: incident ray DA, it begins to be quite unable to penetrate into the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: other transparent substance. For if the angle DAQ or CBA is such that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in the triangle ACB, CB is equal to 2/3 of AB, or is greater, then AN
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: cannot form one side of the triangle ANB, since it becomes equal to or
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: greater than AB: so that the portion of wave BN cannot be found
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: anywhere, neither consequently can AN, which ought to be perpendicular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to it. And thus the incident ray DA does not then pierce the surface
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AB.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: When the ratio of the velocities of the waves is as two to three, as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in our example, which is that which obtains for glass and air, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angle DAQ must be more than 48 degrees 11 minutes in order that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ray DA may be able to pass by refraction. And when the ratio of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: velocities is as 3 to 4, as it is very nearly in water and air, this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angle DAQ must exceed 41 degrees 24 minutes. And this accords
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perfectly with experiment.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But it might here be asked: since the meeting of the wave AC against
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the surface AB ought to produce movement in the matter which is on the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: other side, why does no light pass there? To which the reply is easy
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: if one remembers what has been said before. For although it generates
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: an infinitude of partial waves in the matter which is at the other
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: side of AB, these waves never have a common tangent line (either
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight or curved) at the same moment; and so there is no line
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: terminating the propagation of the wave AC beyond the plane AB, nor
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: any place where the movement is gathered together in sufficiently
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: great quantity to produce light. And one will easily see the truth of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this, namely that CB being larger than 2/3 of AB, the waves excited
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: beyond the plane AB will have no common tangent if about the centres K
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: one then draws circles having radii equal to 3/2 of the lengths LB to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which they correspond. For all these circles will be enclosed in one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: another and will all pass beyond the point B.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now it is to be remarked that from the moment when the angle DAQ is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: smaller than is requisite to permit the refracted ray DA to pass into
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the other transparent substance, one finds that the interior reflexion
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which occurs at the surface AB is much augmented in brightness, as is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: easy to realize by experiment with a triangular prism; and for this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: our theory can afford this reason. When the angle DAQ is still large
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: enough to enable the ray DA to pass, it is evident that the light from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the portion AC of the wave is collected in a minimum space when it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reaches BN. It appears also that the wave BN becomes so much the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: smaller as the angle CBA or DAQ is made less; until when the latter is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: diminished to the limit indicated a little previously, this wave BN is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: collected together always at one point. That is to say, that when the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: piece C of the wave AC has then arrived at B, the wave BN which is the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: propagation of AC is entirely reduced to the same point B. Similarly
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: when the piece H has reached K, the part AH is entirely reduced to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: same point K. This makes it evident that in proportion as the wave CA
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: comes to meet the surface AB, there occurs a great quantity of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: movement along that surface; which movement ought also to spread
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: within the transparent body and ought to have much re-enforced the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: partial waves which produce the interior reflexion against the surface
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AB, according to the laws of reflexion previously explained.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And because a slight diminution of the angle of incidence DAQ causes
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the wave BN, however great it was, to be reduced to zero, (for this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angle being 49 degrees 11 minutes in the glass, the angle BAN is still
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 11 degrees 21 minutes, and the same angle being reduced by one degree
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: only the angle BAN is reduced to zero, and so the wave BN reduced to a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: point) thence it comes about that the interior reflexion from being
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: obscure becomes suddenly bright, so soon as the angle of incidence is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: such that it no longer gives passage to the refraction.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now as concerns ordinary external reflexion, that is to say which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: occurs when the angle of incidence DAQ is still large enough to enable
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the refracted ray to penetrate beyond the surface AB, this reflexion
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: should occur against the particles of the substance which touches the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparent body on its outside. And it apparently occurs against the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particles of the air or others mingled with the ethereal particles and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: larger than they. So on the other hand the external reflexion of these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: bodies occurs against the particles which compose them, and which are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: also larger than those of the ethereal matter, since the latter flows
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in their interstices. It is true that there remains here some
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: difficulty in those experiments in which this interior reflexion
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: occurs without the particles of air being able to contribute to it, as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in vessels or tubes from which the air has been extracted.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Experience, moreover, teaches us that these two reflexions are of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: nearly equal force, and that in different transparent bodies they are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: so much the stronger as the refraction of these bodies is the greater.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Thus one sees manifestly that the reflexion of glass is stronger than
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that of water, and that of diamond stronger than that of glass.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I will finish this theory of refraction by demonstrating a remarkable
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: proposition which depends on it; namely, that a ray of light in order
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to go from one point to another, when these points are in different
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: media, is refracted in such wise at the plane surface which joins
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: these two media that it employs the least possible time: and exactly
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the same happens in the case of reflexion against a plane surface. Mr.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Fermat was the first to propound this property of refraction, holding
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: with us, and directly counter to the opinion of Mr. Des Cartes, that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: light passes more slowly through glass and water than through air.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But he assumed besides this a constant ratio of Sines, which we have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: just proved by these different degrees of velocity alone: or rather,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: what is equivalent, he assumed not only that the velocities were
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: different but that the light took the least time possible for its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: passage, and thence deduced the constant ratio of the Sines. His
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: demonstration, which may be seen in his printed works, and in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: volume of letters of Mr. Des Cartes, is very long; wherefore I give
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: here another which is simpler and easier.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let KF be the plane surface; A the point in the medium which the light
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: traverses more easily, as the air; C the point in the other which is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: more difficult to penetrate, as water. And suppose that a ray has come
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: from A, by B, to C, having been refracted at B according to the law
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: demonstrated a little before; that is to say that, having drawn PBQ,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which cuts the plane at right angles, let the sine of the angle ABP
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: have to the sine of the angle CBQ the same ratio as the velocity of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: light in the medium where A is to the velocity of light in the medium
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: where C is. It is to be shown that the time of passage of light along
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AB and BC taken together, is the shortest that can be. Let us assume
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that it may have come by other lines, and, in the first place, along
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AF, FC, so that the point of refraction F may be further from B than
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the point A; and let AO be a line perpendicular to AB, and FO parallel
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to AB; BH perpendicular to FO, and FG to BC.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Since then the angle HBF is equal to PBA, and the angle BFG equal to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: QBC, it follows that the sine of the angle HBF will also have the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ratio to the sine of BFG, as the velocity of light in the medium A is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to its velocity in the medium C. But these sines are the straight
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: lines HF, BG, if we take BF as the semi-diameter of a circle. Then
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: these lines HF, BG, will bear to one another the said ratio of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: velocities. And, therefore, the time of the light along HF, supposing
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that the ray had been OF, would be equal to the time along BG in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: interior of the medium C. But the time along AB is equal to the time
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: along OH; therefore the time along OF is equal to the time along AB,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: BG. Again the time along FC is greater than that along GC; then the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: time along OFC will be longer than that along ABC. But AF is longer
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: than OF, then the time along AFC will by just so much more exceed the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: time along ABC.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now let us assume that the ray has come from A to C along AK, KC; the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: point of refraction K being nearer to A than the point B is; and let
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CN be the perpendicular upon BC, KN parallel to BC: BM perpendicular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: upon KN, and KL upon BA.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Here BL and KM are the sines of angles BKL, KBM; that is to say, of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the angles PBA, QBC; and therefore they are to one another as the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: velocity of light in the medium A is to the velocity in the medium C.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Then the time along LB is equal to the time along KM; and since the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: time along BC is equal to the time along MN, the time along LBC will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be equal to the time along KMN. But the time along AK is longer than
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that along AL: hence the time along AKN is longer than that along ABC.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And KC being longer than KN, the time along AKC will exceed, by as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: much more, the time along ABC. Hence it appears that the time along
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ABC is the shortest possible; which was to be proven.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CHAPTER IV
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ON THE REFRACTION OF THE AIR
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: We have shown how the movement which constitutes light spreads by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spherical waves in any homogeneous matter. And it is evident that when
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the matter is not homogeneous, but of such a constitution that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: movement is communicated in it more rapidly toward one side than
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: toward another, these waves cannot be spherical: but that they must
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: acquire their figure according to the different distances over which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the successive movement passes in equal times.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It is thus that we shall in the first place explain the refractions
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which occur in the air, which extends from here to the clouds and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: beyond. The effects of which refractions are very remarkable; for by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: them we often see objects which the rotundity of the Earth ought
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: otherwise to hide; such as Islands, and the tops of mountains when one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is at sea. Because also of them the Sun and the Moon appear as risen
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: before in fact they have, and appear to set later: so that at times
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the Moon has been seen eclipsed while the Sun appeared still above the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: horizon. And so also the heights of the Sun and of the Moon, and those
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of all the Stars always appear a little greater than they are in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reality, because of these same refractions, as Astronomers know. But
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there is one experiment which renders this refraction very evident;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which is that of fixing a telescope on some spot so that it views an
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: object, such as a steeple or a house, at a distance of half a league
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: or more. If then you look through it at different hours of the day,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: leaving it always fixed in the same way, you will see that the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spots of the object will not always appear at the middle of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: aperture of the telescope, but that generally in the morning and in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the evening, when there are more vapours near the Earth, these objects
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: seem to rise higher, so that the half or more of them will no longer
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be visible; and so that they seem lower toward mid-day when these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: vapours are dissipated.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Those who consider refraction to occur only in the surfaces which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: separate transparent bodies of different nature, would find it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: difficult to give a reason for all that I have just related; but
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: according to our Theory the thing is quite easy. It is known that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: air which surrounds us, besides the particles which are proper to it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and which float in the ethereal matter as has been explained, is full
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: also of particles of water which are raised by the action of heat; and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it has been ascertained further by some very definite experiments that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: as one mounts up higher the density of air diminishes in proportion.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now whether the particles of water and those of air take part, by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: means of the particles of ethereal matter, in the movement which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: constitutes light, but have a less prompt recoil than these, or
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: whether the encounter and hindrance which these particles of air and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: water offer to the propagation of movement of the ethereal progress,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: retard the progression, it follows that both kinds of particles flying
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: amidst the ethereal particles, must render the air, from a great
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: height down to the Earth, gradually less easy for the spreading of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: waves of light.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Whence the configuration of the waves ought to become nearly such as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this figure represents: namely, if A is a light, or the visible point
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of a steeple, the waves which start from it ought to spread more
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: widely upwards and less widely downwards, but in other directions more
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: or less as they approximate to these two extremes. This being so, it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: necessarily follows that every line intersecting one of these waves at
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: right angles will pass above the point A, always excepting the one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: line which is perpendicular to the horizon.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let BC be the wave which brings the light to the spectator who is at
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: B, and let BD be the straight line which intersects this wave at right
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angles. Now because the ray or straight line by which we judge the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spot where the object appears to us is nothing else than the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to the wave that reaches our eye, as will be understood
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: by what was said above, it is manifest that the point A will be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perceived as being in the line BD, and therefore higher than in fact it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Similarly if the Earth be AB, and the top of the Atmosphere CD, which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: probably is not a well defined spherical surface (since we know that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the air becomes rare in proportion as one ascends, for above there is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: so much less of it to press down upon it), the waves of light from the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sun coming, for instance, in such a way that so long as they have not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reached the Atmosphere CD the straight line AE intersects them
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicularly, they ought, when they enter the Atmosphere, to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: advance more quickly in elevated regions than in regions nearer to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Earth. So that if CA is the wave which brings the light to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spectator at A, its region C will be the furthest advanced; and the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight line AF, which intersects this wave at right angles, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which determines the apparent place of the Sun, will pass above the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: real Sun, which will be seen along the line AE. And so it may occur
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that when it ought not to be visible in the absence of vapours,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: because the line AE encounters the rotundity of the Earth, it will be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perceived in the line AF by refraction. But this angle EAF is scarcely
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ever more than half a degree because the attenuation of the vapours
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: alters the waves of light but little. Furthermore these refractions
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: are not altogether constant in all weathers, particularly at small
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: elevations of 2 or 3 degrees; which results from the different
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: quantity of aqueous vapours rising above the Earth.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And this same thing is the cause why at certain times a distant object
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will be hidden behind another less distant one, and yet may at another
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: time be able to be seen, although the spot from which it is viewed is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: always the same. But the reason for this effect will be still more
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: evident from what we are going to remark touching the curvature of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rays. It appears from the things explained above that the progression
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: or propagation of a small part of a wave of light is properly what one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: calls a ray. Now these rays, instead of being straight as they are in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: homogeneous media, ought to be curved in an atmosphere of unequal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: penetrability. For they necessarily follow from the object to the eye
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the line which intersects at right angles all the progressions of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: waves, as in the first figure the line AEB does, as will be shown
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hereafter; and it is this line which determines what interposed bodies
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: would or would not hinder us from seeing the object. For although the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: point of the steeple A appears raised to D, it would yet not appear to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the eye B if the tower H was between the two, because it crosses the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: curve AEB. But the tower E, which is beneath this curve, does not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hinder the point A from being seen. Now according as the air near the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Earth exceeds in density that which is higher, the curvature of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ray AEB becomes greater: so that at certain times it passes above the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: summit E, which allows the point A to be perceived by the eye at B;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and at other times it is intercepted by the same tower E which hides A
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: from this same eye.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But to demonstrate this curvature of the rays conformably to all our
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: preceding Theory, let us imagine that AB is a small portion of a wave
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of light coming from the side C, which we may consider as a straight
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: line. Let us also suppose that it is perpendicular to the Horizon, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: portion B being nearer to the Earth than the portion A; and that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: because the vapours are less hindering at A than at B, the particular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: wave which comes from the point A spreads through a certain space AD
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: while the particular wave which starts from the point B spreads
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: through a shorter space BE; AD and BE being parallel to the Horizon.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Further, supposing the straight lines FG, HI, etc., to be drawn from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: an infinitude of points in the straight line AB and to terminate on
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the line DE (which is straight or may be considered as such), let the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: different penetrabilities at the different heights in the air between
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: A and B be represented by all these lines; so that the particular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: wave, originating from the point F, will spread across the space FG,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and that from the point H across the space HI, while that from the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: point A spreads across the space AD.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now if about the centres A, B, one describes the circles DK, EL, which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: represent the spreading of the waves which originate from these two
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: points, and if one draws the straight line KL which touches these two
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: circles, it is easy to see that this same line will be the common
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: tangent to all the other circles drawn about the centres F, H, etc.;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and that all the points of contact will fall within that part of this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: line which is comprised between the perpendiculars AK, BL. Then it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will be the line KL which will terminate the movement of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particular waves originating from the points of the wave AB; and this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: movement will be stronger between the points KL, than anywhere else at
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the same instant, since an infinitude of circumferences concur to form
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this straight line; and consequently KL will be the propagation of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: portion of wave AB, as has been said in explaining reflexion and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ordinary refraction. Now it appears that AK and BL dip down toward the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: side where the air is less easy to penetrate: for AK being longer than
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: BL, and parallel to it, it follows that the lines AB and KL, being
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: prolonged, would meet at the side L. But the angle K is a right angle:
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hence KAB is necessarily acute, and consequently less than DAB. If one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: investigates in the same way the progression of the portion of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: wave KL, one will find that after a further time it has arrived at MN
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in such a manner that the perpendiculars KM, LN, dip down even more
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: than do AK, BL. And this suffices to show that the ray will continue
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: along the curved line which intersects all the waves at right angles,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: as has been said.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CHAPTER V
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ON THE STRANGE REFRACTION OF ICELAND CRYSTAL
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: There is brought from Iceland, which is an Island in the North Sea, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the latitude of 66 degrees, a kind of Crystal or transparent stone,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: very remarkable for its figure and other qualities, but above all for
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: its strange refractions. The causes of this have seemed to me to be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: worthy of being carefully investigated, the more so because amongst
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparent bodies this one alone does not follow the ordinary rules
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: with respect to rays of light. I have even been under some necessity
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to make this research, because the refractions of this Crystal seemed
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to overturn our preceding explanation of regular refraction; which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: explanation, on the contrary, they strongly confirm, as will be seen
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: after they have been brought under the same principle. In Iceland are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: found great lumps of this Crystal, some of which I have seen of 4 or 5
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: pounds. But it occurs also in other countries, for I have had some of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the same sort which had been found in France near the town of Troyes
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in Champagne, and some others which came from the Island of Corsica,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: though both were less clear and only in little bits, scarcely capable
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of letting any effect of refraction be observed.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 2. The first knowledge which the public has had about it is due to Mr.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Erasmus Bartholinus, who has given a description of Iceland Crystal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and of its chief phenomena. But here I shall not desist from giving my
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: own, both for the instruction of those who may not have seen his book,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and because as respects some of these phenomena there is a slight
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: difference between his observations and those which I have made: for I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: have applied myself with great exactitude to examine these properties
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of refraction, in order to be quite sure before undertaking to explain
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the causes of them.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 3. As regards the hardness of this stone, and the property which it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: has of being easily split, it must be considered rather as a species
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of Talc than of Crystal. For an iron spike effects an entrance into it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: as easily as into any other Talc or Alabaster, to which it is equal in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: gravity.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 4. The pieces of it which are found have the figure of an oblique
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parallelepiped; each of the six faces being a parallelogram; and it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: admits of being split in three directions parallel to two of these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: opposed faces. Even in such wise, if you will, that all the six faces
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: are equal and similar rhombuses. The figure here added represents a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: piece of this Crystal. The obtuse angles of all the parallelograms, as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: C, D, here, are angles of 101 degrees 52 minutes, and consequently
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the acute angles, such as A and B, are of 78 degrees 8 minutes.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 5. Of the solid angles there are two opposite to one another, such as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: C and E, which are each composed of three equal obtuse plane angles.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: The other six are composed of two acute angles and one obtuse. All
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that I have just said has been likewise remarked by Mr. Bartholinus in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the aforesaid treatise; if we differ it is only slightly about the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: values of the angles. He recounts moreover some other properties of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this Crystal; to wit, that when rubbed against cloth it attracts
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straws and other light things as do amber, diamond, glass, and Spanish
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: wax. Let a piece be covered with water for a day or more, the surface
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: loses its natural polish. When aquafortis is poured on it it produces
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ebullition, especially, as I have found, if the Crystal has been
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: pulverized. I have also found by experiment that it may be heated to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: redness in the fire without being in anywise altered or rendered less
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparent; but a very violent fire calcines it nevertheless. Its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparency is scarcely less than that of water or of Rock Crystal,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and devoid of colour. But rays of light pass through it in another
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: fashion and produce those marvellous refractions the causes of which I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: am now going to try to explain; reserving for the end of this Treatise
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the statement of my conjectures touching the formation and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: extraordinary configuration of this Crystal.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 6. In all other transparent bodies that we know there is but one sole
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and simple refraction; but in this substance there are two different
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ones. The effect is that objects seen through it, especially such as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: are placed right against it, appear double; and that a ray of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sunlight, falling on one of its surfaces, parts itself into two rays
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and traverses the Crystal thus.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 7. It is again a general law in all other transparent bodies that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ray which falls perpendicularly on their surface passes straight on
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: without suffering refraction, and that an oblique ray is always
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refracted. But in this Crystal the perpendicular ray suffers
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction, and there are oblique rays which pass through it quite
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 8. But in order to explain these phenomena more particularly, let
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there be, in the first place, a piece ABFE of the same Crystal, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: let the obtuse angle ACB, one of the three which constitute the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equilateral solid angle C, be divided into two equal parts by the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight line CG, and let it be conceived that the Crystal is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: intersected by a plane which passes through this line and through the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: side CF, which plane will necessarily be perpendicular to the surface
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AB; and its section in the Crystal will form a parallelogram GCFH. We
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will call this section the principal section of the Crystal.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 9. Now if one covers the surface AB, leaving there only a small
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: aperture at the point K, situated in the straight line CG, and if one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: exposes it to the sun, so that his rays face it perpendicularly above,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: then the ray IK will divide itself at the point K into two, one of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which will continue to go on straight by KL, and the other will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: separate itself along the straight line KM, which is in the plane
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: GCFH, and which makes with KL an angle of about 6 degrees 40 minutes,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: tending from the side of the solid angle C; and on emerging from the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: other side of the Crystal it will turn again parallel to JK, along MZ.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And as, in this extraordinary refraction, the point M is seen by the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refracted ray MKI, which I consider as going to the eye at I, it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: necessarily follows that the point L, by virtue of the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction, will be seen by the refracted ray LRI, so that LR will be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parallel to MK if the distance from the eye KI is supposed very great.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: The point L appears then as being in the straight line IRS; but the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: same point appears also, by ordinary refraction, to be in the straight
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: line IK, hence it is necessarily judged to be double. And similarly if
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: L be a small hole in a sheet of paper or other substance which is laid
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: against the Crystal, it will appear when turned towards daylight as if
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there were two holes, which will seem the wider apart from one another
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the greater the thickness of the Crystal.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 10. Again, if one turns the Crystal in such wise that an incident ray
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: NO, of sunlight, which I suppose to be in the plane continued from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: GCFH, makes with GC an angle of 73 degrees and 20 minutes, and is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: consequently nearly parallel to the edge CF, which makes with FH an
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angle of 70 degrees 57 minutes, according to the calculation which I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: shall put at the end, it will divide itself at the point O into two
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rays, one of which will continue along OP in a straight line with NO,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and will similarly pass out of the other side of the crystal without
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: any refraction; but the other will be refracted and will go along OQ.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And it must be noted that it is special to the plane through GCF and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to those which are parallel to it, that all incident rays which are in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: one of these planes continue to be in it after they have entered the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Crystal and have become double; for it is quite otherwise for rays in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: all other planes which intersect the Crystal, as we shall see
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: afterwards.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 11. I recognized at first by these experiments and by some others that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the two refractions which the ray suffers in this Crystal, there is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: one which follows the ordinary rules; and it is this to which the rays
