author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: KL and OQ belong. This is why I have distinguished this ordinary
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction from the other; and having measured it by exact
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: observation, I found that its proportion, considered as to the Sines
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the angles which the incident and refracted rays make with the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular, was very precisely that of 5 to 3, as was found also by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Mr. Bartholinus, and consequently much greater than that of Rock
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Crystal, or of glass, which is nearly 3 to 2.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 12. The mode of making these observations exactly is as follows. Upon
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: a leaf of paper fixed on a thoroughly flat table there is traced a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: black line AB, and two others, CED and KML, which cut it at right
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angles and are more or less distant from one another according as it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is desired to examine a ray that is more or less oblique. Then place
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the Crystal upon the intersection E so that the line AB concurs with
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that which bisects the obtuse angle of the lower surface, or with some
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: line parallel to it. Then by placing the eye directly above the line
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AB it will appear single only; and one will see that the portion
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: viewed through the Crystal and the portions which appear outside it,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: meet together in a straight line: but the line CD will appear double,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and one can distinguish the image which is due to regular refraction
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: by the circumstance that when one views it with both eyes it seems
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: raised up more than the other, or again by the circumstance that, when
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the Crystal is turned around on the paper, this image remains
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: stationary, whereas the other image shifts and moves entirely around.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Afterwards let the eye be placed at I (remaining always in the plane
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular through AB) so that it views the image which is formed
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: by regular refraction of the line CD making a straight line with the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: remainder of that line which is outside the Crystal. And then, marking
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: on the surface of the Crystal the point H where the intersection E
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: appears, this point will be directly above E. Then draw back the eye
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: towards O, keeping always in the plane perpendicular through AB, so
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that the image of the line CD, which is formed by ordinary refraction,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: may appear in a straight line with the line KL viewed without
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction; and then mark on the Crystal the point N where the point
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of intersection E appears.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 13. Then one will know the length and position of the lines NH, EM,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and of HE, which is the thickness of the Crystal: which lines being
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: traced separately upon a plan, and then joining NE and NM which cuts
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: HE at P, the proportion of the refraction will be that of EN to NP,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: because these lines are to one another as the sines of the angles NPH,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: NEP, which are equal to those which the incident ray ON and its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction NE make with the perpendicular to the surface. This
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: proportion, as I have said, is sufficiently precisely as 5 to 3, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is always the same for all inclinations of the incident ray.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 14. The same mode of observation has also served me for examining the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: extraordinary or irregular refraction of this Crystal. For, the point
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: H having been found and marked, as aforesaid, directly above the point
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: E, I observed the appearance of the line CD, which is made by the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: extraordinary refraction; and having placed the eye at Q, so that this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: appearance made a straight line with the line KL viewed without
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction, I ascertained the triangles REH, RES, and consequently the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angles RSH, RES, which the incident and the refracted ray make with
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the perpendicular.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 15. But I found in this refraction that the ratio of FR to RS was not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: constant, like the ordinary refraction, but that it varied with the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: varying obliquity of the incident ray.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 16. I found also that when QRE made a straight line, that is, when the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: incident ray entered the Crystal without being refracted (as I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ascertained by the circumstance that then the point E viewed by the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: extraordinary refraction appeared in the line CD, as seen without
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction) I found, I say, then that the angle QRG was 73 degrees 20
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: minutes, as has been already remarked; and so it is not the ray
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parallel to the edge of the Crystal, which crosses it in a straight
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: line without being refracted, as Mr. Bartholinus believed, since that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: inclination is only 70 degrees 57 minutes, as was stated above. And
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this is to be noted, in order that no one may search in vain for the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: cause of the singular property of this ray in its parallelism to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: edges mentioned.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 17. Finally, continuing my observations to discover the nature of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this refraction, I learned that it obeyed the following remarkable
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rule. Let the parallelogram GCFH, made by the principal section of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Crystal, as previously determined, be traced separately. I found then
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that always, when the inclinations of two rays which come from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: opposite sides, as VK, SK here, are equal, their refractions KX and KT
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: meet the bottom line HF in such wise that points X and T are equally
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: distant from the point M, where the refraction of the perpendicular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ray IK falls; and this occurs also for refractions in other sections
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of this Crystal. But before speaking of those, which have also other
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particular properties, we will investigate the causes of the phenomena
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which I have already reported.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It was after having explained the refraction of ordinary transparent
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: bodies by means of the spherical emanations of light, as above, that I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: resumed my examination of the nature of this Crystal, wherein I had
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: previously been unable to discover anything.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 18. As there were two different refractions, I conceived that there
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: were also two different emanations of waves of light, and that one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: could occur in the ethereal matter extending through the body of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Crystal. Which matter, being present in much larger quantity than is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that of the particles which compose it, was alone capable of causing
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparency, according to what has been explained heretofore. I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: attributed to this emanation of waves the regular refraction which is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: observed in this stone, by supposing these waves to be ordinarily of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spherical form, and having a slower progression within the Crystal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: than they have outside it; whence proceeds refraction as I have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: demonstrated.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 19. As to the other emanation which should produce the irregular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction, I wished to try what Elliptical waves, or rather
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheroidal waves, would do; and these I supposed would spread
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: indifferently both in the ethereal matter diffused throughout the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: crystal and in the particles of which it is composed, according to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: last mode in which I have explained transparency. It seemed to me that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the disposition or regular arrangement of these particles could
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: contribute to form spheroidal waves (nothing more being required for
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this than that the successive movement of light should spread a little
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: more quickly in one direction than in the other) and I scarcely
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: doubted that there were in this crystal such an arrangement of equal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and similar particles, because of its figure and of its angles with
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: their determinate and invariable measure. Touching which particles,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and their form and disposition, I shall, at the end of this Treatise,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: propound my conjectures and some experiments which confirm them.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 20. The double emission of waves of light, which I had imagined,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: became more probable to me after I had observed a certain phenomenon
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in the ordinary [Rock] Crystal, which occurs in hexagonal form, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which, because of this regularity, seems also to be composed of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particles, of definite figure, and ranged in order. This was, that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this crystal, as well as that from Iceland, has a double refraction,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: though less evident. For having had cut from it some well polished
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Prisms of different sections, I remarked in all, in viewing through
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: them the flame of a candle or the lead of window panes, that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: everything appeared double, though with images not very distant from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: one another. Whence I understood the reason why this substance, though
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: so transparent, is useless for Telescopes, when they have ever so
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: little length.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 21. Now this double refraction, according to my Theory hereinbefore
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: established, seemed to demand a double emission of waves of light,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: both of them spherical (for both the refractions are regular) and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: those of one series a little slower only than the others. For thus the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: phenomenon is quite naturally explained, by postulating substances
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which serve as vehicle for these waves, as I have done in the case of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Iceland Crystal. I had then less trouble after that in admitting two
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: emissions of waves in one and the same body. And since it might have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: been objected that in composing these two kinds of crystal of equal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particles of a certain figure, regularly piled, the interstices which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: these particles leave and which contain the ethereal matter would
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: scarcely suffice to transmit the waves of light which I have localized
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there, I removed this difficulty by regarding these particles as being
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of a very rare texture, or rather as composed of other much smaller
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: particles, between which the ethereal matter passes quite freely.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: This, moreover, necessarily follows from that which has been already
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: demonstrated touching the small quantity of matter of which the bodies
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: are built up.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 22. Supposing then these spheroidal waves besides the spherical ones,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I began to examine whether they could serve to explain the phenomena
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the irregular refraction, and how by these same phenomena I could
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: determine the figure and position of the spheroids: as to which I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: obtained at last the desired success, by proceeding as follows.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 23. I considered first the effect of waves so formed, as respects the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ray which falls perpendicularly on the flat surface of a transparent
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: body in which they should spread in this manner. I took AB for the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: exposed region of the surface. And, since a ray perpendicular to a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: plane, and coming from a very distant source of light, is nothing
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: else, according to the precedent Theory, than the incidence of a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: portion of the wave parallel to that plane, I supposed the straight
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: line RC, parallel and equal to AB, to be a portion of a wave of light,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in which an infinitude of points such as RH_h_C come to meet the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surface AB at the points AK_k_B. Then instead of the hemispherical
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: partial waves which in a body of ordinary refraction would spread from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: each of these last points, as we have above explained in treating of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction, these must here be hemi-spheroids. The axes (or rather the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: major diameters) of these I supposed to be oblique to the plane AB, as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is AV the semi-axis or semi-major diameter of the spheroid SVT, which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: represents the partial wave coming from the point A, after the wave RC
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: has reached AB. I say axis or major diameter, because the same ellipse
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: SVT may be considered as the section of a spheroid of which the axis
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is AZ perpendicular to AV. But, for the present, without yet deciding
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: one or other, we will consider these spheroids only in those sections
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of them which make ellipses in the plane of this figure. Now taking a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: certain space of time during which the wave SVT has spread from A, it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: would needs be that from all the other points K_k_B there should
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: proceed, in the same time, waves similar to SVT and similarly
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: situated. And the common tangent NQ of all these semi-ellipses would
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be the propagation of the wave RC which fell on AB, and would be the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: place where this movement occurs in much greater amount than anywhere
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: else, being made up of arcs of an infinity of ellipses, the centres of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which are along the line AB.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 24. Now it appeared that this common tangent NQ was parallel to AB,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and of the same length, but that it was not directly opposite to it,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: since it was comprised between the lines AN, BQ, which are diameters
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of ellipses having A and B for centres, conjugate with respect to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: diameters which are not in the straight line AB. And in this way I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: comprehended, a matter which had seemed to me very difficult, how a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ray perpendicular to a surface could suffer refraction on entering a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: transparent body; seeing that the wave RC, having come to the aperture
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AB, went on forward thence, spreading between the parallel lines AN,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: BQ, yet itself remaining always parallel to AB, so that here the light
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: does not spread along lines perpendicular to its waves, as in ordinary
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction, but along lines cutting the waves obliquely.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 25. Inquiring subsequently what might be the position and form of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: these spheroids in the crystal, I considered that all the six faces
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: produced precisely the same refractions. Taking, then, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parallelopiped AFB, of which the obtuse solid angle C is contained
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: between the three equal plane angles, and imagining in it the three
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: principal sections, one of which is perpendicular to the face DC and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: passes through the edge CF, another perpendicular to the face BF
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: passing through the edge CA, and the third perpendicular to the face
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AF passing through the edge BC; I knew that the refractions of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: incident rays belonging to these three planes were all similar. But
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there could be no position of the spheroid which would have the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: relation to these three sections except that in which the axis was
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: also the axis of the solid angle C. Consequently I saw that the axis
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of this angle, that is to say the straight line which traversed the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: crystal from the point C with equal inclination to the edges CF, CA,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CB was the line which determined the position of the axis of all the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheroidal waves which one imagined to originate from some point,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: taken within or on the surface of the crystal, since all these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheroids ought to be alike, and have their axes parallel to one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: another.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 26. Considering after this the plane of one of these three sections,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: namely that through GCF, the angle of which is 109 degrees 3 minutes,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: since the angle F was shown above to be 70 degrees 57 minutes; and,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: imagining a spheroidal wave about the centre C, I knew, because I have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: just explained it, that its axis must be in the same plane, the half
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of which axis I have marked CS in the next figure: and seeking by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: calculation (which will be given with others at the end of this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: discourse) the value of the angle CGS, I found it 45 degrees 20
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: minutes.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 27. To know from this the form of this spheroid, that is to say the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: proportion of the semi-diameters CS, CP, of its elliptical section,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which are perpendicular to one another, I considered that the point M
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: where the ellipse is touched by the straight line FH, parallel to CG,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ought to be so situated that CM makes with the perpendicular CL an
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angle of 6 degrees 40 minutes; since, this being so, this ellipse
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: satisfies what has been said about the refraction of the ray
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to the surface CG, which is inclined to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular CL by the same angle. This, then, being thus disposed,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and taking CM at 100,000 parts, I found by the calculation which will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be given at the end, the semi-major diameter CP to be 105,032, and the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: semi-axis CS to be 93,410, the ratio of which numbers is very nearly 9
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to 8; so that the spheroid was of the kind which resembles a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: compressed sphere, being generated by the revolution of an ellipse
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: about its smaller diameter. I found also the value of CG the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: semi-diameter parallel to the tangent ML to be 98,779.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 28. Now passing to the investigation of the refractions which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: obliquely incident rays must undergo, according to our hypothesis of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheroidal waves, I saw that these refractions depended on the ratio
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: between the velocity of movement of the light outside the crystal in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the ether, and that within the crystal. For supposing, for example,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this proportion to be such that while the light in the crystal forms
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the spheroid GSP, as I have just said, it forms outside a sphere the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: semi-diameter of which is equal to the line N which will be determined
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hereafter, the following is the way of finding the refraction of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: incident rays. Let there be such a ray RC falling upon the surface
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CK. Make CO perpendicular to RC, and across the angle KCO adjust OK,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equal to N and perpendicular to CO; then draw KI, which touches the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Ellipse GSP, and from the point of contact I join IC, which will be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the required refraction of the ray RC. The demonstration of this is,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it will be seen, entirely similar to that of which we made use in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: explaining ordinary refraction. For the refraction of the ray RC is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: nothing else than the progression of the portion C of the wave CO,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: continued in the crystal. Now the portions H of this wave, during the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: time that O came to K, will have arrived at the surface CK along the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight lines H_x_, and will moreover have produced in the crystal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: around the centres _x_ some hemi-spheroidal partial waves similar to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the hemi-spheroidal GSP_g_, and similarly disposed, and of which the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: major and minor diameters will bear the same proportions to the lines
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: they meet the tangent ML at T and _t_, the distances MT, M_t_, will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: also be equal. And so, by our hypothesis, we explain perfectly the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equally inclined, but coming from opposite sides, as here the rays RC,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: crystal.

text: 30. To find the length of the line N, in proportion to CP, CS, CG, it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: must be determined by observations of the irregular refraction which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: occurs in this section of the crystal; and I find thus that the ratio
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of N to GC is just a little less than 8 to 5. And having regard to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: some other observations and phenomena of which I shall speak
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: afterwards, I put N at 156,962 parts, of which the semi-diameter CG is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: found to contain 98,779, making this ratio 8 to 5-1/29. Now this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: proportion, which there is between the line N and CG, may be called
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the Proportion of the Refraction; similarly as in glass that of 3 to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 2, as will be manifest when I shall have explained a short process in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the preceding way to find the irregular refractions.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 31. Supposing then, in the next figure, as previously, the surface of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the crystal _g_G, the Ellipse GP_g_, and the line N; and CM the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: degrees 40 minutes. Now let there be some other ray RC, the refraction
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: RCO is a right angle, it is easy to see that the right-angled
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: triangles RCV, KCO, are similar. As then, CK is to KO, so also is RC
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to CV. But KO is equal to N, and RC to CG: then as CK is to N so will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CG be to CV. But as N is to CG, so, by construction, is CV to CD. Then
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: as CK is to CG so is CG to CD. And because DI is parallel to CM, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: conjugate diameter to CG, it follows that KI touches the Ellipse at I;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 32. One sees then that as there is in the refraction of ordinary
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: media a certain constant proportion between the sines of the angles
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which the incident ray and the refracted ray make with the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular, so here there is such a proportion between CV and CD or
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Ellipse, between the refraction of this ray and the diameter CM. For
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the ratio of CV to CD is, as has been said, the same as that of N to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the semi-diameter CG.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 33. I will add here, before passing away, that in comparing together
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the regular and irregular refraction of this crystal, there is this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: remarkable fact, that if ABPS be the spheroid by which light spreads
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in the Crystal in a certain space of time (which spreading, as has
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: been said, serves for the irregular refraction), then the inscribed
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sphere BVST is the extension in the same space of time of the light
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which serves for the regular refraction.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: For we have stated before this, that the line N being the radius of a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spherical wave of light in air, while in the crystal it spread through
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the spheroid ABPS, the ratio of N to CS will be 156,962 to 93,410. But
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it has also been stated that the proportion of the regular refraction
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: was 5 to 3; that is to say, that N being the radius of a spherical
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: wave of light in air, its extension in the crystal would, in the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: space of time, form a sphere the radius of which would be to N as 3 to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 5. Now 156,962 is to 93,410 as 5 to 3 less 1/41. So that it is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sufficiently nearly, and may be exactly, the sphere BVST, which the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: light describes for the regular refraction in the crystal, while it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: describes the spheroid BPSA for the irregular refraction, and while it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: describes the sphere of radius N in air outside the crystal.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Although then there are, according to what we have supposed, two
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: different propagations of light within the crystal, it appears that it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is only in directions perpendicular to the axis BS of the spheroid
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that one of these propagations occurs more rapidly than the other; but
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that they have an equal velocity in the other direction, namely, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that parallel to the same axis BS, which is also the axis of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: obtuse angle of the crystal.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 34. The proportion of the refraction being what we have just seen, I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the crystal (of which ray mention has been made above); if one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the refraction of the ray RC, the proportion of CV to CD is 156,962 to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 35. Further it will be seen that the ray CI in emerging through the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: opposite surface of the crystal, ought to pass out quite straight,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: according to the following demonstration, which proves that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reciprocal relation of refraction obtains in this crystal the same as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in other transparent bodies; that is to say, that if a ray RC in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: meeting the surface of the crystal CG is refracted as CI, the ray CI
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: emerging through the opposite parallel surface of the crystal, which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I suppose to be IB, will have its refraction IA parallel to the ray
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: RC.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let the same things be supposed as before; that is to say, let CO,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to CR, represent a portion of a wave the continuation of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which in the crystal is IK, so that the piece C will be continued on
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: along the straight line CI, while O comes to K. Now if one takes a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: second period of time equal to the first, the piece K of the wave IK
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will, in this second period, have advanced along the straight line KB,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equal and parallel to CI, because every piece of the wave CO, on
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: arriving at the surface CK, ought to go on in the crystal the same as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the piece C; and in this same time there will be formed in the air
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: from the point I a partial spherical wave having a semi-diameter IA
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equal to KO, since KO has been traversed in an equal time. Similarly,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: if one considers some other point of the wave IK, such as _h_, it will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: go along _hm_, parallel to CI, to meet the surface IB, while the point
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: K traverses K_l_ equal to _hm_; and while this accomplishes the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: remainder _l_B, there will start from the point _m_ a partial wave the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: semi-diameter of which, _mn_, will have the same ratio to _l_B as IA
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to KB. Whence it is evident that this wave of semi-diameter _mn_, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the other of semi-diameter IA will have the same tangent BA. And
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: similarly for all the partial spherical waves which will be formed
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: outside the crystal by the impact of all the points of the wave IK
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: against the surface of the Ether IB. It is then precisely the tangent
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: BA which will be the continuation of the wave IK, outside the crystal,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: when the piece K has reached B. And in consequence IA, which is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to BA, will be the refraction of the ray CI on emerging
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: from the crystal. Now it is clear that IA is parallel to the incident
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ray RC, since IB is equal to CK, and IA equal to KO, and the angles A
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and O are right angles.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It is seen then that, according to our hypothesis, the reciprocal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: relation of refraction holds good in this crystal as well as in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ordinary transparent bodies; as is thus in fact found by observation.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 36. I pass now to the consideration of other sections of the crystal,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and of the refractions there produced, on which, as will be seen, some
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: other very remarkable phenomena depend.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let ABH be a parallelepiped of crystal, and let the top surface AEHF
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be a perfect rhombus, the obtuse angles of which are equally divided
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: by the straight line EF, and the acute angles by the straight line AH
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to FE.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: The section which we have hitherto considered is that which passes
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: through the lines EF, EB, and which at the same time cuts the plane
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AEHF at right angles. Refractions in this section have this in common
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: with the refractions in ordinary media that the plane which is drawn
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: through the incident ray and which also intersects the surface of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: crystal at right angles, is that in which the refracted ray also is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: found. But the refractions which appertain to every other section of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this crystal have this strange property that the refracted ray always
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: quits the plane of the incident ray perpendicular to the surface, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: turns away towards the side of the slope of the crystal. For which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: fact we shall show the reason, in the first place, for the section
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: through AH; and we shall show at the same time how one can determine
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the refraction, according to our hypothesis. Let there be, then, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the plane which passes through AH, and which is perpendicular to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: plane AFHE, the incident ray RC; it is required to find its refraction
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in the crystal.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan
