author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheroid, that is to say, as 156,962 to 105,032, very nearly as 3 to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 2, but just a little less. Which still agrees perfectly with what one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: finds by observation.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 39. For the rest, this diversity of proportion of refraction produces
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: a very singular effect in this Crystal; which is that when it is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: placed upon a sheet of paper on which there are letters or anything
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: else marked, if one views it from above with the two eyes situated in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the plane of the section through EF, one sees the letters raised up by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this irregular refraction more than when one puts one's eyes in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: plane of section through AH: and the difference of these elevations
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: appears by comparison with the other ordinary refraction of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: crystal, the proportion of which is as 5 to 3, and which always raises
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the letters equally, and higher than the irregular refraction does.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: For one sees the letters and the paper on which they are written, as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: on two different stages at the same time; and in the first position of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the eyes, namely, when they are in the plane through AH these two
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: stages are four times more distant from one another than when the eyes
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: are in the plane through EF.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: We will show that this effect follows from the refractions; and it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will enable us at the same time to ascertain the apparent place of a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: point of an object placed immediately under the crystal, according to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the different situation of the eyes.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 40. Let us see first by how much the irregular refraction of the plane
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: through AH ought to lift the bottom of the crystal. Let the plane of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this figure represent separately the section through Q_q_ and CL, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which section there is also the ray RC, and let the semi-elliptic
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: plane through Q_q_ and CM be inclined to the former, as previously, by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: an angle of 6 degrees 40 minutes; and in this plane CI is then the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction of the ray RC.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: If now one considers the point I as at the bottom of the crystal, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that it is viewed by the rays ICR, _Icr_, refracted equally at the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: points C_c_, which should be equally distant from D, and that these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rays meet the two eyes at R_r_; it is certain that the point I will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: appear raised to S where the straight lines RC, _rc_, meet; which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: point S is in DP, perpendicular to Q_q_. And if upon DP there is drawn
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the perpendicular IP, which will lie at the bottom of the crystal, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: length SP will be the apparent elevation of the point I above the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: bottom.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let there be described on Q_q_ a semicircle cutting the ray CR at B,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: from which BV is drawn perpendicular to Q_q_; and let the proportion
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the refraction for this section be, as before, that of the line N
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to the semi-diameter CQ.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Then as N is to CQ so is VC to CD, as appears by the method of finding
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the refraction which we have shown above, Article 31; but as VC is to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CD, so is VB to DS. Then as N is to CQ, so is VB to DS. Let ML be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to CL. And because I suppose the eyes R_r_ to be distant
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: about a foot or so from the crystal, and consequently the angle RS_r_
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: very small, VB may be considered as equal to the semi-diameter CQ, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: DP as equal to CL; then as N is to CQ so is CQ to DS. But N is valued
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: at 156,962 parts, of which CM contains 100,000 and CQ 105,032. Then DS
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will have 70,283. But CL is 99,324, being the sine of the complement
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the angle MCL which is 6 degrees 40 minutes; CM being supposed as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: radius. Then DP, considered as equal to CL, will be to DS as 99,324 to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 70,283. And so the elevation of the point I by the refraction of this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: section is known.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 41. Now let there be represented the other section through EF in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: figure before the preceding one; and let CM_g_ be the semi-ellipse,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: considered in Articles 27 and 28, which is made by cutting a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheroidal wave having centre C. Let the point I, taken in this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ellipse, be imagined again at the bottom of the Crystal; and let it be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: viewed by the refracted rays ICR, I_cr_, which go to the two eyes; CR
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and _cr_ being equally inclined to the surface of the crystal G_g_.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: This being so, if one draws ID parallel to CM, which I suppose to be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the refraction of the perpendicular ray incident at the point C, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: distances DC, D_c_, will be equal, as is easy to see by that which has
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: been demonstrated in Article 28. Now it is certain that the point I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: should appear at S where the straight lines RC, _rc_, meet when
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: prolonged; and that this point will fall in the line DP perpendicular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to G_g_. If one draws IP perpendicular to this DP, it will be the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: distance PS which will mark the apparent elevation of the point I. Let
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there be described on G_g_ a semicircle cutting CR at B, from which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: let BV be drawn perpendicular to G_g_; and let N to GC be the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: proportion of the refraction in this section, as in Article 28. Since
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: then CI is the refraction of the radius BC, and DI is parallel to CM,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: VC must be to CD as N to GC, according to what has been demonstrated
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in Article 31. But as VC is to CD so is BV to DS. Let ML be drawn
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to CL. And because I consider, again, the eyes to be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: distant above the crystal, BV is deemed equal to the semi-diameter CG;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and hence DS will be a third proportional to the lines N and CG: also
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: DP will be deemed equal to CL. Now CG consisting of 98,778 parts, of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which CM contains 100,000, N is taken as 156,962. Then DS will be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 62,163. But CL is also determined, and contains 99,324 parts, as has
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: been said in Articles 34 and 40. Then the ratio of PD to DS will be as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 99,324 to 62,163. And thus one knows the elevation of the point at the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: bottom I by the refraction of this section; and it appears that this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: elevation is greater than that by the refraction of the preceding
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: section, since the ratio of PD to DS was there as 99,324 to 70,283.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But by the regular refraction of the crystal, of which we have above
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: said that the proportion is 5 to 3, the elevation of the point I, or
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: P, from the bottom, will be 2/5 of the height DP; as appears by this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: figure, where the point P being viewed by the rays PCR, P_cr_,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refracted equally at the surface C_c_, this point must needs appear
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to be at S, in the perpendicular PD where the lines RC, _rc_, meet
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: when prolonged: and one knows that the line PC is to CS as 5 to 3,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: since they are to one another as the sine of the angle CSP or DSC is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to the sine of the angle SPC. And because the ratio of PD to DS is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: deemed the same as that of PC to CS, the two eyes Rr being supposed
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: very far above the crystal, the elevation PS will thus be 2/5 of PD.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 42. If one takes a straight line AB for the thickness of the crystal,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: its point B being at the bottom, and if one divides it at the points
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: C, D, E, according to the proportions of the elevations found, making
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AE 3/5 of AB, AB to AC as 99,324 to 70,283, and AB to AD as 99,324 to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 62,163, these points will divide AB as in this figure. And it will be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: found that this agrees perfectly with experiment; that is to say by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: placing the eyes above in the plane which cuts the crystal according
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to the shorter diameter of the rhombus, the regular refraction will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: lift up the letters to E; and one will see the bottom, and the letters
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: over which it is placed, lifted up to D by the irregular refraction.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But by placing the eyes above in the plane which cuts the crystal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: according to the longer diameter of the rhombus, the regular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction will lift the letters to E as before; but the irregular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction will make them, at the same time, appear lifted up only to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: C; and in such a way that the interval CE will be quadruple the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: interval ED, which one previously saw.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 43. I have only to make the remark here that in both the positions of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the eyes the images caused by the irregular refraction do not appear
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: directly below those which proceed from the regular refraction, but
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: they are separated from them by being more distant from the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equilateral solid angle of the Crystal. That follows, indeed, from all
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that has been hitherto demonstrated about the irregular refraction;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and it is particularly shown by these last demonstrations, from which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: one sees that the point I appears by irregular refraction at S in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular line DP, in which line also the image of the point P
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ought to appear by regular refraction, but not the image of the point
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I, which will be almost directly above the same point, and higher than
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: S.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But as to the apparent elevation of the point I in other positions of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the eyes above the crystal, besides the two positions which we have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: just examined, the image of that point by the irregular refraction
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will always appear between the two heights of D and C, passing from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: one to the other as one turns one's self around about the immovable
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: crystal, while looking down from above. And all this is still found
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: conformable to our hypothesis, as any one can assure himself after I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: shall have shown here the way of finding the irregular refractions
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which appear in all other sections of the crystal, besides the two
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which we have considered. Let us suppose one of the faces of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: crystal, in which let there be the Ellipse HDE, the centre C of which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is also the centre of the spheroid HME in which the light spreads, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of which the said Ellipse is the section. And let the incident ray be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: RC, the refraction of which it is required to find.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let there be taken a plane passing through the ray RC and which is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to the plane of the ellipse HDE, cutting it along the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight line BCK; and having in the same plane through RC made CO
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to CR, let OK be adjusted across the angle OCK, so as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to be perpendicular to OC and equal to the line N, which I suppose to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: measure the travel of the light in air during the time that it spreads
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in the crystal through the spheroid HDEM. Then in the plane of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Ellipse HDE let KT be drawn, through the point K, perpendicular to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: BCK. Now if one conceives a plane drawn through the straight line KT
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and touching the spheroid HME at I, the straight line CI will be the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction of the ray RC, as is easy to deduce from that which has
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: been demonstrated in Article 36.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But it must be shown how one can determine the point of contact I. Let
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there be drawn parallel to the line KT a line HF which touches the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Ellipse HDE, and let this point of contact be at H. And having drawn a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight line along CH to meet KT at T, let there be imagined a plane
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: passing through the same CH and through CM (which I suppose to be the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction of the perpendicular ray), which makes in the spheroid the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: elliptical section HME. It is certain that the plane which will pass
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: through the straight line KT, and which will touch the spheroid, will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: touch it at a point in the Ellipse HME, according to the Lemma which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will be demonstrated at the end of the Chapter. Now this point is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: necessarily the point I which is sought, since the plane drawn through
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: TK can touch the spheroid at one point only. And this point I is easy
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to determine, since it is needful only to draw from the point T, which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is in the plane of this Ellipse, the tangent TI, in the way shown
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: previously. For the Ellipse HME is given, and its conjugate
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: semi-diameters are CH and CM; because a straight line drawn through M,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parallel to HE, touches the Ellipse HME, as follows from the fact that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: a plane taken through M, and parallel to the plane HDE, touches the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheroid at that point M, as is seen from Articles 27 and 23. For the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rest, the position of this ellipse, with respect to the plane through
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the ray RC and through CK, is also given; from which it will be easy
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to find the position of CI, the refraction corresponding to the ray
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: RC.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now it must be noted that the same ellipse HME serves to find the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refractions of any other ray which may be in the plane through RC and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CK. Because every plane, parallel to the straight line HF, or TK,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which will touch the spheroid, will touch it in this ellipse,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: according to the Lemma quoted a little before.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I have investigated thus, in minute detail, the properties of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: irregular refraction of this Crystal, in order to see whether each
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: phenomenon that is deduced from our hypothesis accords with that which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is observed in fact. And this being so it affords no slight proof of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the truth of our suppositions and principles. But what I am going to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: add here confirms them again marvellously. It is this: that there are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: different sections of this Crystal, the surfaces of which, thereby
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: produced, give rise to refractions precisely such as they ought to be,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and as I had foreseen them, according to the preceding Theory.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: In order to explain what these sections are, let ABKF _be_ the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: principal section through the axis of the crystal ACK, in which there
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will also be the axis SS of a spheroidal wave of light spreading in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the crystal from the centre C; and the straight line which cuts SS
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: through the middle and at right angles, namely PP, will be one of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: major diameters.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration: {Section ABKF}]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now as in the natural section of the crystal, made by a plane parallel
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to two opposite faces, which plane is here represented by the line GG,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the refraction of the surfaces which are produced by it will be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: governed by the hemi-spheroids GNG, according to what has been
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: explained in the preceding Theory. Similarly, cutting the Crystal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: through NN, by a plane perpendicular to the parallelogram ABKF, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction of the surfaces will be governed by the hemi-spheroids NGN.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And if one cuts it through PP, perpendicularly to the said
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parallelogram, the refraction of the surfaces ought to be governed by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the hemi-spheroids PSP, and so for others. But I saw that if the plane
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: NN was almost perpendicular to the plane GG, making the angle NCG,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which is on the side A, an angle of 90 degrees 40 minutes, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hemi-spheroids NGN would become similar to the hemi-spheroids GNG,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: since the planes NN and GG were equally inclined by an angle of 45
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: degrees 20 minutes to the axis SS. In consequence it must needs be, if
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: our theory is true, that the surfaces which the section through NN
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: produces should effect the same refractions as the surfaces of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: section through GG. And not only the surfaces of the section NN but
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: all other sections produced by planes which might be inclined to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: axis at an angle equal to 45 degrees 20 minutes. So that there are an
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: infinitude of planes which ought to produce precisely the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refractions as the natural surfaces of the crystal, or as the section
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parallel to any one of those surfaces which are made by cleavage.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I saw also that by cutting it by a plane taken through PP, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to the axis SS, the refraction of the surfaces ought to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be such that the perpendicular ray should suffer thereby no deviation;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and that for oblique rays there would always be an irregular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction, differing from the regular, and by which objects placed
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: beneath the crystal would be less elevated than by that other
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: That, similarly, by cutting the crystal by any plane through the axis
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: SS, such as the plane of the figure is, the perpendicular ray ought to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: suffer no refraction; and that for oblique rays there were different
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: measures for the irregular refraction according to the situation of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the plane in which the incident ray was.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now these things were found in fact so; and, after that, I could not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: doubt that a similar success could be met with everywhere. Whence I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: concluded that one might form from this crystal solids similar to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: those which are its natural forms, which should produce, at all their
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surfaces, the same regular and irregular refractions as the natural
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surfaces, and which nevertheless would cleave in quite other ways, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: not in directions parallel to any of their faces. That out of it one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: would be able to fashion pyramids, having their base square,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: pentagonal, hexagonal, or with as many sides as one desired, all the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surfaces of which should have the same refractions as the natural
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surfaces of the crystal, except the base, which will not refract the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular ray. These surfaces will each make an angle of 45
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: degrees 20 minutes with the axis of the crystal, and the base will be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the section perpendicular to the axis.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: That, finally, one could also fashion out of it triangular prisms, or
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: prisms with as many sides as one would, of which neither the sides nor
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the bases would refract the perpendicular ray, although they would yet
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: all cause double refraction for oblique rays. The cube is included
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: amongst these prisms, the bases of which are sections perpendicular to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the axis of the crystal, and the sides are sections parallel to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: same axis.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: From all this it further appears that it is not at all in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: disposition of the layers of which this crystal seems to be composed,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and according to which it splits in three different senses, that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: cause resides of its irregular refraction; and that it would be in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: vain to wish to seek it there.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But in order that any one who has some of this stone may be able to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: find, by his own experience, the truth of what I have just advanced, I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will state here the process of which I have made use to cut it, and to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: polish it. Cutting is easy by the slicing wheels of lapidaries, or in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the way in which marble is sawn: but polishing is very difficult, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: by employing the ordinary means one more often depolishes the surfaces
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: than makes them lucent.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: After many trials, I have at last found that for this service no plate
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of metal must be used, but a piece of mirror glass made matt and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: depolished. Upon this, with fine sand and water, one smoothes the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: crystal little by little, in the same way as spectacle glasses, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: polishes it simply by continuing the work, but ever reducing the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: material. I have not, however, been able to give it perfect clarity
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and transparency; but the evenness which the surfaces acquire enables
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: one to observe in them the effects of refraction better than in those
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: made by cleaving the stone, which always have some inequality.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Even when the surface is only moderately smoothed, if one rubs it over
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: with a little oil or white of egg, it becomes quite transparent, so
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that the refraction is discerned in it quite distinctly. And this aid
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is specially necessary when it is wished to polish the natural
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surfaces to remove the inequalities; because one cannot render them
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: lucent equally with the surfaces of other sections, which take a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: polish so much the better the less nearly they approximate to these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: natural planes.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Before finishing the treatise on this Crystal, I will add one more
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: marvellous phenomenon which I discovered after having written all the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: foregoing. For though I have not been able till now to find its cause,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I do not for that reason wish to desist from describing it, in order
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to give opportunity to others to investigate it. It seems that it will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be necessary to make still further suppositions besides those which I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: have made; but these will not for all that cease to keep their
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: probability after having been confirmed by so many tests.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: The phenomenon is, that by taking two pieces of this crystal and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: applying them one over the other, or rather holding them with a space
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: between the two, if all the sides of one are parallel to those of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: other, then a ray of light, such as AB, is divided into two in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: first piece, namely into BD and BC, following the two refractions,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: regular and irregular. On penetrating thence into the other piece
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: each ray will pass there without further dividing itself in two; but
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that one which underwent the regular refraction, as here DG, will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: undergo again only a regular refraction at GH; and the other, CE, an
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: irregular refraction at EF. And the same thing occurs not only in this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: disposition, but also in all those cases in which the principal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: section of each of the pieces is situated in one and the same plane,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: without it being needful for the two neighbouring surfaces to be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parallel. Now it is marvellous why the rays CE and DG, incident from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the air on the lower crystal, do not divide themselves the same as the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: first ray AB. One would say that it must be that the ray DG in passing
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: through the upper piece has lost something which is necessary to move
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the matter which serves for the irregular refraction; and that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: likewise CE has lost that which was necessary to move the matter
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which serves for regular refraction: but there is yet another thing
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which upsets this reasoning. It is that when one disposes the two
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: crystals in such a way that the planes which constitute the principal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sections intersect one another at right angles, whether the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: neighbouring surfaces are parallel or not, then the ray which has come
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: by the regular refraction, as DG, undergoes only an irregular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction in the lower piece; and on the contrary the ray which has
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: come by the irregular refraction, as CE, undergoes only a regular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But in all the infinite other positions, besides those which I have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: just stated, the rays DG, CE, divide themselves anew each one into
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: two, by refraction in the lower crystal so that from the single ray AB
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there are four, sometimes of equal brightness, sometimes some much
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: less bright than others, according to the varying agreement in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: positions of the crystals: but they do not appear to have all together
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: more light than the single ray AB.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: When one considers here how, while the rays CE, DG, remain the same,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it depends on the position that one gives to the lower piece, whether
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it divides them both in two, or whether it does not divide them, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: yet how the ray AB above is always divided, it seems that one is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: obliged to conclude that the waves of light, after having passed
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: through the first crystal, acquire a certain form or disposition in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: virtue of which, when meeting the texture of the second crystal, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: certain positions, they can move the two different kinds of matter
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which serve for the two species of refraction; and when meeting the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: second crystal in another position are able to move only one of these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: kinds of matter. But to tell how this occurs, I have hitherto found
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: nothing which satisfies me.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Leaving then to others this research, I pass to what I have to say
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: touching the cause of the extraordinary figure of this crystal, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: why it cleaves easily in three different senses, parallel to any one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of its surfaces.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: There are many bodies, vegetable, mineral, and congealed salts, which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: are formed with certain regular angles and figures. Thus among flowers
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there are many which have their leaves disposed in ordered polygons,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to the number of 3, 4, 5, or 6 sides, but not more. This well deserves
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to be investigated, both as to the polygonal figure, and as to why it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: does not exceed the number 6.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Rock Crystal grows ordinarily in hexagonal bars, and diamonds are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: found which occur with a square point and polished surfaces. There is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: a species of small flat stones, piled up directly upon one another,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which are all of pentagonal figure with rounded angles, and the sides
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: a little folded inwards. The grains of gray salt which are formed from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sea water affect the figure, or at least the angle, of the cube; and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in the congelations of other salts, and in that of sugar, there are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: found other solid angles with perfectly flat faces. Small snowflakes
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: almost always fall in little stars with 6 points, and sometimes in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hexagons with straight sides. And I have often observed, in water
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which is beginning to freeze, a kind of flat and thin foliage of ice,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the middle ray of which throws out branches inclined at an angle of 60
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: degrees. All these things are worthy of being carefully investigated
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to ascertain how and by what artifice nature there operates. But it is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: not now my intention to treat fully of this matter. It seems that in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: general the regularity which occurs in these productions comes from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the arrangement of the small invisible equal particles of which they
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: are composed. And, coming to our Iceland Crystal, I say that if there
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: were a pyramid such as ABCD, composed of small rounded corpuscles, not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spherical but flattened spheroids, such as would be made by the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rotation of the ellipse GH around its lesser diameter EF (of which the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ratio to the greater diameter is very nearly that of 1 to the square
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: root of 8)--I say that then the solid angle of the point D would be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equal to the obtuse and equilateral angle of this Crystal. I say,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: further, that if these corpuscles were lightly stuck together, on
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: breaking this pyramid it would break along faces parallel to those
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that make its point: and by this means, as it is easy to see, it would
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: produce prisms similar to those of the same crystal as this other
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: figure represents. The reason is that when broken in this fashion a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: whole layer separates easily from its neighbouring layer since each
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheroid has to be detached only from the three spheroids of the next
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: layer; of which three there is but one which touches it on its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: flattened surface, and the other two at the edges. And the reason why
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the surfaces separate sharp and polished is that if any spheroid of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the neighbouring surface would come out by attaching itself to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surface which is being separated, it would be needful for it to detach
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: itself from six other spheroids which hold it locked, and four of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which press it by these flattened surfaces. Since then not only the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angles of our crystal but also the manner in which it splits agree
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: precisely with what is observed in the assemblage composed of such
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheroids, there is great reason to believe that the particles are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: shaped and ranged in the same way.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration: {Pyramid and section of spheroids}]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: There is even probability enough that the prisms of this crystal are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: produced by the breaking up of pyramids, since Mr. Bartholinus relates
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that he occasionally found some pieces of triangularly pyramidal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: figure. But when a mass is composed interiorly only of these little
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheroids thus piled up, whatever form it may have exteriorly, it is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: certain, by the same reasoning which I have just explained, that if
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: broken it would produce similar prisms. It remains to be seen whether
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there are other reasons which confirm our conjecture, and whether
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there are none which are repugnant to it.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration: {paralleloid arrangement of spheroids with planes of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: potential cleavage}]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It may be objected that this crystal, being so composed, might be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: capable of cleavage in yet two more fashions; one of which would be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: along planes parallel to the base of the pyramid, that is to say to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the triangle ABC; the other would be parallel to a plane the trace of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which is marked by the lines GH, HK, KL. To which I say that both the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: one and the other, though practicable, are more difficult than those
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which were parallel to any one of the three planes of the pyramid; and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that therefore, when striking on the crystal in order to break it, it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ought always to split rather along these three planes than along the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: two others. When one has a number of spheroids of the form above
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: described, and ranges them in a pyramid, one sees why the two methods
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of division are more difficult. For in the case of that division which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: would be parallel to the base, each spheroid would be obliged to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: detach itself from three others which it touches upon their flattened
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surfaces, which hold more strongly than the contacts at the edges. And
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: besides that, this division will not occur along entire layers,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: because each of the spheroids of a layer is scarcely held at all by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the 6 of the same layer that surround it, since they only touch it at
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the edges; so that it adheres readily to the neighbouring layer, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the others to it, for the same reason; and this causes uneven
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surfaces. Also one sees by experiment that when grinding down the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: crystal on a rather rough stone, directly on the equilateral solid
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angle, one verily finds much facility in reducing it in this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: direction, but much difficulty afterwards in polishing the surface
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which has been flattened in this manner.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: As for the other method of division along the plane GHKL, it will be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: seen that each spheroid would have to detach itself from four of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: neighbouring layer, two of which touch it on the flattened surfaces,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and two at the edges. So that this division is likewise more difficult
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: than that which is made parallel to one of the surfaces of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: crystal; where, as we have said, each spheroid is detached from only
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: three of the neighbouring layer: of which three there is one only
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which touches it on the flattened surface, and the other two at the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: edges only.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: However, that which has made me know that in the crystal there are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: layers in this last fashion, is that in a piece weighing half a pound
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which I possess, one sees that it is split along its length, as is the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: above-mentioned prism by the plane GHKL; as appears by colours of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Iris extending throughout this whole plane although the two pieces
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: still hold together. All this proves then that the composition of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: crystal is such as we have stated. To which I again add this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: experiment; that if one passes a knife scraping along any one of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: natural surfaces, and downwards as it were from the equilateral obtuse
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angle, that is to say from the apex of the pyramid, one finds it quite
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: hard; but by scraping in the opposite sense an incision is easily
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: made. This follows manifestly from the situation of the small
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheroids; over which, in the first manner, the knife glides; but in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the other manner it seizes them from beneath almost as if they were
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the scales of a fish.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I will not undertake to say anything touching the way in which so many
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: corpuscles all equal and similar are generated, nor how they are set
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in such beautiful order; whether they are formed first and then
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: assembled, or whether they arrange themselves thus in coming into
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: being and as fast as they are produced, which seems to me more
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: probable. To develop truths so recondite there would be needed a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: knowledge of nature much greater than that which we have. I will add
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: only that these little spheroids could well contribute to form the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheroids of the waves of light, here above supposed, these as well as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: those being similarly situated, and with their axes parallel.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: _Calculations which have been supposed in this Chapter_.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Mr. Bartholinus, in his treatise of this Crystal, puts at 101 degrees
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the obtuse angles of the faces, which I have stated to be 101 degrees
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 52 minutes. He states that he measured these angles directly on the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: crystal, which is difficult to do with ultimate exactitude, because
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the edges such as CA, CB, in this figure, are generally worn, and not
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: quite straight. For more certainty, therefore, I preferred to measure
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: actually the obtuse angle by which the faces CBDA, CBVF, are inclined
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to one another, namely the angle OCN formed by drawing CN
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to FV, and CO perpendicular to DA. This angle OCN I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: found to be 105 degrees; and its supplement CNP, to be 75 degrees, as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it should be.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: centre at C, and on its surface a spherical triangle, formed by the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: intersection of three planes which enclose the solid angle C. In this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equilateral triangle, which is ABF in this other figure, I see that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: each of the angles should be 105 degrees, namely equal to the angle
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: OCN; and that each of the sides should be of as many degrees as the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angle ACB, or ACF, or BCF. Having then drawn the arc FQ perpendicular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to the side AB, which it divides equally at Q, the triangle FQA has a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: right angle at Q, the angle A 105 degrees, and F half as much, namely
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 52 degrees 30 minutes; whence the hypotenuse AF is found to be 101
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: degrees 52 minutes. And this arc AF is the measure of the angle ACF in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the figure of the crystal.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: In the same figure, if the plane CGHF cuts the crystal so that it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: divides the obtuse angles ACB, MHV, in the middle, it is stated, in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Article 10, that the angle CFH is 70 degrees 57 minutes. This again is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: easily shown in the same spherical triangle ABF, in which it appears
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that the arc FQ is as many degrees as the angle GCF in the crystal,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the supplement of which is the angle CFH. Now the arc FQ is found to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be 109 degrees 3 minutes. Then its supplement, 70 degrees 57 minutes,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is the angle CFH.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It was stated, in Article 26, that the straight line CS, which in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: preceding figure is CH, being the axis of the crystal, that is to say
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: being equally inclined to the three sides CA, CB, CF, the angle GCH is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 45 degrees 20 minutes. This is also easily calculated by the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spherical triangle. For by drawing the other arc AD which cuts BF
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equally, and intersects FQ at S, this point will be the centre of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: triangle. And it is easy to see that the arc SQ is the measure of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angle GCH in the figure which represents the crystal. Now in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: triangle QAS, which is right-angled, one knows also the angle A, which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is 52 degrees 30 minutes, and the side AQ 50 degrees 56 minutes;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: whence the side SQ is found to be 45 degrees 20 minutes.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan

author: Huygens, Christiaan
