text: on DC and CP to the square on CD, so also is the square on PE to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: square on _g_C. But DP, CP, and PE are known; hence also one knows GC,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which is 98,779.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: _Lemma which has been supposed_.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: If a spheroid is touched by a straight line, and also by two or more
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: planes which are parallel to this line, though not parallel to one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: another, all the points of contact of the line, as well as of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: planes, will be in one and the same ellipse made by a plane which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: passes through the centre of the spheroid.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let LED be the spheroid touched by the line BM at the point B, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: also by the planes parallel to this line at the points O and A. It is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: required to demonstrate that the points B, O, and A are in one and the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: same Ellipse made in the spheroid by a plane which passes through its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: centre.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Through the line BM, and through the points O and A, let there be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: drawn planes parallel to one another, which, in cutting the spheroid
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: make the ellipses LBD, POP, QAQ; which will all be similar and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: similarly disposed, and will have their centres K, N, R, in one and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the same diameter of the spheroid, which will also be the diameter of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the ellipse made by the section of the plane that passes through the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: centre of the spheroid, and which cuts the planes of the three said
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Ellipses at right angles: for all this is manifest by proposition 15
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the book of Conoids and Spheroids of Archimedes. Further, the two
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: latter planes, which are drawn through the points O and A, will also,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: by cutting the planes which touch the spheroid in these same points,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: generate straight lines, as OH and AS, which will, as is easy to see,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be parallel to BM; and all three, BM, OH, AS, will touch the Ellipses
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: LBD, POP, QAQ in these points, B, O, A; since they are in the planes
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of these ellipses, and at the same time in the planes which touch the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spheroid. If now from these points B, O, A, there are drawn the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight lines BK, ON, AR, through the centres of the same ellipses,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and if through these centres there are drawn also the diameters LD,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: PP, QQ, parallel to the tangents BM, OH, AS; these will be conjugate
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to the aforesaid BK, ON, AR. And because the three ellipses are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: similar and similarly disposed, and have their diameters LD, PP, QQ
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parallel, it is certain that their conjugate diameters BK, ON, AR,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will also be parallel. And the centres K, N, R being, as has been
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: stated, in one and the same diameter of the spheroid, these parallels
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: BK, ON, AR will necessarily be in one and the same plane, which passes
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: through this diameter of the spheroid, and, in consequence, the points
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: R, O, A are in one and the same ellipse made by the intersection of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this plane. Which was to be proved. And it is manifest that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: demonstration would be the same if, besides the points O, A, there had
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: been others in which the spheroid had been touched by planes parallel
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to the straight line BM.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: CHAPTER VI
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ON THE FIGURES OF THE TRANSPARENT BODIES
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Which serve for Refraction and for Reflexion
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: After having explained how the properties of reflexion and refraction
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: follow from what we have supposed concerning the nature of light, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of opaque bodies, and of transparent media, I will here set forth a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: very easy and natural way of deducing, from the same principles, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: true figures which serve, either by reflexion or by refraction, to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: collect or disperse the rays of light, as may be desired. For though I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: do not see yet that there are means of making use of these figures, so
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: far as relates to Refraction, not only because of the difficulty of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: shaping the glasses of Telescopes with the requisite exactitude
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: according to these figures, but also because there exists in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction itself a property which hinders the perfect concurrence of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the rays, as Mr. Newton has very well proved by experiment, I will yet
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: not desist from relating the invention, since it offers itself, so to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: speak, of itself, and because it further confirms our Theory of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction, by the agreement which here is found between the refracted
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ray and the reflected ray. Besides, it may occur that some one in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: future will discover in it utilities which at present are not seen.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: To proceed then to these figures, let us suppose first that it is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: desired to find a surface CDE which shall reassemble at a point B rays
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: coming from another point A; and that the summit of the surface shall
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be the given point D in the straight line AB. I say that, whether by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reflexion or by refraction, it is only necessary to make this surface
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: such that the path of the light from the point A to all points of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: curved line CDE, and from these to the point of concurrence (as here
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the path along the straight lines AC, CB, along AL, LB, and along AD,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: DB), shall be everywhere traversed in equal times: by which principle
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the finding of these curves becomes very easy.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: So far as relates to the reflecting surface, since the sum of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: lines AC, CB ought to be equal to that of AD, DB, it appears that DCE
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ought to be an ellipse; and for refraction, the ratio of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: velocities of waves of light in the media A and B being supposed to be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: known, for example that of 3 to 2 (which is the same, as we have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: shown, as the ratio of the Sines in the refraction), it is only
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: necessary to make DH equal to 3/2 of DB; and having after that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: described from the centre A some arc FC, cutting DB at F, then
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: describe another from centre B with its semi-diameter BX equal to 2/3
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of FH; and the point of intersection of the two arcs will be one of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the points required, through which the curve should pass. For this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: point, having been found in this fashion, it is easy forthwith to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: demonstrate that the time along AC, CB, will be equal to the time
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: along AD, DB.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: For assuming that the line AD represents the time which the light
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: takes to traverse this same distance AD in air, it is evident that DH,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equal to 3/2 of DB, will represent the time of the light along DB in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the medium, because it needs here more time in proportion as its speed
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is slower. Therefore the whole line AH will represent the time along
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AD, DB. Similarly the line AC or AF will represent the time along AC;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and FH being by construction equal to 3/2 of CB, it will represent the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: time along CB in the medium; and in consequence the whole line AH will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: represent also the time along AC, CB. Whence it appears that the time
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: along AC, CB, is equal to the time along AD, DB. And similarly it can
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be shown if L and K are other points in the curve CDE, that the times
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: along AL, LB, and along AK, KB, are always represented by the line AH,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and therefore equal to the said time along AD, DB.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: In order to show further that the surfaces, which these curves will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: generate by revolution, will direct all the rays which reach them from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the point A in such wise that they tend towards B, let there be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: supposed a point K in the curve, farther from D than C is, but such
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that the straight line AK falls from outside upon the curve which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: serves for the refraction; and from the centre B let the arc KS be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: described, cutting BD at S, and the straight line CB at R; and from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the centre A describe the arc DN meeting AK at N.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Since the sums of the times along AK, KB, and along AC, CB are equal,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: if from the former sum one deducts the time along KB, and if from the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: other one deducts the time along RB, there will remain the time along
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AK as equal to the time along the two parts AC, CR. Consequently in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the time that the light has come along AK it will also have come along
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AC and will in addition have made, in the medium from the centre C, a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: partial spherical wave, having a semi-diameter equal to CR. And this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: wave will necessarily touch the circumference KS at R, since CB cuts
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this circumference at right angles. Similarly, having taken any other
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: point L in the curve, one can show that in the same time as the light
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: passes along AL it will also have come along AL and in addition will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: have made a partial wave, from the centre L, which will touch the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: circumference KS. And so with all other points of the curve CDE. Then
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: at the moment that the light reaches K the arc KRS will be the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: termination of the movement, which has spread from A through DCK. And
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: thus this same arc will constitute in the medium the propagation of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the wave emanating from A; which wave may be represented by the arc
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: DN, or by any other nearer the centre A. But all the pieces of the arc
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: KRS are propagated successively along straight lines which are
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to them, that is to say, which tend to the centre B (for
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that can be demonstrated in the same way as we have proved above that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the pieces of spherical waves are propagated along the straight lines
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: coming from their centre), and these progressions of the pieces of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: waves constitute the rays themselves of light. It appears then that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: all these rays tend here towards the point B.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: One might also determine the point C, and all the others, in this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: curve which serves for the refraction, by dividing DA at G in such a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: way that DG is 2/3 of DA, and describing from the centre B any arc CX
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which cuts BD at N, and another from the centre A with its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: semi-diameter AF equal to 3/2 of GX; or rather, having described, as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: before, the arc CX, it is only necessary to make DF equal to 3/2 of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: DX, and from-the centre A to strike the arc FC; for these two
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: constructions, as may be easily known, come back to the first one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which was shown before. And it is manifest by the last method that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this curve is the same that Mr. Des Cartes has given in his Geometry,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and which he calls the first of his Ovals.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It is only a part of this oval which serves for the refraction,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: namely, the part DK, ending at K, if AK is the tangent. As to the,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: other part, Des Cartes has remarked that it could serve for
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reflexions, if there were some material of a mirror of such a nature
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that by its means the force of the rays (or, as we should say, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: velocity of the light, which he could not say, since he held that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: movement of light was instantaneous) could be augmented in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: proportion of 3 to 2. But we have shown that in our way of explaining
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reflexion, such a thing could not arise from the matter of the mirror,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and it is entirely impossible.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: From what has been demonstrated about this oval, it will be easy to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: find the figure which serves to collect to a point incident parallel
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rays. For by supposing just the same construction, but the point A
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: infinitely distant, giving parallel rays, our oval becomes a true
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Ellipse, the construction of which differs in no way from that of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: oval, except that FC, which previously was an arc of a circle, is here
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: a straight line, perpendicular to DB. For the wave of light DN, being
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: likewise represented by a straight line, it will be seen that all the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: points of this wave, travelling as far as the surface KD along lines
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parallel to DB, will advance subsequently towards the point B, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will arrive there at the same time. As for the Ellipse which served
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: for reflexion, it is evident that it will here become a parabola,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: since its focus A may be regarded as infinitely distant from the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: other, B, which is here the focus of the parabola, towards which all
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the reflexions of rays parallel to AB tend. And the demonstration of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: these effects is just the same as the preceding.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But that this curved line CDE which serves for refraction is an
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Ellipse, and is such that its major diameter is to the distance
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: between its foci as 3 to 2, which is the proportion of the refraction,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: can be easily found by the calculus of Algebra. For DB, which is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: given, being called _a_; its undetermined perpendicular DT being
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: called _x_; and TC _y_; FB will be _a - y_; CB will be sqrt(_xx + aa
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: -2ay + yy_). But the nature of the curve is such that 2/3 of TC
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: together with CB is equal to DB, as was stated in the last
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: construction: then the equation will be between _(2/3)y + sqrt(xx + aa
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: - 2ay + yy)_ and _a_; which being reduced, gives _(6/5)ay - yy_ equal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to _(9/5)xx_; that is to say that having made DO equal to 6/5 of DB,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the rectangle DFO is equal to 9/5 of the square on FC. Whence it is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: seen that DC is an ellipse, of which the axis DO is to the parameter
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: as 9 to 5; and therefore the square on DO is to the square of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: distance between the foci as 9 to 9 - 5, that is to say 4; and finally
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the line DO will be to this distance as 3 to 2.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Again, if one supposes the point B to be infinitely distant, in lieu
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of our first oval we shall find that CDE is a true Hyperbola; which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will make those rays become parallel which come from the point A. And
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in consequence also those which are parallel within the transparent
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: body will be collected outside at the point A. Now it must be remarked
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that CX and KS become straight lines perpendicular to BA, because they
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: represent arcs of circles the centre of which is infinitely distant.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And the intersection of the perpendicular CX with the arc FC will give
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the point C, one of those through which the curve ought to pass. And
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: this operates so that all the parts of the wave of light DN, coming to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: meet the surface KDE, will advance thence along parallels to KS and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will arrive at this straight line at the same time; of which the proof
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is again the same as that which served for the first oval. Besides one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: finds by a calculation as easy as the preceding one, that CDE is here
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: a hyperbola of which the axis DO is 4/5 of AD, and the parameter
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equal to AD. Whence it is easily proved that DO is to the distance
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: between the foci as 3 to 2.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: These are the two cases in which Conic sections serve for refraction,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and are the same which are explained, in his _Dioptrique_, by Des
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Cartes, who first found out the use of these lines in relation to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction, as also that of the Ovals the first of which we have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: already set forth. The second oval is that which serves for rays that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: tend to a given point; in which oval, if the apex of the surface which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: receives the rays is D, it will happen that the other apex will be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: situated between B and A, or beyond A, according as the ratio of AD to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: DB is given of greater or lesser value. And in this latter case it is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the same as that which Des Cartes calls his 3rd oval.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now the finding and construction of this second oval is the same as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that of the first, and the demonstration of its effect likewise. But
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it is worthy of remark that in one case this oval becomes a perfect
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: circle, namely when the ratio of AD to DB is the same as the ratio of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the refractions, here as 3 to 2, as I observed a long time ago. The
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 4th oval, serving only for impossible reflexions, there is no need to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: set it forth.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: As for the manner in which Mr. Des Cartes discovered these lines,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: since he has given no explanation of it, nor any one else since that I
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: know of, I will say here, in passing, what it seems to me it must have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: been. Let it be proposed to find the surface generated by the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: revolution of the curve KDE, which, receiving the incident rays coming
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to it from the point A, shall deviate them toward the point B. Then
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: considering this other curve as already known, and that its apex D is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: in the straight line AB, let us divide it up into an infinitude of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: small pieces by the points G, C, F; and having drawn from each of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: these points, straight lines towards A to represent the incident rays,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and other straight lines towards B, let there also be described with
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: centre A the arcs GL, CM, FN, DO, cutting the rays that come from A at
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: L, M, N, O; and from the points K, G, C, F, let there be described
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the arcs KQ, GR, CS, FT cutting the rays towards B at Q, R, S, T; and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: let us suppose that the straight line HKZ cuts the curve at K at
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: right-angles.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Then AK being an incident ray, and KB its refraction within the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: medium, it needs must be, according to the law of refraction which was
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: known to Mr. Des Cartes, that the sine of the angle ZKA should be to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the sine of the angle HKB as 3 to 2, supposing that this is the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: proportion of the refraction of glass; or rather, that the sine of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: angle KGL should have this same ratio to the sine of the angle GKQ,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: considering KG, GL, KQ as straight lines because of their smallness.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But these sines are the lines KL and GQ, if GK is taken as the radius
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of the circle. Then LK ought to be to GQ as 3 to 2; and in the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ratio MG to CR, NC to FS, OF to DT. Then also the sum of all the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: antecedents to all the consequents would be as 3 to 2. Now by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: prolonging the arc DO until it meets AK at X, KX is the sum of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: antecedents. And by prolonging the arc KQ till it meets AD at Y, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sum of the consequents is DY. Then KX ought to be to DY as 3 to 2.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Whence it would appear that the curve KDE was of such a nature that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: having drawn from some point which had been assumed, such as K, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight lines KA, KB, the excess by which AK surpasses AD should be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to the excess of DB over KB, as 3 to 2. For it can similarly be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: demonstrated, by taking any other point in the curve, such as G, that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the excess of AG over AD, namely VG, is to the excess of BD over DG,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: namely DP, in this same ratio of 3 to 2. And following this principle
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Mr. Des Cartes constructed these curves in his _Geometric_; and he
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: easily recognized that in the case of parallel rays, these curves
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: became Hyperbolas and Ellipses.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let us now return to our method and let us see how it leads without
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: difficulty to the finding of the curves which one side of the glass
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: requires when the other side is of a given figure; a figure not only
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: plane or spherical, or made by one of the conic sections (which is the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: restriction with which Des Cartes proposed this problem, leaving the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: solution to those who should come after him) but generally any figure
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: whatever: that is to say, one made by the revolution of any given
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: curved line to which one must merely know how to draw straight lines
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: as tangents.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let the given figure be that made by the revolution of some curve such
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: as AK about the axis AV, and that this side of the glass receives rays
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: coming from the point L. Furthermore, let the thickness AB of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: middle of the glass be given, and the point F at which one desires the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rays to be all perfectly reunited, whatever be the first refraction
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: occurring at the surface AK.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: I say that for this the sole requirement is that the outline BDK which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: constitutes the other surface shall be such that the path of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: light from the point L to the surface AK, and from thence to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surface BDK, and from thence to the point F, shall be traversed
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: everywhere in equal times, and in each case in a time equal to that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which the light employs, to pass along the straight line LF of which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the part AB is within the glass.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let LG be a ray falling on the arc AK. Its refraction GV will be given
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: by means of the tangent which will be drawn at the point G. Now in GV
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the point D must be found such that FD together with 3/2 of DG and the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight line GL, may be equal to FB together with 3/2 of BA and the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight line AL; which, as is clear, make up a given length. Or
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rather, by deducting from each the length of LG, which is also given,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it will merely be needful to adjust FD up to the straight line VG in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: such a way that FD together with 3/2 of DG is equal to a given
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight line, which is a quite easy plane problem: and the point D
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will be one of those through which the curve BDK ought to pass. And
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: similarly, having drawn another ray LM, and found its refraction MO,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the point N will be found in this line, and so on as many times as one
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: desires.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: To demonstrate the effect of the curve, let there be described about
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the centre L the circular arc AH, cutting LG at H; and about the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: centre F the arc BP; and in AB let AS be taken equal to 2/3 of HG; and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: SE equal to GD. Then considering AH as a wave of light emanating from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the point L, it is certain that during the time in which its piece H
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: arrives at G the piece A will have advanced within the transparent
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: body only along AS; for I suppose, as above, the proportion of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction to be as 3 to 2. Now we know that the piece of wave which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: is incident on G, advances thence along the line GD, since GV is the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction of the ray LG. Then during the time that this piece of wave
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: has taken from G to D, the other piece which was at S has reached E,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: since GD, SE are equal. But while the latter will advance from E to B,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the piece of wave which was at D will have spread into the air its
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: partial wave, the semi-diameter of which, DC (supposing this wave to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: cut the line DF at C), will be 3/2 of EB, since the velocity of light
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: outside the medium is to that inside as 3 to 2. Now it is easy to show
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that this wave will touch the arc BP at this point C. For since, by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: construction, FD + 3/2 DG + GL are equal to FB + 3/2 BA + AL; on
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: deducting the equals LH, LA, there will remain FD + 3/2 DG + GH equal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to FB + 3/2 BA. And, again, deducting from one side GH, and from the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: other side 3/2 of AS, which are equal, there will remain FD with 3/2
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: DG equal to FB with 3/2 of BS. But 3/2 of DG are equal to 3/2 of ES;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: then FD is equal to FB with 3/2 of BE. But DC was equal to 3/2 of EB;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: then deducting these equal lengths from one side and from the other,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there will remain CF equal to FB. And thus it appears that the wave,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the semi-diameter of which is DC, touches the arc BP at the moment
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: when the light coming from the point L has arrived at B along the line
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: LB. It can be demonstrated similarly that at this same moment the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: light that has come along any other ray, such as LM, MN, will have
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: propagated the movement which is terminated at the arc BP. Whence it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: follows, as has been often said, that the propagation of the wave AH,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: after it has passed through the thickness of the glass, will be the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spherical wave BP, all the pieces of which ought to advance along
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight lines, which are the rays of light, to the centre F. Which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: was to be proved. Similarly these curved lines can be found in all the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: cases which can be proposed, as will be sufficiently shown by one or
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: two examples which I will add.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Let there be given the surface of the glass AK, made by the revolution
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: about the axis BA of the line AK, which may be straight or curved. Let
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: there be also given in the axis the point L and the thickness BA of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the glass; and let it be required to find the other surface KDB, which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: receiving rays that are parallel to AB will direct them in such wise
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that after being again refracted at the given surface AK they will all
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be reassembled at the point L.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: From the point L let there be drawn to some point of the given line
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AK the straight line LG, which, being considered as a ray of light,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: its refraction GD will then be found. And this line being then
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: prolonged at one side or the other will meet the straight line BL, as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: here at V. Let there then be erected on AB the perpendicular BC, which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will represent a wave of light coming from the infinitely distant
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: point F, since we have supposed the rays to be parallel. Then all the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parts of this wave BC must arrive at the same time at the point L; or
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: rather all the parts of a wave emanating from the point L must arrive
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: at the same time at the straight line BC. And for that, it is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: necessary to find in the line VGD the point D such that having drawn
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: DC parallel to AB, the sum of CD, plus 3/2 of DG, plus GL may be equal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to 3/2 of AB, plus AL: or rather, on deducting from both sides GL,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which is given, CD plus 3/2 of DG must be equal to a given length;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: which is a still easier problem than the preceding construction. The
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: point D thus found will be one of those through which the curve ought
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to pass; and the proof will be the same as before. And by this it will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be proved that the waves which come from the point L, after having
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: passed through the glass KAKB, will take the form of straight lines,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: as BC; which is the same thing as saying that the rays will become
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: parallel. Whence it follows reciprocally that parallel rays falling on
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the surface KDB will be reassembled at the point L.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Again, let there be given the surface AK, of any desired form,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: generated by revolution about the axis AB, and let the thickness of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the glass at the middle be AB. Also let the point L be given in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: axis behind the glass; and let it be supposed that the rays which fall
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: on the surface AK tend to this point, and that it is required to find
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the surface BD, which on their emergence from the glass turns them as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: if they came from the point F in front of the glass.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Having taken any point G in the line AK, and drawing the straight line
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: IGL, its part GI will represent one of the incident rays, the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refraction of which, GV, will then be found: and it is in this line
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that we must find the point D, one of those through which the curve DG
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ought to pass. Let us suppose that it has been found: and about L as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: centre let there be described GT, the arc of a circle cutting the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight line AB at T, in case the distance LG is greater than LA; for
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: otherwise the arc AH must be described about the same centre, cutting
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the straight line LG at H. This arc GT (or AH, in the other case) will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: represent an incident wave of light, the rays of which tend towards
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: L. Similarly, about the centre F let there be described the circular
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: arc DQ, which will represent a wave emanating from the point F.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Then the wave TG, after having passed through the glass, must form the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: wave QD; and for this I observe that the time taken by the light along
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: GD in the glass must be equal to that taken along the three, TA, AB,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and BQ, of which AB alone is within the glass. Or rather, having taken
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AS equal to 2/3 of AT, I observe that 3/2 of GD ought to be equal to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: 3/2 of SB, plus BQ; and, deducting both of them from FD or FQ, that FD
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: less 3/2 of GD ought to be equal to FB less 3/2 of SB. And this last
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: difference is a given length: and all that is required is to draw the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: straight line FD from the given point F to meet VG so that it may be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: thus. Which is a problem quite similar to that which served for the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: first of these constructions, where FD plus 3/2 of GD had to be equal
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to a given length.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: In the demonstration it is to be observed that, since the arc BC falls
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: within the glass, there must be conceived an arc RX, concentric with
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it and on the other side of QD. Then after it shall have been shown
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that the piece G of the wave GT arrives at D at the same time that the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: piece T arrives at Q, which is easily deduced from the construction,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it will be evident as a consequence that the partial wave generated at
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the point D will touch the arc RX at the moment when the piece Q shall
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: have come to R, and that thus this arc will at the same moment be the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: termination of the movement that comes from the wave TG; whence all
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the rest may be concluded.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Having shown the method of finding these curved lines which serve for
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the perfect concurrence of the rays, there remains to be explained a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: notable thing touching the uncoordinated refraction of spherical,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: plane, and other surfaces: an effect which if ignored might cause some
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: doubt concerning what we have several times said, that rays of light
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: are straight lines which intersect at right angles the waves which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: travel along them.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: For in the case of rays which, for example, fall parallel upon a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spherical surface AFE, intersecting one another, after refraction, at
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: different points, as this figure represents; what can the waves of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: light be, in this transparent body, which are cut at right angles by
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the converging rays? For they can not be spherical. And what will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: these waves become after the said rays begin to intersect one another?
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It will be seen in the solution of this difficulty that something very
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: remarkable comes to pass herein, and that the waves do not cease to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: persist though they do not continue entire, as when they cross the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: glasses designed according to the construction we have seen.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: According to what has been shown above, the straight line AD, which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: has been drawn at the summit of the sphere, at right angles to the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: axis parallel to which the rays come, represents the wave of light;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and in the time taken by its piece D to reach the spherical surface
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AGE at E, its other parts will have met the same surface at F, G, H,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: etc., and will have also formed spherical partial waves of which these
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: points are the centres. And the surface EK which all those waves will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: touch, will be the continuation of the wave AD in the sphere at the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: moment when the piece D has reached E. Now the line EK is not an arc
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of a circle, but is a curved line formed as the evolute of another
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: curve ENC, which touches all the rays HL, GM, FO, etc., that are the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: refractions of the parallel rays, if we imagine laid over the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: convexity ENC a thread which in unwinding describes at its end E the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: said curve EK. For, supposing that this curve has been thus described,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: we will show that the said waves formed from the centres F, G, H,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: etc., will all touch it.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: It is certain that the curve EK and all the others described by the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: evolution of the curve ENC, with different lengths of thread, will cut
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: all the rays HL, GM, FO, etc., at right angles, and in such wise that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the parts of them intercepted between two such curves will all be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: equal; for this follows from what has been demonstrated in our
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: treatise _de Motu Pendulorum_. Now imagining the incident rays as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: being infinitely near to one another, if we consider two of them, as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: RG, TF, and draw GQ perpendicular to RG, and if we suppose the curve
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: FS which intersects GM at P to have been described by evolution from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the curve NC, beginning at F, as far as which the thread is supposed
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to extend, we may assume the small piece FP as a straight line
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to the ray GM, and similarly the arc GF as a straight
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: line. But GM being the refraction of the ray RG, and FP being
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: perpendicular to it, QF must be to GP as 3 to 2, that is to say in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: proportion of the refraction; as was shown above in explaining the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: discovery of Des Cartes. And the same thing occurs in all the small
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: arcs GH, HA, etc., namely that in the quadrilaterals which enclose
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: them the side parallel to the axis is to the opposite side as 3 to 2.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Then also as 3 to 2 will the sum of the one set be to the sum of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: other; that is to say, TF to AS, and DE to AK, and BE to SK or DV,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: supposing V to be the intersection of the curve EK and the ray FO.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: But, making FB perpendicular to DE, the ratio of 3 to 2 is also that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: of BE to the semi-diameter of the spherical wave which emanated from
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the point F while the light outside the transparent body traversed the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: space BE. Then it appears that this wave will intersect the ray FM at
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the same point V where it is intersected at right angles by the curve
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: EK, and consequently that the wave will touch this curve. In the same
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: way it can be proved that the same will apply to all the other waves
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: above mentioned, originating at the points G, H, etc.; to wit, that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: they will touch the curve EK at the moment when the piece D of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: wave ED shall have reached E.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Now to say what these waves become after the rays have begun to cross
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: one another: it is that from thence they fold back and are composed of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: two contiguous parts, one being a curve formed as evolute of the curve
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ENC in one sense, and the other as evolute of the same curve in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: opposite sense. Thus the wave KE, while advancing toward the meeting
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: place becomes _abc_, whereof the part _ab_ is made by the evolute
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: _b_C, a portion of the curve ENC, while the end C remains attached;
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: and the part _bc_ by the evolute of the portion _b_E while the end E
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: remains attached. Consequently the same wave becomes _def_, then
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: _ghk_, and finally CY, from whence it subsequently spreads without any
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: fold, but always along curved lines which are evolutes of the curve
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: ENC, increased by some straight line at the end C.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: There is even, in this curve, a part EN which is straight, N being the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: point where the perpendicular from the centre X of the sphere falls
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: upon the refraction of the ray DE, which I now suppose to touch the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: sphere. The folding of the waves of light begins from the point N up
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: to the end of the curve C, which point is formed by taking AC to CX in
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the proportion of the refraction, as here 3 to 2.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: As many other points as may be desired in the curve NC are found by a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Theorem which Mr. Barrow has demonstrated in section 12 of his
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: _Lectiones Opticae_, though for another purpose. And it is to be noted
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that a straight line equal in length to this curve can be given. For
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: since it together with the line NE is equal to the line CK, which is
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: known, since DE is to AK in the proportion of the refraction, it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: appears that by deducting EN from CK the remainder will be equal to
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the curve NC.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Similarly the waves that are folded back in reflexion by a concave
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: spherical mirror can be found. Let ABC be the section, through the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: axis, of a hollow hemisphere, the centre of which is D, its axis being
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: DB, parallel to which I suppose the rays of light to come. All the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: reflexions of those rays which fall upon the quarter-circle AB will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: touch a curved line AFE, of which line the end E is at the focus of
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the hemisphere, that is to say, at the point which divides the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: semi-diameter BD into two equal parts. The points through which this
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: curve ought to pass are found by taking, beyond A, some arc AO, and
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: making the arc OP double the length of it; then dividing the chord OP
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: at F in such wise that the part FP is three times the part FO; for
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: then F is one of the required points.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: [Illustration]
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: And as the parallel rays are merely perpendiculars to the waves which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: fall on the concave surface, which waves are parallel to AD, it will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be found that as they come successively to encounter the surface AB,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: they form on reflexion folded waves composed of two curves which
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: originate from two opposite evolutions of the parts of the curve AFE.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: So, taking AD as an incident wave, when the part AG shall have met the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: surface AI, that is to say when the piece G shall have reached I, it
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: will be the curves HF, FI, generated as evolutes of the curves FA, FE,
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: both beginning at F, which together constitute the propagation of the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: part AG. And a little afterwards, when the part AK has met the surface
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: AM, the piece K having come to M, then the curves LN, NM, will
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: together constitute the propagation of that part. And thus this folded
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: wave will continue to advance until the point N has reached the focus
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: E. The curve AFE can be seen in smoke, or in flying dust, when a
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: concave mirror is held opposite the sun. And it should be known that
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: it is none other than that curve which is described by the point E on
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: the circumference of the circle EB, when that circle is made to roll
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: within another whose semi-diameter is ED and whose centre is D. So
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: that it is a kind of Cycloid, of which, however, the points can be
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: found geometrically.
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: Its length is exactly equal to 3/4 of the diameter of the sphere, as
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: can be found and demonstrated by means of these waves, nearly in the
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: same way as the mensuration of the preceding curve; though it may also
author: Huygens, Christiaan

text: be demonstrated in other ways, which I omit as outside the subject.

text: assertained my selfe, that the first and neerest to _Jupiter_, moved
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: revolution in one naturall day, and 18 hours, and almost an halfe. The
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: second moves in its Orbe 14 _gr._ 13 _min._ or very neer, in an hour,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and its compleat conversion is consummate in 3 dayes, 13 hours, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: one third, or thereabouts. The third passeth in an hour, 2 _gr._ 6
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: rest, goes in one houre, 0 _gr_ 54 _min._ and almost an halfe of its
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Sphere, and finisheth it all in 16 dayes, and very neer 18 hours. But
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: because the excessive velocity of their returns or restitutions,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: requires a most scrupulous precisenesse to calculate their places, in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: times past and future, especially if the time be for many Moneths or
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than the former, and in times more remote from one another, to correct
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [1] The Authors Observations of the Solar Spots
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo
