author: Galilei, Galileo

text: thereabouts, finisheth its Period, caried about in a Circle, an
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: accident great of it selfe, and greater for its Consequences._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: As to the other particular in the next place [B] Many causes have
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: moved me to write the present Tract, the subject whereof, is the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Dispute which I held some dayes since, with some learned men of this
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: City, about which, as your Highnesse knows, have followed many
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Discourses: The principall of which Causes hath been the Intimation of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: your Highnesse, having commended to me Writing, as a singular means to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: make true known from false, reall from apparent Reasons, farr better
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than by Disputing vocally, where the one or the other, or very often
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: both the Disputants, through too greate heate, or exalting of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: voyce, either are not understood, or else being transported by
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ostentation of not yeilding to one another, farr from the first
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Proposition, with the novelty, of the various Proposals, confound both
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: themselves and their Auditors.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [B] The occasion inducing the Author to write this Treatise.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Moreover, it seemed to me convenient to informe your Highnesse of all
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the sequell, concerning the Controversie of which I treat, as it hath
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: been advertised often already by others: and because the Doctrine
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which I follow, in the discussion of the point in hand, is different
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: from that of _Aristotle_; and interferes with his Principles, I have
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: considered that against the Authority of that most famous Man, which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: amongst many makes all suspected that comes not from the Schooles of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Peripateticks, its farr better to give ones Reasons by the Pen
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than by word of mouth, and therfore I resolved to write the present
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: discourse: in which yet I hope to demonstrate that it was not out of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: capritiousnesse, or for that I had not read or understood _Aristotle_,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that I sometimes swerve from his opinion, but because severall Reasons
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: perswade me to it, and the same _Aristotle_ hath tought me to fix my
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: judgment on that which is grounded upon Reason, and not on the bare
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Authority of the Master[2]; and it is most certaine according to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sentence of _Alcinoos_, that philosophating should be free. Nor is the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: resolution of our Question in my judgment without some benefit to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Universall[3], forasmuch as treating whether the figure of Solids
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: operates, or not, in their going, or not going to the bottome in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water, in occurrences of building Bridges or other Fabricks on the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water, which happen commonly in affairs of grand import, it may be of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: great availe to know the truth.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [2] _Aristotle_ prefers Reason to the Authority ofan Author.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [3] The benefit of this Argument.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I say therfore, that being the last Summer in company with certain
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Learned men, it was said in the argumentation; That Condensation was
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the propriety of Cold[4], and there was alledged for instance, the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: example of Ice: now I at that time said, that, in my judgment, the Ice
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: should be rather Water rarified than condensed[5], and my reason was,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: because Condensation begets diminution of Mass, and augmentation of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: gravity, and Rarifaction causeth greater Lightness, and augmentarion
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of Masse: and Water in freezing, encreaseth in Masse, and the Ice made
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: thereby is lighter than the Water on which it swimmeth.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [4] Condensation the Propriety of Cold, according to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Peripateticks.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [5] Ice rather water rarified, than condensed, and why:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _What I say, is manifest, because, the medium subtracting from the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: whole Gravity of Sollids the weight of such another Masse of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: said Medium; as_ Archimedes _proves in his_ [C] First Booke De
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Insidentibus Humido; _when ever the Masse of the said Solid
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: encreaseth by Distraction, the more shall the_ Medium _detract from
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: its entire Gravity; and lesse, when by Compression it shall be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: condensed and reduced to a lesse Masse._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [C] In lib: 1. of Natation of Bodies Prop. 7.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: Figure operates not in the Natation of Sollids.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: It was answered me, tha{t} that proceeded not from the greater Levity,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but from the Figure, large and flat, which not being able to penetrate
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Resistance of the Water, is the cause that it submergeth not. I
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: replied, that any piece of Ice, of whatsoever Figure, swims upon the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water, a manifest signe, that its being never so flat and broad, hath
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: not any part in its floating: and added, that it was a manifest proofe
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: hereof to see a piece of Ice of very broad Figure being thrust to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: botome of the Water, suddenly return to flote atoppe, which had it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: been more grave, and had its swimming proceeded from its Forme, unable
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to penetrate the Resistance of the _Medium_, that would be altogether
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: impossible; I concluded therefore, that the Figure was in sort a Cause
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the Natation or Submersion of Bodies, but the greater or lesse
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Gravity in respect of the Water: and therefore all Bodyes heavier than
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: it of what Figure soever they be, indifferently go to the bottome, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the lighter, though of any figure, float indifferently on the top: and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I suppose that those which hold otherwise, were induced to that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: beliefe, by seeing how that diversity of Formes or Figures, greatly
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: altereth the Velosity, and Tardity of Motion; so that Bodies of Figure
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: broad and thin, descend far more leasurely into the Water, than those
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of a more compacted Figure, though both made of the same Matter: by
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which some might be induced to believe that the Dilatation of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figure might reduce it to such amplenesse that it should not only
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: retard but wholly impede and take away the Motion, which I hold to be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: false. Upon this Conclusion, in many dayes discourse, was spoken much,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and many things, and divers Experiments produced, of which your
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Highnesse heard, and saw some, and in this discourse shall have all
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that which hath been produced against my Assertion, and what hath been
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: suggested to my thoughts on this matter, and for confirmation of my
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Conclusion: which if it shall suffice to remove that (as I esteem
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: hitherto false) Opinion, I shall thinke I have not unprofitably spent
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: my paynes and time. and although that come not to passe, yet ought I
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to promise another benefit to my selfe, namely, of attaining the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: knowledge of the truth, by hearing my Fallacyes confuted, and true
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: demonstrations produced by those of the contrary opinion.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And to proceed with the greatest plainness and perspicuity that I can
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: possible, it is, I conceive, necessary, first of all to declare what
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: is the true, intrinsecall, and totall Cause, of the ascending of some
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Sollid Bodyes in the Water, and therein floating; or on the contrary,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of their sinking and so much the rather in asmuch as I cannot satisfie
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: myselfe in that which _Aristotle_ hath left written on this Subject.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: The cause of the Natation & submersion of Solids in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Water.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I say then the Cause why some Sollid Bodyes descend to the Bottom of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water, is the excesse of their Gravity, above the Gravity of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water; and on the contrary, the excess of the Waters Gravity above the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Gravity of those, is the Cause that others do not descend, rather that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: they rise from the Bottom, and ascend to the Surface. This was
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: subtilly demonstrated by _Archimedes_ in his Book Of the NATATION of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: BODIES: Conferred afterwards by a very grave Author, but, if I erre
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: not invisibly, as below for defence of him, I shall endeavour to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: prove.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I, with a different Method, and by other meanes, will endeavour to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: demonstrate the same, reducing the Causes of such Effects to more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: intrinsecall and immediate Principles, in which also are discovered
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Causes of some admirable and almost incredible Accidents, as that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: would be, that a very little quantity of Water, should be able, with
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: its small weight, to raise and sustain a Solid Body, an hundred or a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: thousand times heavier than it.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And because demonstrative Order so requires, I shall define certain
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Termes, and afterwards explain some Propositions, of which, as of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: things true and obvious, I may make use of to my present purpose.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: DEFINITION I.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _I then call equally Grave_ in specie, _those Matters of which equall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Masses weigh equally._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: As if for example, two Balls, one of Wax, and the other of some Wood
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of equall Masse, were also equall in Weight, we say, that such Wood,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and the Wax are _in specie_ equally grave.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: DEFINITION II.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _But equally grave in Absolute Gravity, we call two Sollids,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: weighing equally, though of Mass they be unequall._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: As for example, a Mass of Lead, and another of Wood, that weigh each
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ten pounds, I call equall in Absolute Gravity, though the Mass of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Wood be much greater then that of the Lead.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _And, consequently, less Grave_ in specie.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: DEFINITION III.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _I call a Matter more Grave_ in specie _than another, of which a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Mass, equall to a Mass of the other, shall weigh more._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And so I say, that Lead is more grave _in specie_ than Tinn, because
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: if you take of them two equall Masses, that of the Lead weigheth more.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: DEFINITION IV.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _But I call that Body more grave absolutely than this, if that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: weigh more than this, without any respect had to the Masses._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And thus a great piece of Wood is said to weigh more than a little
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: lump of Lead, though the Lead be _in specie_ more heavy than the Wood.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And the same is to be understood of the less grave _in specie_, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the less grave absolutely.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: These Termes defined, I take from the Mechanicks two Principles: the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: first is, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: AXIOME. I.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Weights absolutely equall, moved with equall Velocity, are of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: equall Force and Moment in their operations._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _DEFINITION V._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Moment, amongst Mechanicians, signifieth that Vertue, that Force,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: or that Efficacy, with which the Mover moves, and the Moveable
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: resists.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Which Vertue dependes not only on the simple Gravity, but on the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Velocity of the Motion, and on the diverse Inclinations of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Spaces along which the Motion is made: For a descending Weight
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: makes a greater Impetus in a Space much declining, than in one less
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: declining; and in summe, what ever is the occasion of such Vertue,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: it ever retaines the name of Moment; nor in my Judgement, is this
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sence new in our Idiome, for, if I mistake not, I think we often
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: say; This is a weighty businesse, but the other is of small moment:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and we consider lighter matters and let pass those of Moment; a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Metaphor, I suppose, taken from the Mechanicks._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: As for example, two weights equall in absolute Gravity, being put
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: into a Ballance of equall Arms, they stand in _Equilibrium_, neither
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: one going down, nor the other up: because the equality of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Distances of both, from the Centre on which the Ballance is supported,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and about which it moves, causeth that those weights, the said
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Ballance moving, shall in the same Time move equall Spaces, that is,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall move with equall Velocity, so that there is no reason for which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: this Weight should descend more than that, or that more than this; and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: therefore they make an _Equilibrium_, and their Moments continue of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: semblable and equall Vertue.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: The second Principle is; That
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: AXIOME II.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _The Moment and Force of the Gravity, is encreased by the Velocity
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the Motion._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: So that Weights absolutely equall, but conjoyned with Velocity
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: unequall, are of Force, Moment and Vertue unequall: and the more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: potent, the more swift, according to the proportion of the Velocity of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the one, to the Velocity of the other. Of this we have a very
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: pertinent example in the Balance or Stiliard of unequall Arms, at
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which Weights absolutely equall being suspended, they do not weigh
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: down, and gravitate equally, but that which is at a greater distance
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: from the Centre, about which the Beam moves, descends, raising the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: other, and the Motion of this which ascends is slow, and the other
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: swift: and such is the Force and Vertue, which from the Velocity of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Mover, is conferred on the Moveable, which receives it, that it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: can exquisitely compensate, as much more Weight added to the other
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: slower Moveable: so that if of the Arms of the Balance, one were ten
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: times as long as the other, whereupon in the Beames moving about the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Centre, the end of that would go ten times as far as the end of this,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: a Weight suspended at the greater distance, may sustain and poyse
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: another ten times more grave absolutely than it: and that because the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Stiliard moving, the lesser Weight shall move ten times faster than
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the bigger. It ought alwayes therefore to be understood, that Motions
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: are according to the same Inclinations, namely, that if one of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Moveables move perpendicularly to the Horizon, then the other makes
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: its Motion by the like Perpendicular; and if the Motion of one were to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: be made Horizontally; that then the other is made along the same
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Horizontall plain: and in summe, alwayes both in like Inclinations.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: This proportion between the Gravity and Velocity is found in all
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Mechanicall Instruments: and is considered by _Aristotle_, as a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Principle in his _Mechanicall Questions_; whereupon we also may take
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: it for a true Assumption, That
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: AXIOME III.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Weights absolutely unequall, do alternately counterpoyse and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: become of equall Moments, as oft as their Gravities, with
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: contrary proportion, answer to the Velocity of their Motions._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: That is to say, that by how much the one is less grave than the other,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: by so much is it in a constitution of moving more swiftly than that.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Having prefatically explicated these things, we may begin to enquire,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: what Bodyes those are which totally submerge in Water, and go to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Bottom, and which those that by constraint float on the top, so that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: being thrust by violence under Water, they return to swim, with one
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: part of their Mass visible above the Surface of the Water: and this we
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: will do by considering the respective operation of the said Solids,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and of Water: Which operation followes the Submersion and sinking; and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: this it is[6], That in the Submersion that the Solid maketh, being
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: depressed downwards by its proper Gravity, it comes to drive away the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water from the place where it successively subenters, and the water
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: repulsed riseth and ascends above its first levell, to which Ascent on
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the other side it, as being a grave Body of its own nature, resists:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And because the descending Solid more and more immerging, greater and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: greater quantity of Water ascends, till the whole Sollid be submerged;
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: its necessary to compare the Moments of the Resistance of the water to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Ascension, with the Moments of the pressive Gravity of the Solid: And
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: if the Moments of the Resistance of the water, shall equalize the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Moments of the Solid, before its totall Immersion[7]; in this case
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: doubtless there shall be made an _Equilibrium_, nor shall the Body
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sink any farther. But if the Moment of the Solid, shall alwayes exceed
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Moments wherewith the repulsed water successively makes
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Resistance[8], that Solid shall not only wholly submerge under water, but
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall descend to the Bottom. But if, lastly, in the instant of totall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Submersion, the equality shall be made between the Moments of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: prement Solid, and the resisting Water[9]; then shall rest, ensue, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the said Solid shall be able to rest indifferently, in whatsoever part
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the water. By this time is manifest the necessity of comparing the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Gravity of the water, and of the Solid[10]; and this comparison might at
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: first sight seem sufficient to conclude and determine which are the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Solids that float a-top, and which those that sink to the Bottom in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the water, asserting that those shall float which are lesse grave _in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: specie_ than the water, and those submerge, which are _in specie_ more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: grave. For it seems in appearance, that the Sollid in sinking
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: continually, raiseth so much Water in Mass, as answers to the parts of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: its own Bulk submerged: whereupon it is impossible, that a Solid less
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: grave _in specie_, than water, should wholly sink, as being unable to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: raise a weight greater than its own, and such would a Mass of water
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: equall to its own Mass be. And likewise it seems necessary, that the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: graver Solids do go to the Bottom, as being of a Force more than
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sufficient for the raising a Masse of water, equall to its own, though
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: inferiour in weight. Nevertheless the business succeeds otherwise: and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: though the Conclusions are true, yet are the Causes thus assigned
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: deficient, nor is it true, that the Solid in submerging, raiseth and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: repulseth Masses of Water, equall to the parts of it self submerged;
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but the Water repulsed, is alwayes less than the parts of the Solid
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: submerged[11]: and so much the more by how much the Vessell in which the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water is contained is narrower: in such manner that it hinders not,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but that a Solid may submerge all under Water, without raising so much
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water in Mass, as would equall the tenth or twentieth part of its own
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Bulk: like as on the contrary, a very small quantity of Water, may
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: raise a very great Solid Mass[12], though such Solid should weigh
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: absolutely a hundred times as much, or more, than the said Water, if
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: so be that the Matter of that same Solid be _in specie_ less grave
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than the Water. And thus a great Beam, as suppose of a 1000 weight,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: may be raised and born afloat by Water, which weighs not 50: and this
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: happens when the Moment of the Water is compensated by the Velocity of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: its Motion.
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: hath to it the same proportion, that the Surface of the Water
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Levell E F G, before the Solid Prisme H I K be therein immerged; but
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Water N F, equall to the whole Solid H I K: And, therefore, the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Mass L G shall have the same proportion to E M, as to the Mass H I K:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: But the Mass L G hath the same proportion to the Mass E M, as the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Surface L M hath to the Surface M H: Therefore it is manifest, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Mass of Water repulsed L G, is in proportion to the Mass of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Solid submerged H I K; as the Surface L M, namely, that of the Water
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which likewise, the said Mass of Water abated L G, hath the same
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: This is all that I have been able to collect, as produced against
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Archimedes_ by _Signor Buonamico_: who hath not well observed the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Principles and Suppositions of _Archimedes_; which yet must be false,
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: alledge therein some Inconveniences, and some Repugnances to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Doctrine and Opinion of _Aristotle_. In answer to which Objections, I
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: from the Doctrine of _Aristotle_, ought not to move any to suspect it,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: there being no cause, why the Authority of this should be preferred to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Authority of the other: but, because, where the decrees of Nature
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: are indifferently exposed to the intellectuall eyes of each, the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Authority of the one and the other, loseth all a{u}thenticalness of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Perswasion, the absolute power residing in Reason; therefore I pass to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that which he alledgeth in the second place[22], as an absurd consequent
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the Doctrine of _Archimedes_, namely, That water should be more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: grave than Earth. But I really find not, that ever _Archimedes_ said
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: this Vessell is lesse grave than water. If this be the Illation. I
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than Water. The Vessel that swims occupieth in the water, not only a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: place equall to the Mass of the Earth, of which it is formed; but
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: place, than that which is only possest by Earth, it shall then go to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Bottom, by reason that the Earth is heavier than the water: and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: this corresponds well with the meaning of _Archimedes_. See the same
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: effect illustrated, with such another Experiment, In pressing a Viall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Glass to the Bottom of the water, when it is full of Air, it will meet
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Returning, therefore, to our first purpose; I say, that Earth is more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: grave than water, and that therefore, a Solid of Earth goeth to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: bottom of it; but one may possibly make a composition of Earth and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Air, which shall be less grave than a like Mass of Water; and this
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall swim: and yet both this and the other experiment shall very well
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: accord with the Doctrine of _Archimedes_. But because that in my
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: judgment it hath nothing of difficulty in it, I will not positively
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: affirme that _Signor Buonamico_, would by such a discourse object unto
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Archimedes_ the absurdity of inferring by his doctrine, that Earth
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: was less grave than Water, though I know not how to conceive what
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: other accident he could have induced thence.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Perhaps such a Probleme (in my judgement false) was read by _Signor
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Buonamico_ in some other Author, by whom peradventure it was
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: attributed as a singular propertie, of some particular Water, and so
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: comes now to be used with a double errour in confutation of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Archimedes_, since he saith no such thing, nor by him that did say it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: was it meant of the common Element of Water.
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: whatsoever, and then filled with Water: and he that would readily see
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall just carry it to the bottome, so that being a graine less it
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of a Dish, and filling it with Water, he shall finde that without the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: said Lead it shall not sinke, and that with the Lead it shall descend
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: with much slowness: & in short he shall satisfie himself, that the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water included makes no alteration. I say not all this while, but that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: its possible of Wood to make Barkes, which being filled with water,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sinke; but that proceeds not through its Gravity, encreased by the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water, but rather from the Nailes and other Iron Workes, so that it no
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: longer hath a Body less grave than Water, but one mixt of Iron and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Wood, more grave than a like Masse of Water. Therefore let _Signor
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Buonamico_ desist from desiring a reason of an effect, that is not in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: nature: yea if the sinking of the Woodden Vessell when its full of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water, may call in question the Doctrine of _Archimedes_, which he

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: aptly agreeth with true experiments, and question the other, whose
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Deductions are fastened upon erroneouss Conclusions. As for the other
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: The Authors answer to the fourth Objection.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: As to that finally which presents itself in the fourth place,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: namely, that the _Ancients_ have been heretofore confuted by
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Aristotle_, who denying Positive and Absolute Levity, and truely
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: esteeming all Bodies to be grave, said, that that which moved upward
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: was driven by the circumambient Air, and therefore that also the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Doctrine of _Archimedes_, as an adherent to such an Opinion was
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: convicted and confuted: I answer first, that _Signor Buonamico_ in my
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: judgement hath imposed upon _Archimedes_, and deduced from his words
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: more than ever he intended by them, or may from his Propositions be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: collected, in regard that _Archimedes_ neither denies, nor admitteth
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Positive Levity, nor doth he so much as mention it: so that much less
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ought _Buonamico_ to inferre, that he hath denyed that it might be the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cause and Principle of the Ascension of Fire, and other Light Bodies[23]:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: having but only demonstrated, that Solid Bodies more grave than Water
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: descend in it, according to the excess of their Gravity above the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Gravity of that, he demonstrates likewise, how the less grave ascend
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in the same Water[24], accordng to its excess of Gravity, above the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Gravity of them. So that the most that can be gathered from the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Demonstration of _Archimedes_ is, that like as the excess of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Gravity of the Moveable above the Gravity of the Water, is the Cause
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that it descends therein, so the excess of the Gravity of the water
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: above that of the Moveable, is a sufficient Cause why it descends not,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but rather betakes it self to swim: not enquiring whether of moving
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: upwards there is, or is not any other Cause contrary to Gravity: nor
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: doth _Archimedes_ discourse less properly than if one should say: If
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the South Winde shall assault the Barke with greater _Impetus_ than is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the violence with which the Streame of the River carries it towards
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the South, the motion of it shall be towards the North: but if the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Impetus_ of the Water shall overcome that of the Winde, its motion
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall be towards the South. The discourse is excellent and would be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: unworthily contradicted by such as should oppose it, saying: Thou
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: mis-alledgest as Cause of the motion of the Bark towards the South,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the _Impetus_ of the Stream of the Water above that of the South
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Winde; mis-alledgest I say, for it is the Force of the North Winde
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: opposite to the South, that is able to drive the Bark towards the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: South. Such an Objection would be superfluous, because he which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: alledgeth for Cause of the Motion the Stream of the Water, denies not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but that the Winde opposite to the South may do the same, but only
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: affirmeth that the force of the Water prevailing over the South Wind,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Bark shall move towards the South: and saith no more than is true.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And just thus when _Archimedes_ saith, that the Gravity of the Water
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: prevailing over that by which the moveable descends to the Bottom,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: such moveable shall be raised from the Bottom to the Surface alledgeth
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: a very true Cause of such an Accident, nor doth he affirm or deny that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: there is, or is not, a vertue contrary to Gravity, called by some
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Levity, that hath also a power of moving some Matters upwards. Let
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: therefore the Weapons of _Signor Buonamico_ be directed against
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Plato_[25], and other _Ancients_, who totally denying _Levity_, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: taking all Bodies to be grave, say that the Motion upwards is made,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: not from an intrinsecal Principle of the Moveable, but only by the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Impulse of the _Medium_; and let _Archimedes_ and his Doctrine escape
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: him, since he hath given him no Cause of quarelling with him. But if
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: this Apologie, produced in defence of _Archimedes_, should seem to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: some insufficient to free him from the Objections and Arguments,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: produced by _Aristotle_ against _Plato_, and the other _Ancients_, as if
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: they did also fight against _Archimedes_, alledging the Impulse of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water as the Cause of the swimming of some Bodies less grave than it[26],
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I would not question, but that I should be able to maintaine the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Doctrine of _Plato_ and those others to be most true, who absolutely
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: deny Levity, and affirm no other Intrinsecal Principle of Motion to be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in Elementary Bodies save only that towards the Centre of the Earth[27],
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: nor no other Cause of moving upwards, speaking of that which hath the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: resemblance of natural Motion, but only the repulse of the _Medium_,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: fluid, and exceeding the Gravity of the Moveable[28]: and as to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Reasons of _Aristotle_ on the contrary, I believe that I could be able
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: fully to answer them, and I would assay to do it, if it were
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: absolutely necessary to the present Matter, or were it not too long a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Digression for this short Treatise. I will only say, that if there
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: were in some of our Ellementary Bodies an Intrinsecall Principle and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Naturall Inclination to shun the Centre of the Earth, and to move
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: towards the Concave of the Moon, such Bodies, without doubt, would
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: more swiftly ascend through those _Mediums_ that least oppose the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Velocity of the Moveable, and these are the more tenuous and subtle;
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: as is, for example, the Air in comparison of the Water, we daily
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: proving that we can with farre more expeditious Velocity move a Hand
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: or a Board to and again in one than in the other[29]: nevertheless, we
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: never could finde any Body, that did not ascend much more swiftly in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the water than in the Air. Yea of Bodies which we see continually to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ascend in the Water, there is none that having arrived to the confines
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the Air, do not wholly lose their Motion[30]; even the Air it self,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which rising with great Celerity through the Water, being once come to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: its Region it loseth all
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Ancients_, who absolutely deny Levity:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [27] According to _Plato_ there is no Principle of the Motion, of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: descent in Naturall Bodies, save that to the Centre.
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Medium_, exceeding the Moveable in Gravitie.
author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: comming to the confines of the Air.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: The lighter Bodies ascend more swiftly through Water.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And, howbeit, Experience shewes, that the Bodies, successively less
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: grave, do most expeditiously ascend in water, it cannot be doubted,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but that the Ignean Exhalations do ascend more swiftly through the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, than doth the Air: which Air is seen by Experience to ascend
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: more swiftly through the Water, than the Fiery Exhalations through the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Air[31]: Therefore, we must of necessity conclude, that the said
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Exhalations do much more expeditiously ascend through the Water, than
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: through the Air; and that, consequently, they are moved by the Impulse
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the Ambient _Medium_, and not by an intrinsick Principle that is in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: them, of avoiding the Centre of the Earth; to which other grave Bodies
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: tend.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [31] Fiery Exhalations ascend thorow the Water more swiftly than
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: doth the Air; & the Air ascends more swiftly thorow the Water,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than Fire thorow the Air.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: _T_he Authors confutation of the Peripateticks Causes
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of Natation & Submersion.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: To that which for a finall conclusion, _Signor Buonamico_ produceth
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of going about to reduce the descending or not descending, to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: easie and uneasie Division of the _Medium_, and to the predominancy of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Elements: I answer, as to the first part, that that cannot in any
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: manner be admitted as a Cause, being that in none of the Fluid
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Mediums_, as the Air, the Water, and other Liquids, there is any
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Resistance against Division[32], but all by every the least Force, are
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: divided and penetrated, as I will anon demonstrate: so, that of such
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Resistance of Division there can be no Act, since it self is not in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: being. As to the other part, I say, that the predominancy of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Elements in Moveables[33], is to be considered, as far as to the excesse
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: or defect of Gravity, in relation to the _Medium_: for in that Action,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Elements operate not, but only, so far as they are grave or light:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: therefore, to say that the Wood of the Firre sinks not, because Air
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: predominateth in it, is no more than to say, because it is less grave
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than the Water. Yea, even the immediate Cause, is its being less grave
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than the Water[34]: and it being under the predominancy of the Air, is the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cause of its less Gravity: Therefore, he that alledgeth the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: predominancy of the Element for a Cause, brings the Cause of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cause, and not the neerest and immediate Cause. Now, who knows not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that the true Cause is the immediate, and not the mediate[35]? Moreover,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: he that alledgeth Gravity, brings a Cause most perspicuous to Sence[36]:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: The cause we may very easily assertain our selves; whether Ebony, for
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: example, and Firre, be more or less grave than water: but whether
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Earth or Air predominates in them, who shall make that manifest?
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Certainly, no Experiment can better do it than to observe whether they
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: swim or sink. So, that he who knows, not whether such a Solid swims,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: unless when he knows that Air predominates in it, knows not whether it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: swim, unless he sees it swim, for then he knows that it swims, when he
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: knows that it is Air that predominates, but knows not that Air hath
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the predominance, unless he sees it swim: therefore, he knows not if
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: it swims, till such time as he hath seen it swim.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [32] Water & other fluids void of Resistance against Division.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [33] _T_he predominancy of Elements in Moveables to be considered
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: only in relation to their excess or defect of Gravity in reference
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to the _Medium_.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [34] _T_he immediate Cause of Natation is that the Moveable is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: less grave than the Water.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [35] _T_he Peripateticks alledge for the reason of Natation the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cause of the Cause.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [36] Gravity a Cause most perspicuous to sence.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Let us not then despise those Hints, though very dark, which Reason,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: after some contemplation, offereth to our Intelligence, and lets be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: content to be taught by _Archimedes_, that then any Body shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: submerge in water[37], when it shall be specifically more grave than it,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and that if it shall be less grave[38], it shall of necessity swim, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that it will rest indifferently in any place under water, if its
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Gravity be perfectly like to that of the water.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [37] Lib 1. of Natation Prop. 7
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [38] Id. Lib. 1. Prop. 4.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: These things explained and proved[39], I come to consider that which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: offers it self, touching what the Diversity of figure given unto the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: said Moveable hath to do with these Motions and Rests; and proceed to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: affirme, that,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [39] Id. Lib 1. Prop. 3.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: THEOREME V.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: Diversity of Figure no Cause of its absolute Natation
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: or Submersion.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _The diversity of Figures given to this or that Solid, cannot any
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: way be a Cause of its absolute Sinking or Swimming._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: So that if a Solid being formed, for example, into a Sphericall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figure, doth sink or swim in the water, I say, that being formed into
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: any other Figure, the same figure in the same water, shall sink or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: swim: nor can such its Motion by the Expansion or by other mutation of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figure, be impeded or taken away.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: The Expansion of Figure, retards the Velocity of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ascent or descent of the Moveable in the water; but doth not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: deprive it of all Motion.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: The Expansion of the Figure may indeed retard its Velocity, aswell of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ascent as descent, and more and more according as the said Figure is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: reduced to a greater breadth and thinness: but that it may be reduced
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to such a form as that that same matter be wholly hindred from moving
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in the same water, that I hold to be impossible. In this I have met
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: with great contradictors, who producing some Experiments, and in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: perticular a thin Board of Ebony, and a Ball of the same Wood, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shewing how the Ball in Water descended to the bottom, and the Board
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: being put lightly upon the Water submerged not, but rested; have held,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and with the Authority of _Aristotle_, confirmed themselves in their
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Opinions, that the Cause of that Rest was the breadth of the Figure,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: u{n}able by its small weight to pierce and penetrate the Resistance of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Waters Crassitude, which Resistance is readily overcome by the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: other Sphericall Figure.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: This is the Principal point in the present Question, in which I
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: perswade my self to be on the right side.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Therefore, beginning to investigate with the examination of exquisite
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Experiments that really the Figure doth not a jot alter the descent or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Ascent of the same Solids, and having already demonstrated that the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: greater or less Gravity of the Solid in relation to the Gravity of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Medium_ is the cause of Descent or Ascent: when ever we would make
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: proof of that, which about this Effect the diversity of Figure
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: worketh, its necessary to make the Experiment with Matter wherein
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: variety of Gravities hath no place. For making use of Matters which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: may be different in their Specifical Gravities, and meeting with
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: varieties of effects of Ascending and Descending, we shall alwayes be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: left unsatisfied whether that diversity derive it self really from the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sole Figure, or else from the divers Gravity also. We may remedy this
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: by takeing one only Matter, that is tractable and easily reduceable
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: into every sort of Figure. Moreover, it will be an excellent expedient
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to take a kinde of Matter, exactly alike in Gravity unto the Water:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: for that Matter, as far as pertaines to the Gravity, is indifferent
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: either to Ascend or Descend; so that we may presently observe any the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: least difference that derives it self from the diversity of Figure.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: An Experiment in Wax, that proveth Figure to have no
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Operation in Natation & Submersion.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Now to do this, Wax is most apt, which, besides its incapacity of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: receiveing any sensible alteration from its imbibing of Water, is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ductile or pliant, and the same piece is easily reduceable into all
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figures: and being _in Specie_ a very inconsiderable matter inferiour
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in Gravity to the Water, by mixing therewith a little of the fileings
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of Lead it is reduced to a Gravity exactly equall to that of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: This Matter prepared, and, for example, a Ball being made thereof as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: bigge as an Orange or biger, and that made so grave as to sink to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: bottom, but so lightly, that takeing thence one only Grain of Lead, it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: returns to the top, and being added, it submergeth to the bottom, let
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the same Wax afterwards be made into a very broad and thin Flake or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cake; and then, returning to make the same Experiment, you shall see
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that it being put to the bottom, it shall, with the Grain of Lead rest
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: below, and that Grain deducted, it shall ascend to the very Surface,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and added again it shall dive to the bottom. And this same effect
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall happen alwaies in all sort of Figures, as wel regular as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: irregular: nor shall you ever finde any that will swim without the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: removall of the Grain of Lead, or sinke to the bottom unless it be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: added: and, in short, about the going or not going to the Bottom, you
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall discover no diversity, although, indeed, you shall about the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: quick and slow descent: for the more expatiated and distended Figures
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: move more slowly aswel in the diveing to the bottom as in the rising
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to the top; and the other more contracted and compact Figures, more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: speedily. Now I know not what may be expected from the diversity of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figures, if the most contrary to one another operate not so much as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: doth a very small Grain of Lead, added or removed.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Me thinkes I hear some of the Adversaries to raise a doubt upon my
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: produced Experiment[40]. And first that they offer to my consideration,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that the Figure, as a Figure simply, and disjunct from the Matter
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: workes not any effect, but requires to be conjoyned with the Matter;
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and, furthermore, not with every Matter, but with those only,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: wherewith it may be able to execute the desired operation. Like as we
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: see it verified by Experience, that the Acute and sharp Angle is more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: apt to cut, than the Obtuse; yet alwaies provided, that both the one
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and the other, be joyned with a Matter apt to cut, as for example,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: with Steel. Therefore, a Knife with a fine and sharp edge, cuts Bread
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: or Wood with much ease, which it will not do, if the edge be blunt and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: thick: but he that will instead of Steel, take Wax, and mould it into
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: a Knife, undoubtedly shall never know the effects of sharp and blunt
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: edges: because neither of them will cut, the Wax being unable by
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: reason of its flexibility, to overcome the hardness of the Wood and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Bread. And, therefore, applying the like discourse to our purpose,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: they say, that the difference of Figure will shew different effects,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: touching Natation and Submersion, but not conjoyned with any kind of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Matter, but only with those Matters which, by their Gravity, are apt
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to resist the Velocity of the water, whence he that would elect for
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Matter, Cork or other light wood, unable, through its Levity, to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: superate the Crassitude of the water, and of that Matter should forme
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Solids of divers Figures, would in vain seek to find out what
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: operation Figure hath in Natation or Submersion; because all would
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: swim, and that not through any property of this or that Figure, but
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: through the debility of the Matter, wanting so much Gravity, as is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: requisite to superate and overcome the Density and Crassitude of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [40] An objection against the Experiment in Water.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Its needfull, therefore, if wee would see the effect wrought by the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Diversity of Figure, first to make choice of a Matter of its nature
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: apt to penetrate the Crassitude of the water. And, for this effect[41],
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: they have made choice of such a Matter, as fit, that being readily
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: reduced into Sphericall Figure, goes to the Bottom; and it is Ebony,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of which they afterwards making a small Board or Splinter, as thin as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: a Lath, have illustrated how that this, put upon the Surface of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, rests there without descending to the Bottom: and making, on
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the otherside, of the same wood a Ball, no less than a hazell Nut,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: they shew, that this swims not, but descendes. From which Experiment,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: they think they may frankly conclude, that the Breadth of the Figure
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in the flat Lath or Board, is the cause of its not descending to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Bottom, for as much as a Ball of the same Matter, not different from
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Board in any thing but in Figure, submergeth in the same water to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Bottom. The discourse and the Experiment hath really so much of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: probability and likelyhood of truth in it, that it would be no wonder,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: if many perswaded by a certain cursory observation, should yield
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: credit to it; nevertheless, I think I am able to discover, how that it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: is not free from falacy.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [41] An Experiment in Ebany, brought to disprove the Experiment
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in Wax.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Beginning, therefore, to examine one by one, all the particulars that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: have been produced, I say, that Figures, as simple Figures, not only
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: operate not in naturall things, but neither are they ever seperated
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: from the Corporeall substance[42]: nor have I ever alledged them stript of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sensible Matter, like as also I freely admit, that in our endeavouring
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to examine the Diversity of Accidents, dependant upon the variety of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figures, it is necessary to apply them to Matters, which obstruct not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the various operations of those various Figures: and I admit and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: grant, that I should do very ill; if I would experiment the influence
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of Acutenesse of edge with a Knife of Wax, applying it to cut an Oak,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: because there is no Acuteness in Wax able to cut that very hard wood.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: But yet such an Experiment of this Knife, would not be besides the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: purpose, to cut curded Milk, or other very yielding Matter: yea, in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: such like Matters, the Wax is more commodious than Steel; for finding
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the diversity depending upon Angles, more or less Acute, for that Milk
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: is indifferently cut with a Raisor, and with a Knife, that hath a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: blunt edge. It needs, therefore, that regard be had, not only to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: hardness, solidity or Gravity of Bodies, which under divers figures,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: are to divide and penetrate some Matters, but it forceth also, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: regard be had, on the other side, to the Resistance of the Matters, to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: be divided and penetrated. But since I have in making the Experiment
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: concerning our Contest; chosen a Matter which penetrates the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Resistance of the water; and in all figures descendes to the Bottome,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Adversaries can charge me with no defect; yea, I have propounded
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: so much a more excellent Method than they, in as much as I have
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: removed all other Causes, of descending or not descending to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Bottom, and retained the only sole and pure variety of Figures,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: demonstrating that the same Figures all descende with the only
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: alteration of a Grain in weight: which Grain being removed, they
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: return to float and swim; it is not true, therefore, (resuming the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Example by them introduced) that I have gon{e} about to experiment the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: efficacy of Acuteness, in cutting with Matters unable to cut, but with
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Matters proportioned to our occasion, since they are subjected to no
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: other variety, then that alone which depends on the Figure more or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: less acute.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [42] Figure is unseperable from Corporeall Substance.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: The answer to the Objection against the Experiment of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Wax.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: But let us proceed a little farther, and observe, how that indeed the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Consideration, which, they say, ought to be had about the Election of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Matter, to the end, that it may be proportionate for the making of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: our experiment, is needlessly introduced, declaring by the example of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cutting, that like as Acuteness is inefficient to cut, unless when it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: is in a Matter hard and apt to superate the Resistance of the wood or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: other Matter, which we intend to cut; so the aptitude of descending or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: not descending in water, ought and can only be known in those Matters,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that are able to overcome the Renitence, and superate the Crassitude
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the water. Unto which, I say, that to make distinction and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: election, more of this than of that Matter, on which to impress the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figures for cutting or penetrating this or that Body, as the solidity
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: or obdurateness of the said Bodies shall be greater or less, is very
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: necessary: but withall I subjoyn, that such distinction, election and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: caution would be superfluous and unprofitable, if the Body to be cut
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: or penetrated, should have no Resistance, or should not at all
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: withstand the Cutting or Penitration: and if the Knife were to be used
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in cutting a Mist or Smoak, one of Paper would be equally serviceable
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: with one of _Damascus_ Steel: and so by reason the water hath not any
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Resistance against the Penitration of any Solid Body, all choice of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Matter is superfluous and needless, and the Election which I said
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: above to have been well made of a Matter reciprocall in Gravity to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, was not because it was necessary, for the overcoming of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: crassitude of the water, but its Gravity, with which only it resists
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the sinking of Solid Bodies: and for what concerneth the Resistance of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the crassitude, if we narrowly consider it, we shall find that all
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Solid Bodies, as well those that sink, as those that swim, are
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: indifferently accomodated and apt to bring us to the knowledge of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: truth in question. Nor will I be frighted out of the belief of these
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Conclusions, by the Experiments which may be produced against me, of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: many severall Woods, Corks, Galls, and, moreover, of subtle slates and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: plates of all sorts of Stone and Mettall, apt by means of their
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Naturall Gravity, to move towards the Centre of the Earth, the which,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: nevertheless, being impotent, either through the Figure (as the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Adversaries thinke) or through Levity, to break and penetrate the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Continuity of the parts of the water, and to distract its union, do
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: continue to swimm without submerging in the least: nor on the other
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: side, shall the Authority of _Aristotle_ move me, who in more than one
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: place, affirmeth the contrary to this, which Experience shews me.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: No Solid of such Levity, nor of such Figure, but that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: it doth penetrate the Crassitude of the Water.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: Bodies of all Figures, laid upon the water, do
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: penetrate its Crassitude, and in what proportion.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I return, therefore, to assert, that there is not any Solid of such
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Levity, nor of such Figure, that being put upon the water, doth not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: divide and penetrate its Crassitude: yea if any with a more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: perspicatious eye, shall return to observe more exactly the thin
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Boards of Wood, he shall see them to be with part of their thickness
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: under water, and not only with their inferiour Superficies, to kisse
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Superiour of the water, as they of necessity must have believed,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: who have said, that such Boards submerge not, as not being able to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: divide the Tenacity of the parts of the water: and, moreover, he shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: see, that subtle shivers of Ebony, Stone or Metall, when they float,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: have not only broak the Continuity of the water, but are with all
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: their thickness, under the Surface of it; and more and more, according
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: as the Matters are more grave: so that a thin Plate of Lead, shall be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: lower than the Surface of the circumfused water, by at least twelve
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: times the thickness of the Plate, and Gold shall dive below the Levell
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the water, almost twenty times the thickness of the Plate, as I
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall anon declare.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: But let us proceed to evince, that the water yields and suffers it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: self to be penetrated by every the lightest Body; and therewithall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: demonstrate, how, even by Matters that submerge not, we may come to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: know that Figure operates nothing about the going or not going to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Bottom, seeing that the water suffers it self to be penetrated equally
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: by every Figure.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: The Experiment of a Cone, demitted with its Base, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: after with its Point downwards.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Make a Cone, or a Piramis of Cypress, of Firre, or of other Wood of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: like Gravity, or of pure Wax, and let its height be somewhat great,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: namely a handfull, or more, and put it into the water with the Base
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: downwards: first, you shall see that it will penetrate the water, nor
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall it be at all impeded by the largeness of the Base, nor yet shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: it sink all under water, but the part towards the point shall lye
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: above it: by which shall be manifest, first, that that Solid forbeares
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: not to sink out of an inability to divide the Continuity of the water,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: having already divided it with its broad part, that in the opinion of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Adversaries is the less apt to make the division. The Piramid
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: being thus fixed, note what part of it shall be submerged, and revert
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: it afterwards with the point downwards, and you shall see that it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall not dive into the water more than before, but if you observe how
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: far it shall sink, every person expert in Geometry, may measure, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: those parts that remain out of the water, both in the one and in the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: other Experiment are equall to an hair: whence he may manifestly
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: conclude, that the acute Figure which seemed most apt to part and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: penetrate the water, doth not part or penetrate it more than the large
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and spacious.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And he that would have a more easie Experiment, let him take two
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cylinders of the same Matter, one long and small, and the other short,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but very broad, and let him put them in the water, not distended, but
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: erect and endways: he shall see, if he diligently measure the parts of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the one and of the other, that in each of them the part submerged,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: retains exactly the same proportion to that out of the water, and that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: no greater part is submerged of that long and small one, than of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: other more spacious and broad: howbeit, this rests upon a very large,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and that upon a very little Superficies of water: therefore the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: diversity of Figure, occasioneth neither facility, nor difficulty, in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: diverse grave Matters float, by vertue of the Air conjoyned with them)
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: did affirm, That Figure was not the Cause of the Natation or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Submersion of such Solids as were placed in the water. Nay more, I
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: cannot omit, but must tell my Antagonists, that this new conceit of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: denying that the Superficies of the Board should be bathed, may beget
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in a third person an opinion of a poverty of Arguments of defence on
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: their part, since that such bathing was never insisted upon by them in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the beginning of our Dispute, and was not questioned in the least,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: being that the Originall of the discourse arose upon the swiming of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Flakes of Ice, wherein it would be simplicity to require that their
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Superficies might bedry: besides, that whether these pieces of Ice be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: wet or dry they alwayes swim, and as the Adversaries say, by reason of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Figure.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [45] Water hath no Gravity in Water.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [46] Water deminisheth the Gravity of Solids immerged therein.
author: Galilei, Galileo
