author: Galilei, Galileo

text: when full, alledged to prove that water gravitates in water,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: answered.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [48] An Ocean sufficeth not to sink a Vessel specifically less
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: grave than water.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [49] Air, the Cause of the Natation of empty Vessels of Matters
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: graver _in specie_ than the water.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [50] Neither Figure, nor the breadth of Figure, is the Cause of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Natation.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Some peradventure, by way of defence, may say, that wetting the Board
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of Ebony, and that in the superiour Superficies, it would, though of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: it self unable to pierce and penetrate the water, be born downwards,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: if not by the weight of the additionall water, at least by that desire
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and propension that the superiour parts of the water have to re-unite
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and rejoyn themselves: by the Motion of which parts, the said Board
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: cometh in a certain manner, to be depressed downwards.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: The Bathed Solid descends not out of any affectation
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of union in the upper parts of the water.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: This weak Refuge will be removed, if we do but consider, that the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: repugnancy of the inferiour parts of the water, is as great against
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Dis-union, as the Inclination of its superiour parts is to union: nor
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: can the uper unite themselves without depressing the board, nor can it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: descend without disuniting the parts of the nether Water: so that it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: doth follow, by necessary consequence, that for those respects, it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall not descend. Moreover, the same that may be said of the upper
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: parts of the water, may with equall reason be said of the nether,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: namely, that desiring to unite, they shall force the said Board
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: upwards.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Happily, some of these Gentlemen that dissent from me, will wonder,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that I affirm, that the contiguous superiour Air is able to sustain
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that Plate of Brass or of Silver, that stayeth above water; as if I
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: would in a certain sence allow the Air[51], a kind of Magnetick vertue of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sustaining the grave Bodies, with which it is contiguous. To satisfie
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: all I may, to all doubts, I have been considering how by some other
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sensible Experiment I might demonstrate, how truly that little
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: contiguous and superiour Air sustaines those Solids, which being by
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: nature apt to descend to the Bottom, being placed lightly on the water
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: submerge not, unless they be first thorowly bathed; and have found,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that one of these Bodies having descended to the Bottom, by
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: conveighing to it (without touching it in the least) a little Air,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which conjoyneth with the top of the same, it becometh sufficient, not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: only, as before to sustain it, but also to raise it, and to carry it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: back to the top, where it stays and abideth in the same manner, till
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: such time, as the assistance of the conjoyned Air is taken away. And
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to this effect, I have taken a Ball of Wax, and made it with a little
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lead, so grave, that it leasurely descends to the Bottom, making with
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: all its Superficies very smooth and pollite: and this being put gently
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: into the water, almost wholly submergeth, there remaining vissible
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: only a little of the very top[52], the which so long as it is conjoyned
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: with the Air, shall retain the Ball a-top, but the Contiguity of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Air taken away by wetting it, it shall descend to the Bottom and there
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: remain. Now to make it by vertue of the Air, that before sustained it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to return again to the top, and stay there, thrust into the water a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Glass reversed with the mouth downwards, the which shall carry with it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Air it contains, and move this towards the Ball, abasing it till
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: such time that you see, by the transparency of the Glass, that the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: contained Air do arrive to the summity of the _B_all[53]: then gently
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: withdraw the Glass upwards, and you shall see the _B_all to rise, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: afterwards stay on the top of the water[54], if you carefully part the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Glass and the water without overmuch commoving and disturbing it.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: There is, therefore, a certain affinity between the Air and other
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Bodies, which holds them unied, so, that they seperate not without a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: kind of violence. The same likewise is seen in the water[55]; for if we
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall wholly submerge some Body in it, so that it be thorowly bathed,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in the drawing of it afterwards gently out again, we shall see the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water follow it, and rise notably above its Surface, before it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: seperates from it. Solid Bodies, also[56], if they be equall and alike in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Superficies, so, that they make an exact Contact without the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: interposition of the least Air, that may part them in the seperation
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and yield untill that the ambient _Medium_ succeeds to replenish the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: place, do hold very firmly conjoyned, and are not to be seperated
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: without great force but, because, the Air, Water, and other Liquids,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: very expeditiously shape themselves to contact with any Solid
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _B_odies, so that their Superficies do exquisitely adopt themselves to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that of the Solids, without any thing remaining between them,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: therefore, the effect of this Conjunction and Adherence is more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: manifestly and frequently observed in them, than in hard and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: inflexible Bodies, whose Superficies do very rarely conjoyn with
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: exactness of Contact[57]. This is therefore that Magnetick vertue, which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: with firm Connection conjoyneth all Bodies, that do touch without the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: interposition of flexible fluids; and, who knows, but that that a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Contact, when it is very exact, may be a sufficient Cause of the Union
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and Continuity of the parts of a naturall _B_ody?
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [51] _A_ Magnetisme in the _A_ir, by which it bears up those
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Solids in the water, that are contiguous with it.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [52] The Effect of the Airs Contiguity in the Natation of Solids.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [53] The force of Contact.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [54] _A_n Affectation of Conjunction betwixt Solids and the Air
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: contiguous to them.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [55] The like affectation of Conjunction betwixt Solids & the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [56] Also the like affectation and Conjunction betwixt Solids
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: themselves.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [57] Contact may be the Cause of the Continuity of Naturall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Bodies.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Now, pursuing my purpose, I say; that it needs not, that we have
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: recourse to the Tenacity, that the parts of the water have amongst
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: themselves, by which they resist and oppose Division, Distraction, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Seperation, because there is no such Coherence and Resistance of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Division for if there were, it would be no less in the internall parts
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than in those nearer the superiour or externall Surface, so that the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: same Board, finding alwayes the same Resistance and Renitence, would
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: no less stop in the middle of the water than about the Surface, which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: is false. Moreover, what Resistance can we place in the Continuity of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the water, if we see that it is impossible to find any Body of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: whatsoever Matter, Figure or Magnitude, which being put into the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, shall be obstructed and impeded by the Tenacity of the parts of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the water to one another, so, but that it is moved upwards or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: downwards, according as the Cause of their Motion transports it? And,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: what greater proof of it can we desier, than that which we daily see
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in Muddy waters, which being put into Vessels to be drunk, and being,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: after some hours setling[58], still, as we say, thick in the end, after
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: four or six dayes they are wholly setled, and become pure and clear?
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Nor can their Resistance of Penetration stay those impalpable and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: insensible Atomes of Sand, which by reason of their exceeding small
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: force, spend six dayes in descending the space of half a yard.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [58] The settlement of _M_uddy Water, proveth that that Element
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: hath no aversion to Division.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Nor let them say, that the seeing of such small Bodies, consume
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: six dayes in descending so little a way, is a sufficient Argument
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the Waters Resistance of Division; because that is no resisting
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of Division, but a retarding of Motion; and it would be simplicity
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to say, that a thing opposeth Division[59], and that in the same
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: instant, it permits it self to be divided: nor doth the Retardation
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of Motion at all favour the Adversaries cause, for that they are to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: instance in a thing that wholly prohibiteth Motion, and procureth
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Rest; it is necessary, therefore, to find out Bodies that stay in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the water, if one would shew its repugnancy to Division, and not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: such as move in it, howbeit but slowly._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [59] Water cannot oppose division, and at the same time permit it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: self to be divided.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: What then is this Crassitude of the water, with which it resisteth
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Division? What, I beseech you, should it be, if we (as we have said
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: above) with all diligence attempting the reduction of a Matter into so
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: like a Gravity with the water, that forming it into a dilated Plate it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: rests suspended as we have said, between the two waters, it be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: impossible to effect it, though we bring them to such an
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Equiponderance, that as much Lead as the fourth part of a Grain of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Musterd-seed, added to the same expanded Plate, that in Air [_i. e.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: out of the water_] shall weigh four or six pounds, sinketh it to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Bottom, and being substracted, it ascends to the Surface of the water?
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I cannot see, (if what I say be true, as it is most certain) what
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: minute vertue and force we can possibly find or imagine, to which the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Resistance of the water against Division and Penetration is not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: inferiour; whereupon, we must of necessity conclude that it is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: nothing: because, if it were of any sensible power, some large Plate
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: might be found or compounded of a Matter alike in Gravity to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, which not only would stay between the two waters; but,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: moreover, should not be able to descend or ascend without notable
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: force. We may likewise collect the same from an other Experiment[60],
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shewing that the Water gives way also in the same manner to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: transversall Division; for if in a setled and standing water we should
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: place any great Mass that goeth not to the bottom, drawing it with a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: single Womans Hair, we might carry it from place to place without any
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: opposition, and this whatever Figure it hath, though that it possess a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: great space of water, as for instance, a great Beam would do moved
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: side-ways. Perhaps some might oppose me and say, that if the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Resistance of water against Division, as I affirm, were nothing; Ships
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: should not need such a force of Oars and Sayles for the moving of them
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: from place to place in a tranquile Sea, or standing Lake. To him that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: should make such an objection, I would reply[61], that the water
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: contrasteth not against, nor simply resisteth Division, but a sudden
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Division, and with so much greater Renitence, by how much greater the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Velocity is: and the Cause of this Resistance depends not on
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Crassitude, or any other thing that absolutely opposeth Division, but
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: because that the parts of the water divided, in giving way to that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Solid that is moved in it, are themselves also necessitated locally to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: move, some to the one side, and some to the other, and some downwards:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and this must no less be done by the waves before the Ship, or other
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Body swimming through the water, than by the posteriour and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: subsequent; because, the Ship proceeding forwards, to make it self a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: way to receive its Bulk, it is requisite, that with the Prow it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: repulse the adjacent parts of the water, as well on one hand as on the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: other, and that it move them as much transversly, as is the half of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the breadth of the Hull: and the like removall must those waves make,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that succeeding the Poump do run from the remoter parts of the Ship
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: towards those of the middle, successively to replenish the places,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which the Ship in advancing forwards, goeth, leaving vacant. Now,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: because, all Motitions are made in Time[62], and the longer in greater
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: time: and it being moreover true, that those Bodies that in a certain
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: time are moved by a certain power such a certain space, shall not be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: moved the same space, and in a shorter Time, unless by a greater
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Power: therefore, the broader Ships move slower than the narrower,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: being put on by an equall Force: and the same Vessel requires so much
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: greater force of Wind, or Oars, the faster it is to move.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [60] An hair will draw a great Mass thorow the Water; which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: proveth, that it hath no Resistance against transversall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Division.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [61] How ships are moved in the water.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [62] Bodies moved a certain space in a certain Time, by a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: certain power, cannot be moved the same space and in a shorter
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: time, but by a greater power.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _But yet for all this, any great Mass swimming in a standing Lake,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: may be moved by any petit force; only it is true, that a lesser
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: force more slowly moves it: but if the waters Resistance of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Division, were in any manner sensible, it would follow, that the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: said Mass, should, notwithstanding the percussion of some sensible
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: force, continue immoveable, which is not so[63]. Yea, I will say
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: farther, that should we retire our selves into the more internall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: contemplation of the Nature of water and other Fluids, perhaps we
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: should discover the Constitution of their parts to be such, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: they not only do not oppose Division, but that they have not any
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: thing in them to be divided: so that the Resistance that is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: observed in moving through the water[64], is like to that which we meet
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: with in passing through a great Throng of People, wherein we find
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: impediment, and not by any difficulty in the Division, for that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: none of those persons are divided whereof the Croud is composed,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but only in moving of those persons side-ways which were before
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: divided and disjoyned: and thus we find Resistance in thrusting a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Stick into an heap of Sand, not because any part of the Sand is to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: be cut in pieces, but only to be moved and raised[65]. Two manners of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Penetration, therefore, offer themselves to us, one in Bodies,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: whose parts were continuall, and here Division seemeth necessary,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the other in the aggregates of parts not continuall, but contiguous
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: only[66], and here there is no necessity of dividing but of moving
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: only. Now, I am not well resolved, whether water and other Fluids
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: may be esteemed to be of parts continuall or contiguous only[67]; yet I
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: find my self indeed inclined to think that they are rather
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: contiguous (if there be in Nature no other manner of aggregating,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than by the union, or by the touching of the extreams:) and I am
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: induced thereto by the great difference that I see between the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Conjunction of the parts of an hard or Solid Body[68], and the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Conjunction of the same parts when the same Body shall be made
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Liquid and Fluid: for if, for example, I take a Mass of Silver or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: other Solid and hard Mettall, I shall in dividing it into two
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: parts, find not only the resistance that is found in the moving of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: it only[69], but an other incomparably greater, dependent on that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: vertue, whatever it be, which holds the parts united: and so if we
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: would divide again those two parts into other two, and successively
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: into others and others, we should still find a like Resistance, but
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ever less by how much smaller the parts to be divided shall be; but
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: if, lastly, employing most subtile and acute Instruments, such as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: are the most tenuous parts of the Fire, we shall resolve it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: (perhaps) into its last and least Particles, there shall not be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: left in them any longer either Resistance of Division, or so much
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: as a capacity of being farther divided, especially by Instruments
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: more grosse than the acuities of Fire: and what Knife or Rasor put
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: into well melted Silver can we finde, that will divide a thing
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which surpasseth the separating power of Fire? Certainly none:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: because either the whole shall be reduced to the most minute and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ultimate Divisions, or if there remain parts capable still of other
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Subdidivisions, they cannot receive them, but only from acuter
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Divisors than Fire; but a Stick or Rod of Iron, moved in the melted
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Metall, is not such a one. Of a like Constitution and Consistence,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I account the parts of Water[70], and other Liquids to be, namely,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: incapable of Division by reason of their Ienuity; or if not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: absolutely indivisible, yet at least not to be divided by a Board,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: or other Solid Body, palpable unto the hand, the Sector being
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: alwayes required to be more sharp than the Solid to be cut. Solid
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Bodies, therefore, do only move, and not divide the Water[71], when put
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: into it; whose parts being before divided to the extreamest
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: minuity, and therefore capable of being moved, either many of them
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: at once, or few, or very few, they soon give place to every small
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Corpuscle, that descends in the same: for that, it being little and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: light, descending in the Air, and arriving to the Surface of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water, it meets with Particles of Water more small, and of less
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Resistance against Motion and Extrusion, than is its own prement
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and extrusive force; whereupon it submergeth, and moveth such a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: portion of them, as is proportionate to its Power. There is not,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: therefore, any Resistance in Water against Division, nay, there is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: not in it any divisible parts. I adde; moreover, that in case yet
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: there should be any small Resistance found (which is absolutely
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: false)[72] haply in attempting with an Hair to move a very great natant
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Machine, or in essaying by the addition of one small Grain of Lead
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to sink, or by removall of it to raise a very broad Plate of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Matter, equall in Gravity with Water, (which likewise will not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: happen, in case we proceed with dexterity) we may observe that that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Resistance is a very different thing from that which the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Adversaries produce for the Cause of the Natation of the Plate of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lead or Board of Ebony, for that one may make a Board of Ebony,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which being put upon the Water swimmeth, and cannot be submerged,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: no not by the addition of an hundred Grains of Lead put upon the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: same, and afterwards being bathed, not only sinks, though the said
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lead be taken away, but though moreover a quantity of Cork, or of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: some other light Body fastened to it, sufficeth not to hinder it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: from sinking unto the bottome: so that you see, that although it

author: Galilei, Galileo

text: demonstrate therefore, that,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _It is possible to form a Piramide, of any whatsoever Matter
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: preposed, which being put with its Base upon the Water, rests not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: only without submerging, but without wetting it more then its
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Base._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: For the explication of which it is requisite, that we first
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: demonstrate the subsequent Lemma, namely, that,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: LEMMA II.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: Solids whose Masses are in contrary proportion to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: their Specifick Gravities are equall in absolute Gravity.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Solids whose Masses answer in proportion contrarily to their
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Specificall Gravities, are equall in Absolute Gravities._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Illustration]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Let A C and B be two Solids, and let the Mass A C be to the Mass B,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: as the Specificall Gravity of the Solid B, is to the Specificall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Gravity of the Solid A C: I say, the Solids A C and B are equall in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: absolute weight, that is, equally grave. For if the Mass A C be equall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to the Mass B, then, by the Assumption, the Specificall Gravity of B,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall be equall to the Specificall Gravity of A C, and being equall in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Mass, and of the same Specificall Gravity they shall absolutely weigh
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: one as much as another. But if their Masses shall be unequall, let the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Mass A C be greater, and in it take the part C, equall to the Mass B.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And, because the Masses B and C are equall; the Absolute weight of B,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall have the same proportion to the Absolute weight of C, that the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Specificall Gravity of B, hath to the Specificall Gravity of C; or of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: C A, which is the same _in specie_: But look what proportion the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Specificall Gravity of B, hath to the Specificall Gravity of C A, the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: like proportion, by the Assumption, hath the Mass C A, to the Mass B,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that is, to the Mass C: Therefore, the absolute weight of B, to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: absolute weight of C, is as the Mass A C to the Mass C: But as the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Mass A C, is to the Mass C, so is the absolute weight of A C, to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: absolute weight of C: Therefore the absolute weight of B, hath the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: same proportion to the absolute weight of C, that the absolute weight
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of A C, hath to the absolute weight of C: Therefore, the two Solids A
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: C and B are equall in absolute Gravity: which was to be demonstrated.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Having demonstrated this, I say,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: THEOREME X.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: There may be Cones and Piramides of any Matter, which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: demitted into the water, rest only their Bases.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _That it is possible of any assigned Matter, to form a Piramide or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cone upon any Base, which being put upon the Water shall not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: submerge, nor wet any more than its Base._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Illustration]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Let the greatest possible Altitude of the Rampart be the Line D B,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and the Diameter of the Base of the Cone to be made of any Matter
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: assigned B C, at right angles to D B: And as the Specificall Gravity
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the Matter of the Piramide or Cone to be made, is to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Specificall Gravity of the water, so let the Altitude of the Rampart D
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: B, be to the third part of the Piramide or Cone A B C, described upon
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Base, whose Diameter is B C: I say, that the said Cone A B C, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: any other Cone, lower then the same, shall rest upon the Surface of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the water B C without sinking. Draw D F parallel to B C, and suppose
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Prisme or Cylinder E C, which shall be tripple to the Cone A B C.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And, because the Cylinder D C hath the same proportion to the Cylinder
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: C E, that the Altitude D B, hath to the Altitude B E: But the Cylinder
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: C E, is to the Cone A B C, as the Altitude E B is to the third part of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Altitude of the Cone: Therefore, by Equality of proportion, the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cylinder D C is to the Cone A B C, as D B is to the third part of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Altitude B E: But as D B is to the third part of B E, so is the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Specificall Gravity of the Cone A B C, to the Specificall Gravity of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the water: Therefore, as the Mass of the Solid D C, is to the Mass of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Cone A _B_ C, so is the Specificall Gravity of the said Cone, to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Specificall Gravity of the water: Therefore, by the precedent
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lemma, the Cone A B C weighs in absolute Gravity, as much as a Mass of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Water equall to the Mass D C: But the water which by the imposition of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Cone A B C, is driven out of its place, is as much as would
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: precisely lie in the place D C, and is equall in weight to the Cone
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that displaceth it: Therefore, there shall be an _Equilibrium_, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Cone shall rest without farther submerging. And its manifest,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: COROLARY I.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: Amongst Cones of the same Base, those of least
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Altitude shall sink the least.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _That making upon the same Basis, a Cone of a less Altitude, it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall be also less grave, and shall so much the more rest without
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Submersion._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: COROLARY II.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: There may be Cones and Piramides of any Matter, which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: demitted with the Point downwards do float atop.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _It is manifest, also, that one may make Cones and Piramids of any
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Matter whatsoever, more grave than the water, which being put
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: into the water, with the Apix or Point downwards, rest without
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Submersion._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Because if we reassume what hath been above demonstrated, of Prisms
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and Cylinders, and that on Bases equall to those of the said
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cylinders, we make Cones of the same Matter, and three times as high
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: as the Cylinders, they shall rest afloat, for that in Mass and Gravity
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: they shall be equall to those Cylinders, and by having their Bases
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: equall to those of the Cylinders, they shall leave equall Masses of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Air included within the Ramparts. This, which for Example sake hath
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: been demonstrated, in Prisms, Cylinders, Cones and Piramids, might be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: proved in all other Solid Figures, but it would require a whole Volume
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: (such is the multitude and variety of their Symptoms and Accidents) to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: comprehend the particuler demonstration of them all, and of their
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: severall Segments: but I will to avoid prolixity in the present
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Discourse, content my self, that by what I have declared every one of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ordinary Capacity may comprehend, that there is not any Matter so
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: grave, no not Gold it self, of which one may not form all sorts of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figures, which by vertue of the superiour Air adherent to them, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: not by the Waters Resistance of Penetration, do remain afloat, so that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: they sink not. Nay, farther, I will shew, for removing that Error,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: THEOREME XI.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: A Piramide or Cone, demitted with the Point downwards
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shal swim, with its Base downward shall sink.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _A Piramide or Cone put into the Water, with the Point downward
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall swimme, and the same put with the Base downwards shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sinke, and it shall be impossible to make it float._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Now the quite contrary would happen, if the difficulty of Penetrating
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the water, were that which had hindred the descent, for that the said
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cone is far apter to pierce and penetrate with its sharp Point, than
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: with its broad and spacious Base.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And, to demonstrate this, let the Cone be _A B C_, twice as grave as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the water, and let its height be tripple to the height of the Rampart
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _D A E C_: I say, first, that being put lightly into the water with
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Point downwards, it shall not descend to the bottom: for the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Aeriall Cylinder contained betwixt the Ramparts _D A C E_, is equall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in Mass to the Cone _A B C_; so that the whole Mass of the Solid
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: compounded of the Air _D A C E_, and of the Cone _A B C_, shall be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: double to the Cone _A C B_: And, because the Cone _A B C_ is supposed
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to be of Matter double in Gravity to the water, therefore as much
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water as the whole Masse _D A B C E_, placed beneath the Levell of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, weighs as much as the Cone _A B C_: and, therefore, there shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: be an _Equilibrium_, and the Cone _A B C_ shall descend no lower. Now,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I say farther, that the same Cone placed with the Base downwards,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall sink to the bottom, without any possibility of returning again,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: by any means to swimme.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Illustration]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Let, therefore, the Cone be _A B D_, double in Gravity to the water,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and let its height be tripple the height of the Rampart of water L B:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: It is already manifest, that it shall not stay wholly out of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, because the Cylinder being comprehended betwixt the Ramparts _L
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: B D P_, equall to the Cone _A B D_, and the Matter of the Cone, beig
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: double in Gravity to the water, it is evident that the weight of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: said Cone shall be double to the weight of the Mass of water equall to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Cylinder _L B D P_: Therefore it shall not rest in this state, but
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall descend.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Illustration]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: COROLARY I.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: Much less shall the said Cone swim, if one immerge a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: part thereof.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _I say farther; that much lesse shall the said Cone stay afloat, if
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: one immerge a part thereof._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Which you may see, comparing with the water as well the part that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall immerge as the other above water. Let us therefore of the Cone A
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: B D, submergeth part N T O S, and advance the Point N S F above water.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: The Altitude of the Cone F N S, shall either be more than half the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: whole Altitude of the Cone F T O, or it shall not be more: if it shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: be more than half, the Cone F N S shall be more than half of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cylinder E N S C: for the Altitude of the Cone F N S, shall be more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than Sesquialter of the Altitude of the Cylinder E N S C: And, because
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Matter of the Cone is supposed to be double in Specificall Gravity
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to the water, the water which would be contained within the Rampart E
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: N S C, would be less grave absolutely than the Cone F N S; so that the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: whole Cone F N S cannot be sustained by the Rampart: But the part
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: immerged N T O S, by being double in Specificall Gravity to the water,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall tend to the bottom: Therefore, the whole _C_one F T O, as well
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in respect of the part submerged, as the part above water shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: descend to the bottom. But if the Altitude of the Point F N S, shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: be half the Altitude of the whole Cone F T O, the same Altitude of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: said Cone F N S shall be Sesquialter to the Altitude E N: and,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: therefore, E N S C shall be double to the Cone F N S; and as much
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water in Mass as the _C_ylinder E N S C, would weigh as much as the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: part of the _C_one F N S. But, because the other immerged part N T O
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: S, is double in Gravity to the water, a Mass of water equall to that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: compounded of the _C_ylinder E N S C, and of the Solid N T O S, shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: weigh less than the _C_one F T O, by as much as the weight of a Mass
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of water equall to the Solid N T O S: Therefore, the _C_one sha{l}l
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: also descend. Again, because the Solid N T O S, is septuple to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cone F N S, to which the _C_ylinder E S is double, the proportion of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Solid N T O S, shall be to the _C_ylinder E N S C, as seaven to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: two: Therefore, the whole Solid compounded of the _C_ylinder E N S C,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and of the Solid N T O S, is much less than double the Solid N T O S:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Therefore, the single Solid N T O S, is much graver than a Mass of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water equall to the Mass, compounded of the _C_ylinder E N S C, and of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: N T O S.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: COROLARY II.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: Part of the Cones towards the Cuspis removed, it shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: still sink.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _From whence it followeth, that though one should remove and take
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: away the part of the Cone F N S, the sole remainder N T O S would
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: go to the bottom._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: COROLARY III.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: The more the Cone is immerged, the more impossible is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: its floating.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _And if we should more depress the Cone F T O, it would be so much
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the more impossible that it should sustain it self afloat, the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: part submerged N T O S still encreasing, and the Mass of Air
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: contained in the Rampart diminishing, which ever grows less, the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: more the Cone submergeth._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: That Cone, therefore, that with its Base upwards, and its _Cuspis_
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: downwards doth swimme, being dimitted with its Base downward must of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: necessity sinke. They have argued farre from the truth, therefore, who
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: have ascribed the cause of Natation to waters resistance of Division,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: as to a passive principle, and to the breadth of the Figure, with
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which the division is to be made, as the Efficient.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I come in the fourth place, to collect and conclude the reason of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that which I have proposed to the Adversaries, namely,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: THEOREME XII.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: Solids of any Figure & greatnesse, that naturally
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sink, may by help of the Air in the Rampart swimme.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _That it is possible to fo{r}m Solid Bodies, of what Figure and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: greatness soever, that of their own Nature goe to the Bottome;
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: But by the help of the Air contained in the Rampart, rest without
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: submerging._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Illustration]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: The truth of this Proposition is sufficiently manifest in all those
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Solid Figures, that determine in their uppermost part in a plane
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Superficies: for making such Figures of some Matter specifically as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: grave as the water, putting them into the water, so that the whole
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Mass be covered, it is manifest, that they shall rest in all places,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: provided, that such a Matter equall in weight to the water, may be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: exactly adjusted: and they shall by consequence, rest or lie even with
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Levell of the water, without making any Rampart. If, therefore, in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: respect of the Matter, such Figures are apt to rest without
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: submerging, though deprived of the help of the Rampart, it is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: manifest, that they may admit so much encrease of Gravity, (without
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: encreasing their Masses) as is the weight of as much water as would be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: contained within the Rampart, that is made about their upper plane
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Surface: by the help of which being sustained, they shall rest afloat,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but being bathed, they shall descend, having been made graver than the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water. In Figures, therefore, that determine above in a plane, we may
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: cleerly comprehend, that the Rampart added or removed, may prohibit or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: permit the descent: but in those Figures that go lessening upwards
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: towards the top, some Persons may, and that not without much seeming
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Reason, doubt whether the same may be done, and especially by those
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which terminate in a very acute Point, such as are your Cones and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: small Piramids. Touching these, therefore, as more dubious than the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: rest, I will endeavour to demonstrate, that they also lie under the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: same Accident of going, or not going to the Bottom, be they of any
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: whatever bigness. Let therefore the Cone be A B D, made of a matter
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: specifically as grave as the water; it is manifest that being put all
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: under water, it shall rest in all places (alwayes provided, that it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall weigh exactly as much as the water, which is almost impossible
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to effect) and that any small weight being added to it, it shall sink
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to the bottom: but if it shall descend downwards gently, I say, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: it shall make the Rampart E S T O, and that there shall stay out of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the water the point A S T, tripple in height to the Rampart E S: which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: is manifest, for the Matter of the Cone weighing equally with the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, the part submerged _S B D T_, becomes indifferent to move
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: downwards or upwards; and the Cone _A S T_, being equall in Mass to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the water that would be contained in the concave of the Rampart _E S T
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: O_, shall be also equall unto it in Gravity: and, therefore, there
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall be a perfect _Equilibrium_, and, consequently, a Rest. Now here
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ariseth a doubt, whether the Cone _A B D_ may be made heavier, in such
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sort, that when it is put wholly under water, it goes to the bottom,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but yet not in such sort, as to take from the Rampart the vertue of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sustaining it that it sink not, and, the reason of the doubt is this:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that although at such time as the Cone _A B D_ is specifically as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: grave as the water, the Rampart _E S T O_ sustaines it, not only when
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the point _A S T_ is tripple in height to the Altitude of the Rampart
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _E S_, but also when a lesser part is above water; [for although in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Descent of the Cone the Point _A S T_ by little and little
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: diminisheth, and so likewise the Rampart _E S T O_, yet the Point
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: diminisheth in greater proportion than the Rampart, in that it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: diminisheth according to all the three Dimensions, but the Rampart
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: according to two only, the Altitude still remaining the same; or, if
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: you will, because the Cone _S {A} T_ goes diminishing, according to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the proportion of the cubes of the Lines that do successively become
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Diameters of the Bases of emergent Cones, and the Ramparts
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: diminish according to the proportion of the Squares of the same Lines;
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: whereupon the proportions of the Points are alwayes Sesquialter of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: proportions of the Cylinders, contained within the Rampart; so that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: if, for Example, the height of the emergent Point were double, or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: equall to the height of the Rampart, in these cases, the Cylinder
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: contained within the Rampart, would be much greater than the said
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Point, because it would be either sesquialter or tripple, by reason of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which it would perhaps serve over and above to sustain the whole Cone,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: since the part submerged would no longer weigh any thing;] yet,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: nevertheless, when any Gravity is added to the whole Mass of the Cone,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: so that also the part submerged is not without some excesse of Gravity
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: above the Gravity of the water, it is not manifest, whether the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cylinder contained within the Rampart, in the descent that the Cone
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shall make, can be reduced to such a proportion unto the emergent
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Point, and to such an excesse of Mass above the Mass of it, as to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: compensate the excesse of the Cones Specificall Gravity above the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Gravity of the water: and the Scruple ariseth, because that howbeit in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the descent made by the Cone, the emergent Point _A S T_ diminisheth,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: whereby there is also a diminution of the excess of the Cones Gravity
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: above the Gravity of the water, yet the case stands so, that the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Rampart doth also contract it self, and the Cylinder contained in it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: doth deminish. Nevertheless it shall be demonstrated, how that the
author: Galilei, Galileo
