text: [78] An Experiment of the operation of Figures, in encreasing or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: lessening of the Airs Resistance of Division.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: _Aristotles_ opinion touching the Operation of Figure
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: examined.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I have said all that I could at present think of, to maintain the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Assertion I have undertook. It remains, that I examine that which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Aristotle_ hath writ of this matter towards the end of his Book De
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Caelo[79]; wherein I shall note two things: the one that it being true as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: hath been demonstrated, that Figure hath nothing to do about the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: moving or not moving it self upwards or downwards, its seemes that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Aristotle_ at his first falling upon this Speculation, was of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: same opinion, as in my opinion may be collected from the examination
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of his words. 'Tis true, indeed, that in essaying afterwards to render
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: a reason of such effect, as not having in my conceit hit upon the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: right, (which in the second place I will examine) it seems that he is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: brought to admit the largenesse of Figure, to be interessed in this
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: operation. As to the first particuler, hear the precise words of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Aristotle_.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [79] _Aristot. de Caelo_ Lib. 4. Cap 6.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Figures are not the Causes of moving simply upwards or downwards, but
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of moving more slowly or swiftly[80][81], and by what means this comes to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: pass, it is not difficult to see._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [80] _Aristotle_ makes not Figure the cause of Motion absolutely,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but of swift or slow motion,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [81] Lib. 4. Cap. 6: Text. 42.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Here first I note, that the terms being four, which fall under the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: present consideration, namely, Motion, Rest, Slowly and Swiftly: And
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Aristotle_ naming figures as Causes of Tardity and Velocity,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: excluding them from being the Cause of absolute and simple Motion, it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: seems necessary, that he exclude them on the other side, from being
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Cause of Rest, so that his meaning is this. Figures are not the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Causes of moving or not moving absolutely, but of moving quickly or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: slowly: and, here, if any should say the mind of _Aristotle_ is to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: exclude Figures from being Causes of Motion, but yet not from being
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Causes of Rest, so that the sence would be to remove from Figures,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: there being the Causes of moving simply, but yet not there being
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Causes of Rest, I would demand, whether we ought with _Aristotle_ to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: understand, that all Figures universally, are, in some manner, the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: causes of Rest in those Bodies, which otherwise would move, or else
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: some particular Figures only, as for Example, broad and thinne
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figures: If all indifferently, then every Body shall rest: because
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: every Body hath some Figure, which is false; but if some particular
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figures only may be in some manner a Cause of Rest, as, for Example,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the broad, then the others would be in some manner the Causes of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Motion: for if from seeing some Bodies of a contracted Figure move,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which after dilated into Plates rest, may be inferred, that the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Amplitude of Figure hath a part in the Cause of that Rest; so from
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: seeing such like Figures rest, which afterwards contracted move, it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: may with the same reason be affirmed, that the united and contracted
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figure, hath a part in causing Motion, as the remover of that which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: impeded it: The which again is directly opposite to what _Aristotle_
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: saith, namely, that Figures are not the Causes of Motion. Besides, if
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Aristotle_ had admitted and not excluded Figures from being Causes of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: not moving in some Bodies, which moulded into another Figure would
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: move, he would have impertinently propounded in a dubitative manner,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in the words immediately following, whence it is, that the large and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: thinne Plates of Lead or Iron, rest upon the water, since the Cause
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: was apparent, namely, the Amplitude of Figure. Let us conclude,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: therefore, that the meaning of _Aristotle_ in this place is to affirm,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that Figures are not the Causes of absolutely moving or not moving,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but only of moving swiftly or slowly: which we ought the rather to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: believe, in regard it is indeed a most true conceipt and opinion. Now
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the mind of _Aristotle_ being such, and appearing by consequence,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: rather contrary at the first sight, then favourable to the assertion
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the Oponents, it is necessary, that their Interpretation be not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: exactly the same with that, but such, as being in part understood by
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: some of them, and in part by others, was set down: and it may easily
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: be indeed so, being an Interpretation consonent to the sence of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: more famous Interpretors, which is, that the Adverbe _Simply_ or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Absolutely_, put in the Text, ought not to be joyned to the Verbe to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Move_, but with the Noun _Causes_: so that the purport of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Aristotles_ words, is to affirm, That Figures are not the Causes
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: absolutely of moving or not moving, but yet are Causes _Secundum
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: quid_, _viz._ in some sort; by which means, they are called Auxiliary
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and Concomitant Causes: and this Proposition is received and asserted
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: as true by _Signor Buonamico Lib. 5. Cap. 28._ where he thus writes.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _There are other Causes concomitant, by which some things float, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: others sink, among which the Figures of Bodies hath the first place_,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Concerning this Proposition, I meet with many doubts and difficulties,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: for which me thinks the words of _Aristotle_ are not capable of such a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: construction and sence, and the difficulties are these.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: First in the order and disposure of the words of _Aristotle_, the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: particle _Simpliciter_, or if you will _absolute_, is conjoyned with
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Verb _to move_, and seperated from the Noun _Causes_, the which is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: a great presumption in my favour, seeing that the writing and the Text
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: saith, Figures are not the Cause of moving simply upwards or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: downwards, but of quicker or slower Motion: and, saith not, Figures
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: are not simply the Causes of moving upwards or downwards, and when the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: words of a Text receive, transposed, a sence different from that which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: they sound, taken in the order wherein the Author disposeth them, it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: is not convenient to inverte them. And who will affirm that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Aristotle_ desiring to write a Proposition, would dispose the words
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in such sort, that they should import a different, nay, a contrary
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sence? contrary, I say, because understood as they are written; they
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: say, that Figures are not the Causes of Motion, but inverted, they
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: say, that Figures are the Causes of Motion, &c.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Moreover, if the intent of _Aristotle_ had been to say, that Figures
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: are not simply the Causes of moving upwards or downwards, but only
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Causes _Secundum quid_, he would not have adjoyned those words, _but
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: they are Causes of the more swift or slow Motion_; yea, the subjoining
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: this would have been not only superfluous but false, for that the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: whole tenour of the Proposition would import thus much. Figures are
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: not the absolute Causes of moving upwards or downwards, but are the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: absolute Cause of the swift or slow Motion; which is not true: because
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the primary Causes of greater or lesser Velocity, are by _Aristotle_
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in the 4th of his _Physicks_, _Text. 71._ attributed to the greater or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: lesser Gravity of Moveables, compared among themselves, and to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: greater or lesser Resistance of the _Medium's_, depending on their
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: greater or less Crassitude: and these are inserted by _Aristotle_ as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the primary Causes; and these two only are in that place nominated:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and Figure comes afterwards to be considered, _Text. 74._ rather as an
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Instrumentall Cause of the force of the Gravity, the which divides
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: either with the Figure, or with the _Impetus_; and, indeed, Figure by
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: it self without the force of Gravity or Levity, would opperate
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: nothing.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I adde, that if _Aristotle_ had an opinion that Figure had been in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: some sort the Cause of moving or not moving, the inquisition which he
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: makes immediately in a doubtfull manner, whence it comes, that a Plate
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of Lead flotes, would have been impertinent; for if but just before he
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: had said, that Figure was in a certain sort the Cause of moving or not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: moving, he needed not to call in Question, by what Cause the Plate of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lead swims, and then ascribing the Cause to its Figure; and framing a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: discourse in this manner. Figure is a Cause _Secundum quid_ of not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sinking: but, now, if it be doubted, for what Cause a thin Plate of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lead goes not to the bottom; it shall be answered, that that proceeds
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: from its Figure: a discourse which would be indecent in a Child, much
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: more in _Aristotle_; For where is the occasion of doubting? And who
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sees not, that if _Aristotle_ had held, that Figure was in some sort a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cause of Natation, he would without the least Hesitation have writ;
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: That Figure is in a certain sort the Cause of Natation, and therefore
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Plate of Lead in respect of its large and expatiated Figure swims;
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but if we take the proposition of _Aristotle_ as I say, and as it is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: written, and as indeed it is true, the ensuing words come in very
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: oppositely, as well in the introduction of swift and slow, as in the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: question, which very pertinently offers it self, and would say thus
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: much.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figures are not the Cause of moving or not moving simply upwards or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: downwards, but of moving more quickly or slowly: But if it be so, the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cause is doubtfull, whence it proceeds, that a Plate of Lead or of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Iron broad and thin doth swim, &c. And the occasion of the doubt is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: obvious, because it seems at the first glance, that the Figure is the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Cause of this Natation, since the same Lead, or a less quantity, but
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in another Figure, goes to the bottom, and we have already affirmed,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that the Figure hath no share in this effect.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lastly, if the intent of _Aristotle_ in this place had been to say,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that Figures, although not absolutely, are at least in some measure
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Cause of moving or not moving: I would have it considered, that he
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: names no less the Motion upwards, than the other downwards: and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: because in exemplifying it afterwards, he produceth no other
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Experiments than of a Plate of Lead, and Board of Ebony, Matters that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of their own Nature go to the bottom, but by vertue (as our
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Adversaries say) of their Figure, rest afloat; it is fit that they
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: should produce some other Experiment of those Matters, which by their
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Nature swims, but retained by their Figure rest at the bottom. But
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: since this is impossible to be done, we conclude, that _Aristotle_ in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: this place, hath not attributed any action to the Figure of simply
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: moving or not moving.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: But though he hath exquisitely Philosophiz'd, in investigating the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: solution of the doubts he proposeth, yet will I not undertake to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: maintain, rather various difficulties, that present themselves unto
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: me, give me occasion of suspecting that he hath not entirely displaid
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: unto us, the true Cause of the present Conclusion: which difficulties
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I will propound one by one, ready to change opinion, whenever I am
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: shewed, that the Truth is different from what I say; to the confession
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: whereof I am much more inclinable than to contradiction.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: _Aristotle_ erred in affirming a Needle dimitted long
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: wayes to sink.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Aristotle_ having propounded the Question, whence it proceeds, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: broad Plates of Iron or Lead, float or swim; he addeth (as it were
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: strengthening the occasion of doubting) forasmuch as other things,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: less, and less grave, be they round or long, as for instance a Needle
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: go to the bottom. Now I here doubt, or rather am certain that a Needle
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: put lightly upon the water, rests afloat, no less than the thin Plates
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of Iron or Lead. I cannot believe, albeit it hath been told me, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: some to defend _Aristotle_ should say, that he intends a Needle
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: demitted not longwayes but endwayes, and with the Point downwards;
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: nevertheless, not to leave them so much as this, though very weak
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: refuge, and which in my judgement _Aristotle_ himself would refuse, I
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: say it ought to be understood, that the Needle must be demitted,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: according to the Dimension named by _Aristotle_, which is the length:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: because, if any other Dimension than that which is named, might or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ought to be taken, I would say, that even the Plates of Iron and Lead,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sink to the bottom, if they be put into the water edgewayes and not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: flatwayes. But because _Aristotle_ saith, broad Figures go not to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: bottom, it is to be understood, being demitted broadwayes: and,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: therefore, when he saith, long Figures as a Needle, albeit light, rest
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: not afloat, it ought to be understood of them when demitted longwayes.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Moreover, to say that_ Aristotle _is to be understood of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Needle demitted with the Point downwards, is to father upon him a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: great impertinency; for in this place he saith, that little
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Particles of Lead or Iron, if they be round or long as a Needle, do
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sink to the bottome; so that by his Opinion, a Particle or small
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Grain of Iron cannot swim: and if he thus believed, what a great
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: folly would it be to subjoyn, that neither would a Needle demitted
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: endwayes swim? And what other is such a Needle, but many such like
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Graines accumulated one upon another? It was too unworthy of such a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: man to say, that one single Grain of Iron could not swim, and that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: neither can it swim, though you put a hundred more upon it._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lastly, either _Aristotle_ believed, that a Needle demitted longwayes
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: upon the water, would swim, or he believed that it would not swim: If
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: he believed it would not swim, he might well speak as indeed he did;
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but if he believed and knew that it would float, why, together with
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the dubious Problem of the Natation of broad Figures, though of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ponderous Matter, hath he not also introduced the Question; whence it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: proceeds, that even long and slender Figures, howbeit of Iron or Lead
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: do swim? And the rather, for that the occasion of doubting seems
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: greater in long and narrow Figures, than in broad and thin, as from
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Aristotles_ not having doubted of it, is manifested.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: No lesser an inconvenience would they fasten upon _Aristotle_, who in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: his defence should say, that he means a Needle pretty thick, and not a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: small one; for take it for granted to be intended of a small one; and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: it shall suffice to reply, that he believed that it would swim; and I
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: will again charge him with having avoided a more wonderfull and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: intricate Probleme, and introduced the more facile and less
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: wonderfull.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: We say freely therefore, that _Aristotle_ did hold, that only the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: broad Figure did swim, but the long and slender, such as a Needle,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: not. The which nevertheless is false, as it is also false in round
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Bodies: because, as from what hath been predemonstrated, may be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: gathered, little Balls of Lead and Iron, do in like manner swim.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: _Aristotle_ affirmeth some Bodies volatile for their
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Minuity, Text. 42.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: He proposeth likewise another Conclusion, which likewise seems
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: different from the truth, and it is, That some things, by reason of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: their littleness fly in the Air, as the small dust of the Earth, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the thin leaves of beaten Gold: but in my Opinion, Experience shews
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: us, that that happens not only in the Air, but also in the water, in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which do descend, even those Particles or Atomes of Earth, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: disturbe it, whose minuity is such, that they are not deservable, save
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: only when they are many hundreds together. Therefore, the dust of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Earth, and beaten Gold, do not any way sustain themselves in the Air,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but descend downwards, and only fly to and again in the same, when
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: strong Windes raise them, or other agitations of the Air commove them:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and this also happens in the commotion of the water, which raiseth its
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Sand from the bottom, and makes it muddy. But _Aristotle_ cannot mean
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: this impediment of the commotion, of which he makes no mention, nor
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: names other than the lightness of such Minutiae or Atomes, and the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Resistance of the Crassitudes of the Water and Air, by which we see,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that he speakes of a calme, and not disturbed and agitated Air: but in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that case, neither Gold nor Earth, be they never so small, are
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sustained, but speedily descend.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: _Democritus_ placed the Cause of Natation in certain
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: fiery Atomes.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: He passeth next to confute _Democritus_[82], which, by his Testimony would
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: have it, that some Fiery Atomes, which continually ascend through the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, do spring upwards, and sustain those grave Bodies, which are
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: very broad, and that the narrow descend to the bottom, for that but a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: small quantity of those Atomes, encounter and resist them.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [82] _Aristot. De Caelo_ lib. 4. cap. 6. text. 43.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I say, _Aristotle_ confutes this position[83], saying, that that should
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: much more occurre in the Air, as the same _Democritus_ instances
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: against himself, but after he had moved the objection, he slightly
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: resolves it, with saying, that those Corpuscles which ascend in the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Air, make not their _Impetus_ conjunctly. Here I will not say, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the reason alledged by _Democritus_ is true[84], but I will only say, it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: seems in my judgement, that it is not wholly confuted by _Aristotle_,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: whilst he saith, that were it true, that the calid ascending Atomes,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: should sustain Bodies grave, but very broad, it would much more be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: done in the Air, than in Water, for that haply in the Opinion of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Aristotle_, the said calid Atomes ascend with much greater Force and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Velocity through the Air, than through the water. And if this be so,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: as I verily believe it is, the Objection of _Aristotle_ in my
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: judgement seems to give occasion of suspecting, that he may possibly
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: be deceived in more than one particular: First, because those calid
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Atomes, (whether they be Fiery Corpuscles, or whether they be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Exhalations, or in short, whatever other matter they be, that ascends
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: upwards through the Air) cannot be believed to mount faster through
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Air, than through water: but rather on the contrary, they peradventure
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: move more impetuously through the water, than through the Air, as hath
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: been in part demonstrated above. And here I cannot finde the reason,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: why _Aristotle_ seeing, that the descending Motion of the same
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Moveable, is more swift in Air, than in water, hath not advertised us,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that from the contrary Motion, the contrary should necessarily follow;
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to wit, that it is more swift in the water, than in the Air: for since
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that the Moveable which descendeth, moves swifter through the Air,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than through the water, if we should suppose its Gravity gradually to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: diminish, it would first become such, that descending swiftly through
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Air, it would descend but slowly through the water: and then
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: again, it might be such, that descending in the Air, it should ascend
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in the water: and being made yet less grave, it shall ascend swiftly
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: through the water, and yet descend likewise through the Air: and in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: short, before it can begin to ascend, though but slowly through the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Air, it shall ascend swiftly through the water: how then is it true,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that ascending Moveables move swifter through the Air, than through
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the water?
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [83] _Democritus_ confuted by _Aristotle_, text 43.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [84] _Aristotles_ confutation of _Democritus_ refuted by the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Author.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: That which hath made _Aristotle_ believe, the Motion of Ascent to be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: swifter in Air, than in water, was first, the having referred the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Causes of slow and quick, as well in the Motion of Ascent, as of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Descent, only to the diversity of the Figures of the Moveable, and to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the more or less Resistance of the greater or lesser Crassitude, or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Rarity of the _Medium_; not regarding the comparison of the Excesses
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the Gravities of the Moveables, and of the _Mediums_: the which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: notwithstanding, is the most principal point in this affair: for if
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the augmentation and diminution of the Tardity or Velocity, should
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: have only respect to the Density or Rarity of the _Medium_, every Body
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that descends in Air, would descend in water: because whatever
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: difference is found between the Crassitude of the water, and that of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Air, may well be found between the Velocity of the same Moveable
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in the Air, and some other Velocity: and this should be its proper
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Velocity in the water, which is absolutely false. The other occasion
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: is, that he did believe, that like as there is a positive and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: intrinsecall Quality, whereby Elementary Bodies have a propension of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: moving towards the Centre of the Earth, so there is another likewise
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: intrinsecall[85], whereby some of those Bodies have an _Impetus_ of flying
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Centre, and moving upwards: by Vertue of which intrinsecall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Principle, called by him Levity, the Moveables which have that same
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Motion more easily penetrate the more subtle _Medium_, than the more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: dense: but such a Proposition appears likewise uncertain, as I have
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: above hinted in part, and as with Reasons and Experiments, I could
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: demonstrate, did not the present Argument importune me, or could I
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: dispatch it in few words.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: The Objection therefore of _Aristotle_ against _Democritus_, whilst he
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: saith, that if the Fiery ascending Atomes should sustain Bodies grave,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but of a distended Figure, it would be more observable in the Air than
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in the water, because such Corpuscles move swifter in that, than in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: this, is not good; yea the contrary would evene, for that they ascend
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: more slowly through the Air: and, besides their moving slowly, they
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ascend, not united together, as in the water, but discontinue, and, as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: we say, scatter: And, therefore, as _Democritus_ well replyes,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: resolving the instance they make not their push or _Impetus_
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: conjunctly.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Aristotle_, in the second place, deceives himself, whilst he will
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: have the said grave Bodies to be more easily sustained by the said
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Fiery ascending Atomes in the Air than in the Water: not observing,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that the said Bodies are much more grave in that, than in this, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that such a Body weighs ten pounds in the Air, which will not in the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water weigh 1/2 an ounce; how can it then be more easily sustained in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Air, than in the Water?
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Sidenote: _Democritus_ confuted by the Authour.]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Let us conclude, therefore, that _Democritus_ hath in this particular
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: better Philosophated than _Aristotle_. But yet will not I affirm, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Democritus_ hath reason'd rightly, but I rather say, that there is a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: manifest Experiment that overthrows his Reason, and this it is, That
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: if it were true, that calid ascending Atomes should uphold a Body,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that if they did not hinder, would go to the bottom, it would follow,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that we may find a Matter very little superiour in Gravity to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, the which being reduced into a Ball, or other contracted
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figure, should go to the bottom, as encountring but few Fiery Atomes;
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and which being distended afterwards into a dilated and thin Plate,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: should come to be thrust upwards by the impulsion of a great Multitude
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of those Corpuscles, and at last carried to the very Surface of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water: which wee see not to happen; Experience shewing us, that a Body
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _v. gra._ of a Sphericall Figure, which very hardly, and with very
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: great leasure goeth to the bottom, will rest there, and will also
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: descend thither, being reduced into whatsoever other distended Figure.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: We must needs say then, either that in the water, there are no such
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ascending Fiery Atoms, or if that such there be, that they are not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: able to raise and lift up any Plate of a Matter, that without them
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: would go to the bottom: Of which two Positions, I esteem the second to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: be true, understanding it of water, constituted in its naturall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Coldness. But if we take a Vessel of Glass, or Brass, or any other
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: hard matter, full of cold water, within which is put a Solid of a flat
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: or concave Figure, but that in Gravity exceeds the water so little,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that it goes slowly to the bottom; I say, that putting some burning
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Coals under the said Vessel, as soon as the new Fiery Atomes shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: have penetrated the substance of the Vessel, they shall without doubt,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ascend through that of the water, and thrusting against the foresaid
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Solid, they shall drive it to the Superficies, and there detain it, as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: long as the incursions of the said Corpuscles shall last, which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ceasing after the removall of the Fire, the Solid being abandoned by
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: its supporters, shall return to the bottom.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: But _Democritus_ notes, that this Cause only takes place when we
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: treat of raising and sustaining of Plates of Matters, but very little
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: heavier than the water, or extreamly thin: but in Matters very grave,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and of some thickness, as Plates of Lead or other Mettal, that same
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Effect wholly ceaseth: In Testimony of which, let's observe that such
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Plates, being raised by the Fiery Atomes, ascend through all the depth
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the water, and stop at the Confines of the Air, still staying under
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water: but the Plates of the Opponents stay not, but only when they
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: have their upper Superficies dry, nor is there any means to be used,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that when they are within the water, they may not sink to the bottom.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: The cause, therefore, of the Supernatation of the things of which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Democritus_ speaks is one, and that of the Supernatation of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: things of which we speak is another. But, returning to _Aristotle_[86],
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: methinks that he hath more weakly confuted _Democritus_, than
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Democritus_ himself hath done: For _Aristotle_ having propounded the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Objection which he maketh against him, and opposed him with saying,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that if the calid ascendent Corpuscles were those that raised the thin
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Plate, much more then would such a Solid be raised and born upwards
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: through the Air, it sheweth that the desire in _Aristotle_ to detect
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Democritus_, was predominate over the exquisiteness of Solid
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Philosophizing: which desire of his he hath discovered in other
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: occasions, and that we may not digress too far from this place, in the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Text precedent to this Chapter which we have in hand[87]; where he
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: attempts to confute the same _Democritus_ for that he, not contenting
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: himself with names only, had essayed more particularly to declare what
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: things Gravity and Levity were; that is, the Causes of descending and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ascending, (and had introduced Repletion and Vacuity) ascribing this
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to Fire, by which it moves upwards, and that to the Earth, by which it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: descends; afterwards attributing to the Air more of Fire, and to the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water more of Earth. But _Aristotle_ desiring a positive Cause, even
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of ascending Motion, and not as _Plato_, or these others, a simple
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: negation, or privation, such as Vacuity would be in reference to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Repletion[88], argueth against _Democritus_ and saith: If it be true, as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: you suppose, then there shall be a great Mass of water, which shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: have more of Fire, than a small Mass of Air, and a great Mass of Air,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: which shall have more of Earth than a little Mass of water, whereby it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: would ensue, that a great Mass of Air, should come more swiftly
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: downwards, than a little quantity of water: But that is never in any
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: case soever: Therefore _Democritus_ discourseth erroneously.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [86] _Aristotle_ shews his desire of finding _Democritus_ in an
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Error, to exceed that of discovering Truth.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [87] Cap. 5. Text 41.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [88] Id. ibid.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: But in my opinion, the Doctrine of _Democritus_ is not by this
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: allegation overthrown, but if I erre not, the manner of _Aristotle_
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: deduction either concludes not, or if it do conclude any thing, it may
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: with equall force be restored against himself. _Democritus_ will grant
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to _Aristotle_, that there may be a great Mass of Air taken, which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: contains more Earth, than a small quantity of water, but yet will
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: deny, that such a Mass of Air, shall go faster downwards than a little
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, and that for many reasons. First, because if the greater
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: quantity of Earth, contained in the great Mass of Air, ought to cause
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: a greater Velocity than a less quantity of Earth, contained in a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: little quantity of water, it would be necessary, first, that it were
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: true, that a greater Mass of pure Earth, should move more swiftly than
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: a less: But this is false, though _Aristotle_ in many places affirms
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: it to be true: because not the greater absolute, but the greater
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: specificall Gravity, is the cause of greater Velocity[89]: nor doth a Ball
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of Wood, weighing ten pounds, descend more swiftly than one weighing
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: ten Ounces, and that is of the same Matter: but indeed a Bullet of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lead of four Ounces, descendeth more swiftly than a Ball of Wood of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: twenty Pounds: because the Lead is more _grave in specie_ than the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Wood. Therefore, its not necessary, that a great Mass of Air, by
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: reason of the much Earth contained in it, do descend more swiftly than
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: a little Mass of water[90], but on the contrary, any whatsoever Mass of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, shall move more swiftly than any other of Air, by reason the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: participation of the terrene parts _in specie_ is greater in the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, than in the Air. Let us note, in the second place, how that in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: multiplying the Mass of the Air, we not only multiply that which is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: therein of terrene, but its Fire also: whence the Cause of ascending,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: no less encreaseth, by vertue of the Fire, than that of descending on
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the account of its multiplied Earth. It was requisite in increasing
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the greatness of the Air, to multiply that which it hath of terrene
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: only, leaving its Fire in its first state, for then the terrene parts
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the augmented Air, overcoming the terrene parts of the small
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: quantity of water, it might with more probability have been pretended,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that the great quantity of Air, ought to descend with a greater
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Impetus_, than the little quantity of water.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [89] The greater Specificall, not the greater absolute Gravity,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: is the Cause of Velocity.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [90] Any Mass of water shal move more swiftly, than any of Air,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and why.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Therefore, the Fallacy lyes more in the Discourse of _Aristotle_, than
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in that of _Democritus_, who with severall other Reasons might oppose
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Aristotle_, and alledge; If it be true, that the extreame Elements be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: one simply grave, and the other simply light, and that the mean
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Elements participate of the one, and of the other Nature; but the Air
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: more of Levity, and the water more of Gravity, then there shall be a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: great Mass of Air, whose Gravity shall exceed the Gravity of a little
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: quantity of water, and therefore such a Mass of Air shall descend more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: swiftly than that little water: But that is never seen to occurr:
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Therefore its not true, that the mean Elements do participate of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: one, and the other quality. This argument is fallacious, no less than
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the other against _Democritus_.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lastly, _Aristotle_ having said, that if the Position of _Democritus_
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: were true, it would follow, that a great Mass of Air should move more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: swiftly than a small Mass of water, and afterwards subjoyned, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that is never seen in any Case: methinks others may become desirous to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: know of him in what place this should evene, which he deduceth against
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Democritus_, and what Experiment teacheth us, that it never falls out
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: so. To suppose to see it in the Element of water, or in that of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Air is vain, because neither doth water through water, nor Air through
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Air move, nor would they ever by any whatever participation others
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: assign them, of Earth or of Fire: the Earth, in that it is not a Body
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: fluid, and yielding to the mobility of other Bodies, is a most
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: improper place and _Medium_ for such an Experiment: _Vacuum_,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: according to the same _Aristotle_ himself, there is none, and were
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: there, nothing would move in it: there remains the Region of Fire, but
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: being so far distant from us, what Experiment can assure us, or hath
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: assertained _Aristotle_ in such sort, that he should as of a thing
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: most obvious to sence, affirm what he produceth in confutation of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _Democritus_, to wit, that a great Mass of Air, is moved no swifter
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than a little one of water? But I will dwell no longer upon this
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: matter, whereon I have spoke sufficiently: but leaving _Democritus_, I
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: return to the Text of _Aristotle_, wherein he goes about to render the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: true reason, how it comes to pass, that the thin Plates of Iron or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lead do swim on the water; and, moreover, that Gold it self being
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: beaten into thin Leaves, not only swims in water, but flyeth too and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: again in the Air. He supposeth that of Continualls[91], some are easily
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: divisible, others not: and that of the easily divisible, some are more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: so, and some less: and these he affirms we should esteem the Causes.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: He addes that that is easily divisible, which is well terminated, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the more the more divisible, and that the Air is more so, than the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, and the water than the Earth. And, lastly, supposeth that in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: each kind, the lesse quantity is easlyer divided and broken than the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: greater.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Here I note, that the Conclusions of _Aristotle_ in generall are all
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: true, but methinks, that he applyeth them to particulars, in which
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: they have no place, as indeed they have in others, as for Example, Wax
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: is more easily divisible than Lead, and Lead than Silver, inasmuch as
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Wax receives all the terms more easlier than Lead, and Lead than
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Silver. Its true, moreover, that a little quantity of Silver is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: easlier divided than a great Mass: and all these Propositions are
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: true, because true it is, that in Silver, Lead and Wax, there is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: simply a Resistance against Division, and where there is the absolute,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: there is also the respective. But if as well in water as in Air, there
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: be no Renitence against simple Division, how can we say, that the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water is easlier divided than the Air? We know not how to extricate
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: our selves from the Equivocation: whereupon I return to answer, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Resistance of absolute Division is one thing, and Resistance of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Division made with such and such Velocity is another. But to produce
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Rest, and to abate the Motion, the Resistance of absolute Division is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: necessary; and the Resistance of speedy Division, causeth not Rest,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but slowness of Motion. But that as well in the Air, as in water,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: there is no Resistance of simple Division, is manifest, for that there
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: is not found any Solid Body which divides not the Air, and also the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water: and that beaten Gold, or small dust, are not able to superate
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Resistance of the Air, is contrary to that which Experience shews
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: us, for we see Gold and Dust to go waving to and again in the Air, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: at last to descend downwards, and to do the same in the water, if it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: be put therein, and separated from the Air. And, because, as I say,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: neither the water, nor the Air do resist simple Division, it cannot be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: said, that the water resists more than the Air. Nor let any object
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: unto me, the Example of most light Bodies, as a Feather, or a little
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the pith of Elder, or water-reed that divides the Air and not the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water, and from this infer, that the Air is easlier divisible than the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water; for I say unto them, that if they do well observe, they shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: see the same Body likewise divide the Continuity of the water[92], and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: submerge in part, and in such a part, as that so much water in Mass
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: would weigh as much as the whole Solid. And if they shal yet persist
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in their doubt, that such a Solid sinks not through inability to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: divide the water, I will return them this reply, that if they put it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: under water, and then let it go, they shall see it divide the water,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and presently ascend with no less celerity, than that with which it
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: divided the Air in descending: so that to say that this Solid ascends
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in the Air, but that coming to the water, it ceaseth its Motion, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: therefore the water is more difficult to be divided, concludes
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: nothing: for I, on the contrary, will propose them a piece of Wood, or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of Wax, which riseth from the bottom of the water, and easily divides
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: its Resistance, which afterwards being arrived at the Air, stayeth
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: there, and hardly toucheth it; whence I may aswell say, that the water
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: is more easier divided than the Air.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [92] _Archimed. De Insident. humi_ lib. 2. prop. 1.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I will not on this occasion forbear to give warning of another fallacy
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of these persons, who attribute the reason of sinking or swimming to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the greater or lesse Resistance of the Crassitude of the water against
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Division, making use of the example of an Egg, which in sweet water
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: goeth to the bottom, but in salt water swims; and alledging for the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: cause thereof, the faint Resistance of fresh water against Division,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and the strong Resistance of salt water. But if I mistake not, from
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the same Experiment, we may aswell deduce the quite contrary; namely,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that the fresh water is more dense, and the salt more tenuous and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: subtle, since an Egg from the bottom of salt water speedily ascends to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the top, and divides its Resistance, which it cannot do in the fresh,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in whose bottom it stays, being unable to rise upwards. Into such like
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: perplexities, do false Principles Lead men: but he that rightly
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Philosophating, shall acknowledge the excesses of the Gravities of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Moveables and of the Mediums, to be the Causes of those effects, will
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: say, that the Egg sinks to the bottom in fresh water, for that it is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: more grave than it, and swimeth in the salt, for that its less grave
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: than it: and shall without any absurdity, very solidly establish his
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Conclusions.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Therefore the reason totally ceaseth, that _Aristotle_ subjoyns in the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Text saying[93]; The things, therefore, which have great breadth remain
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: above, because they comprehend much, and that which is greater, is not
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: easily divided. Such discoursing ceaseth, I say, because its not true,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that there is in water or in Air any Resistance of Division; besides
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that the Plate of Lead when it stays, hath already divided and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: penetrated the Crassitude of the water, and profounded it self ten or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: twelve times more than its own thickness: besides that such Resistance
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of Division, were it supposed to be in the water, could not rationally
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: be affirmed to be more in its superiour parts than in the middle, and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: lower: but if there were any difference, the inferiour should be the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: more dense, so that the Plate would be no less unable to penetrate the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: lower, than the superiour parts of the water; nevertheless we see that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: no sooner do we wet the superiour Superficies of the Board or thin
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Piece of Wood, but it precipitatly, and without any retension,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: descends to the bottom.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: I believe not after all this, that any (thinking perhaps thereby to
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: defend _Aristotle_) will say, that it being true, that the much water
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: resists more than the little, the said Board being put lower
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: descendeth, because there remaineth a less Mass of water to be divided
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: by it: because if after the having seen the same Board swim in four
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Inches of water, and also after that in the same to sink, he shall try
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the same Experiment upon a profundity of ten or twenty fathom water,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: he shall see the very self same effect. And here I will take occasion
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to remember, for the removall of an Error that is too common; That
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that Ship or other whatsoever Body, that on the depth of an hundred or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: a thousand fathom, swims with submerging only six fathom of its own
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: height, [_or in the Sea dialect, that draws six fathom water_] shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: swim in the same manner in water, that hath but six fathom and half an
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Inch of depth[94]. Nor do I on the other side, think that it can be said,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that the superiour parts of the water are the more dense, although a
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: most grave Authour hath esteemed the superiour water in the Sea to be
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: so, grounding his opinion upon its being more salt, than that at the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: bottom: but I doubt the Experiment, whether hitherto in taking the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: water from the bottom, the Observatour did not light upon some spring
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of fresh water there spouting up: but we plainly see on the contrary,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the fresh Waters of Rivers to dilate themselves for some miles beyond
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: their place of meeting with the salt water of the Sea, without
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: descending in it, or mixing with it, unless by the intervention of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: some commotion or turbulency of the Windes.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [94] A Ship that in 100 Fathome water draweth 6 Fathome, shall
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: float in 6 Fathome and 1/2 an Inch of depth.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: But returning to _Aristotle_, I say, that the breadth of Figure hath
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: nothing to do in this business more or less, because the said Plate of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lead, or other Matter, cut into long Slices, swim neither more nor
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: less[95]; and the same shall the Slices do, being cut anew into little
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: pieces, because its not the breadth but the thickness that operates in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: this business. I say farther, that in case it were really true, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: the Renitence to Division were the proper Cause of swimming[96], the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Figures more narrow and short, would much better swim than the more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: spacious and broad, so that augmenting the breadth of the Figure, the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: facility of supernatation will be deminished, and decreasing, that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: this will encrease.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [95] Thickness not breadth of Figure to be respected in Natation.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [96] Were Renitence the cause of Natation, breadth of Figure would
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: hinder the swiming of Bodies.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And for declaration of what I say, consider that when a thin Plate of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lead descends, dividing the water, the Division and discontinuation is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: made between the parts of the water, invironing the perimeter or
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Circumference of the said Plate, and according to the bigness greater
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: or lesser of that circuit, it hath to divide a greater or lesser
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: quantity of water, so that if the circuit, suppose of a Board, be ten
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Feet in sinking it flatways, it is to make the seperation and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: division, and to so speak, an incission upon ten Feet of water; and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: likewise a lesser Board that is four Feet in Perimeter, must make an
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: incession of four Feet. This granted, he that hath any knowledge in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Geometry, will comprehend, not only that a Board sawed in many long
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: thin pieces, will much better float than when it was entire, but that
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: all Figures, the more short and narrow they be, shall so much the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: better swim. Let the Board A B C D be, for Example, eight Palmes long,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: and five broad, its circuit shall be twenty six Palmes; and so many
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: must the incession be, which it shall make in the water to descend
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: therein: but if we do saw ir, as suppose into eight little pieces,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: according to the Lines E F, G H, {&}c. making seven Segments, we must
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: adde to the twenty six Palmes of the circuit of the whole Board,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: seventy others; whereupon the eight little pieces so cut and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: seperated, have to cut ninty six Palmes of water. And, if moreover, we
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: cut each of the said pieces into five parts, reducing them into
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Squares, to the circuit of ninty six Palmes, with four cuts of eight
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Palmes apiece; we shall adde also sixty four Palmes, whereupon the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: said Squares to descend in the water, must divide one hundred and
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: sixty Palmes of water, but the Resistance is much greater than that of
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: twenty six; therefore to the lesser Superficies, we shall reduce them,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: so much the more easily will they float: and the same will happen in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: all other Figures, whose Superficies are simular amongst themselves,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but different in bigness: because the said Superficies, being either
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: deminished or encreased, always diminish or encrease their Perimeters
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: in subduple proportion; to wit, the Resistance that they find in
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: penetrating the water; therefore the little pieces gradually swim,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: with more and more facility as their breadth is lessened.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: [Illustration]
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: _This is manifest; for keeping still the same height of the Solid,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: with the same proportion as the Base encreaseth or deminisheth,
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: doth the said Solid also encrease or diminish; whereupon the Solid
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: more diminishing than the Circuit, the Cause of Submersion more
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: diminisheth than the Cause of Natation: And on the contrary, the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Solid more encreasing than the Circuit, the Cause of Submersion
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: encreaseth more, that of Natation less._
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: And this may all be deduced out of the Doctrine of _Aristotle_ against
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: his own Doctrine.
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Lastly, to that which we read in the latter part of the Text[97], that is
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: to say, that we must compare the Gravity of the Moveable with the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Resistance of the Medium against Division, because if the force of the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Gravity exceed the Resistance of the _Medium_, the Moveable will
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: descend, if not it will float. I need not make any other answer, but
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: that which hath been already delivered; namely, that its not the
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: Resistance of absolute Division, (which neither is in Water nor Air)
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: but the Gravity of the _Medium_ that must be compared with the Gravity
author: Galilei, Galileo

text: of the Moveables; and if that of the _Medium_ be greater, the Moveable
author: Galilei, Galileo
